(2)  The licensee is operating so as to constitute a nuisance by reason of noise on the premises. 
(b)  Notice of such public hearing or such suspension or revocation shall be promptly communicated to the holder of such license by the village manager or village manager's designee by mailing such notice to the applicant at the address set out in the application for such license. 
(Code 1963, § 9.10(9)) 
Secs. 10-62-10-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND ARCADES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement arcade means any establishment or location at which 11 or more amusement devices, as defined in this section, are maintained for public use. Amusement devices which are maintained in a private residence and which are not held out for public use do not constitute an amusement arcade under this article. 
    Amusement device means any machine, whether mechanical or electronic, or other device which is held out for public use as a game of entertainment, amusement, skill or chance, whether or not a fee is charged for such play. Amusement devices include, but are not limited to, pinball machines, electronic game machines and pool tables. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(2); Ord. No. 455-O-09, § 1, 8-17-09) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-82. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    In addition to or in lieu of suspension or revocation, violations of the provisions of this article shall be punishable in accordance with section 1-7 of this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(8)) 
Sec. 10-83. - Purpose of article. 
    It is the desire of the village to provide for the regulation and supervision of business establishments which maintain amusement devices for public use. It is the intent of this article to ensure that such establishments are operated in an orderly manner and that such machines are not used for illegal gambling, constitute a public nuisance, or contribute to disturbances of the peace. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(1)) 
Sec. 10-84. - Violation of state law. 
    No amusement device covered by this section may be used in violation of Wis. Stats. ch. 945. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(6)(c)) 
Sec. 10-85. - Supervision of premises. 
    There shall be constant, adequate supervision by an adult supervisor on the premises of persons using the premises so as to prevent violation of any law or ordinance. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(6)(d)) 
Sec. 10-86. - Music or noise from devices. 
    Music or noise generated by any device shall not unreasonably disturb residents of adjoining residential property. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(6)(e)) 
Sec. 10-87. - Condition of premises. 
    Premises in which amusement devices are located and used by the public shall at all times be kept in a clean, healthful and sanitary condition with ample approved lighting and ventilation in accordance with Code requirements. Operation shall at all times be in conformance with village building and zoning codes. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(6)(f)) 
Sec. 10-88. - Service of intoxicating liquor or malt beverages. 
    No intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverage may be possessed or consumed on the premises unless the premises is licensed for such purpose, nor may controlled substances, as defined in Wis. Stats. ch. 961, be consumed on the premises. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(6)(i)) 
Secs. 10-89-10-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ARCADE LICENSE AND DEVICE PERMIT 

Sec. 10-106. - Required. 
(a)  No person shall operate a business or maintain a location which constitutes, in whole or in part, an amusement arcade, as defined in this article, without first having obtained an amusement arcade license as set forth in section 10-107 and a conditional use permit under section 122-566(2). 
(b)  No person shall maintain any amusement device which is held out for public use at any location in the village without first having obtained an amusement device permit as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1963, §§ 9.17(3)(a), 9.17(4)(a)) 
Sec. 10-107. - Application and investigation. 
(a)  Application. Application for an arcade license or a device permit shall be on forms provided by the village clerk, shall be under oath and shall contain the following statements: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant or agent. 
(2)  The name, address and specific location of the premises at which the amusement devices will be placed and operated. 
(3)  The number and type of machines and devices at that premises. 
(4)  A statement that the applicant understands and agrees to the conditions of the license or permit. 
(5)  The applicant has not been convicted of a misdemeanor (not involving Wis. Stats. chs. 340-349) more than three times. 
(6)  The applicant has not been convicted of a felony, unless pardoned. 
(7)  The applicant has not been convicted of possession or use of a controlled substance under Wis. Stats. ch. 161. 
(8)  The applicant has not been convicted of gambling, unless pardoned. 
(9)  The applicant has not been convicted of crimes relating to prostitution or crimes of moral turpitude. 
(10)  If the applicant is a corporation, all officers and directors owning ten percent or more of the stock of such corporation shall also sign, under oath, the application. 
(b)  Investigation. The application shall be investigated by the chief of police or his designee who shall report his findings and make his recommendation to the village clerk or village board prior to action thereon. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(5)(a), (5)(b); Ord. No. 698-O-17, § 4, 10-16-17) 
Sec. 10-108. - Issuance. 
(a)  If an application under this division indicates that the premises to be licensed will not constitute an amusement arcade, the village clerk shall, in accordance with the recommendation of the chief of police, issue an amusement device permit upon payment of the fee prescribed above. Such permits shall be issued for a period not to exceed 12 months and shall expire on June 30 of each year. The permit shall specify the maximum number of machines permitted. If the permittee increases the number of machines at the location for which the permit was granted, an amended application must be filed. 
(b)  If an application filed under this division indicates that the premises described will constitute an amusement arcade, the village clerk shall receive a combined fee for the amusement arcade license and shall not issue an amusement arcade license unless satisfied that the applicant for such license meets the requirements set forth as follows and that the issuance of such license is consistent with the purposes of this article. Any license granted under this article shall be for a period not to exceed 12 months and shall expire on June 30 of each year. Should an applicant desire to increase the number of machines permitted under the license, an amended application shall be filed with the village clerk along with payment of any additional fee. An amended application shall be considered in the same manner as a regular application. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(5)(c), (5)(d); Ord. No. 698-O-17, § 5, 10-16-17) 
Sec. 10-109. - Licenses for individuals. 
(a)  In determining whether the applicant is qualified for a license under this article, the village board shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  No license shall be granted to any person who has habitually been a law offender (the term "habitually" being understood to mean three convictions for petty offenses within the past three years, or a conviction of a felony, unless the person so convicted has been duly pardoned). 
(2)  No license shall be granted if the applicant fails to complete the application, if the applicant refuses to disclose any information required thereby or if the applicant misrepresents, evades or lies with respect to any answer. 
(3)  No license shall be granted to any applicant who has failed to comply with the specified conditions of a similar license during the previous 12-month period. 
(b)  No corporation, firm, association or club shall be granted a license under this article except through an agent thereof first duly appointed by it who is at the time of filing application an officer, manager or member thereof, and who shall have vested in him by proper, written and executed authorization, full authority and control of the premises described on the application and of the conduct of all business and acts thereon. Such agent shall be fully qualified for a license under subsection (a) of this section and shall be personally responsible for compliance with all the terms and provisions of this article. If such appointed agents shall, during the license year, cease to be an officer, manager or member of the corporation, firm, association or club on whose behalf the license was issued, a new license shall be required and application therefor shall be made pursuant to the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(5)(e), (5)(f)) 
Sec. 10-110. - Permit fee. 
    The permit fee shall be as set forth in section 42-10(4). 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(3)(b)) 
Sec. 10-111. - Number of devices permitted. 
    The total number of amusement devices may not exceed the maximum number specified on the permit or license at the location for which the permit or license was granted. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(6)(a)) 
Sec. 10-112. - Transfer. 
    Amusement arcade licenses and amusement device permits shall not be transferable. However, one amusement device may be substituted for another without permission from the village. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(6)(g)) 
Sec. 10-113. - Display. 
    The license or permit certificate shall be displayed in a public area of the premises. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(6)(b)) 
Sec. 10-114. - Suspension, revocation or nonrenewal. 
(a)  In addition to any other grounds stated in this article, a license or permit may be suspended and machines sealed by the chief of police or his designee whenever there is a reasonable cause to believe that there is an immediate threat to the public health, safety or welfare by violation of a law or ordinance. Such suspension shall not be effective for more than ten days without a hearing unless agreed to in writing by the village and the licensee or his representative. 
(b)  There shall be no operation of amusement devices without a license or permit during suspension or after revocation. 
(Code 1963, § 9.17(6)(h), (7)) 
Secs. 10-115-10-135. - Reserved. 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 38; animals in parks, § 66-32; water fowl and game birds in parks, § 66-33; agricultural districts, § 122-326. 
State Law reference- Animals generally, Wis. Stats. chs. 172-174; cruelty to animals, Wis. Stats. ch. 951; animal health, Wis. Stats. ch. 95. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any living creature other than a human being which is raised and/or maintained in confinement or which is intended to or is kept as a pet. It shall include, without limitation, the following: dogs, cats; domesticated horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats, swine, fowl, geese, and turkeys; and confined domestic hares and rabbits. 
    At large means any animal off of the premises of its owner or upon the public streets, alleys, public grounds, school grounds, or parks within the village. 
    Cat means all domesticated members of the Felis Catus family, male or female. 
    Dog means all domesticated members of the Canis Familiaris, male or female. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms, including the bathroom and the complete kitchen facilities, which are arranged, designed or used as living quarters for one family or household. 
    Guardian means owner. 
    Keeper means a person who has custodial or supervisory authority or control over an animal. 
    Kennel means any establishment for the commercial care, harboring or breeding of more than two dogs and/or cats. 
    Owner means any person owning, harboring, sheltering, keeping or taking care of an animal. 
    Premises of the guardian or keeper of an animal means only that property over which the guardian or keeper has full possession and control, and from which the guardian or keeper has the authority to exclude, and does exclude, the public. 
(1)  Private property which is fenced or otherwise enclosed so that dogs within it cannot escape, and which is set aside by the owner of the property for use as a dog exercise or play area, and through which persons who are authorized to use the property are not required to pass in order to get to their destination, shall be deemed the premises of any guardian or keeper who has the express permission of the owner of such area to use it with the dog for such purposes. 
(2)  Places which are not "premises of the guardian or keeper of an animal" within the meaning of this definition include, without limitation, the following: 
a.  All public property; or 
b.  On private property: 
1.  Any common sidewalk or walkway, any common unenclosed yard, or any other common unenclosed exterior space; 
2.  Any common parking facility (whether or not spaces are reserved); or 
3.  Any common interior room, hallway, stair, or passageway. 
4.  For the purposes of this definition, "common" means any part of a residential condominium, townhouse development, apartment building, shopping center, business condominium, office building, business center, or industrial park which residents, owners, tenants, employees, customers, or visitors of more than one unit or space may use. 
(Code 1963, § 10.06(1); Ord. No. 175-O-02, §§ 1-3, 3-4-02; Ord. No. 377-O-07, § 3, 6-4-07) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-2. - Impounding. 
(a)  Required. Every police officer, health department or humane officer finding an animal at large shall seize such animal and impound it in a place provided by the village. 
(b)  Repossession of animals. The possession of any dog so seized or impounded may be obtained by the owner upon the payment of all the amounts due as determined by section 42-14(b). 
(c)  Disposal of animals. 
(1)  Any animal not reclaimed by the owner within seven days may be disposed of as provided by the impoundment facility. 
(2)  The carcasses of dead animals must be disposed of in a sanitary manner within 24 hours after death. If such carcasses are disposed of by the village, the village shall, if reasonably possible, notify owners of the disposal of their animal. 
(d)  Reporting. 
(1)  Any person or officer who impounds or kills any animal subject to this chapter shall deliver such animal or its carcass to such village officials or employees as may be designated by the village manager for that purpose. After making this delivery, such person or officer shall make, upon request, a report to the village manager stating when and under what conditions the person or officer seized, impounded or killed such animal, together with the name and address of the owner, if known. 
(2)  Whenever any unlicensed dog or cat is so impounded and delivered to the proper village official, that official may, if practical, give notice to the owner, if known, of the impoundment of such unlicensed dog or cat within 24 hours after the delivery of this animal to that village official. This notice may be given verbally to the owner or keeper of such animal, or to a member of the owner's or the keeper's family who is over 16 years of age and resides with the owner or keeper. 
(Code 1963, § 10.06(4)) 
Sec. 14-3. - Running at large. 
(a)  No person shall permit or suffer any animal which that person owns, or which is in that person's possession or control, to be at large within the village. Any animal found at large shall be deemed to be so with the permission, or at the sufferance, of its owner or the person in possession or control of such animal. 
(b)  No person, except the owner of an animal, or the owner's agent, shall open any door or gate of any private premises or to otherwise entice or enable any animal to leave any private premises, for the purpose or with the result of setting such animal at large. 
(c)  If any person secures an animal, or suffers or permits an animal to be secured by any tie-out, rope, leash or chain on that persons's property or the property of another, such person shall ensure that any such tie-out, rope, leash or chain of so used be of such length as to prevent the animal so secured from roaming beyond the property limits of the property on which the animal is secured. 
(d)  An animal which otherwise falls within the definition set out in section 14-1 will not be deemed to be at large if: 
(1)  It is attached to a leash of sufficient strength to restrain the animal and not more than ten feet in length where such leash is held by a person competent to govern the animal; 
(2)  When the animal is properly restrained within a motor vehicle, provided that such vehicle is properly ventilated for the animal's safety; or 
(3)  When not more than 50 feet from its owner or the agent of such owner in charge of such animal, and competent to govern such animal, at such distance, if the animal is not annoying or worrying pedestrians or trespassing on private property or public areas where such animals are forbidden. 
(Code 1963, § 10.06(2)) 
State Law reference- Livestock at large, Wis. Stats. § 172.01; dogs at large, Wis. Stats. § 174.042. 
Sec. 14-4. - Rabid animals. 
(a)  The owner of any animal which has contracted rabies or which has been subject to rabies, or which is suspected of having rabies, or shall have bitten any person, shall, upon demand of the police department of the village, produce or surrender up such animal to be held in quarantine for observation for a period determined by the health authority. 
(b)  If, upon examination by the health authority, any animal shall be proved to be infected with rabies, such animal shall be killed as directed by the health authority. 
(c)  No persons shall knowingly harbor or keep any animal infected with rabies, or any animal known to have been bitten by a rabid animal, or shall fail to report to the police department the existence of a animal which he knows to be so infected. 
(d)  During the time that the village or any part of the village shall be quarantined for rabies, pursuant to the provision of Wis. Stats. § 95.21, or any other provision of the law, animals within the district so quarantined shall be securely confined, tied, leashed or muzzled. Any animal not kept securely confined, tied, leashed or muzzled is declared to be a public nuisance and shall be impounded by any police officer, health official, humane officer or other person. 
(e)  Upon the impounding of such animal, notice of such shall be given, and the animal may be repossessed, and it may be killed and a report made in the manner described under this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 10.06(6)) 
State Law reference- Rabies control, Wis. Stats. § 95.21. 
Sec. 14-5. - Abandoned animals. 
    No person shall abandon any animal on any public or private lands within the village. 
(Code 1963, § 10.06(9)) 
Sec. 14-6. - Responsibility for care of dogs and cats. 
    The owner of any dog or cat shall be responsible that: 
(1)  All dogs and cats shall be maintained in a healthy condition or, if ill, shall be given appropriate treatment immediately. 
(2)  The quarters outside of the dwelling unit in which the dogs and cats are kept shall be maintained in a clean condition and in a good state of repair and provide adequate protection from the weather. 
(3)  Dog or cat pens or enclosures shall be large enough to provide freedom or movement to the animals contained therein. 
(4)  Food supplies outside of the dwelling unit shall be stored in rodentproof containers, and food and water containers shall be kept clean. 
(5)  Litter and/or bedding material, outside of the dwelling unit, shall be changed as often as necessary to prevent an odor nuisance. 
(6)  Feces shall be removed from yards, pens and enclosure every 24 hours to prevent health problems and shall be stored in a tightly covered metal container until final disposal. 
(7)  Yards, pens, premises and animals shall be kept free of insect infestations. 
(8)  No odor nuisances shall be permitted. 
(Code 1963, § 10.06(7)) 
State Law reference- Mistreating animals, Wis. Stats. § 951.02; food and drink for confined animals, Wis. Stats. § 951.13; shelter for animals, Wis. Stats. § 951.14. 
Sec. 14-7. - Poisoning domestic animals prohibited. 
    No person shall knowingly poison any domestic animal. It is a specific defense to this section that the person was the guardian of the animal or a veterinarian acting at the direction of the guardian or an employee of an animal shelter and the poison was administered directly to the animal to euthanize it. 
(Ord. No. 175-O-02, § 4, 3-4-02) 
Sec. 14-8. - Vicious animals prohibited. 
(a)  Except persons in compliance with section 14-29, no person shall own or keep a vicious animal. 
(b)  Vicious animal defined. 
(1)  Except as provided in subsection (b)(2) below, an animal is deemed vicious under this section when: 
a.  The animal bites, claws, or attempts to bite or claw any person; bites or injures another animal; or 
b.  In a vicious or terrorizing manner the animal approaches any person in an apparent attitude of attack, whether or not the attack is consummated or capable of being consummated; or 
c.  When a propensity of the animal to attack or bite persons, pets or domestic animals shall exist and is known or reasonable to be known to the owner or to any member of the owner's immediate family who resides with the owner. 
(2)  Exceptions. 
a.  This section shall not apply to dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the performance of their duties. 
b.  Not withstanding subsection (b)(1) above, an animal shall not be deemed vicious for engaging in actions describe in subsection (b)(1) under any of the following circumstances: 
(i)  The subject animal was defending its owner, caretaker or another person from an attack by a person or animal. 
(ii)  The subject animal was protecting itself, its young or another animal. 
(iii)  The subject animal was defending itself against any person who was provoking, tormenting, assaulting or abusing the subject; or who was engaging in conduct reasonably calculated to provoke the subject animal to attack, bite, or injure. 
(iv)  The subject animal was defending itself against any other animal that was provoking, tormenting, assaulting or abusing the subject animal; or engaging in conduct reasonably calculated to provoke the subject animal to attack, bite, or injure. 
(v)  The subject animal was defending its owner's or caretaker's property against trespassers. 
(vi)  The person or animal injured, threatened or approached by the subject animal was unlawfully engaging in entry into or upon a fenced or enclosed portion of the premises upon which the subject animal was lawfully kept or upon a portion of the premises where the subject animal was lawfully chained; 
(vii)  The person injured, threatened or approached by the subject animal was engaging in unlawful entry into or unlawfully in or upon a vehicle in which the subject animal was confined; 
(viii)  The person injured, threatened or approached by the subject animal was attempting to stop a fight between that animal and any other animal. 
(ix)  The person injured, threatened or approached by the subject animal was attempting to aid that animal when the animal was injured. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, a person is lawfully upon the premises of a guardian or keeper when such person is on said premises in the performance of any duty imposed by law or by the express or implied invitation of the owner of such premises or the owner's agent. 
(d)  Any vicious animal which is found off the premises of its owner may be seized by any police officer or humane officer and, upon establishing to the satisfaction of the court of the vicious character of such animal by testimony under oath, reduced to writing, be killed by the police authorities. 
(Ord. No. 175-O-02, § 5, 3-4-02; Ord. No. 377-O-07, §§ 2, 4, 6-4-07; Ord. No. 638-O-15, § 1, 12-7-15) 
Sec. 14-9. - Animals as nuisance prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall own or keep any animal that constitutes a nuisance. An animal constitutes a nuisance under this section by violating any of the sections in this chapter, by being a safety or health hazard, by damaging the property of another, or creating offensive odors; any of which materially interferes with or disrupts another individual in the conduct of lawful activities at such individual's home. 
(b)  Penalties. 
(1)  Forfeiture. Any person who violates this section shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-7 of this Municipal Code. Each day a violation exists constitutes a separate violation and is punishable as such. 
(2)  In addition to any other penalties or remedies available under this code, if the village manager or the village manager's designee finds that a nuisance exists in violation of this chapter, the village manager or the village manager's designee may request that the owner or keeper of the animal correct the violation by notifying the owner or keeper, or both the owner and the keeper, that such person has 24 hours from the date of the notice to correct the violation or such longer period as the village manager or the village manager's designee determines is reasonably necessary to correct the violation. Notice under this subsection is sufficient if it is delivered to the owner or keeper or mailed first class to the address of the owner of property on which the animal is kept. If the person notified fails to correct the violation as required by the notice, the village may correct the violation by taking any necessary and reasonable means to do so and charge the costs thereof, plus an additional amount of $25.00 for administrative costs, to the owner of the property where the animal is kept, and jointly and severally to the owner and keeper of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 175-O-02, § 6, 3-4-02; Ord. No. 394-O-08, § 1, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 14-10. - Barking, howling, or other unreasonable animal noise prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this section for any person who owns, keeps, has in that person's possession or harbors any animal to permit such animal to disturb any person or neighborhood by making loud and persistent or habitual howling, yelping, barking, whining or like sounds that can be heard beyond the boundary of the person's property. 
(b)  In any prosecution for a violation of this section, the fact that the animal noise that disturbed a person or neighborhood occurred under either of the following circumstances shall create a rebuttable presumption that the animal noise was unlawful: 
(1)  When none of the residents who reside at the place where the subject animal is being kept are at home; or 
(2)  If the subject animal howls, yelps, barks, whines or makes like sounds for ten minutes or more in any 15 minute period. 
(Ord. No. 175-O-02, § 7, 3-4-02; Ord. No. 394-O-08, § 2, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 14-11. - Removal of animal excrement required. 
(a)  No person owning or keeping any animal shall fail to prevent such animal from defecating upon any property other than the premises of the guardian or keeper. 
(b)  It is a specific defense to a charge of violating this section that the defecation occurred on private property with express permission of the owner or all tenants thereof. 
(c)  It is a specific defense to a charge of violating this section that the defecation was from an ungulate or camelid within any park, recreation area, or open space. 
(d)  It is a specific defense to a charge of violating this section that the guardian or keeper immediately removed or cleaned up such deposit and disposed thereof by depositing it in a toilet or a receptacle ordinarily used for garbage and covered by a lid or in an otherwise lawful and sanitary manner. 
(e)  The maximum penalty for a first conviction within two years, based on date of violation shall be $500.00. For a second or subsequent violation, the court shall impose the maximum forfeiture allowed under section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 175-O-02, § 8, 3-4-02) 
Secs. 14-12-14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, Wis. Stats. ch. 174. 

Sec. 14-26. - Licensing. 
(a)  Dog defined. As used in this article, the term "dog" includes all domesticated members of Canis Familiaris, male or female. 
(b)  Tag required. All dogs more than five months of age must be licensed and wear a license tag attached to its dog collar. The fact that a dog is without a proper license tag attached to its collar shall be presumptive evidence that it is unlicensed. 
(c)  Fee. The fee to be paid for a village dog license shall be as provided in section 42-14(a). An additional late fee shall be collected from every owner of a dog required to be licensed if the owner failed to obtain a license prior to April 1 of each year, or within 30 days of acquiring ownership of a dog subject to a license, or if the owner failed to obtain a license on before the date the dog reached an age which would subject it to the licensing requirement. 
(Code 1963, §§ 9.11(1)-(3), 27.09(8)(c)) 
State Law reference- Dog license tax, Wis. Stats. § 174.05. 
Sec. 14-27. - Offensive action by dogs. 
    It shall be unlawful, and is declared to be a violation of this article to own, harbor, or keep any dog which: 
(1)  Habitually pursues any vehicle upon any public highway, street or alley in the village. 
(2)  Litters any place other than on the premises of the keeper or owner. Accumulation of decayed animal matter in which flies may breed is prohibited. The owner or person walking a dog shall remove and dispose of any deposited excrement immediately after it is deposited by such dog. The owner or any person walking a dog not immediately removing such excrement shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1963, § 10.06(5); Ord. No. 175-O-02, §§ 9-10c., 3-4-02) 
Sec. 14-28. - Kennels prohibited in certain areas. 
    It shall be unlawful to establish, operate or maintain any kennel consisting of more than two dogs which are at least six months of age within 100 feet of any church, school, hospital or sanitarium; or any building used wholly or partially for residential purposes in the village. No public kennels shall be established, operated or maintained in any residential district or on any property zoned for residential purposes. 
(Code 1963, § 10.06(8); Ord. No. 175-O-02, § 11, 3-4-02) 
Sec. 14-29. - Regulation of vicious dogs. 
(a)  Definition of vicious dog. Any dog, except dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the performance of their duties, shall be deemed a vicious dog if it falls into any of the following categories: 
(1)  Any dog where the dog's owner or caretaker has been convicted of violating section 14-8 of this chapter for actions relating to that dog. 
(2)  Any dog that has been declared dangerous or vicious by any agency or department of another municipality, county, or state shall be subject to the provisions of this ordinance for the remainder of its life. 
(b)  Owner of vicious dog to comply with provisions of this section. 
(1)  Unless another time period or deadline is set out elsewhere in this ordinance, any person owning or having custody of any dog defined as vicious under subsection (a)(1) of this section shall comply with all the provisions of this section within ten days of the conviction of the owner or caretaker. 
(2)  Any person owning or having custody or care of any dog defined as vicious under subsection (a)(2) of this section shall notify the police department of the dog's address and the conditions or restrictions of maintenance already imposed by the other agency or department within seven days of moving the animal into the village. In addition, the owner of the vicious dog shall comply with all of the provisions of this section within ten days after notifying the police department of moving the animal into the village. 
(c)  Signage. The owner or caretaker of a vicious dog shall display in a prominent place on his or her premises a warning sign in letters no less than two inches high, stating that there is a vicious dog on the premises. This sign shall be clearly visible and capable of being read from any public property, street or highway adjacent to the premises. If the entrance to the premises is not visible from an adjacent street or highway, such as an apartment or condominium, then the sign shall be displayed on all entrance doors to an owner's or caretaker's premises. A similar sign shall be posted on the pen or kennel of the dog. The sign or signs shall contain a symbol warning children of the presence of a vicious dog. 
(d)  Confinement. All vicious dogs shall be securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or kennel on the premises of the owner or caretaker except when leashed and muzzled. When constructed in an open yard, the pen or kennel must be childproof from the outside and dog proof from the inside. A strong metal double fence with adequate space between fences (at least two feet) must be provided so that a child cannot reach into the dog enclosure. The pen, kennel or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top attached to all sides. A structure used to confine a vicious dog shall be locked with a key or combination lock when the dog is within the structure. The structure shall have a secure bottom or floor attached to the sides of the pen or the sides of the pen must be embedded in the ground no less than two feet. All structures erected to house vicious dogs shall comply with all zoning and building regulations of the village. No vicious dog may be kept on a porch, patio or in any part of a house or structure on the premises of the owner or caretaker that could allow the dog to exit the house or structure on its own volition, except through a door leading directly to a pen or kennel meeting all of the requirements of this subsection. No vicious dog may be kept in a house or structure when the windows are open or when screen windows or screen door are the only obstacles preventing the dog from exiting the house or structure. 
(e)  Leash and muzzle. No person owning, harboring or having care of a vicious dog may permit that dog to go outside of its kennel or pen unless the dog is securely leashed on a leash, no longer than four feet in length. No person may permit a vicious dog to be kept on a chain, rope, leash or similar restraining device outside its kennel or pen unless a person who is at least 18 years of age and competent to govern the animal is in physical control of the restraining device and remains in position to control the dog at all times. The dog may not be leashed to inanimate objects such as tees, posts and buildings. A vicious dog outside the dog's kennel shall be muzzled in a humane way by a muzzling device sufficient to prevent the dog from biting persons or other animals. A vicious dog shall not be required to be muzzled when either shown in a sanctioned American Kennel Club Show or upon prior written approval by the chief of police. 
(f)  Spay and neuter requirement. Within 30 days after a dog has been designated vicious, the owner or caretaker of the dog shall provide written proof from a licensed veterinarian that the dog has been spayed or neutered. If the owner submits a timely appeal of the conviction under section 14-8 of this chapter or designation of the dog as vicious by the other department or agency noted in subsection (a)(2) above, then this requirement shall be stayed until such time as any further right to appeal has been exhausted, or until such time as the designation or conviction has been overturned on appeal. 
(g)  Liability insurance. The owner or caretaker of the vicious dog shall present to the village manager or the manager's designee a certificate of insurance that shows that the owner has procured liability insurance in the amount of at least $100,000.00, insuring the owner for any personal injuries or physical damage inflicted by the vicious dog. In addition the policy of insurance shall require a minimum of ten days notice to the village of any cancellation or termination of such policy. Instead of the liability insurance requirement, the owner of a vicious dog may present evidence of a bond in the sum of at least $100,000.00, payable to any person injured or whose property has been damaged by the vicious dog. The proof of insurance or surety bond must be presented to the village manager or the manager's each year at the time the dog's license is renewed. 
(h)  Required notification by owner. The owner or caretaker of a vicious dog shall immediately notify the police department if the dog escapes, is unconfined, has attacked another animal or human being, has died, has been sold or given away. If the dog has been sold or given away the owner shall give the police department the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner. 
(i)  Reserved. 
(j)  Penalties. In addition to any other action or remedy, any person convicted of violating any provision of this section shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. Each violation and each day that a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(k)  Removal or destruction of vicious dogs. 
(1)  If the owner or caretaker of a vicious dog is unwilling to comply with the regulations for keeping the dog in accordance with this section, the owner or caretaker shall notify the police department, and shall remove the dog from the village within 48 hours of such notice. If the owner or caretaker removes a dog under this subsection, the dog may not be returned until the owner or caretaker presents documentation acceptable to the police chief that there is compliance with all regulations of this section. In addition to any other remedy or penalty, should the owner or caretaker fail to timely remove the vicious dog as required under this subsection, the dog may be subject to destruction as provided in subsection (k)(3) below. 
(2)  If the owner or caretaker of a vicious dog is unable to comply with the regulations for keeping the dog in accordance with this section, owner shall remove the dog within 24 hours of service of written notice to do so. If the owner refuses to accept such notice, the police department may attach the written notice to the front door of the owner's residence and such notice shall be deemed served upon posting on the door. In addition to any other remedy or penalty, should the owner fail to timely remove the vicious dog as required under this subsection, the dog may be subject to destruction as provided in subsection (k)(3) below. An owner or caretaker shall be deemed to be unable to comply with the regulations for keeping the dog in accordance with this section if the owner has been convicted of violating any provision of this section. 
(3)  In addition to any other penalty or remedy, upon reasonable suspicion that a vicious dog is being kept in the village in violation this subsection, the village may file an action in the circuit court seeking an order authorizing the destruction of the vicious dog. Upon establishing the vicious character of the dog, the court may enter an order authorizing the village to kill the dog. 
[(l)  Reserved.] 
(m)  Inspection. The police department may make whatever inquiry is deemed reasonably necessary to insure compliance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 377-O-07, § 1, 6-4-07; Ord. No. 638-O-15, §§ 2, 3, 12-7-15) 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 58; signs, ch. 78; solid waste, ch. 82; litter control on construction sites, § 82-41 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; subdivision and other divisions of land, ch. 94; utilities, ch. 110; vegetation, ch. 114; zoning, ch. 122; shoreland-wetland zoning ordinance, app. B. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contractor means the owner, agents or representatives of the owner, and contractors required by ordinance to obtain permits and inspections for their work. 
    Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate including, but not limited to, construction of or additions or substantial improvements to buildings, other structures or accessory structures; mining; dredging; filling; grading; paving; excavation or drilling operations; or disposition of materials. 
    Parking, temporary means the parking of vehicles for not more than 72 hours in any period of seven consecutive days. 
    Pool means a receptacle, either temporary or permanent, for water, or an artificial pool having a capable depth at any point of more than 18 inches, greater in surface area than 100 square feet, intended for the purpose of immersion or partial immersion therein of human beings, and including all appurtenant equipment, and shall encompass either a swimming pool or a wading pool or a combination swimming and wading pool, not enclosed in a permanent building. 
(Code 1963, § 14.03) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-2. - Buildings damaged by fire or natural calamity. 
    It shall be unlawful to repair any existing structure or building when such structure or building shall have been damaged by fire or natural calamity to the extent of 50 percent of the present assessed value of such structure or building. When a building or structure is damaged by fire or natural calamity, the fire department shall submit a report to the village manager or designee describing the location and extent of damage to the building as well as an approximate value of the damage. If the village manager or designee determines that the building has become dangerous, unsafe, insanitary or otherwise unfit for human habitation, occupancy or use, the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.0413 shall be used. 
(Code 1963, § 14.07; Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 10, 11-19-01) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46. 
Sec. 18-3. - Dumping of material on lots. 
(a)  No person shall dump or cause to be dumped any ground, dirt or similar material on any unimproved lot in such manner that the resultant elevation of any part of the lot becomes higher than the elevations at the abutting property lines. 
(b)  In the event of a violation of this section, the village manager or designee shall notify the owner, in writing, to cause such unimproved lot to be graded to the proper level within 15 days after the date of such notice. Upon failure to comply with such notice, the village manager or designee may enter upon the premises with such assistance as may be necessary, causing the existing condition to be corrected and the cost of such correction charged against the property and shall be a lien thereon and shall be assessed and collected as a special tax. 
(Code 1963, § 14.09) 
State Law reference- Littering, Wis. Stats. § 287.81. 
Sec. 18-4. - Wrecking or razing of buildings and structures. 
(a)  Whenever a building is demolished or wrecked, it shall be removed in a manner that disturbs the adjoining properties and public areas as little as possible. Adjacent areas must be protected from damage. 
(b)  Waste material and rubbish shall not be stored nor allowed to accumulate within the building or in the immediate vicinity, but shall be removed from the premises as rapidly as practicable. 
(c)  The building site of any building wrecked shall be properly cleared of all debris and rubbish and shall be properly graded and leveled so that the site does not spoil the appearance of the neighborhood. 
(d)  When any building, which is served by public sanitary sewer or water, is either to be moved from the land upon which it stands, or is demolished, the service laterals shall be disconnected at the curb or main, at the discretion of the village manager or designee, in accordance with all applicable regulations. No buildings shall be moved or demolished until the sanitary sewer and/or water service laterals are disconnected. 
(e)  When any building which is served by on-site sanitary sewer or water facilities (well and/or septic system or holding tank) is either to be moved from the land upon which it stands or is demolished, the on-site facilities shall be abandoned in accordance with all applicable regulations. No buildings shall be moved or demolished until the on-site facilities are abandoned. 
(f)  Before a building can be demolished or removed, the owner or agent shall notify all utilities having service connections within the building, such as water, electric, gas, sewer and other connections. A permit to demolish or to remove a building shall not be issued until it is ascertained that service connections and appurtenant equipment, such as meters and regulators, have been removed or sealed and plugged in a safe manner, and all on-site wells, septic systems or holding tanks have been properly abandoned. 
(Code 1963, § 14.08) 
Secs. 18-5-18-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-26. - Occupancy permits. 
(a)  Occupancy permit required. Before any building or vacant land is occupied or used, an occupancy permit or temporary occupancy permit shall be issued by the village manager or designee. An occupancy permit is required for: 
(1)  Residential, one- and two-family (Uniform Dwelling Code [UDC]). New buildings only. 
(2)  Residential, multi-tenant. New buildings, and additions. Prior to the issuance of an occupancy permit or temporary occupancy permit, the fire department shall certify in writing to the village manager or designee that a thorough inspection has been made of the premises and all required systems are installed and functioning properly. 
(3)  Commercial, industrial, institutional and other non-UDC. New buildings, additions, change of use, change of business or tenant. Prior to the issuance of an occupancy permit or temporary occupancy permit, the fire department shall certify in writing to the village manager or designee that a thorough inspection has been made of the premises and all required systems are installed and functioning properly. 
(b)  Application and review/inspection procedure. 
(1)  Inspections for occupancy shall be requested by the owner or tenant on forms supplied by the village manager or designee at least ten days before the anticipated date of occupancy. 
(2)  No occupancy permit shall be issued without an approved zoning permit. 
(3)  Any change in use, or substantial building modification, shall require a zoning permit and/or building permit before applying for the occupancy permit. 
(4)  The building inspector shall inspect the building, site, or premises for compliance with all current codes, plans, specifications, and conditions of approval before issuance of an occupancy permit. No occupancy shall be allowed if any other outstanding violations exist on the site. As-built plans may be required to substantiate or verify that certain conditions of the zoning permit, use approval, conditional use permit, developer's agreement, or building permit have been complied with. 
(5)  Before occupying a site, existing building or part of a building located in a business, office, manufacturing, or institutional district, or any site, existing building or part of a building used for business, office, manufacturing, or institutional purposes by a new tenant or owner, a new occupancy permit must first be applied for and issued by the village manager or designee before any new use by the new tenant or owner. 
(c)  Temporary occupancy permits. The village manager or designee may issue a temporary occupancy permit for a part or parts of a building or structure, before the entire work covered by a building permit shall have been completed provided such portion or portions may be occupied safely prior to full completion of the building without endangering life or public welfare. No such partial occupancy permit may be issued prior to full compliance with those provisions of State Statutes and the Wisconsin Administrative Code that affect health and safety or before full completion of accessible routes to, into, and through the building or structure. A temporary occupancy permit may be issued for a period not exceeding six months. 
(d)  Hardship. The village manager or designee shall have the authority and power to allow the occupancy of any building, structure or equipment before the issuance of an occupancy permit, if the village manager or designee determines that a hardship exists and that occupancy is warranted before the final stage of completion as described in this chapter. This provision shall not apply with respect to any occupancy for commercial purposes or occupancy by tenants for residential purposes. Before granting such permission, the village manager or designee shall first inspect the subject property to determine that it is safe and otherwise sanitary and to determine the time, not to exceed 120 days, within which the construction or other work thereon shall be completed. 
(e)  Permit to be posted. The occupancy permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the subject building or structure or on the subject premises, except one- and two-family dwellings and accessory buildings or structures thereto. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(n); Ord. No. 224-O-03, § 1, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 18-27. - Impact fees. 
    No permit shall be issued for the construction or occupancy of any building or structure until all impact fees required by section 42-141 et seq. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(o)) 
Secs. 18-28-18-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING PERMIT 

Sec. 18-46. - Required. 
    No development shall occur, nor any structure or building be enlarged, nor added to, moved, improved, altered, extended, demolished or removed, unless a permit therefor shall first be obtained by the owner or his agent from the village manager or designee. Permits are also required for all uses prescribed in the permit fee schedule of this Code. Compliance with the provisions of this chapter does not relieve the owner from compliance with rules established in other related codes. Construction or erection of fences, walls or other architectural screening devices, which extend 41/2 feet or more above the adjacent grade level, shall require a building permit. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(1)) 
Sec. 18-47. - Application. 
(a)  Application for a permit shall be made in writing. 
(1)  Permits to be issued under the State Uniform Dwelling Code shall use the form prescribed by the state. 
(2)  All other permits shall be upon a form to be furnished by the village manager or designee and shall state: 
a.  The name and address of the owner of the building and the owner of the land on which it is to be erected. 
b.  The name and address of the applicant for the permit. 
c.  The name and address of the contractor that will do the work. 
d.  The address of the building or property where the work will be done. 
e.  Legal description of the land on which the building is (is to be) located. 
f.  The estimated cost of the project. 
(b)  With such application, there shall be submitted to the village manager or designee two complete sets of plans and specifications, and four copies of a plat of survey complying with Wis. Admin. Code Ch. A-E 7, including an original seal on each copy of the survey. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(2)) 
Sec. 18-48. - Survey. 
    When a survey is required, it shall be prepared and certified by a surveyor registered by the state. The survey shall indicate: 
(1)  A complete and accurate legal description of the lot or parcel of land involved; 
(2)  Name and address of the owner; 
(3)  Location and dimensions of all lot lines; 
(4)  Location and dimensions of all buildings on the lot, both existing and proposed, relative to the lot lines; 
(5)  Information to tie the lot or parcel to the nearest quarter section corner or block corner; 
(6)  Proposed grade at the proposed structure, along with grades at adjacent buildings, lot corners, and road right-of-way opposite the lot or parcel; 
(7)  Location and dimensions of easements, encroachments, etc.; 
(8)  Names and right-of-way widths of adjoining streets; 
(9)  A north arrow and the scale of the drawing; 
(10)  Watercourses or existing drainage ditches; 
(11)  Seal and signature of the surveyor, along with the date of the survey. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(3)) 
Sec. 18-49. - Plans and specifications. 
(a)  Plans and specifications for work proposed under the State Uniform Dwelling Code shall be as required by the Uniform Dwelling Code. 
(b)  Plans and specifications for work proposed under the State Building Code shall be as required by the State Building Code. 
(c)  Plans and specifications for all other work shall be of sufficient clarity to indicate the nature and character of the work proposed and to show that the law will be complied with. All plans shall disclose the existing and proposed provisions for water supply, sanitary sewer connections and surface water drainage. 
(d)  Plans and specifications shall be kept on file in the office of the village manager or designee until the completion of the building and for one year thereafter. The owner or contractor may have the plans and specifications returned to him after the one year, provided that the village manager or designee has no further use for them and a written request for the return of the plans and specifications is filed with the village manager or designee. Plans and specifications not requested to be returned may be destroyed by the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(4)(a)-(4)(d)) 
Sec. 18-50. - Submission of additional plans. 
    In addition to the information provided on the building permit application required by the Uniform Dwelling Code, as incorporated in this chapter, an applicant for a permit under the Uniform Dwelling Code shall also submit such plans as may be requested by the village manager or designee showing land formation, grading sites, and landscaping plans; all work provided in these plans must be completed within the time limits set out in section 18-5. 
(Code 1963, § 14.02(2)) 
Sec. 18-51. - Waiver of some requirements. 
    At the option of the village manager or designee, plans, data, specifications and survey need not be submitted with an application for a permit to execute minor alterations and repairs to any building, structure or equipment, provided that the proposed construction is sufficiently described in the application for the permit. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(4)(e)) 
Sec. 18-52. - Issuance. 
(a)  The application, plans and specifications filed by an applicant for a permit shall be reviewed by the village manager or designee, and if found to be in conformity with the requirements of this chapter and all other laws or ordinance applicable thereto, the village manager or designee shall, upon receipt of the required fee, issue a permit. 
(b)  When the village manager or designee issues the permit, he shall endorse in writing or stamp two sets of plans and specifications "conditionally approved." One such approved set of plans and specifications shall be retained by the village manager or designee as a public record, and one such approved set of plans shall be returned to the applicant and kept on the building or work site at all times during which the work authorized is in progress and shall be available to officials. Approved plans and specifications shall not be changed, modified or altered without approval from the village manager or designee. 
(c)  In case adequate plans are presented, the village manager or designee, at his discretion, may issue a permit for a part of the building before receiving the plans and specifications of the entire building. It shall be unlawful to commence work on any building or alteration before the building permit has been issued. The issuance of a permit upon the plans and specifications shall not prevent the village manager or designee from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in said plans and specifications or from preventing building operations being carried on thereunder when in violation of any ordinances of the village or laws of the state, or lawful orders issued pursuant thereto. 
(d)  For the construction of buildings requiring approval of the department of commerce, no permit shall be issued until such approved plans are received by the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(6); Ord. No. 357-O-06, §§ 1, 2, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 479-O-10, §§ 1, 2, 5-17-10) 
Sec. 18-53. - Withholding permits pending acquisition of land by government body. 
(a)  Whenever the village board shall find and determine that an expressway, grade separation project or other public improvement is being planned by the federal government, state, county or the village involving any real estate within the village, the village board may direct the village manager or designee to withhold the issuance of any building permit relating to proposed improvements to such real estate for a period not to exceed 120 days after application of permit has been made to enable such governmental unit or agency to acquire such property by purchase or condemnation. 
(b)  To provide for the orderly acquisition of property for permanent improvement projects contemplated by the village, to minimize the cost thereof by avoiding further improvements thereon, the cost of which would ultimately be borne by the village at the time of purchase or condemnation, to ensure the prompt and least expensive acquisition of property in the village by other governmental organizations, and to best serve the general interest, convenience and necessity, this section is enacted to expedite and systematize the purchase of such property. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(11)) 
Sec. 18-54. - Refusal. 
    The village manager or designee may refuse a permit when the applicant has been guilty of continued or willful code violations. A continued violation shall include, without limitation, any work incomplete under an earlier permit, or if complete, failure to request a reinspection or a final inspection for the work. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(7)) 
Sec. 18-55. - Drainage. 
    No permit shall be issued if the erection of the building and the proposed grades shall unreasonably obstruct the natural flow of water from the surface of adjoining property or obstruct the flow of any existing ravine, ditch, drain or stormwater sewer draining neighboring property, unless suitable provision is made for such flow by means of an adequate ditch or pipe, which shall be shown on the plans and shall be constructed so as to provide continuous drainage at all times. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(a)) 
Sec. 18-56. - Sanitary permit required for areas without public sewers. 
    For building construction in areas without a public sewer, a sanitary permit shall be obtained from the county health department, a copy of which shall be filed with the permit application or prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(b)) 
Sec. 18-57. - Grade approval required. 
    The village manager or designee shall not issue a building permit to any person for the construction of any building (other than a temporary building which shall be removed within six months after the date of issuance of the permit) on land abutting on any street or other public way prior to establishment of grade by the village manager or designee. Every building hereafter erected, structurally altered, or relocated shall be at a grade approved by the village manager or designee as being in satisfactory relationship with the established street grades, or with the existing street grade where none is established, with particular consideration for proper drainage and safe vehicular access. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(c)) 
Sec. 18-58. - Residential construction. 
    No permit for the construction of a residence shall be granted where the elevation of the top of the basement or foundation wall is to be less than 12 inches above the fixed grade of the sidewalk on the street or other public way at the points directly out from the front corners of the building, except with written approval of the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(d)) 
Sec. 18-59. - Commercial or industrial construction. 
    No permit for the construction of a commercial or industrial building shall be granted where the elevation of the top of the basement or foundation wall is to be lower than the fixed grade for the sidewalk on the street or other public way at a point directly out from the front or main entrance of said commercial or industrial buildings, except with written approval of the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(e)) 
Sec. 18-60. - Private garages. 
    No building permit shall be issued to any person for the construction of a private garage where the elevation of the floor at any point of such garage is to be less than six inches above the fixed grade of the street, sidewalk, alley or other public way from which access by car is to be made, except with written approval of the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(f)) 
Sec. 18-61. - Residential construction where village water or sewer unavailable. 
    No permit will be issued for the erection of a residential building for which village water or village sanitary sewer are not immediately available and in service; nor will such permit be issued unless the lot abuts upon a passable graded roadway which will allow proper and ready access for fire, police and other village services and equipment, except for the purpose of constructing model homes, in which case the maximum number of building permits issued shall be equal to five percent of the building lots in the subdivision. In areas where village sewer and water are not available, an approved well system and approved septic system can be used in lieu of municipal sewer and water; however, a passable graded road must abut such lot. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(g)) 
Sec. 18-62. - Stormwater disposal requirements. 
(a)  No permit will be issued for the erection of a building upon a lot within the limits of the village which lies in a natural drainage area where no storm sewer is available. The storm sewer requirements may be waived by the village manager or designee where the applicant makes provision for a ditch, culvert or other satisfactory means which will operate to drain off stormwater accumulations which could amount to a nuisance or a hazard to the public health, safety or welfare. 
(b)  In structures other than one-family and two-family residences, where storm sewer systems are available, surface waters of the building or structure, of parking areas, courts, driveways and unenclosed storage areas shall be provided with a storm sewer drainage system to collect surface waters before the drainage water reaches a public right-of-way. 
(c)  No permit will be issued until a culvert, when needed, has been installed subject to the approval of the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(i)-(5)(k)) 
Sec. 18-63. - Parking areas and driveways. 
    Parking areas and driveways and approaches thereto, serving all uses except one-family and two-family residences, shall be subject to the specific approval of the village manager or designee, both as to location and arrangement. No permit shall be issued for a building or structure with which such parking area, driveway or approach is to be used until such approval is obtained. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(l)) 
Sec. 18-64. - Plans for fire department use. 
    Developers shall submit one set of plans for fire department use. This shall apply to all new buildings in the village excluding the construction of one-family and two-family dwellings and appurtenant structures. Changes of use or modifications of existing buildings or structures shall follow the same procedure. Prior to the issuance of a building permit, written requirements shall be secured from the fire department relating to fire safety measures of the proposed development. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(m)) 
Sec. 18-65. - Permit fees. 
    The fees for permits required by this article shall be as established in section 42-18(a). 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(9)) 
Sec. 18-66. - Cash deposit. 
(a)  A cash deposit in the amount established in section 42-18(a)(2) shall be required upon the issuance of a building permit for a principal building or structure or an addition thereto. Subject to the village manager or designee's approval, minor alterations and residential accessory structures may be exempted from the deposit. 
(b)  The deposit monies may, when required, be used by the village as reimbursement to restore water stop boxes to the finished yard grade elevation and be operational; to repair damage to street pavement and/or curbs and gutters; to repair damage to swales, ditches and/or culverts; or to repair other damage done to public facilities during the construction of the building or structure. 
(c)  Only after an occupancy permit has been issued will the deposit monies be refunded to the person having paid such deposit, subject then to all the conditions set forth in this section. 
(d)  The full allocated amount of the building deposit shall be forfeited if any contractor fails to request a final inspection and if the building or structure is occupied without final approval or issuance of an occupancy permit by the village manager or designee. If a deficiency or noncompliance is observed upon the final inspection, the contractor shall, within 45 days from the date of written notice, provide compliance and request a final reinspection. Failure to complete work or request a final reinspection within the 45 days shall provide for automatic deposit forfeiture. Forfeiture of deposit monies does not in any manner relieve the owner and/or contractors of the obligation and responsibility for completion in compliance to applicable codes and laws. Reinspection fees shall be charged as set forth in the permit fee schedule. If a deficiency or noncompliance is observed before the final inspection, the contractor shall, within 45 days from the date of written notice, provide compliance. Failure to complete compliance within the 45 days shall provide for automatic authorization for the village to repair or restore the damaged facilities. Village costs incurred during repair or restoration shall be deducted from the deposit monies; any costs over the amount of the deposit shall be billed to the contractor. 
(e)  The full deposit fee shall be maintained until final approval or issuance of an occupancy permit. 
(f)  Any building deposit which becomes subject to forfeiture under subsection (d) of this section shall be forfeited on December 31 of the year in which the deposit becomes subject to forfeiture, unless the depositor presents proof to the satisfaction of the village manager or designee on or before that date that the depositor has remedied the conditions and code violations which caused these deposits to be subject to forfeiture. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(5)(h)) 
Sec. 18-67. - Expiration and validity. 
(a)  Principal buildings. 
(1)  A building permit issued for a principal building shall be valid for a period of 24 months. 
(2)  A permit shall be invalid if: 
a.  Work is stopped at any time during the 24-month calendar period for a period of 60 or more calendar days. 
b.  Work is not started and continued within 120 calendar days from the date of issuance. 
(b)  Other construction. 
(1)  A permit for other than a principal building shall be valid for a period of 12 calendar months from the date of issuance. 
(2)  If work is not started and continued within 80 days from the date of issuance, or if work ceases for a period of 60 days after work is started, the permit shall be invalid. 
(c)  Extensions. 
(1)  A permit may be extended if the applicant applies for an extension prior to the date the permit expires or the date the permit becomes invalid under subsection (a)(2) of this section. 
(2)  Before extending any permit or recommencing any work on the expired or invalidated permit, the holder of the expired or invalidated permit shall pay one-half of the total original permit fees. Renewed permits shall experience like terms and conditions as the original permit. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(10)) 
Sec. 18-68. - Revocation. 
(a)  The village manager or designee may revoke any permit, certificate of occupancy or approval issued under the regulations of this chapter and may stop construction or use of approved new materials, equipment, methods of construction, devices, or appliances for any of these reasons: 
(1)  Whenever there is a violation of any regulation of this chapter or of any other ordinance, law, or lawful orders or state statute relating to the same subject matter. 
(2)  Whenever the continuance of any construction becomes dangerous to life or property. 
(3)  Whenever there is any violation of any condition or provision of the application for permit, or of the permit. 
(4)  Whenever in the opinion of the village manager or designee there is inadequate supervision provided on the job site. 
(5)  Whenever any false statement or misrepresentation has been made in the application for permit, plans, drawings, data specifications, or certified lot or plot plan on which the issuance of the permit or approval was based. 
(6)  Whenever there is a violation of any of the conditions of an approval or occupancy given by the village manager or designee for the use of any new materials, equipment, methods of construction, devices or appliances. 
(b)  The notice revoking a permit, certificate of occupancy or approval shall be in writing and may be served upon the applicant for the permit, owner of the premises, or his agent, if any, or on the person having charge of construction. 
(c)  A revocation placard shall also be posted upon the building, structure, equipment or premises in question by the village manager or designee. 
(d)  After the notice is served upon such persons described in subsection (c) of this section and posted, it shall be unlawful for any person to proceed thereafter with any construction operation whatsoever on the premises, and the permit which has been so revoked shall be null and void, and before any construction or operation is again resumed, a new permit, as required by this article, shall be procured and fees paid therefor, and thereafter the resumption of any construction or operation shall be in compliance with the regulation of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 14.05(8)) 
Secs. 18-69-18-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- One- and two-family dwelling code, Wis. Stats. § 101.60 et seq.; multifamily dwelling code, Wis. Stats. § 101.971 et seq. 

Sec. 18-91. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for safety, health and public welfare through structural strength and stability, means of egress, adequate light and ventilation and protection to life and property from fire and hazards incident to the design, construction, alteration, removal or demolition of buildings and structures. A violation of any applicable provision of the building code shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 14.01(1)) 
Sec. 18-92. - Scope of article. 
    This article shall apply to new buildings or structure and additions or alterations to existing buildings hereafter erected or undertaken in the village. 
(Code 1963, § 14.01(2)) 
Sec. 18-93. - Interpretation. 
    The provisions of this article shall supplement any laws and regulations of the state, and orders, rules and regulations of the department of commerce relating to buildings. 
(Code 1963, § 14.01(3); Ord. No. 222-O-03, § 1, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 18-94. - Legal responsibility. 
    The village shall not assume legal responsibility for the design, construction or modification of any building or structure. 
(Code 1963, § 14.01(4)) 
Sec. 18-95. - Vacating unlawful buildings. 
    Whenever any building or portion of a building is being used or occupied contrary to the provisions of this chapter, the village manager or designee shall order such use or occupancy discontinued and the building or portion of a building vacated by notice served on any person using or causing such use or occupancy to be continued, and such person shall vacate such building or portion thereof within ten days after receipt of such notice, or make the building or portion thereof comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 14.04(5)) 
Sec. 18-96. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject in addition to any other remedy provided in this article, to the penalties provided by section 1-7 of this Code. Each violation, and each day a violation continues or occurs, shall constitute a separate offense. The village manager or designee may, in addition to any other remedy provided in this article, issue citations or complaints to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 14.04(7)) 
Sec. 18-97. - Adoption of certain portions of Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
(a)  The following chapters of the Wisconsin Administrative Code, their referenced codes and standards, and subsequent revisions, are adopted for municipal enforcement by the building inspector, who shall be certified as a commercial building inspector by the State of Wisconsin Department of Safety and Professional Services. 
(1)  Ch. SPS 302.31, Plan Review Fee Schedule 
(2)  Ch. SPS 305, Credentials 
(3)  Ch. SPS 316, Electrical Code 
(4)  Chs. SPS 320-325, Uniform Dwelling Code 
(5)  Chs. SPS 361-366, Commercial Building Code 
(6)  Ch. SPS 375-379, Buildings constructed prior to October 9, 1914 
(7)  Chs. SPS 381-387, Uniform Plumbing Code 
(b)  A violation of any of the applicable provisions of the Wisconsin Administrative Code adopted and incorporated into subsection (a) of this section shall constitute a violation of this chapter. References in this chapter to the state building code shall be to the provisions of the Wisconsin Administrative Code hereby adopted by reference in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1963, § 14.02(1), (3); Ord. No. 202-O-02, § 1, 9-16-02; Ord. No. 222-O-03, § 2, 3-3-03; Ord. No. 671-O-16, § 1, 7-18-16) 
Sec. 18-98. - Survey required to verify footing and foundation information. 
    A recertification survey that verifies the location and elevation of footings and foundations shall be provided to the building inspector before pouring concrete. 
Sec. 18-99. - Foundation repair and damp proofing. 
(a)  No person shall repair any basement foundation, or damp proof any existing basement, without first obtaining a building permit from the Village of Menomonee Falls. 
(b)  The application for a permit shall include a statement describing the existing defects, and an analysis of the cause of the existing defects to ensure that all conditions responsible for foundation defects are corrected. 
(c)  Plans and/or specifications shall be submitted for approval before the issuance of a permit. The plans shall follow the "Best Management Standards for Foundation Repair" adopted by the Safety and Buildings Division of the Wisconsin Department of Commerce. 
(Ord. No. 148-O-01, § 1, 10-1-01; Ord. No. 439-O-09, § 1, 3-16-09; Ord. No. 583-O-14, § 1, 2-17-14) 
Sec. 18-100. - Scope of Uniform Dwelling Code expanded. 
    For the purposes of this section, the standards contained in the Wisconsin Uniform Dwelling Code shall be expanded to apply as the standards for construction of the following: 
(a)  Additions, alterations and major equipment replacements for one and two family dwellings built before June 1, 1980. 
(b)  Detached accessory buildings greater than 200 square feet serving one and two family dwellings. 
(1)  Frost protection for footings and foundations. 
a.  Grade-beam slabs are required for structures with a continuous floating slab of reinforced concrete. Slab shall not be less than four inches in thickness. Reinforcement shall be a minimum of six by six inch, number ten wire mesh or by using 1.5 pounds of fiber mesh per cubic yard of concrete with varying fiber mesh lengths. The slab shall be provided with a thickened edge all around, eight inches wide and eight inches below the top of the slab. The thickened edge shall have two #4 horizontal reinforcement bars placed at the center. The lower reinforcement bar shall be set two inches above the bottom of the thickened edge, and the upper reinforcement bar shall be set six inches above the bottom of the thickened edge. 
b.  Structures not constructed with a floating slab shall have footings and foundations placed below frost penetration level, but in no case less than 48 inches below grade per COMM 21. 
(c)  Detached accessory buildings less than 200 square feet in size, concrete slabs, frost-free footings, and the like are not required, but if they are installed, they shall follow (b) above and/or COMM 21. Wood bearing beams, walls or members in contact with the ground shall be pressure treated or decay resistant type wood per COMM 21.10. 
(Ord. No. 222-O-03, § 3, 3-3-03; Ord. No. 236-O-03, §§ 1, 2, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 301-O-05, § 1, 4-4-05) 
Sec. 18-101. - Certified municipality status. 
    The village hereby adopts by reference the certified municipality status as described in SPS 361.60 of the Wisconsin Administrative Code, and subsequent revisions. 
(a)  Responsibilities. The village shall assume the following responsibilities for the department of safety and professional services: 
(1)  Provide inspection of commercial buildings with certified commercial building inspectors. 
(2)  Provide plan examination of commercial buildings with certified commercial building inspectors. 
(b)  Plan examination. Drawings, specifications and calculations for all the types of buildings and structures, except state-owned buildings and structures, to be constructed within the limits of the village shall be submitted, if the plans are for any of the following: 
(1)  A new building or structure. 
(2)  An addition to a building or structure. 
(3)  An alteration of a building space, element, or structure. 
(c)  [Jurisdictional waiver.] The village may waive its jurisdiction for the plan review of a specific project or types of projects, or components thereof, in which case plans and specifications shall be submitted to the department for review and approval.
