(d)  Plan submission procedures. All commercial buildings, structures and alterations require plan submission as follows: 
(1)  Building permit application. 
(2)  Application for review-SBD-118. 
a.  Fees per Table 302.31-2 and SPS 302.31. 
b.  Fees apply to all commercial projects. 
(3)  Four sets of plans. 
a.  Signed and sealed per SPS 361.31. 
b.  One set of specifications. 
c.  Component and systems plans. 
d.  Calculations showing code compliance. 
(Ord. No. 222-O-03, § 4, 3-3-03; Ord. No. 671-O-16, § 2, 7-18-16) 
Secs. 18-102-18-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL CODE[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Electrical regulations, Wis. Stats. § 101.80 et seq.; municipal authority relative to electricity, Wis. Stats. § 101.86. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Electrical system means all wires, equipment or devices installed for the purpose of conducting or safeguarding electrical current. 
    Electrical work means any act in connection with the installing, altering or maintaining of an electrical system, which act ordinarily requires the use of tools. 
    N.E.C. means the National Electrical Code. 
    Qualified means qualified by the village. 
    Wiring means the wires and other devices incident to the means for safety conducting electrical current. 
(Code 1963, § 13.06) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-122. - Inspection and supervision. 
(a)  There is hereby created the position of electrical inspector, who shall be appointed by the village manager as part of the department of community development. The electrical inspector shall be under the direct supervision of the building inspector. 
(b)  The electrical inspector shall perform inspections and such other duties as may be prescribed. The electrical inspector shall enforce all provisions of this article and all state laws and ordinances relating to electrical inspection; and, where requirements of state law and local ordinance conflict, the stricter requirements shall govern. The electrical inspector shall prepare suitable forms for applications, permits and other reports. 
(c)  Instead of appointing an electrical inspector, the village may appoint a state certified inspection agency to perform electrical inspections. The inspector supplied by the agency shall be under the supervision of the director of community development. The term "electrical inspector" is used within this article to also include the inspector supplied by the agency. 
(d)  The electrical inspector or his authorized agent may, at all reasonable hours for any proper purpose, enter any public or private building or premises in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose of making any inspection or test of the electrical wires, equipment or devices contained therein. The inspector or his agent shall be given prompt access to any premises upon request made to the owner or persons in immediate charge of the premises. If consent to enter personal or real properties which are not public buildings, or to enter portions of public buildings which are not open to the public for inspection purposes, has been denied, the electrical inspector shall obtain a special warrant under Wis. Stats. §§ 66.0119(1), (2) and 66.0119(3). 
(Ord. No. 158-O-01, §§ 11, 12, 11-19-01) 
Sec. 18-123. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to safeguard life and property by regulating and providing for inspection of the installation and condition of electrical wiring, equipment and devices, and providing for the licensing of persons undertaking electrical work. 
(Code 1963, § 13.01) 
Sec. 18-124. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall be subject to the penalty provided in section 1-7 of this Code. Each violation and each day a violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. This section shall not preclude the village from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 13.20) 
Sec. 18-125. - Exceptions from license and permit requirements. 
(a)  Maintenance personnel employed in public or private buildings or one-family and two-family homeowners shall be permitted to make minor repairs. No license or permit shall be required for this minor work. 
(1)  Maintenance personnel employed in public or private buildings shall be bona fide employees and have complete authority and supervision over the electrical maintenance and repair work in the building or structural plant of their employer. A maintenance electrician shall maintain and keep in good state of repair or replacement all existing electrical equipment solely within their own buildings or structures. In no case shall such maintenance electrician be permitted to install or construct any additional electrical equipment. 
(2)  One-family and two-family homeowners shall be permitted to make minor repairs. These shall include the replacement of switches, receptacles and fixtures, but shall not include the extension of circuits or the adding, replacing or creating of new circuits. 
(b)  A property owner may do electrical work in a single-family residence owned and occupied by him as a permanent residence, provided that all work is done on the load side of the service panel and all requirements of the electrical permit process have been satisfied. 
(Code 1963, § 13.09(2)) 
Sec. 18-126. - Emergency work. 
    In emergency work, the person doing or causing such work to be done, shall report the work to the village manager or designee immediately after beginning work, and such work shall be done in accordance with the provisions of this article. The person doing or causing such work to be done shall obtain all necessary permits as soon as possible. 
(Code 1963, § 13.13) 
Sec. 18-127. - State standards for electrical work adopted. 
    The standards adopted by the state governing electrical installation, as now or hereafter amended, are hereby adopted by reference for all electrical work done within the village. 
(Code 1963, § 13.17) 
Sec. 18-128. - Village and officers not liable. 
    This article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility or liability of any person supplying electricity to or selling, renting, leasing, owning, using, operating, controlling, installing, altering, removing, replacing, disturbing, repairing, connecting, disconnecting or maintaining any electrical equipment for damages to person or property caused by any defect therein or therefrom; nor shall the village or its officers, agents or employees be held as assuming any such responsibility or liability by reason of the issuance or revocation of any license, permit or the inspection authorized by this article, or by reason of the approval or disapproval of any electrical equipment, sales, rentals, drawings, plans, specifications, materials, samples, test reports, literature, information or schedules authorized in this article. The village or its officers, agents or employees shall not be held liable for any damages resulting from the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 13.19) 
Secs. 18-129-18-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 18-141. - Appeals. 
    Appeals of any orders of the electrical inspector not otherwise appealable under the state electrical standards may be made under chapter 122 of this Code. This section, however, does not apply to any citations issued under this article which involve penalties provided under section 18-123, or to any judgment or order of the village municipal court. 
(Code 1963, § 13.18) 
Sec. 18-142. - Service of notices and orders. 
    All inspection notices and orders of the village manager or designee shall be considered final when served in writing upon the licensee. Service shall be by certified mail, return receipt requested. The effective date of notification shall be the date of mailing. 
(Code 1963, § 13.15) 
Sec. 18-143. - Authority to discontinue electrical operation. 
(a)  The village manager or designee may order the cutting off of all electrical current from any electrical system which is found to be in an unsafe condition, and may order the cutting off of electrical current in cases of emergency, and where such electrical currents are dangerous to life or property or may interfere with the work of the fire department. 
(b)  No person shall reconnect any equipment thus cut off until permission is given by the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 13.07) 
Secs. 18-144-18-160. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Permit 

Sec. 18-161. - Required. 
    No electrical equipment shall be installed, altered, renewed, replaced or connected without first procuring a permit therefor. Permits shall be issued to state certified license holders only. Application shall be made on forms furnished by the village manager or designee and shall prescribe the nature of the work as well as such other information as may be required by the village manager or designee. Permits shall not be transferable from the contractor to whom issued. 
(Code 1963, § 13.10(1)(a)) 
Sec. 18-162. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Any person manufacturing or repairing electrical apparatus and equipment and employing a qualified electrician holding a state certified license, shall not be required to have a permit for his testing equipment. 
(b)  Maintenance personnel employed in public or private buildings or one-family and two-family homeowners shall be permitted to make minor repairs. These shall include the replacement of switches, receptacles and fixtures, but shall not include the extension of circuits or the adding, replacing or creating of new circuits. No license or permit shall be required for this minor work. 
(c)  No permit shall be required for portable devices, such as grinders, drills, washing machines, vacuum cleaners, radios, electric refrigerators and similar devices not permanently wired, but intended to be connected to, the circuit by a flexible cord and plug. However, proper approved wiring is to be installed, together with approved receptacle and plug. 
(d)  Electrical installations for temporary structures or assemblies, such as carnivals, picnics, circuses, side shows or sport events, are not required to be permitted under this subdivision; provided, however, that the same shall be in accordance with all provisions of this article. Where overhead wiring for light or power, festoon lighting or receptacles is used, it shall be isolated by elevation or properly guarded and grounded. All exposed metal parts of devices shall be installed in approved enclosures. Where cables or cords are laid upon the ground, they shall be protected by approved means such as trenches, metal ducts or board runways. Devices of amusement, such as rides or games, shall conform to the provisions of this article. All equipment, on or in which the public is expected to be conveyed or otherwise acted upon, shall be effectively bonded and grounded by means of clamp or screw type connections which are approved for this purpose. All contiguous metal parts of each such device shall be bonded. All metal railings or fences which are within three feet of such devices, and with which the public can simultaneously come in contact, shall be bonded. All equipment shall be approved for the purpose and conditions of use. 
(Code 1963, § 13.10(2)) 
Sec. 18-163. - Change of contractors; release required. 
    Whenever there is a change of contractors on a job for which a permit has been issued, before any subsequent permits will be issued, the village manager or designee shall, upon call, inspect the work performed to date and, if satisfied that the work conforms to all applicable electrical codes, given a written release to the owner of the premises. It shall be the obligation of the owner to obtain this release from the village manager or designee. If this release is not obtained, any subsequent contractor performing electrical work on the job shall be responsible for all previous electrical installation. 
(Code 1963, § 13.10(1)(b)) 
Sec. 18-164. - Required submittals for buildings of three or more families. 
    For all commercial, industrial or residential buildings of three families or more, the contractor may be required to submit for approval, along with permit application, the following: 
(1)  Complete riser diagrams for services and feeders showing location, source and destination, conduit size and type, as well as conductor size, type and quantity. 
(2)  Short circuit current available at source and destination of each feeder with verifying calculations. 
(3)  Switch and panel size and rating. 
(Code 1963, § 13.10(1)(c)) 
Sec. 18-165. - Utility outlet location letter. 
    The utility outlet location letter will be considered as the initial available short circuit current. 
(Code 1963, § 13.10(1)(d)) 
Sec. 18-166. - Changes to electrical work. 
    Changes in approved electrical work must be submitted for approval prior to construction. 
(Code 1963, § 13.10(1)(e)) 
Sec. 18-167. - Temporary work. 
    On applying for a permit for temporary work, a specified period of time during which such wiring is to remain in service must be stated, until permanent service is available. Service shall be cut off at the end of this period and shall not again be connected without written permission from the village manager or designee. For buildings where conduit wiring is required, special permits for temporary work may be granted by the village manager or designee for the installation of open work and exposed wiring, lights, power for building operations, display, decorative lighting, etc., for use for a limited period, subject to discontinuance and complete removal at expiration, and to condemnation and revocation within such period. 
(Code 1963, § 13.12) 
Sec. 18-168. - Expiration. 
    Every permit under the provisions of this subdivision, shall expire by limitation, and become null and void, if the work authorized by such permit is not commenced for a period of six months and not completed within 12 months from the date of issuance. Before such work can be recommenced, a new permit must first be obtained, and the fee therefor shall be one-half the amount required for a first permit. 
(Code 1963, § 13.10(3)) 
Sec. 18-169. - Fees. 
    The fees to be paid to the village for permits required by this subdivision shall be as established in section 42-18(b)(2). 
(Code 1963, § 13.11) 
Secs. 18-170-18-185. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Inspections 

Sec. 18-186. - Generally. 
    The village manager or designee shall accept as existing any work which was previously installed under permit and which conformed to all codes and ordinances at the time of installation. Where violations are found, he shall notify the person owning, using, operating or installing them, to place items affected in compliance. The necessary repairs or changes shall be completed within 15 days after the receipt of such notice. The village manager or designee may order the discontinuance of electrical service to such defective electrical system until it shall have been repaired, removed or changed as directed by the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 13.08) 
Sec. 18-187. - Final inspection. 
(a)  Upon the completion of the wiring in or on any building, and before any wiring is to be hidden from view, the licensee doing the same shall notify the village manager or designee, who shall inspect the installation within 48 hours of the time such notification is received. If, upon inspection, it is found that the installation is in compliance with this article and does not constitute a hazard to life or property, he shall approve the same and authorize concealment of the wiring or connection for electrical service. If the installation is incomplete, or not strictly in accordance with this article, he shall issue orders to the person installing the same to remove all hazards and make necessary changes or additions. 
(b)  No person shall conceal any electric work before inspection or fail to comply with any order of the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 13.14) 
Sec. 18-188. - Construction requirements. 
    No inspection approval shall be issued unless the electric light, power or heating installation, and all other electrical apparatus connected with it, are in strict conformity with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 13.16) 
Secs. 18-189-18-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICIANS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Secs. 18-201-18-215. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - License[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Local licensing of electricians, Wis. Stats. § 101.87. 

Sec. 18-216. - Required. 
    No person shall install, alter, repair, remove, renew, replace, disturb, connect, disconnect or maintain electrical equipment or apparatus without first being licensed by the village. 
(Code 1963, § 13.09(1)) 
Sec. 18-217. - Classifications. 
    There shall be the following license classifications: Master electrician. 
(Code 1963, § 13.09(3)(a)) 
Sec. 18-218. - Fee. 
    The fee for any license required by the provisions of this article shall be as established in section 42-18(b)(1). 
(Code 1963, § 13.09(3)(a)) 
Sec. 18-219. - Transfer. 
    No license shall be assignable or transferable, and no license shall be used by persons other than to whom issued. 
(Code 1963, § 13.09(3)(b)) 
Sec. 18-220. - Expiration; proration. 
    All electrical licenses shall expire on June 30 next following the date of issuance. There shall be no prorating of any licenses. If a license is permitted to expire and not renewed for one year, the former holder shall be required to show proof of certification by the state as a master electrician. 
(Code 1963, § 13.09(4)) 
Secs. 18-221-18-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MOVING OF STRUCTURES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90. 

Sec. 18-241. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall move any structure upon any of the public rights-of-way of the village without first obtaining a permit therefor from the village manager or designee and upon the payment of the required fee. Every such permit issued shall designate the route to be taken, the conditions to be complied with, and shall limit the time during which such moving operations shall be continued. 
(b)  No permit shall be granted for the moving of any structure or portion of a structure which has deteriorated or been damaged to an extent greater than 50 percent of the assessed value of the structure. This determination shall be made by the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 14.06(1), (2)) 
Sec. 18-242. - Bond. 
(a)  Before a permit is issued to move any structure over any public way in this village, the party applying therefor shall give a bond to the village in a sum to be fixed by the village manager or designee and which shall not be less than $50,000.00. Such bond shall be executed by a corporate surety or two personal sureties to be approved by the governing body or designated agent conditioned upon, among other things, the indemnification to the village for any costs or expenses incurred by it in connection with any claims for damages to any persons or property, and the payment of any judgment together with the costs and expenses incurred by the village in connection therewith, arising out of the removal of the structure for which the permit is issued. 
(b)  Unless the village manager or designee, upon investigation, shall find it to be a fact that the excavation exposed by the removal of such structure from its foundation shall not be so close to a public thoroughfare as to permit the accidental falling therein of travelers or the location, nature and physical characteristics of the premises and the falling into such excavation of children under 12 years of age unlikely, the bond required by subsection (a) of this section shall be further conditioned upon the permittee erecting adequate barriers and within 48 hours, filling in such excavation or adopting and employing such other means, devices or methods approved by the village manager or designee and reasonably adopted or calculated to prevent the occurrences set forth in this subsection. 
(Code 1963, § 14.06(5)) 
Sec. 18-243. - Insurance. 
    The village manager or designee shall require, in addition to the bond indicated in section 18-242, public liability insurance covering injury to one person in the sum of not less than $500,000.00 and for one accident in a sum not less than $1,000,000.00, together with property damage insurance in a sum not less than $50,000.00, or such other coverage as deemed necessary. 
(Code 1963, § 14.06(6)) 
Sec. 18-244. - Continuous movement. 
    The movement of structures shall be a continuous operation during all the hours of the day, and day and at night, until such movement is fully completed. All of such operations shall be performed with the least possible obstruction to thoroughfares. No structure shall be allowed to remain overnight upon any street crossing or intersection, or so near thereto as to prevent easy access to any fire hydrant or any other public facility. Lighted lanterns shall be kept in conspicuous places at each end of the building during the night. 
(Code 1963, § 14.06(3)) 
Sec. 18-245. - Street repair. 
    Every person receiving a permit to move a structure shall, within one day after such structure reaches its destination, report that fact to the village manager or designee who shall thereupon in the company of the municipal highway commissioner, inspect the streets and highways over which such structure has been moved and ascertain their condition. If the removal of such structure had caused any damage to any street or highway, the person to whom the permit was issued shall forthwith place them in good repair as they were before the permit was granted. On the failure of the permittee to do so within ten days thereafter to the satisfaction of the governing body, such body shall repair the damage done to such streets and hold the person obtaining such permit and the sureties on his bond responsible for the payment of the same. 
(Code 1963, § 14.06(4)) 
Sec. 18-246. - Architectural control board approval. 
(a)  Before issuing a permit for moving a structure, the architectural control board shall review and approve the structure to be moved. The applicant for such permit may appeal a decision of the architectural board, or disapproving the issuance of the moving permit, to the village board of trustees, by filing written notice of appeal with the village manager within 15 days after the day of such decision. The determination of the village board shall be binding. 
(b)  No permit shall be granted for the moving of any structure from one location to another location on the same premises or from one premises to another premises unless the structure to be moved not to be so at variance with either the exterior architectural appeal and functional plan of existing structures in the immediate neighborhood or the character of the immediate neighborhood so as to cause a substantial depreciation in the property values of the neighborhood. This determination shall be made by the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 14.06(7)) 
Sec. 18-247. - Conformance of structure with chapter provisions. 
    No permit shall be issued to move a structure within or into the village and to establish it upon a location within the village until the village manager or designee has made an investigation of such structure at the location from which it is to be moved, and is satisfied from such investigation that such structure is in a sound and stable condition and of such construction that it will meet the requirements of this chapter in all respects. A complete plan of all further repairs, improvements and remodeling with reference to such structure shall be submitted to the village manager or designee, and he shall make a finding of fact to the effect that all such repairs improvements and remodeling are in conformity with the requirements of this chapter, and that when the repairs are completed, the structure, as such, will so comply with this chapter. If a structure is to be moved from the village to some point outside the boundaries of the village, the provisions with respect to the furnishing of plans and specifications for proposed alterations to such structure, may be disregarded. 
(Code 1963, § 14.06(8)) 
Secs. 18-248-18-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PLUMBING CODE[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Plumbing, Wis. Stats. ch. 145. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-271. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Plumbing means: 
(1)  As is stated in Wis. Stats. § 145.01(10). 
(2)  The construction, connection to or alteration of any drain, soil or waste pipe to carry domestic sewage, stormwater or industrial waste from a point three feet outside of the foundation walls of any building to the sewer lateral at the curb or other disposal terminal including the private sewage disposal or treatment plant. This definition does not include minor repairs to faucets and the removal of stoppages in soil or waste pipes. 
(Code 1963, § 15.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-272. - Inspection and supervision. 
(a)  There is hereby created the position of plumbing inspector who shall be appointed by the village manager as part of the department of community development. The plumbing inspector shall perform such duties as are provided for in Wis. Stats. § 145.05(1) and Wis. Admin. Code § Comm 82.21. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall be under the direct supervision of the building inspector and shall enforce all of the provisions of this article. The plumbing inspector shall prepare suitable forms for applications, permits and other reports. 
(c)  In lieu of appointing a plumbing inspector, the village may contract with a state certified inspection agency to perform plumbing inspections per Wis. Admin. Code § Comm 82.21(3). The inspector supplied by the agency shall under the direct supervision of the superintendent of development. The term "plumbing inspector" is used within this article to also include the inspector supplied by the agency. 
(Code 1963, § 15.03) 
Sec. 18-273. - State code adopted. 
    The provisions and regulations of Wis. Stats. ch. 145 and Wis. Admin. Code chs. Comm 82-Comm 87 are hereby made a part of this article by reference, and shall extend over and govern the installation of all plumbing installed, altered or repaired in the village. 
(Code 1963, § 15.01) 
State Law reference- State plumbing code, Wis. Stats. § 145.13. 
Sec. 18-274. - Plumber's license required. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person shall engage in the installation of plumbing or plumbing connections, or do or perform any such work within the village, until such person shall have first obtained the license prescribed by Wis. Stats. ch. 145 by law, and until all the provisions of this article have been fully complied with. 
(b)  A property owner may do plumbing work in a single-family residence owned and occupied by him as a permanent residence provided that all requirements of the plumbing permit process have been satisfied. 
(Code 1963, § 15.04(1)) 
State Law reference- Licensing of plumbers, Wis. Stats. § 145.06 et seq. 
Sec. 18-275. - Permit required; fees. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person shall do plumbing work or install plumbing within the village without a permit therefor issued by the village manager or designee. Application for a permit shall be made on a form provided by the village manager or designee. Such application shall list all plumbing to be installed, which shall be installed only by the holder of the permit or his employees. 
(b)  A property owner may do plumbing work in a single-family residence owned and occupied by him as a permanent residence provided that all requirements of the plumbing permit process have been satisfied. 
(c)  The fees to be paid to the village for plumbing permits shall be as established in section 42-18(c)(1). 
(d)  Every permit under the provisions of this subdivision, shall expire by limitation, and become null and void, if the work authorized by such permit is not commenced for a period of six months and not completed within 12 months from the date of issuance. Before such work can be recommenced, a new permit must first be obtained, and the fee therefor shall be one-half the amount required for a first permit. 
(Code 1963, §§ 15.06, 15.07; Ord. No. 137-O-01, § 1, 6-4-01) 
Sec. 18-276. - Water lines. 
    This article shall apply to water supply lines of less than two inches diameter. Water supply lines with a diameter of two inches or greater shall conform to the requirements of the water utility. 
Sec. 18-277. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-278. - Expiration. 
    Every permit under the provisions of this subdivision, shall expire by limitation, and become null and void, if the work authorized by such permit is not commenced for a period of six months and not completed within 12 months from the date of issuance. Before such work can be recommenced, a new permit must first be obtained, and the fee therefore shall be one-half the amount required for a first permit. 
(Ord. No. 452-O-09, § 2, 7-6-09) 
Secs. 18-279-18-290. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 18-291. - Grounding of electrical plumbing fixtures. 
    All plumbing fixtures provided with flexible electrical cords shall be installed within six feet of a grounding type receptacle outlet to supply current needed by the fixture. All such flexible cords and caps shall be of the three-wire grounding type. 
(Code 1963, § 15.10(21)) 
Sec. 18-292. - Water softeners and water softener systems. 
(a)  Water softeners . Ion exchange water softeners used primarily for hardness reduction, that during regeneration discharge a brine solution, shall be of a demand-initiated regeneration type equipped with a water meter or a sensor unless a wastewater treatment system downstream of the water softener specifically documents the reduction of chlorides. This requirement applies for both newly installed and replacement softeners for residences, commercial and industrial businesses. 
(b)  Water softener systems . When installing new water softener systems, the "soft water" line of the water distribution piping shall not be connected to any hose bib or lawn sprinkler irrigation systems. When at the time of a replacement of a water softener, any soft water distribution piping connected to a hose bib or lawn sprinkler irrigation system, it is encouraged to be removed from the softened piping but not required. 
(Ord. No. 630-O-15, § 1, 10-19-15) 
Secs. 18-293-18-305. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Water 

Sec. 18-306. - Water supply systems. 
(a)  Scope. This section applies to water supply systems. 
(b)  Meters. Water meters and sprinkling meters shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the water utility. 
(c)  Sizing for water softeners. Plumbing shall be sized to include a water softener, even if a water softener is not installed. 
(Ord. No. 452-O-09, § 3, 7-6-09) 
Sec. 18-307. - Materials. 
(a)  The material for all one and one-quarter inch minimum diameter to two-inch diameter water services from the municipal watermain to the building shall be polyethylene. 
(b)  The water service shall be continuous (non-jointed) pipe. 
(c)  All rulings pertaining to other materials shall be as per state code and review of the village manager or designee. 
(d)  Non metallic water lines installed after December 31, 2006 shall have a wire installed adjacent to the water line. 
(1)  The locating wire shall be 12 gauge insulated copper wire and shall be secured to the water line every six feet and at all bends. 
(2)  There must be access to the wire at both ends and at least every 300 feet. 
(3)  At the access points, the wire must be brought to grade in two-inch PVC pipe with a clean out fitting on top. At the curb stop, the wire may be coiled around the pipe just under the curb stop flange. The access point at the building must be on the out side of the foundation. 
(4)  Splices must be made with split bolts or compression type connectors and taped for protection. 
(5)  Continuity of the wire must be checked after backfilling. 
(6)  If water and sewer lines are installed in the same trench, only one locating tracer wire is required. 
(Code 1963, § 15.10(9); Ord. No. 157-O-01, § 6, 11-5-01; Ord. No. 374-O-07, § 1, 5-21-07) 
Sec. 18-308. - Bypass valve and stops. 
    A bypass valve and stops on the inlet and outlet shall be installed on all water softeners and filters. 
(Code 1963, § 15.10(18)) 
Secs. 18-309-18-325. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Sewers 

Sec. 18-326. - Sanitary facilities. 
    Every building intended for human habitation or occupancy or premises abutting on a street in which there is a public sewer shall have a connection with the sewer. Any building abutting on a street in which there is a public sewer and which is used exclusively for dwelling purposes shall have available to its occupants a water closet, wash basin and bathtub, all in clean working order and shall be provided with a water supply piping adequate in size to properly cleanse or flush all fixtures. 
(Code 1963, § 15.10(17)) 
Sec. 18-327. - Building sewers and drains. 
(a)  The roof must be completed before a building sewer is started. 
(b)  All building sewers and drains shall be installed per Wis. Admin. Code chs. Comm 82-87. 
(c)  Non-metallic sewer and storm sewer lines installed after December 31, 2006 shall have a wire installed adjacent to the water line. 
(1)  The locating wire shall be 12 gauge insulated copper wire and shall be secured to the water line every six feet and at all bends. 
(2)  There must be access to the wire at both ends and at least every 300 feet. 
(3)  At the access points, the wire must be brought to grade in two-inch PVC pipe with a clean out fitting on top. At the curb stop, the wire may be coiled around the pipe just under the curb stop flange. The access point at the building must be on the out side of the foundation. 
(4)  Splices must be made with split bolts or compression type connectors and taped for protection. 
(5)  Continuity of the wire must be checked after backfilling. 
(6)  If water and sewer lines are installed in the same trench, only one locating tracer wire is required. 
(Code 1963, § 15.10(1); Ord. No. 374-O-07, § 2, 5-21-07) 
Sec. 18-328. - Industrial waste. 
    All persons who own property from which industrial wastes are discharged into the sewer system shall construct and maintain sampling manholes as required by law. 
Sec. 18-329. - Rain and surface water connections. 
(a)  No person shall connect any building or premises with any public sanitary sewer by a drain or connection by which rain, surface or subsurface waters may be discharged into the public sanitary sewer systems and any existing drain or connection by which such waters may be discharged into a public sanitary sewer shall be disconnected, mechanically severed or altered within six months after official written notification from the village of a violation of this section. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector and designates, upon identification, may enter any building or premises supplied with public water service or public sewer facilities for the purpose of inspecting and testing all plumbing, together with all forms of clear water drainage, to ascertain quantity, quality and condition of sanitary and clear water sewer facilities. 
(c)  All buildings with basements shall have a foundation drain. All building foundation drains shall terminate in a sump pit. 
(d)  All sump pumps installed for the purpose of discharging clear waters from foundation drains and ground infiltration, and where the building is not serviced by a storm sewer shall either discharge into a conduit leading to a drainage ditch or shall discharge onto the ground at least three feet out from the building and one foot above the permanent grade. The sump discharge pipe shall be to the front of the building except where a public drainage ditch, street or drainage easement is on another side of the property, it may be located on that side of the building at least three feet from the corner of the building and be located in such a manner that the drainage shall be across the owner's property toward a street or drainage easement so as not to run on adjacent properties, or to create a nuisance. 
(e)  Garage floor drainage may be connected to a public sanitary sewer installed in compliance with the Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
(f)  State code. All other rulings pertaining to clear water connections shall be as governed by Wis. Admin. Code ch. Comm 82.36. 
(Code 1963, § 15.10(8)) 
Sec. 18-330. - Repairs and construction. 
    All other rulings pertaining to repairs and construction shall be as per state code. 
(Code 1963, § 15.10(11)) 
Sec. 18-331. - Private sewage disposal systems. 
(a)  Compliance with state standards. All private sewage disposal systems shall be installed per Wis. Admin. Code ch. Comm 83. 
(b)  Holding tanks. Where the owner of real estate is permitted to install a sewage holding tank under the provisions of Wis. Admin. Code § Comm 83.18, the owner shall deposit and maintain a cash bond with the village in the amount established in section 42-18(c)(2) to reimburse the village for any expenses incurred by it if the owner fails to maintain the holding tank in a healthful, sanitary and safe condition. Such cash bond shall be deposited in an escrow account maintained by the village. Any income derived therefrom shall be deposited in the village general funds in payment of the expense of maintaining and handling such escrow. Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the village from recovering any expense it may incur with respect to the maintenance and operation of such tank by any other course of action available to it. 
(c)  Connection to municipal sanitary sewer. 
(1)  Compulsory connection to municipal sewers. Except as set forth elsewhere in this section, private systems for sewage disposal must be disconnected from the private system and be connected with the municipal sewer within six months of the date municipal sewers become available to the property. The septic tank is to be removed, or pumped out, a hole provided in the bottom of the tank to provide adequate drainage, and filled with dirt, gravel or sand. When calculating the six-month period for compulsory connection, the months of December, January, February and March shall not be included in the computation. This compulsory connection to municipal sewers may be deferred for such period of time as the village board of trustees may direct from time to time, but only in the instances provided in subsections (c)(1)a or (c)(1)b of this section, and the village board is of the opinion that other facilities for the disposal of sewage are adequate to protect the public health and safety: 
a.  When a municipal sewer has been installed to serve the property and the payment of the assessment therefor deferred pursuant to the provisions of section 86-12(e) of this Code; or 
b.  When, because of the distance of elevation, it is not feasible to serve the property by such municipal sewer. 
(2)  Standby charges. Sewer rates and charges are hereby imposed and shall be collected from the owner of each improved property required to be connected with the municipal sewer system. A standby charge shall be assessed against any such property not connected for each improved property to the sewer system. Such charges shall be determined by the village and shall be payable quarterly. 
(3)  Failure to comply; payment arrangement. If any person fails to comply with this subsection (c) for more than ten days after notice in writing to do so, the village may cause connection to be made to the sewer system, and the expense of such connection shall be assessed as a special tax. The owner of a property may, within 30 days after the completion of the work, file a written opinion with the village clerk-treasurer stating that he cannot pay the amount in one sum, and asking that it be levied in not to exceed five equal annual installments, and the amount shall be so collected with interest at a rate of 15 percent per year from the date of completion of the work. The unpaid balance shall be a special tax lien. 
(Code 1963, §§ 15.11, 15.15(2)(b)) 
Secs. 18-332-18-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RESERVED[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 2, adopted October 1, 2018, repealed §§ 18-351-18-356, 18-371-18-380, which pertained to property maintenance code. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Secs. 18-351-18-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SWIMMING POOLS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 18-401-18-415. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRIVATE RESIDENTIAL SWIMMING POOLS AND WADING POOLS 

Sec. 18-416. - Pool defined. 
    In this division, the term "pool" means a private residential swimming pool or a private residential wading pool. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-417. - Permit required. 
    No person shall commence installation of a pool without first obtaining a permit therefor from the village manager or designee. The application for permit shall include: 
(1)  Two copies of a survey or accurate drawing of the property, showing all existing structures, location of proposed pool, decking and fencing, if required, and overhead or underground electrical wiring; 
(2)  Two copies of pool construction data, depth and appurtenances thereto; 
(3)  Payment of the prescribed fee. 
(Code 1963, § 14.11(1)) 
Sec. 18-418. - Location. 
    The location of all pools shall conform to the requirements of the zoning ordinance of the village dealing with accessory structures, and to the requirements of the county health department. 
(Code 1963, § 14.11(2)) 
Sec. 18-419. - Fences. 
(a)  Pools not enclosed within a permanent building shall be completely enclosed by a fence of sufficient strength to prevent access to the pool. The fence shall be not less than 31/2 feet in height, so constructed as not to have voids, holes or openings larger than four inches in any dimension, except for gates or doors which shall be equipped with a self-closing and self-latching device for keeping the gate securely closed at all times when not in actual use. Latches shall be located at least three feet above the ground, accessible deck or stairs. 
(b)  A fence shall not be required around an aboveground pool where the pool wall is at least 31/2 feet above grade for the full pool perimeter. The finished grade shall be maintained for a minimum of four feet beyond the outside perimeter of the pool. 
(c)  Permanent access from grade to aboveground pools having stationary ladders, stairs or ramps shall have not less than equal safeguard fencing and gates as are provided the pool proper. 
(d)  Location of fencing required in this section shall be subject to all other applicable ordinances. In any case: 
(1)  No fence shall be located, erected, constructed or maintained closer to a pool than four feet. 
(2)  The wall of the house or building faced to a pool may be incorporated as a portion of such fence. 
(3)  A temporary fence not less than four feet in height (snow fence, etc.), adequately supported, can be used while a pool is under construction. A permanent fence must be constructed within 30 days after water is in the pool. 
(e)  Every pool shall have an unobstructed areaway directly adjacent to the entire perimeter of not less than four feet. 
(Code 1963, § 14.11(3)) 
Sec. 18-420. - Temporary swimming pools. 
    Storable swimming or wading pools which are constructed so that they may be readily disassembled for storage and reassembled to its original integrity are exempt from the provisions of sections 18-417, 18-418 and 18-419 as long as they meet all of the following criteria. 
(1)  The pool is located in the rear or side yard and meets the appropriate zoning offset. 
(2)  The pool is 20 feet or less in diameter. 
(3)  The pool is removed by October 1, and installed after May 1, of each year. 
(Code 1963, § 14.11(5); Ord. No. 373-O-07, § 1, 5-21-07) 
Sec. 18-421. - Drainage. 
    Every pool shall be provided with a suitable drainage system. In no case shall any such pool be drained into the village sanitary sewer system or onto lands of other property owners in the vicinity or onto or across lands which contain a private sewage system. 
(Code 1963, § 14.11(6); Ord. No. 264-O-04, § 1, 4-5-04; Ord. No. 373-O-07, § 2, 5-21-07) 
Sec. 18-422. - Public water supply. 
    No person shall divert water from any public unmetered water supply line for the purpose of filling a pool. 
(Code 1963, § 14.11(7); Ord. No. 373-O-07, § 3, 5-21-07) 
Sec. 18-423. - Gaseous chlorination systems. 
    Gaseous chlorination systems shall not be used as a disinfection method for pool waters. 
(Ord. No. 373-O-07, § 4, 5-21-07) 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcohol beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; kennels prohibited in certain areas, § 14-29; electricians, § 18-201 et seq.; emergency services, ch. 34; fees, ch. 42; fair housing, § 50-21 et seq.; peddlers, solicitors and transient merchants, ch. 70; secondhand goods, ch. 74; taxation, ch. 98; telecommunications, ch. 102; utilities, ch. 110; vehicles for hire, ch. 118; business districts, § 122-286 et seq.; industrial districts, § 122-306 et seq.; sign regulations for commercial and industrial districts, § 122-763. 
State Law reference- General authority to regulate and license, Wis. Stats. § 61.34(1). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. This section shall not preclude the village from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 9.40) 
Sec. 22-2. - Denial of licenses and permits. 
    No license or permit shall be issued if the license or permit applicant is delinquent in the payment of taxes, fines or other outstanding debts to the village. This section shall not apply to marriage, dog, hunting or fishing licenses. 
(Code 1963, § 9.50) 
Sec. 22-3. - Revocation, suspension and nonrenewal of licenses and permits. 
(a)  In addition to the grounds stated elsewhere in this chapter, it shall be grounds for revocation, suspension or nonrenewal of a business license or business permit issued under this chapter or chapter 6 of this Code if the license holder or permit holder is delinquent in the payment of taxes, forfeitures or other outstanding obligations to the village; or if the application for such license or permit contains any misrepresentations regarding the financial status of the applicant or holder of such permit or license as to taxes, forfeitures or other obligations owed to the village. 
(b)  Notice of hearing on revocation, suspension or nonrenewal of licenses and permits shall be given by the village. Notice shall be personally served on the licensee or person in charge of the licensed premises not less than five, nor more than ten, days prior to the scheduled hearing. The notice shall contain the grounds for the revocation, suspension or nonrenewal; and the time, place and purpose of the hearing. 
(c)  The hearing shall be before the village board. Witnesses shall be placed under oath. Counsel may be present. Cross examination of witnesses shall be permitted. The decision of the board shall be final. 
(d)  Upon a finding of a violation of subsection (a) of this section or that an amount is delinquent, the village board shall suspend the license or permit in question for such time until the taxes, forfeitures or other outstanding obligations are paid in full to the village, but not to exceed 90 days. If after 90 days the debt has not been satisfied, the license shall be automatically revoked. 
(e)  This section shall not apply to marriage, dog, hunting or fishing licenses. 
(f)  The village shall not enforce revocation, suspension, nonrenewal or denial if an appeal of the imposition of a forfeiture is pending. 
(g)  No refund of fees shall be made of fees paid by a licensee subject to suspension or revocation. 
(Code 1963, § 9.45) 
Sec. 22-4. - Transfer. 
(a)  Licenses issued under this chapter shall not be transferable from one person to another, nor from one premises to another. 
(b)  As used in the previous subsection, the phrase "transferable from one person to another includes any of the following: 
(1)  The sale, lease, or sublease of the business; 
(2)  The transfer of securities which constitute a controlling interest in the business, whether by sale, exchange or other means; or 
(3)  The establishment of a trust, gift, or other similar legal device which transfers the ownership or control of the business, except for transfer by bequest or other operation of the law upon the death of the person possessing the ownership or control. 
(Ord. No. 560-O-13, § 4, 7-15-13) 
Secs. 22-5-22-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADULT-ORIENTED ESTABLISHMENTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning regulations for adult oriented establishments, § 122-649. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult bookstore means an establishment having as its stock-in-trade for sale, rent, lease, inspection or viewing books, films, video cassettes, magazines or other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matters depicting, describing or relating to specific sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this section and, in conjunction therewith, have facilities for the presentation of adult entertainment as defined in this section, including adult-oriented films, movies or live performances for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult cabaret means a cabaret which features topless dancers, strippers, male or female impersonators or similar entertainers. 
    Adult entertainment means any exhibition of any motion picture, live performance, display or dance of any type, which has as its dominant theme or is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on any actual or simulated specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult minimotion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of less than 50 persons used for presenting material having as its dominant theme or distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matters depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons used for presenting material having as its dominant theme or distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matters depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult-oriented establishment means any premises including, but not limited to, adult bookstores, adult motion picture theaters, adult minimotion picture establishments or adult cabarets, to which public patrons or members are invited or admitted and which are so physically arranged so as to provide booths, cubicles, rooms, compartments or stalls separate from the common area of the premises for the purposes of viewing adult-oriented motion pictures or wherein an entertainer provides adult entertainment to a member of the public, a patron or member of the public, a patron or a member, whether or not such adult entertainment is held, conducted, operated or maintained for a profit, direct or indirect. 
    Operators means any person, partnership or corporation operating, conducting, maintaining or owning any adult-oriented establishment. 
    Specified anatomical areas means: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region, buttocks and female breasts below the point immediately above the top of the areola. 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernible turgid state, even if opaquely covered. 
    Specified sexual activities means simulated or actual: 
(1)  Showing of human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal. 
(2)  Acts of masturbation, sexual intercourse, sodomy, bestiality, necrophilia, sadomasochistic abuse, fellatio or cunnilingus. 
(3)  Fondling or erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breasts. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(1)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-22. - Responsibilities of the operator. 
(a)  Every act or omission by an employee constituting a violation of the provisions of this article shall be deemed the act or omission of the operator if such act or omission occurs either with the authorization, knowledge or approval of the operator or as a result of the operator's negligent failure to supervise the employee's conduct. The operator shall be punishable for such act or omission in the same manner as if the operator committed the act or caused the omission. 
(b)  Any act or omission of any employee constituting a violation of the provisions of this article shall be deemed the act or omission of the operator for purposes of determining whether the operator's license shall be revoked, suspended or renewed. 
(c)  No employee of an adult-oriented establishment shall allow any minor to loiter around or to frequent an adult-oriented establishment or to allow any minor to view adult entertainment. 
(d)  The operator shall maintain the premises in a clean and sanitary manner at all times. 
(e)  The operator shall maintain at least ten footcandles of light in the public portions of the establishment, including aisles, at all times. However, if a lesser level of illumination in the aisles shall be necessary to enable a patron to view the adult entertainment in a booth, room or cubicle adjoining an aisle, a lesser amount of illumination may be maintained in such aisles; provided, however, that at no time shall there be less than one footcandle of illumination in such aisles, as measured from the floor. 
(f)  The operator shall ensure compliance of the establishment and its patrons with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(10)) 
Sec. 22-23. - Establishment requirements. 
    Any adult-oriented establishment having available for customers, patrons or members any booth, room or cubicle for the private viewing of any adult entertainment must comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Access. Each booth, room or cubicle shall be totally accessible to and from aisles and public areas of the adult-oriented establishment and shall be unobstructed by any door, lock or other control-type devices. 
(2)  Construction. Every booth, room or cubicle shall meet the following construction requirements: 
a.  Each booth, room or cubicle shall be separated from adjacent booths, rooms or cubicles and any nonpublic areas by a wall. 
b.  Have at least one side totally open to a public lighted aisle so that there is an unobstructed view at all times of anyone occupying the same. 
c.  All walls shall be solid and without openings, extended from the floor to a height of not less than six feet and be light colored, nonabsorbent, smooth textured and easily cleanable. 
d.  The floor must be light colored, nonabsorbent, smooth textured and easily cleanable. 
e.  The lighting level of each booth, room or cubicle when not in use shall be a minimum of ten footcandles at all times, as measured from the floor. 
(3)  Occupants. Only one individual shall occupy a booth, room or cubicle at any time. No occupant of the same shall engage in any type of sexual activity, cause any bodily discharge or litter while in the booth. No individual shall damage or deface any portion of the booth. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(9)) 
Sec. 22-24. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    The sale, use, or consumption of any alcoholic beverages, fermented malt beverages, or intoxicating liquors on the premises of an adult-oriented establishment is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 651-O-16, 3-7-16) 
Secs. 22-25-22-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-41. - Required; one per establishment. 
(a)  No adult-oriented establishment shall be operated or maintained in the village without first obtaining a license to operate issued by the village. 
(b)  A license may be issued only for one adult-oriented establishment located at a fixed and certain place. Any person who desires to operate more than one adult-oriented establishment must have a license for each. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(2)(a), (2)(b)) 
Sec. 22-42. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring to secure a license shall make application to the village clerk-treasurer. The application shall be filed in triplicate and dated by the village clerk-treasurer. A copy of the application shall be distributed promptly by the village clerk-treasurer to the village police department and to the applicant. 
(b)  The application for a license shall be upon a form provided by the village clerk-treasurer. An applicant for a license shall furnish the following information under oath: 
(1)  Name and address. 
(2)  Written proof that the individual is at least 21 years of age. 
(3)  The address of the adult-oriented establishment to be operated by the applicant. 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation, the application shall specify the name of the corporation, date and state of incorporation, name and address of the registered agents and name and address of all shareholders owning more than five percent of the stock in such corporation and all officers and directors of the corporation. 
(5)  Whether the applicant or any person identified pursuant to subsection (b)(4) of this article has been convicted of violating this article or a similar ordinance or statute within five years immediately preceding the date of the application; together with the circumstances surrounding any such convictions. 
(c)  Within 30 days of receiving an application for a license, the village clerk-treasurer shall notify the applicant whether the application is granted or denied. 
(d)  Whenever an application is denied, the village clerk-treasurer shall advise the applicant in writing of the reasons for such action. If the applicant requests a hearing within ten days of receipt of notification of denial, a public hearing shall be held as provided in this article within ten days thereafter before the village board or a designated committee as provided in this article. 
(e)  Failure or refusal of the applicant to give any information relevant to the application or his refusal or failure to appear at any reasonable time and place for examination under oath regarding such application, or his refusal to submit to or cooperate with regard to any information required by this article shall constitute an admission by the applicant that he is ineligible for such license and shall be grounds for denial by the village clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(3)) 
Sec. 22-43. - Standards for issuance. 
    To receive a license to operate an adult-oriented establishment, an applicant must meet the following standards: 
(1)  If the applicant is an individual: 
a.  The applicant must be at least 21 years of age. 
b.  The applicant shall not have been found to have previously violated this article or of a similar statute or ordinance within five years immediately preceding the date of the application. 
(2)  If the applicant is a corporation: 
a.  All officers, directors and stockholders required to be named under section 22-42(b) shall be at least 21 years of age. 
b.  No officer, director or stockholder required to be named under section 22-42(b) shall have been found to have previously violated this article or of a similar statute or ordinance within five years immediately preceding the date of the application. 
(3)  If the applicant is a partnership, joint venture or any other type of organization where two or more persons have a financial interest: 
a.  All persons having a financial interest in the partnership, joint venture or other type or organization shall be at least 21 years of age. 
b.  No person having a financial interest in the partnership, joint venture or other type of organization shall have been found to have violated any provision of this article or of a similar statute or ordinance within five years immediately preceding the date of the application. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(4)) 
Sec. 22-44. - Fees. 
    A license fee as provided in section 42-22(a) shall be submitted with the application for a license. If the application is denied, one-half of the fee shall be returned. The license fee shall not be prorated if the license is issued for a period of less then one year. 
(Code 1963, § 9.2(5)) 
Sec. 22-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 560-O-13, § 2, adopted July 15, 2013, repealed § 22-45 in its entirety, which pertained to transfer and derived from the Code of 1963, § 9.20(2)(c). 
Sec. 22-46. - Expiration; renewal. 
(a)  Every license issued pursuant to this article will expire on the June 30 following the date of issuance, unless sooner revoked; and must be renewed before operation is allowed thereafter. 
(b)  Any operator desiring to renew a license shall make application to the village clerk-treasurer. The application for renewal must be filed not later than 60 days before the license expires. The application for renewal shall be upon a form provided by the village clerk-treasurer and shall contain such information and data given under oath or affirmation as is required for an application for a new license. 
(c)  A license renewal fee as provided in section 42-22(a)(2) shall be submitted with the application for renewal. In addition to the renewal fee, a late penalty of $100.00 shall be assessed against any applicant who files for a renewal less than 60 days before the license expires. If the application is denied, one-half of the total fees collected shall be returned. 
(d)  If the village police department is aware of any information bearing on the operator's qualifications, that information shall be filed in writing with the village clerk-treasurer. 
(e)  The village manager or designee shall inspect the establishment prior to the renewal of a license to determine compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(7)) 
Sec. 22-47. - Display. 
    The license shall be displayed in a conspicuous public place in the adult-oriented establishment. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(6)) 
Sec. 22-48. - Revocation. 
(a)  The village board shall revoke a license or permit for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Discovery that false or misleading information or data was given on any application or material facts were omitted from any application. 
(2)  The operator or any employee of the operator violates any provision of this article or any rules or regulations adopted by the village board pursuant to this article; provided, however, that in the case of a first offense by an operator where the conduct was solely that of an employee, the penalty shall not exceed a suspension of 30 days if the village board shall find that the operator had no actual or constructive knowledge of such violation and could not by the exercise of due diligence have had such actual or constructive knowledge. 
(3)  The operator becomes ineligible to obtain a license or permit. 
(4)  Any cost or fee required to be paid by this article is not paid. 
(5)  Any intoxicating liquor or cereal malt beverage is served or consumed on the premises of the adult-oriented establishment. 
(b)  The village board, before revoking or suspending any license or permit, shall give the operator at least ten days' written notice of the charges against him and the opportunity for a public hearing before the village board or its designated committee as provided in this article. 
(c)  The transfer of a license or any interest in a license shall automatically and immediately revoke the license. 
(d)  Any operator whose license is revoked shall not be eligible to receive a license for one year from the date of revocation. No location or premises for which a license has been issued shall be used as an adult-oriented establishment for six months from the date of revocation of the license. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(8)) 
Sec. 22-49. - Administrative review procedure. 
    The village ordinances and state law shall govern the administrative procedure and review regarding the granting, denial, renewal, nonrenewal, revocation or suspension of a license. 
(Code 1963, § 9.20(11)) 
Secs. 22-50-22-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CIGARETTE AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS RETAILERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-71. - Penalty for violation of article. 
(a)  Forfeiture. Any person violating this article shall forfeit not more than $100.00, nor less than $25.00, for the first offense and not more than $200.00, nor less than $25.00, for the second or subsequent offense. 
(b)  Termination of license. Conviction shall immediately terminate the license of the person convicted of being personally guilty of such failure to exercise due care and the person shall not be entitled to another license under this article for a period of five years thereafter, nor shall the person in that period act as the servant or agent of a person licensed under this article for the performance of the acts authorized by such license. 
(Ord. No. 51-O-99, § 1(9.01(7)), 4-19-1999) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 134.66(5). 
Sec. 22-72. - Records. 
    Every licensed retailer shall keep complete and accurate records of all purchases and receipts of cigarettes and tobacco products. Such records shall be preserved on the licensed premises for two years in such a manner as to ensure permanency and accessibility for inspection and shall be subject to inspection at all reasonable hours by authorized state and local law enforcement officials. 
(Ord. No. 51-O-99, § 1(9.01(6)), 4-19-1999) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 134.65(4). 
Secs. 22-73-22-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Licensing of retail tobacco dealers, Wis. Stats. § 134.65. 

Sec. 22-86. - Required. 
    No person shall, in any manner, or upon any pretense, or by any device, directly or indirectly, sell, expose for sale, possess with intent to sell, exchange, barter, dispose of or give away any cigarettes or tobacco products without first obtaining a license from the village clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 51-O-99, § 1(9.01(1)), 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 22-87. - Fee. 
    The fee for the licenses issued under this article shall be as determined in section 42-22(b). 
(Ord. No. 51-O-99, § 1(9.01(2)), 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 22-88. - Period of validity. 
    Upon the filing of a proper written application and the payment of the fee set out in section 22-87, a license shall be issued on July 1 of each year or when applied for and continue in force until the following June 30, unless sooner revoked. 
(Ord. No. 51-O-99, § 1(9.01(3)), 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 22-89. - Licensee and premises to be described. 
    Each license issued under this article shall name the licensee and specifically describe the premises where such business is to be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 51-O-99, § 1(9.01(4)), 4-19-1999) 
Secs. 22-90-22-200. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 560-O-13, § 3, adopted July 15, 2013, repealed § 22-90 in its entirety, which pertained to transfer and derived from Ord. No. 51-O-99, § 9.01(5), adopted April 19, 1999. 
ARTICLE IV. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 22-201. - Sale of motorized scooters. 
(a)  Definition. In this section, "motorized scooter" means a vehicle which is designed and built to be stood or sat upon by the operator and that has two small-diameter wheels in tandem, upright t-shaped handlebars, and is powered by an internal combustion engine or electric motor that is capable of propelling the device with or without human propulsion. For the purposes of this section, an electric personal assistive mobility device, a moped, a motor bicycle or a motorcycle, as defined under § 340.01, Wis. Stats., is not a motorized scooter. 
(b)  Posting of notices to buyers required. Every retail commercial establishment selling motorized scooters shall have posted on the premises in a prominent and conspicuous manner at or near the display of such item a placard stating as follows: 
"IMPORTANT NOTICE TO POTENTIAL MOTORIZED SCOOTER BUYERS: 
The operation of motorized scooters upon public roadways, bicycle ways and sidewalks is against the law. Motorized scooters may only be operated with permission on private property, and on private roads and driveways." 
(c)  Signed statement required. Every retail commercial establishment selling motorized scooters shall obtain from every person buying a motorized scooter a signed statement on forms provided by the village clerk stating that the buyer is aware that motorized scooters cannot be operated within the village on public roadways, bicycle ways and sidewalks, as set forth in chs. 341 and 346, Wis. Stats., as amended. The seller must retain the statement for a period of not less than one year from the date of sale. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person convicted of violating any provision of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-7 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 310-O-05, § 1, 6-20-05) 
Secs. 22-202-22-249. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - REGULATION OF NEWSPAPER DISTRIBUTION BOXES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 335-O-06, § 1, adopted April 3, 2006, provided for the addition of art. III, §§ 22-150-22-161. Inasmuch as art. III was previously codified as cigarette and tobacco product retailers regulations, the provisions of Ord. No. 335-O-06 have been redesignated as art. V, §§ 22-250-22-261 to read as herein set out. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-250. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote the public health, safety and welfare through the regulation of placement, appearance, servicing and insuring of newspaper distribution boxes on public rights-of-way to: 
(1)  Reduce the exposure of the village to personal injury or property damage claims and litigation; 
(2)  Provide for pedestrian and driving safety and convenience; 
(3)  Provide reasonable access for the use and maintenance of sidewalks, poles, posts, traffic signs and signals, benches, hydrants, mailboxes and access to locations used by pedestrians and for public transportation purposes; 
(4)  Protect and improve the aesthetics and value of properties within the village; 
(5)  Treat all newspapers equally without regard to their size, content, circulation or frequency of publication; 
(6)  Maintain and preserve freedom of the press. 
(Ord. No. 225-O-06, § 1, 4-3-06) 
Sec. 22-251. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Block," means both sides of any street in a public right-of-way which exists between two consecutive intersecting streets and is intended to include, but not limited to, the roadways, streets, parkways, alleys and sidewalks within that right-of-way. 
    "Newspaper distribution box" shall mean any self-service or coin-operated device used for the vending or free distribution of newspapers, news periodicals or written materials, including circulars, pamphlets, papers, booklets and any other printed or otherwise reproduced written material which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing which attracts attention to business, commercial establishment or other activity for the purpose of directly promoting the interest thereof by sales, private gain or profit. 
    "Public right-of-way" means all of the area dedicated to public use existing between property lines adjacent thereto and is intended to include, but not limited to, roadways, streets, parkways, alleys and sidewalks. 
(Ord. No. 225-O-06, § 1, 4-3-06) 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 22-252. - Applications. 
(a)  Permit required. No newspaper distribution box shall be maintained within any public highway or upon any village property, except by permit issued by the department of public works. 
(b)  The application for a permit shall be made at the office of director of public works. A written application for such permit shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant who is the owner and/or principal responsible or in charge of the newspaper distribution box. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of a responsible person whom the village may notify or contact at any time concerning the applicant's newspaper distribution box. 
(3)  The number of newspaper distribution boxes and names of newspapers or periodicals to be contained in each, including any existing newspaper distribution boxes. 
(4)  Site plan showing exact location of each newspaper distribution box and supporting or enclosing structure, including installation and maintenance, and sufficient information to determine that said location complies with the provisions of this section. 
(5)  A certificate of insurance showing general liability insurance, including property damage, in the amount of $1,000,000.00 per occurrence and naming the village as an additional insured. 
(6)  An agreement that the applicant will hold harmless, defend, and indemnify the village from and against all liability, damages, and penalties resulting from the installation, use, maintenance, or presence of the applicants newspaper distribution box(es). 
(7)  The applicant shall submit an application fee set out in subsection 42-22(c)(1). 
(c)  A finding made by the director of public works whether an applicant is in compliance with the provisions of this section will be made within five working days of the village's receipt of the completed application. 
(Ord. No. 225-O-06, § 1, 4-3-06) 
Sec. 22-253. - Appeals. 
    Any person or entity aggrieved by a finding, determination, notice, order or action taken under the provisions of this section may appeal to the village board within 30 days of being served with such finding, determination, notice, order or notice of action taken. 
(Ord. No. 225-O-06, § 1, 4-3-06) 
Sec. 22-254. - Fees. 
(a)  If such application is approved by the department of public works, the permit shall be issued upon payment of fees by the applicant in the amount set out in subsection 42-22(c)(2). Additional locations may be added to such permit during the permit year, upon approval of the department of public works and payment of the required additional fees. 
(b)  All such permits shall commence on December 1 and shall expire on November 30; all renewal fees shall be paid by November 30. 
(c)  The fee specified herein has been determined to be the minimum processing fee for the issuance of such permits and necessary inspections. 
(Ord. No. 225-O-06, § 1, 4-3-06) 
Sec. 22-255. - Bond. 
    No permit shall be issued until the applicant files a bond in the amount of $10,000.00 running to the village and to such parties as may be injured because of installation or maintenance of such newspaper distribution boxes within the public right-of-way or upon Village property. There shall be one bond per applicant. 
(Ord. No. 225-O-06, § 1, 4-3-06) 
Sec. 22-256. - Conditions of permit. 
(a)  All such permits shall be granted only upon the condition that by acceptance of such permit the applicant: 
(1)  Shall become primarily liable for damages to person or property by reason of the granting of the privilege; 
(2)  Shall be obligated to remove any such newspaper distribution box within ten- days' notice by the State of Wisconsin or by the village; 
(3)  Shall waive its right to contest in any manner the validity of § 66.0425 of the Wisconsin Statutes, or of this section. 
(b)  It shall be a further condition of any such permit that the village shall not be responsible for any damage to such box or boxes because of snow plowing or removal operations or any other municipal maintenance function. 
(c)  The holder of any such permit shall be entitled to no damages for the removal of any such newspaper distribution box and, if such holder shall not remove the same upon due notice, it shall be removed by the village at the holder's expense. 
(d)  Third parties whose rights are interfered with by the granting of such permit shall have a right of action against the holder of the permit only. 
(e)  Written notice by the village to the person designated in subsection 22-152(b)(2) above shall constitute proper notice. 
(Ord. No. 225-O-06, § 1, 4-3-06) 
Sec. 22-257. - Placement generally. 
(a)  In any one block, there shall be no more than 24 newspaper distribution boxes of which no more than four newspaper distribution boxes dispense any one publication. There shall be no more than 12 newspaper distribution boxes of which no more than two newspaper distribution boxes dispense any one publication on one side of any street between two intersecting streets. 
(b)  Newspaper distribution boxes between intersecting streets may be placed together in groups consisting of one to eight newspaper distribution boxes. Each group shall be separated by a distance not less than 100 feet. Each newspaper distribution box within a group shall be separated no more than two feet from each other. 
(c)  Newspaper distribution boxes shall be placed parallel to and not less than 12 inches nor more than 24 inches from the face of the curb. Newspaper distribution boxes placed near the wall of a building must be placed parallel to and not more than six inches from, the wall. 
(Ord. No. 225-O-06, § 1, 4-3-06) 
Sec. 22-258. - Prohibitions. 
    No newspaper distribution box shall be located: 
(1)  Within ten feet of any marked crosswalk or the curb return of any unmarked crosswalk;
