If the discharge of prohibited materials emanates from a commercial or industrial establishment, the owner or operator of such establishment shall also retain an on-site written record of the discharge and the actions taken to prevent its recurrence. Such records shall be retained for at least three years. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-313. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Notice of violation. Whenever the village manager or the manager's designee finds that a person has violated a prohibition or failed to meet a requirement of this article, the authorized enforcement agency may order compliance by written notice of violation to the responsible person. Such notice may require without limitation: 
(1)  The performance of monitoring, analyses, and reporting; 
(2)  The elimination of illicit connections or discharges; 
(3)  That violating discharges, practices, or operations shall cease and desist; 
(4)  The abatement or remediation of stormwater pollution or contamination hazards and the restoration of any affected property; 
(5)  Payment of a fine to cover administrative and remediation costs; and 
(6)  The implementation of source control or treatment BMPs. 
(b)  If abatement of a violation and/or restoration of affected property is required, the notice shall set forth a deadline within which such remediation or restoration must be completed. Said notice shall further advise that, should the violator fail to remediate or restore within the established deadline, the work will be done by a designated governmental agency or a contractor and the expense thereof shall be charged to the violator. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-314. - Appeal of notice of violation. 
(a)  Any person receiving a notice of violation may appeal the determination of the authorized enforcement agency. The notice of appeal shall be in writing, and shall be filed with the village manager. The notice of appeal must be received by the village manager within five days from the date of the notice of violation. The notice of appeal shall state the ground or grounds upon which the person appealing contends the decision shall be modified or reversed. 
(b)  Hearing before the utilities and public works committee of the village board. 
(1)  The utilities and public works committee of the village board shall hold a hearing on the appeal within 30 days from the date of receipt of the notice of appeal. The decision of the committee shall be final. 
(2)  The utilities and public works committee shall follow the procedures for public hearings set out in Wis. Stats. § 68.11 and final determinations under Wis. Stats. § 68.12. The committee may adopt rules to implement these procedures. 
(c)  The decision of the committee may be appealed to the circuit court of Waukesha County by writ of certiorari. Such appeal must be commenced with 30 days of the date of the decision of the committee. The common law rules of certiorari shall apply to such appeals. 
(d)  The procedure set out under this section is intended to be the sole procedure for appeals under this article. The village elects not to be governed by Wis. Stats. ch. 68 of the for appeals of decisions under this article. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-315. - Enforcement measures after appeal. 
    If the violation has not been corrected pursuant to the requirements set forth in the notice of violation, or, in the event of an appeal, within ten days of the decision of the municipal authority upholding the decision of the authorized enforcement agency, then representatives of the authorized enforcement agency shall enter upon the subject private property and are authorized to take any and all measures necessary to abate the violation and/or restore the property. It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, agent or person in possession of any premises to refuse to allow the government agency or designated contractor to enter upon the premises for the purposes set forth above. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-316. - Cost of abatement of the violation. 
    Within 15 days after abatement of the violation, the owner of the property will be notified of the cost of abatement, including administrative costs. If the amount due is not paid within 60 days after receipt of the final bill, the charges shall become a special charge against the property pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.027, and shall constitute a lien on the property for the amount of the charge. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the village by reason of such violation. Interest may be assessed on the balance beginning on the 31st day following notice to the property owner of the cost of the abatement. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-317. - Injunctive relief. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this article. If a person has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this article, the authorized enforcement agency may petition for a preliminary or permanent injunction restraining the person from activities which would create further violations or compelling the person to perform abatement or remediation of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-318. - Compensatory action. 
    In lieu of enforcement proceedings, penalties, and remedies authorized by this article, the authorized enforcement agency may impose upon a violator one or more alternative compensatory actions, such as storm drain stenciling, attendance at compliance workshops, creek cleanup, or some other action determined by the authorized enforcement agency. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-319. - Violations deemed a public nuisance. 
    In addition to the enforcement processes and penalties provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this article is a threat to public health, safety, and welfare, and is declared and deemed a nuisance, and may be summarily abated or restored at the violator's expense, and/or a civil action to abate, enjoin, or otherwise compel the cessation of such nuisance may be taken. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-321. - Administrative expenses. 
    The authorized enforcement agency may recover all attorneys' fees, court costs and other expenses associated with enforcement of this article, including sampling and monitoring expenses. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-322. - Violators subject to forfeiture. 
    In addition to the enforcement processes and penalties provided elsewhere in this article, any person who violates this article shall be subject to a forfeiture of not less than $50.00 or more than $10,000.00 per offense, together with the costs of prosecution. Each day each violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 38-323. - Remedies not exclusive. 
    The remedies listed in this article are not exclusive of any other remedies available under any applicable federal, state or local law and it is within the discretion of the authorized enforcement agency to seek cumulative remedies. 
(Ord. No. 432-O-09, § 1, 2-2-09) 
Chapter 42 - FEES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-161 et seq.; businesses, ch. 22; taxation, ch. 98. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - General provisions (Reserved). 
Sec. 42-2. - Administration. 
(a)  Industrial revenue bond application fees and costs. 
(1)  Application for initial resolution. The fee to be paid at the time application is made for approval of a preliminary resolution by the village board or the community development authority shall be $500.00. 
(2)  Application for final resolution. The fee to be paid at the time application is made for approval of the final resolution by the village board or the community development authority shall be $500.00. 
(Code 1963, § 27.50(1)) 
Secs. 42-3-42-5. - Reserved. 
Sec. 42-6. - Alcohol beverages. 
    Fees for licenses and permits under chapter 6 of this Code. 
    Unless otherwise indicated, fees for licenses issued under chapter 6 of this Code shall be as follows: 
(1)  Class A fermented malt beverage retailer's license: 
a.  Full annual fee: $100.00. 
b.  Part-time: prorated from the month in which the applicant applied to the succeeding June 30. 
State Law reference- Authority to determine license fee for class A fermented malt beverage license, Wis. Stats. § 125.25(4). 
(2)  Class B fermented malt beverage retailer's license: 
a.  Full annual fee: $100.00. 
b.  Part-time: prorated from the month in which the applicant applied to the succeeding June 30. 
c.  Temporary class B retailer's license: $10.00 per day. 
State Law reference- Authority to determine license fee and limitations on fee for class B fermented malt beverage license, Wis. Stats. § 125.26(4), (6). 
(3)  Wholesaler's fermented malt beverage license: $25.00. 
State Law reference- Authority to determine wholesaler's fermented malt beverage license fee and limitations thereon, Wis. Stats. § 125.28(4). 
(4)  Retail class A intoxicating liquor license. 
a.  Full annual fee: $500.00. 
b.  Part-time: prorated from the month in which the applicant applied to the succeeding June 30. 
State Law reference- Authority to determine retail class A intoxicating license fee and limitations thereon, Wis. Stats. § 125.51(2)(d). 
(5)  Retail class B intoxicating license: 
a.  Regular class B retailer's license: 
1.  Full annual fee: $500.00. 
2.  Part-time: prorated from the month in which the applicant applied to the succeeding June 30. 
b.  Temporary class B retailer's license: $10.00 per day. However, this fee is not charged if the applicant is applying for both a temporary class B fermented malt beverage license and a temporary class B wine license for the same event. 
State Law reference- Authority to determine retail class B intoxicating license fee and limitations thereon, Wis. Stats. § 125.51(3)(e), (10). 
(6)  Class C intoxicating liquor license: $100.00. 
State Law reference- Authority to determine class C intoxicating license fee and limitations thereon, Wis. Stats. § 125.51(3m)(e). 
(7)  Operator's license: $50.00. 
State Law reference- Authority to determine operator's license fee, Wis. Stats. § 125.17(4). 
(8)  Provisional operator's license: $15.00. 
State Law reference- Authority to determine provisional operator's license fee and limitations thereon, Wis. Stats. § 125.17(5)(e). 
(9)  Provisional retail license: $15.00. 
State Law reference- Authority to determine provisional retail license fee and limitations thereon, Wis. Stats. § 125.185(3). 
(10)  Unenclosed premise permit: $50.00. 
(11)  Fees for Reserve Class B licenses: 
a.  The fee for a reserve Class B liquor license shall be $10,000.00 for initial issuance except that the fee for the initial issuance of a reserve Class B license to a bona fide club or lodge situated and incorporated in the state for at least six years is $500.00. The fee established in this subdivision is in addition to any other fee required under this chapter. The annual fee for renewal of a reserve Class B license is $500.00. 
b.  Reserved. 
(Code 1963, § 27.28; Ord. No. 125-O-00, § 1, 12-18-00; Ord. No. 153-O-01, § 2, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 528-O-12, § 3(a)-(f), 2-20-12; Ord. No. 672-O-16, § 1, 7-18-16; Ord. No. 729-O-18, § 1, 10-1-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 153-O-01, § 2, adopted Oct. 15, 2001, provided for the inclusion of a new subsection 42-6(11). Subsection (11) was previously codified as provided by Ord. No. 125-O-00, § 1, adopted Dec. 18, 2000; hence, inclusion of the provisions of Ord. No. 153-O-01, § 2, have been redesignated as subsection (12) at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 42-7-42-9. - Reserved. 
Sec. 42-10. - Amusements and entertainments. 
    Amusement and entertainment license and permit fees are as follows: 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  Theater licenses. The fee for an annual license for a theater issued under article III, chapter 10 of this Code shall be $250.00. The full fee shall be charged for the year in which it is issued, or for any portion thereof. 
(3)  Amusement devices and arcades. 
a.  Amusement arcade license. The annual fee for an amusement arcade license shall be $200.00, plus $25.00 per machine or device. 
b.  Amusement device permit. The annual fee for an amusement device permit shall be $25.00 per machine or device. 
(4)  Reserved. 
(Code 1963, § 27.09(1), (2), (7), (12); Ord. No. 140-O-01, § 1, 6-18-01; Ord. No. 455-O-09, § 2, 8-17-09; Ord. No. 698, §§ 10, 11, 10-16-17) 
Secs. 42-11-42-13. - Reserved. 
Sec. 42-14. - Animals. 
(a)  Dog license fees. The fees for all dog licenses issued under section 14-26 shall be as follows: 
(1)  Neutered and spayed dogs ..... $10.00 
(2)  Unneutered and unspayed dogs ..... 15.00 
(3)  The late for a dog license shall be ..... 5.00 
State Law reference- Dog license tax, Wis. Stats. § 174.05. 
(b)  Impoundment fees and costs. The possession of any dog seized or impounded under section 14-2 of this Code may be obtained by the owner upon payment of all the following amounts as may be applicable: 
(1)  If the dog has been transported to a location within the village, the sum of $7.50, plus the current daily fee for keeping such dog for each day or fraction thereof during which such dog has been impounded. 
(2)  If the dog has been transported to an impoundment facility outside the village, the sum of $15.00, plus the following amounts as may be applicable: 
a.  The current daily fees or charges which are incurred by the village or which the village is required to collect pursuant to any agreement with the impoundment facility for keeping such dog for each day or fraction thereof during which such dog has been impounded. 
b.  Any additional costs or fees of the impoundment facility which are not payable by the village as provided in subsection (b)(2)a of this section, but which are incurred by the impoundment facility for keeping such dog for each day or fraction thereof during which such dog has been impounded. 
(3)  In the case of any unlicensed dog, the owner shall also obtain a license under section 14-26 of this Code and shall pay the license fee required under subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1963, §§ 27.09(8), 27.10; Ord. No. 250-O-03, § 1, 11-17-03)

Sec. 42-22. - Businesses. 
(a)  Adult-oriented establishments. The fees for licenses issued under article II, chapter 22 of this Code shall be as follows: 
(1)  License fee: $600.00. 
(2)  License renewal fee: $600.00. 
(3)  Late renewal additional charge: $100.00. 
(b)  Cigarette and tobacco products retailer: The fee for licenses issued under division 2 of article III of chapter 22 of this Code shall be $100.00. 
(c)  Newspaper distribution boxes. 
(1)  The application fee under subsection 22-152(b)(7) shall be $15.00 per box up to a maximum of $300.00. 
(2)  The permit fee under subsection 22-154(a) shall be $30.00 per box per year for a new installation, and $25.00 per box per year for a renewal. 
(Code 1963, §§ 9.20(7)(c), 27.09(15); Ord. No. 51-O-99, § 1(27.09(16)), 4-19-99; Ord. No. 225-O-06, § 2, 4-3-06)

Sec. 42-34. - Emergency services. 
Alarm fees. 
(a)  False alarms. The fees for false alarms occurring during any calendar year for permits issued under article III of chapter 34 of this Code that result in the response of fire department personnel and equipment shall be as follows: 
0-3 No charge 4-5 $100.00/per false alarm 6-9 $200.00/per false alarm 10 or more $300.00/per false alarm.  
(b)  Other alarms. For any false alarm resulting in the response of police department personnel, the following fees shall apply to the false alarms occurring during any calendar year: 
0-3 No charge 4-5 $75.00 per false alarm 6-9 $150.00 per false alarm 10 or more $200.00 per false alarm  
(c)  Alarm permits. The fees for alarm permits issued under article III, chapter 34 of this Code shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential alarm permits: $10.00. 
(2)  Commercial alarm permits: $20.00. 
(3)  Alarm monitoring service fee: $15.00 per month. 
(4)  A $5.00 late fee shall be charged for any alarm permit payment that is delinquent 30 days after initial invoicing. 
(Code 1963, § 27.09(10), (13); Ord. No. 105-O-00, § 1, 9-18-00; Ord. No. 213-O-02, § 88, 12-16-02)

(d)  Post-construction stormwater management permit fees. 
(1)  Permit fees for private developments where there is no development agreement. 
a. Project area is less than one acre $200.00 b. Project area is one to five acres 400.00 c. Project area is five to 15 acres 600.00 d. Project area is over 15 acres 650.00  
(2)  Permit fees for developments where there is a development agreement. Applicant shall pay fees necessary to defray the total direct and indirect costs incurred by any and all village department staff and other representatives or professionals employed or otherwise retained by the village to process, review, inspect, record, or take any other administrative or enforcement action pertaining to or resulting from the disposition of such permit application. These fees shall be paid as follows: 
a.  Filing fee of $200.00. This fee shall be applied against the permit fees required under this subsection. 
b.  The remaining fees shall be paid in accordance with the development agreement between the applicant and the village. 
(Code 1963, §§ 11.08(2), 27.08(1), 27.15(3), 27.31; Ord. No. 99-O-00, § 1, 8-3-00; Ord. No. 133-O-01, § 3, 5-21-01; Ord. No. 344-O-06, § 2, 8-7-06; Ord. No. 400-O-08, § 2, 4-21-08; Ord. No. 431-O-09, § 2, 2-2-09; Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 5, 10-1-18) 
Secs. 42-39-42-45. - Reserved. 
Sec. 42-46. - Fire prevention and protection. 
    Fire inspection fees. The following fees will be charged for the following inspections: 
(1)  Hood and duct extinguishing systems under section 46-57. 
a.  Acceptance testing ..... $75.00 
b.  Retest ..... 75.00 
c.  Double fees. Upon failure to obtain a permit before work has started, the total fees shall be double the regular fees charged. 
(2)  Fire sprinkler systems under section 18-97. 
a.  Acceptance testing: 
1-10 heads ..... $50.00 
11 heads and up (each) ..... 0.25 
b.  Hose valves (each) ..... 50.00 
c.  Retest same as acceptance testing fee. 
d.  Double fees. Upon failure to obtain a permit before work has started, the total fees shall be double the regular fees charged. 
(3)  Fire alarm system under section 18-97. 
a.  Acceptance testing: 
1-10 total initiating and notification devices ..... $50.00 
11 and up total initiating and notifications devices (each) ..... 2.00 
b.  Retest same as acceptance testing fee. 
c.  Double fees. Upon failure to obtain a permit before work has started, the total fees shall be double the regular fees charged. 
(4)  Dry chemical extinguishing systems under section 18-97: 
a.  Acceptance testing ..... $100.00 
b.  Retest ..... 100.00 
c.  Double fees. Upon failure to obtain a permit before work has started, the total fees shall be double the regular fees charged. 
(5)  Private hydrants under section 18-97: 
a.  Acceptance testing ..... $50.00 
(Ord. No. 216-O-03, § 1, 1-20-03; Ord. No. 244-O-03, § 1, 8-18-03; Ord. No. 296-O-05, § 1, 2-21-05; Ord. No. 500-O-10, § 1, 12-20-10; Ord. No. 613-O-15, § 1, 1-5-15; Ord. No. 639-O-15, §§ 3-5, 12-7-15)

Sec. 42-66. - Parks and recreation. 
(a)  In general. The permit fee required under section 66-52(b) for all permits authorized under section 66-51 except permits authorized under subsection 66-51(k) shall be as follows: 
(1)  For activities or events involving less then 150 persons, the fee shall be $75.00 per park area reserved per day. 
(2)  For activities or events involving 150 persons or greater, the fee shall be $250.00 per park area reserved per day. 
(b)  Athletic field permits. The permit fee required under section 66-52(b) for permits authorized under subsection 66-51(k) shall be as follows: 
(1)  To reserve a soccer field, baseball diamond or other ball field for four hours or less per day, the fee shall be $75.00 per day for each soccer field, baseball diamond or other ball field. 
(2)  To reserve a soccer field, baseball diamond or other ball field for greater than four hours per day, the fee shall be $150.00 per day for each soccer field, baseball diamond or other ball field. 
(3)  Tournaments that are conducted as part of the village's baseball, softball or soccer programs are exempt from the athletic field fees required under this subsection. 
(Code 1963, § 27.19; Ord. No. 216-O-03, § 2, 1-20-03; Ord. No. 390-O-07, § 1, 11-19-07) 
Secs. 42-67-42-69. - Reserved.

(b)  Food peddlers. The fee for a food peddler's permit issued under section 70-82 of this Code shall be $50.00 per year or for any fraction of a year.

Sec. 42-78. - Signs. 
(a)  Permit fees. The permit fee required under section 78-3(c)(1)(f) of this Code shall be: 
(1)  The fee for non-electrified permanent and temporary signs shall be $100.00. 
(2)  The fee for electrified permanent and temporary signs shall be $100.00 
(3)  The fee for special event signs for non-profits shall be $25.00. 
(4)  In case a permit is not obtained before work is started, the total fee for such permit shall be double the usual fee charged. The granting of a permit after work is started shall not relieve the licensee or permittee from any liability from any of the penalties provided for violation or this chapter. 
(b)  Sign exception fees. The fee for a sign exception under section 78-11 shall be $100.00. 
(c)  Appeals fees. 
(1)  The fee for an appeal of village manager or designee as provided under section 78-11(a) shall be $150.00. 
(2)  The fee for an appeal of the architectural control board as provided under section 78-11(b) shall be $150.00. 
(Code 1963, §§ 16.08, 27.16(1); Ord. No. 125-O-00, § 8, 12-18-00; Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 3, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 200-O-02, § 1, 9-16-02; Ord. No. 207-O-02, §§ 45, 46, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 213-O-02, §§ 89, 90, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 254-O-03, § 4, 12-15-03)

Sec. 42-90. - Streets, sidewalks and other public places. 
(a)  Driveway permit fee. The permit fee required under section 90-27(c)(5) of this Code shall be $20.00.

(Code 1963, § 27.07(1), (2); Ord. No. 40-O-99, § 3, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 41-O-99, § 1, 4-5-99; Ord. No. 54-O-99, § 5, 5-17-99; Ord. No. 617-O-15, § 1, 3-2-15; Ord. No. 624-O-15, § 2, 6-15-15) 
Secs. 42-91-42-93. - Reserved. 
Sec. 42-94. - Subdivisions and other divisions of land; fees in lieu of dedication. 
(a)  Subdivision review fees. The fees for review of a subdivision plat shall be: 
(1)  The fee for scheduling a preliminary consultation shall be $100.00. 
(2)  The fee for reviewing a preliminary plat shall be $1,000.00 
(3)  The fee for reviewing a final plat shall be $500.00. 
(b)  Extraterritorial review fee. The fee for review of a subdivision within the extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction of Menomonee Falls shall be $1,000.00. 
(c)  Certified survey map review fees. The fees for review of a certified survey map shall be: 
(1)  The fee for reviewing a preliminary certified survey map shall be $250.00. 
(2)  The fee for reviewing a final certified survey map shall be $100.00. 
(d)  Fees in lieu of dedication. 
(1)  Where a dedication under section 94-100 is not feasible or compatible with the comprehensive plan, the subdivider shall, in lieu thereof, pay to the village a fee equivalent to the value of the required dedication. 
(2)  The fee shall be $1,000.00 per lot created by the subdivision to be placed in a non-lapsing fund to be used for environmental and/or conservancy land protection. 
(3)  The fees payable under this section shall be used exclusively for immediate or future site acquisition or capital improvements. 
(4)  Where a land division results in the creation of an additional lot or parcel, payment shall only be required for the additional lot(s) or parcel(s). 
(5)  Where a lot or parcel for which payment has once been made is further divided, payment shall be required only for the additional lots or parcels created. 
(6)  The required payment shall be made before the certification of approval is affixed to the final plat or certified survey map. 
(7)  No payment shall be required for a parcel on which a permanent principal structure has existed for at least one year before the date of division. 
(8)  No payment shall be required for a lot or parcel if any other governmental agency obtains the environmental or opens space land associated with that lot or parcel. 
(e)  Recording fee. The fee to record a certified survey map shall be $10.00 per page. 
(Code 1963, § 27.18; Ord. No. 155-O-01, § 3, 11-5-01; Ord. No. 213-O-02, § 91, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 11, 5-17-04; Ord. No. 357-O-06, §§ 7-11, 12, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 479-O-10, §§ 12-14, 5-17-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 479-O-10, §§ 12-14, adopted May 17, 2010, changed the title of section 42-94 from "Subdivisions and other divisions of land" to "Subdivisions and other divisions of land; fees in lieu of dedication."

(Code 1963, §§ 23.05(2), 27.23) 
Secs. 42-103-42-105. - Reserved. 
Sec. 42-106. - Traffic and vehicles. 
    All night parking permit fee. The fees for the special permits referred to in section 106-152(b) of this Code for all night parking shall be determined and collected as follows: 
(1)  Permits for one month or less. If the permit granted is for a period of one month or less, the fee shall be $20.00, provided that if any permit is granted after the 15th day of the month, the permit fee shall be $8.00 for the remainder of that month. 
(2)  Permits for more than one month. 
a.  The fee for a parking permit granted for the entire year shall be $200.00. 
b.  If the permit granted is for a period of less than one year, but is granted for the remainder of the year, the fee shall be $18.00 per month, unless subsection (a)(2)c. of this section applies. 
c.  If the permit granted is after October 15 and is for the remainder of the year, the fee shall be $20.00 per month. 
(Code 1963, §§ 6.10(3)(b), 27.03; Ord. No. 326-O-05, § 1, 11-21-05; Ord. No. 501-O-11, §§ 1, 2, 1-17-11; Ord. No. 698, § 12, 10-16-17)

    The fee for a permit issued under section 114-22(b) of this Code for planting or transplanting a public tree shall be $1.00 for each tree planted or transplanted. The fee for any other permit issued under this section shall be $1.00 for each tree affected. 
(Code 1963, § 27.07(3))

Sec. 42-122. - Zoning. 
(a)  Zoning permit. The fee for zoning permits under section 122-38 shall be: 
(1)  Fifty dollars for residential zoning permits, 
(2)  One hundred dollars for nonresidential zoning permits. 
(b)  Occupancy permit. The fee for an occupancy permit issued under section 122-39 shall be determined under section 42-18(a)(1)q. 
(c)  PRD project fees. 
(1)  Fee to accompany petition, $150.00 per acre. 
(2)  Zoning fee, $50.00 per dwelling unit. 
(d)  OVC review base fee. The base fee for reviews conducted under subdivision II of division 2, article II of chapter 122 of this Code shall be as follows: 
(1)  OVC design review base fee. 
a.  The base fee for a design review under section 122-428 of an application involving only signage shall be: 
1.  The fee for permanent and temporary signs shall be $100.00. 
2.  The fee for a secondary sign shall be $25.00 per sign. 
3.  The fee for a window sign shall be $25.00 per sign when the window coverage exceeds 30 percent of the window area. 
4.  In case a permit is not obtained before work is started, the total fee for such permit, if granted, shall be double the usual fee charged. 
5.  Sign exception fees. The fee for a sign exception under section 78-11 shall be $100.00. 
6.  The fee for a master sign program shall be $25.00 per property. Amendments to a master sign program shall be $25.00. 
7.  The fee for appeal of the village manager or designee or architectural control board shall be as determined under section 42-78(c) of the municipal code. 
b.  The base fee for a design review under section 122-428 of an application not involving only signage shall be $200.00. 
(2)  OVC project review base fee. The base fee for a project review under section 122-429 shall be $1,000.00. 
(e)  Conditional use permit. The fee for a conditional use permit issued under section 122-537 shall be $1,000.00. 
(f)  Appeals to zoning board of appeals. The fee for an appeal to the zoning board of appeals under section 122-162 shall be $100.00. 
(1)  Petition for a variance fee: $150.00. 
(g)  Petitions for changes or amendments to zoning chapter. The fee to be filed with a petition for a change or amendment to the zoning chapter under section 122-58(4) shall be $1,000.00. 
(h)  Planned infill development (PID) application fee. The application fee for a planned infill development (PID) under section 122-487 shall be $500.00. 
(i)  C-3 planned commercial-residential district fees. The development process under section 122-288 requires four (4) steps. The fee for each of the steps is as follows: 
(1)  Conceptual development review. The base fee for a conceptual development review shall be $100.00. 
(2)  Preliminary development review. The base fee for a preliminary development review shall be $500.00. 
(3)  Master development review. The base fee for a master development review shall be $500.00. 
(4)  Precise implementation plan review. The base fee for a precise implementation plan review shall be $200.00. 
(j)  Zoning adjustment fees. 
(1)  Adjustments to yard requirements in the C and I districts. The base fee for a zoning adjustment under section 122-624 shall be $100.00. 
(2)  Adjustments to height requirements in the C and I districts. The base fee for a zoning adjustment under section 122-625 shall be $100.00. 
(3)  Adjustments to outdoor lighting requirements. The base fee for a zoning adjustment under section 122-651 shall be $100.00. 
(k)  Application fee for approval of industrial building and site plans shall be $1,000.00. 
(l)  Corporate campus. 
(1)  The fee to obtain a corporate campus designation shall be $1,000.00. 
(2)  The fee to obtain corporate campus development approval shall be $1,000.00. 
(m)  Application fee for approval of business/commercial building and site plans shall be $1,000.00. 
(n)  The fee for miscellaneous plan commission appearance shall be $150.00. 
(o)  Application fee for architectural control board appearance not associated with a plan commission item shall be $150.00. 
(p)  Planned Development District No. 2 Fees. 
(1)  Conceptual review. The base fee for a conceptual review before the community development authority, plan commission, architectural control board, and village board shall be $150.00 per appearance before each board or $500.00 for review by all four boards. 
(2)  General plan approval. The base fee for a general plan approval shall be $1,000.00. 
(3)  Specific development plan approval. The base fee for a development plan approval shall be $1,000.00. 
(4)  Administrative and architectural control board adjustments. The base fee for an administrative and architectural control board adjustments shall be $150.00. 
(5)  Plan commission adjustments. The base fee for a plan commission adjustments shall be $150.00. 
(6)  Village board exception. The base fee for a village board exception shall be $150.00. 
(7)  Sign permits. The base fee for a sign permit shall be as provided under section 42-78 of the Municipal Code. 
(q)  Comprehensive plan amendment. The fee for amendment to the comprehensive plan shall be $1,000.00. 
(r)  Comprehensive plan and neighborhood plan amendments. The applicant requesting amendments to such plans will be billed for village staff time at the current hourly rate. The applicant will be billed for all outside consulting fees associated with the amendment. 
(s)  Redevelopment plan amendment. The applicant requesting amendment to a redevelopment plan will be billed for village staff time at the current hourly rate. The applicant will be billed for all outside consulting fees associated with the amendment. 
(t)  The fee for non-substantial modifications to an existing mobile service support structure or mobile service facility shall be $500.00. 
(Code 1963, §§ 17.033(8)(j)2, (8)(n)4, 27.14(1), 27.17; Ord. No. 125-O-00, § 10, 12-18-00; Ord. No. 169-O-01, § 1, 12-17-01; Ord. No. 172-O-02, § 5, 2-18-02; Ord. No. 174-O-02, § 1, 2-18-02; Ord. No. 213-O-02, §§ 92-115, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 237-O-03, §§ 1-5, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 353-O-06, § 22, 11-20-06; Ord. No. 417-O-08, § 3, 10-20-08; Ord. No. 467-O-09, § 3, 11-16-09; Ord. No. 508-O-11, § 1, 5-16-11; Ord. No. 537-O-12, §§ 1, 2, 5-21-12; Ord. No. 588-O-14, § 4, 3-17-14) 
Secs. 42-123-42-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - IMPACT FEES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-161 et seq. 

Sec. 42-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building permit means any permit required for new construction and additions pursuant to this chapter. The term "building permit," as used in this article, shall not be deemed to include permits required for remodeling, rehabilitation or other improvements to an existing structure, or rebuilding a damaged or destroyed structure, provided that no increase in gross floor area or number of dwelling units results therefrom. 
    Capital budget means a plan for capital expenditures, including commitments, to be incurred during the budget year from funds subject to appropriation by the governing body of the concerned government for projects scheduled in a given year of the capital program. 
    Capital improvements program (CIP) means a plan for capital expenditures, including commitments, to be incurred each year over a fixed period of years to meet capital needs arising from the longterm work program. It thus sets forth each project or other contemplated expenditure in which the local government is to have a part, and it specifies the full resources estimated to be available to finance the projected expenditures. 
    Comprehensive plan means the Land Use and Transportation System Plan for the Village of Menomonee Falls: 2010, including any subsequent changes or amendments thereto. 
    Costs means the capital cost to construct, expand or improve public facilities, including the cost of land, and including legal, engineering and design costs to construct, expand or improve public facilities, except that not more than ten percent of capital costs may consist of legal, engineering and design costs unless the village can demonstrate that its legal, engineering and design costs which relate directly to the public improvement for which the impact fees were imposed exceed ten percent of capital costs. Costs do not include other noncapital costs to construct, expand or improve public facilities, vehicles; or the costs of equipment to construct, expand or improve public facilities. 
    Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real property, the use of any principal structure or land, or any other activity that requires issuance of a building permit. 
    Development subareas means geographically defined areas of the village that have been designated by the village board as areas in which development potential may create the need for a capital improvements program to be funded by impact fees. The areas may be referenced in the comprehensive plan, and shall be shown on a development subareas map. 
    Development subareas map means a map of development subareas in which impact fees are imposed. This map shall be approved by the village board and filed with the village manager or designee, and incorporated by reference in this article as if fully set forth. 
    Dwelling unit means a single unit providing complete, independent living facilities for one or more persons. 
    Gross floor area means the total floor area of buildings to be constructed. 
    Impact fee means a fee, or equivalent contributions of land or other items of value in lieu of the fee, imposed under this chapter in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 66.0617. 
    Mixed use development means local use of land involving both residential and nonresidential development. 
    Nonresidential development means any local use of land for primarily industrial, commercial, or institutional purposes, or which does not fall within the definition of residential development. 
    Plat. See Subdivision plat. 
    Plumbing permit means any permit required under article V of this chapter for new construction or for connections to the village's water or sewer system. As used in this article, the term shall include permits required for improvements for an existing structure, or building a damaged or destroyed structure, if such improvements or rebuilding result in an increase in the number of dwelling units on the property, or otherwise increase the property's impact on the sewerage or water system by one REC or any fraction thereof. 
    Public facilities or public facilities project means any or all of the following, which are necessary to support and are attributable to one or more designated development areas and which are identified in the capital improvements plan to be financed by the imposition of an impact fee: 
(1)  Parks, playgrounds and land for athletic fields; 
(2)  Streets and highways, including such ancillary facilities as sidewalks, street lighting, curbs, gutters, signalization, signage, and landscaping; 
(3)  Sanitary sewers and sewage collection facilities; 
(4)  Water storage and supply facilities; 
(5)  Storm sewers, drains, and drainage retention facilities; 
(6)  Police facilities; 
(7)  Fire protection facilities; 
(8)  Libraries. 
The costs of such public facilities shall include acquisition of land, construction, improvements, and installing of the same and all other work auxiliary thereto, including administrative, engineering, architectural, and legal work performed in connection with a public facilities project. 
    Redevelopment means the modification or replacement of an older development. 
    Residential development means the local use of land for the primary purpose of housing accommodations. However, congregate care facilities having centralized dining services and private living quarters without an area equipped for preparing and cooking food shall not be considered residential development, nor shall any structure having four or more dwelling units. 
    Residential equivalent connection (REC) means a unit of measure for sewer or water related impact fees equivalent to the amount of sewer or water capacity needed to supply one residential dwelling unit, which has been determined to be 214 gallons per day. 
    Site means a parcel, lot or contiguous group of lots in a single ownership or under single control, considered a unit for purposes of development. 
    Subdivision plat means a preliminary or final map of a subdivision showing the salient features of a proposed subdivision and which is submitted to an approving authority for purposes of preliminary or final consideration. As used in this article, it shall also include a certified survey map. 
    Zoning districts means parts of the village for which the zoning code regulations governing the use and location of land and buildings are uniform. 
    Zoning ordinance means the zoning ordinance of the village. 
(Code 1963, § 26.04; Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 1, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 357-O-06, § 13, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 479-O-10, § 15, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 514-O-11, §§ 1-4, 9-6-11; Ord. No. 527-O-12, § 1, 2-6-12; Ord. No. 559-O-13, §§ 1, 2, 7-15-13) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-142. - Intent of article. 
    This article is intended to impose an impact fee, in order to regulate the effect of new development on public facilities, and to finance public facilities, the demand for which is generated by new development or any improvements made to existing development in designated development areas. 
(Code 1963, § 26.02) 
Sec. 42-143. - Authority. 
    This article is authorized under Wis. Stats. § 66.0617. The provisions of this article shall not be construed to limit the power of the village to adopt such ordinance pursuant to any other source of local authority, nor to utilize any other methods or powers otherwise available for accomplishing the purposes set forth in this article, either in substitution of or in conjunction with this article. 
(Code 1963, § 26.030; Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 17, 11-19-01) 
Sec. 42-144. - Applicability of impact fee. 
    This article shall be uniformly applicable to development which occurs within a designated development subarea. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0617(5), this article may impose different impact fees on different types of land development, and may impose impact fees on land development in a particular subarea that differ from impact fees imposed on similar land development in other subareas within the village. 
(Code 1963, § 26.05; Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 18, 11-19-01) 
_____
Sec. 42-145. - Imposition of impact fee. 
(a)  Sewer impact fees shall be per residential equivalent connection and as follows:

(1)  For single-family residential units and multi-family residential units with three bedrooms or more.

(e)  No building permit shall be issued for a development in a designated development subarea unless the applicant has paid all impact fees imposed by and calculated pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1963, §§ 26.06, 27.26(1); Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 2, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 328-O-06, §§ 1-3, 1-3-06; Ord. No. 357-O-06, §§ 13, 14, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 360-O-07, § 1, 1-2-07; Ord. No. 479-O-10, §§ 3, 4, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 5, 9-6-11; Ord. No. 559-O-13, § 3, 7-15-13; Ord. No. 614-O-15, § 1, 1-19-15) 
Sec. 42-146. - Establishment of development subareas. 
(a)  Development subareas are established as shown on the development subareas map. Such development subareas will be established consistent with any facility service areas established in the capital improvements plan for each public facility. 
(b)  Additional development subareas or combinations of development subareas may be designated by the village board as development subareas consistent with the procedure set forth in this article and with Wis. Stats. § 66.0617. 
(Code 1963, § 26.07; Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 19, 11-19-01) 
Sec. 42-147. - Capital improvements program (by subarea). 
    To service the projected development, the impact fee will be required to fund public facilities as shown on the capital improvements program. 
(Code 1963, § 26.08) 
Sec. 42-148. - Sewer impact fees. 
(a)  Sewer impact fee subarea. For purposes of the sewer impact fee imposed under this section, the subarea shall be all the land within the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  Residential development. The village shall determine the number of residential equivalent connections as follows: 
(1)  Each dwelling unit in a residential development shall be equal to one REC. 
(c)  Nonresidential development. 
(1)  The property owner shall submit, on forms provided by the village, a good faith estimate of the intended sewer usage for the nonresidential development. 
(2)  The village shall calculate the number of residential equivalent connections for the development by dividing the information supplied by the property owner under subsection (c)(1) of this section by "214". 
(3)  Any fraction of a REC shall be rounded up to the next highest whole number. 
(d)  Mixed use development. The village shall separately calculate the number of residential equivalent connections for each type of development as set forth in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(e)  Calculation of the interim sewer impact fee. 
(1)  The amount of the sewer impact fee to be paid shall be the fee provided in subsection 42-145(a) multiplied by the number of RECs determined in subsections (b) through (d) of this section. 
(2)  In cases of redevelopment, the average sewer usage over the previous five years shall be converted to RECs and subtracted from the anticipated RECs of the proposed redevelopment. The difference shall be multiplied by fee found in subsection 42-145(a). 
(f)  Calculation of final impact fee. 
(1)  Since the impact fee determined under subsection (e) of this section is based upon the anticipated impact of estimated intended usage, the village shall average the actual quarterly usage for the first three years of the development. 
(2)  Based upon the information obtained under subsection (f)(1) of this section, the village shall recalculate the number of residential equivalent connections, and may recalculate and impose an additional sewer impact fee pursuant to the schedule set out in subsection 42-145(a). 
(Code 1963, § 26.09; Ord. No. 127-O-01, §§ 3(a), 3(b), 2-22-01; Ord. No. 171-O-02, § 1, 2-4-02; Ord. No. 559-O-13, § 4, 7-15-13) 
Sec. 42-149. - Park impact fees. 
(a)  Park impact fees subarea. For purposes of the park impact fee imposed under this section, the subarea shall be all the land within the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  Type of development. The park impact fee shall be paid for new dwelling units. In cases of a mixed use development, the park impact fee shall be calculated on the number of dwelling units in the mixed use development. There will be no park impact fee imposed on other types of development. 
(c)  Calculation of park impact fee for the initial development, excluding redevelopment. 
(1)  The property owner shall submit information showing the total number of dwelling units in the development broken down by the number of bedrooms. 
(2)  The information supplied by the property owner under subsection (c)(1) of this section, shall be multiplied by the associated fees found in subsection 42-145(b). 
(3)  The park impact fee for each dwelling unit shall be added together to determine the impact fee for the associated building. 
(d)  Calculation of park impact fee for redevelopment projects. 
(1)  The property owner shall submit information showing the total number of dwelling units in the proposed development broken down by the number of bedrooms. 
(2)  The fee in subsection 42-145(b)(1) shall be multiplied by the difference of the number of dwelling units with 3 bedrooms or more in the proposed development, and the number of dwelling units with 3 bedrooms or more existing on the site prior to the proposed development. 
(3)  The fee found in subsection 42-145(b)(2) shall be multiplied by the difference of the number of dwelling units with two bedrooms in the proposed development, and the number of dwelling units with two bedrooms existing on the site prior to the proposed development. 
(4)  The fee found in subsection 42-145(b)(3) shall be multiplied by the difference of the number of dwelling units with less than two bedrooms in the proposed development, and the number of dwelling units with less than two bedrooms existing on the site prior to the proposed development. 
(5)  The park impact fees for redevelopment projects shall be determined by adding all of the values found in subsections (e)(2), (e)(3), and (e)(4) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 4, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 559-O-13, § 5, 7-15-13) 
Sec. 42-150. - Water impact fee. 
(a)  Water impact fees subarea. For purposes of the water impact fee imposed under this section, the subarea shall be all the land within the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  Residential development. The village shall determine the number of residential equivalent connections as follows: 
(1)  Each dwelling unit in a residential development shall be equal to one REC. 
(c)  Nonresidential development. 
(1)  The property owner shall submit, on forms provided by the village, a good faith estimate of the intended water usage for the nonresidential development. 
(2)  The village shall calculate the number of residential equivalent connections for the development by dividing the information supplied by the property owner under subsection (c)(1) of this Section by "214". 
(3)  Any fraction of a REC shall be rounded up to the next highest whole number. 
(d)  Mixed use development. The village shall separately calculate the number of residential equivalent connections for each type of development as set forth in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(e)  Calculation of the interim water impact fee. 
(1)  The amount of the water impact fee to be paid shall be the fee as provided in subsection 42-145(c) multiplied by the number of RECs determined in subsections (b) through (d) of this section. 
(2)  In cases of redevelopment, the average water usage over the previous five years shall be converted to RECs and subtracted from the anticipated RECs of the proposed redevelopment. The difference shall be multiplied by fee found in subsection 42-145(c). 
(f)  Calculation of final impact fee. 
(1)  Since the impact fee determined under subsection (e) of this section is based upon the anticipated impact of estimated intended usage, the village shall average the actual quarterly usage for the first three years of the development. 
(2)  Based upon the information obtained under subsection (f)(1) of this section, the village shall recalculate the number of residential equivalent connections, and may recalculate and impose an additional water impact fee pursuant to the schedule set out in subsection 42-145(c). 
(Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 6, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 559-O-13, § 6, 7-15-13) 
Sec. 42-151. - Fire impact fees. 
(a)  Fire impact fees subarea. For purposes of the fire impact fee imposed under this section, the subarea shall be all the land within the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  Type of development. The fire impact fee shall be based on the type and size of the proposed building. 
(c)  Mixed use development. The village shall separately calculate the fire impact fee for each type of development as set forth in subsection 42-145(d) of this section. 
(d)  Calculation of fire impact fee. The village shall calculate the fire impact fee as follows: 
(1)  Residential development. 
a.  The property owner shall submit information showing the total number of dwelling units proposed in the development, broken down by the number of bedrooms. 
b.  The information supplied by the property owner under subsection (d)(1)(a) of this section shall be multiplied by the associated fee found in subsection 42-145(d)(1), (2), or (3). 
c.  The fire impact fees for each dwelling unit shall be added together to determine the impact fee for the associated building. 
(2)  Nonresidential development. 
a.  The village shall verify the square feet of gross floor area of the new building or an expansion to an existing building. 
b.  The amount of the fire impact fee to be paid shall be the fee provided in subsection 42-145(d)(4) or (5) multiplied by the square feet of proposed gross floor area. 
(3)  Redevelopment. In cases of redevelopment, the fire impact fee shall be calculated based on subsection (d) of this section, however any previously paid fire impact fee shall be subtracted from the total. 
(Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 11, 9-6-11; Ord. No. 559-O-13, § 7, 7-15-13) 
Sec. 42-152. - Collection and accounting. 
(a)  Impact fees calculated and due pursuant to this article shall be collected by the village prior to the issuance of any building permit. 
(b)  Failure to pay the impact fees as provided in this article subjects the developer or landowner to the penalties set out in section 1-7 of this Code and voids any permits issued under subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Upon receipt of impact fees, the village manager or designee shall be responsible for placement of such fees into separate funds as specified in this section. 
(d)  The village manager or designee shall establish a separate interest-bearing fund for fees collected for each subarea. Interest or income earned by each fund shall be credited to that fund and shall be used solely for the purposes specified for such fund. The village manager or designee shall maintain records for each such fund, whereby impact fees collected can be segregated by subarea development. 
(e)  The village manager or designee shall maintain and keep adequate financial records for each such fund, which shall show the source and disbursement of all revenues, which shall account for all monies received, and which shall ensure that the disbursement of monies from each fund shall be used solely and exclusively for the provision of projects specified in the capital improvements program for the particular development subarea. 
(Code 1963, § 26.11(1)-(4); Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 5, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 357- o-06, §§ 15-18, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 479-O-10, §§ 5-7, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 6, 9-6-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 6-10, adopted Sept. 6, 2011, renumbered §§ 42-151-42-159 as §§ 42-152-42-160. 
Sec. 42-153. - Periodic review and modification. 
    The village shall periodically, in conjunction with the annual capital budget and capital improvements plan adoption processes, review the development potential of each subarea and the capital improvements plan and make such modifications as are deemed necessary as a result of: 
(1)  Development occurring in prior years; 
(2)  Public facilities actually constructed; 
(3)  Changing facility needs; 
(4)  Inflation; 
(5)  Revised cost estimates for public facilities; 
(6)  Changes in the availability of other funding sources applicable to public facility projects; and 
(7)  Such other factors as may be relevant. 
(Code 1963, § 26.11(5); Ord. No. 127-O-01, §§ 7, 7(a)-7(c), 2-22-01; Ord. No. 357-O-06, § 19, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 7, 9-6-11; Ord. No. 559-O-13, § 8, 7-15-13) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 42-152. See § 42-152 editor's note. 
Sec. 42-154. - Bonding of excess facility projects. 
    Impact fees paid pursuant to this article shall be restricted to use solely and exclusively for financing directly, or as a pledge against bonds, revenue certificates, and other obligations of indebtedness for the cost of public facilities as specified in this article. 
(Code 1963, § 26.12; Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 5, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 7, 9-6-11) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 42-153. See § 42-152 editor's note. 
Sec. 42-155. - Refunds. 
(a)  Impact fees and all interest earned thereon collected by the village shall be used exclusively for the projects listed in the village public facilities needs assessment. Such fees shall be expended by the village within the time limits imposed by Wis. Stats. § 66.0617(9), or such fee amount paid along with any interest that has accumulated shall be refunded by the village to the current owner(s) of the property with respect to which such fee was imposed in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 66.0617(9). 
(b)  The current owner of property on which an impact fee has been paid may apply for a refund of such fee, along with any interest that has accumulated, if: 
(1)  The building permit for which the impact fee has been paid has lapsed for noncommencement of construction; 
(2)  The project for which a building permit or occupancy permit has been issued has been altered in a manner which has resulted in a decrease in the amount of the impact fee due; or 
(3)  As otherwise authorized in this article. 
(c)  An individual applying for a refund under this section shall comply with the following procedure: 
(1)  A written petition for refund must be filed with the village manager or his designee within one year of the event giving rise to the right to claim a refund, and failure to do so as provided in this section shall be considered a waiver of the right to claim a refund under this article. 
(2)  Within ten business days of the date of filing of a petition for refund, the village manager shall forward a copy of the petition for refund to the appropriate department head. Within 30 business days of receipt, the appropriate department head shall submit a written report and recommendation to the village manager. The village manager shall review this report and make a written recommendation to the village board. Within 45 days of the date of the village manager's written recommendation, the village board shall adopt a resolution denying, approving or approving in part the refund petition. 
(3)  If the petitioner wishes to appeal the decision of the village board, the petitioner may commence an action by certiorari in the county circuit court seeking review of the board's decision within 30 days after the date in which the board adopted the resolution with respect to the petition for refund. 
(Code 1963, § 26.13; Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 5, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 357-O-06, § 20, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 479-O-10, § 8, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 8, 9-6-11; Ord. No. 559-O-13, § 9, 7-15-13) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 42-154. See § 42-152 editor's note. 
Sec. 42-156. - Appeals. 
(a)  Notice of appeal. Any developer or property owner upon whom an impact fee has been imposed may contest the amount, collection or use of the impact fee by filing a notice of appeal to the village board. The notice of appeal shall be filed with the village clerk within 30 days of the date of the determination appealed from. The notice of appeal shall state in detail the relief sought by the developer and any legal or factual basis for the relief requested; and shall include all supporting documentation upon which the developer relies in making the appeal. 
(b)  Appeal bond. If the notice of appeal is accompanied by a bond or other sufficient surety satisfactory to the village attorney in an amount equal to the impact fee due, as calculated by the village manager or designee, and all other requirements have been satisfied, the building permit may be issued. The filing of an appeal shall not stay the collection of the impact fee due unless a bond or other sufficient surety has been filed. 
(c)  Review by the village board. 
(1)  Within ten business days of the date of filing of the notice of appeal, the village manager shall forward a copy of the notice of appeal to the appropriate department head. Within 30 business days of receipt, the appropriate department head shall submit a written report and recommendation to the village manager. The village manager shall review this report and make a written recommendation to the village board. 
(2)  Within 45 days of the date of the village manager's written recommendation, the village board shall adopt a resolution denying, approving or approving in part the appeal. 
(d)  Review by circuit court. If the developer or property owner wishes to appeal the decision of the village board, the developer or property owner may commence an action by certiorari in the county circuit court seeking review of the board's decision within 30 days after the date on which the board adopted the resolution with respect to the developer's appeal. 
(Code 1963, § 26.14; Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 5, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 9, 9-6-11) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 42-155. See § 42-152 editor's note. 
Sec. 42-157. - Effect of impact fee on zoning and subdivision regulations. 
    This article shall not affect, in any manner, the permissible use of property, density of development, design and improvement standards and requirements, or any other aspect of the development of land or provision of public improvements subject to the zoning and subdivision regulations or other regulations of the village, which shall be operative and remain in full force and effect without limitation with respect to all such development. 
(Code 1963, § 26.15; Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 5, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 10, 9-6-11) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 42-156. See § 42-152 editor's note. 
Sec. 42-158. - Impact fee as additional and supplemental requirement. 
    Except as required by Wis. Stats. § 66.0617(6)(d), the impact fees imposed under this article are additional and supplemental to, and not in substitution of, any other requirements imposed by the village on the development of land or the issuance of building permits. 
(Code 1963, § 26.16; Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 5, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 20, 11-19-01; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 10, 9-6-11) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 42-157. See § 42-152 editor's note. 
Sec. 42-159. - Amendments. 
(a)  Before enacting an ordinance that amends this article or section 42-145(a), the village board shall hold a public hearing on the proposed ordinance or amendment. 
(b)  Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0617(3), notice of the public hearing referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall be published as a class 1 notice under Wis. Stats. ch. 985, and shall specify where a copy of the proposed ordinance or amendment and the public needs assessment may be obtained. 
(c)  Before enacting an ordinance that imposes impact fees or amending an ordinance that imposes impact fees by revising the amount of the fee or altering the public facilities for which impact fees may be imposed, a needs assessment shall be prepared and made available for public inspection and copying as required by Wis. Stats. § 66.0617(4). 
(Code 1963, § 26.17; Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 5, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 158-O-01, §§ 21, 22, 11-19-01; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 10, 9-6-11) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 42-158. See § 42-152 editor's note. 
Sec. 42-160. - Credits. 
(a)  A property owner may elect to construct a public facility listed in the capital improvements plan for which an impact fee has been imposed. If the property owner elects to construct such a public facility, the property owner must enter into an agreement with the village prior to issuance of any plumbing or building permit. In any such agreement, the village shall reasonably provide for credits for other past or future monetary or nonmonetary contributions by the developer to the construction of the same public facility, as follows: 
(1)  Present value of amounts contributed within the last three years for any land dedications, physical improvements or financial contributions made for the construction of the public facility; 
(2)  Present land dedications and physical improvements made for the construction of the public facility; 
(3)  Future land dedications, physical improvements made for the construction of the public facility for a period not to exceed three years. 
(b)  In no event shall credit provided under subsection (a) of this section be greater than the otherwise applicable impact fee. 
(c)  No credits shall be given for he construction of local on-site facilities required by zoning, subdivision or other village requirements, or which are not included in the capital improvements program. 
(Code 1963, § 26.18; Ord. No. 127-O-01, § 5, 2-22-01; Ord. No. 514-O-11, § 10, 9-6-11) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 42-159. See § 42-152 editor's note. 
Chapter 46 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Board of police and fire commissioners, § 2-286 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; buildings damaged by fire or natural calamity, § 18-2; emergency services, ch. 34; offenses involving fireworks, § 62-66 et seq.; making of fires in parks, § 66-31. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 46-1-46-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq. 
State Law reference- Fire departments, Wis. Stats. § 61.65. 

Sec. 46-21. - Organization of the fire department. 
(a)  A fire services division of the protective services department established under chapter 72 of this Municipal Code and to be known as the village fire department is hereby established for the protection of life and property through the prevention and extinguishment of fires, and through salvage and rescue work in the event of public emergencies within the village and adjacent territory. 
(b)  The fire department shall be comprised of a fire chief and such other personnel as the village board of trustees may from time to time authorize. 
(c)  The fire department shall consist of as many fire companies as may be provided for by the village board of trustees. 
(d)  Personnel in the village fire department shall be subordinate to and under the control and direction of the fire chief, who shall be under the direction and supervision of the director of protective services. If authorized by the village board of trustees and the director of protective services, the fire chief may appoint as many officers as necessary for the proper operation of the department. 
(Code 1963, § 4.01; Ord. No. 529-O-12, § 4, 2-20-12) 
Sec. 46-22. - Employment in fire department. 
(a)  Original appointment to a position in the fire department shall be made by the fire chief after certification by the board of police and fire commissioners that such appointee meets the standards and requirements as established by the such board of commissioners. Continued employment shall be contingent upon rules established by the board of police and fire commissioners and rules of the department, as approved by such board of police and fire commissioners. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.65(1)(am)1, 62.13. 
(b)  Original appointment to an auxiliary position shall be made by the fire chief, and continuing employment shall be at the discretion of the fire chief. 
(Code 1963, § 4.02(2)) 
Sec. 46-23. - Powers and duties of fire chief. 
    The fire chief shall be subject to the supervision and direction of the director of protective services created under chapter 72 of the Municipal Code. Subject to that direction and supervision, the duties of the fire chief shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The fire chief shall have command and supervision of all members, apparatus and operations of the department. The fire chief shall be responsible for the efficiency and general good conduct of the department. 
(2)  The fire chief, or the officer in charge, shall be present at all fires, have complete command and responsibility for all firefighting operations, plan the control of the same and direct the actions of the firefighters. 
(3)  The fire chief shall enforce all fire prevention ordinances of the village and state laws and regulations pertaining to fire prevention. 
(4)  The fire chief shall keep an inventory of all apparatus and equipment and the results of tests of the same. 
(5)  The fire chief shall keep a fire record book of every fire to which any company was called and shall enter in such book the locality of fire, time of alarm, cause of fire, origin of fire, cause of delay (if any) in responding, method of extinguishment and the equipment used, amount of insurance carried on the building and contents, estimated fire loss, time fire was extinguished, names of men responding and other pertinent information. 
(6)  As authorized by or with the consent of the director of protective services, the fire chief may take such disciplinary action against subordinates as the fire chief shall deem necessary. 
(7)  The fire chief shall perform such other duties as are incumbent on the commanding officer of the fire department, and such other duties as may be assigned from time to time by the director of protective services. 
(Code 1963, § 4.03(1)-(5), (8), (9); Ord. No. 529-O-12, § 5, 2-20-12) 
Sec. 46-24. - Mutual aid. 
    Subject to the approval of both the village board of trustees and the director of protective services, the fire chief may by agreement secure the assistance and cooperation of the fire departments of neighboring municipalities, and extend like assistance and cooperation of the village fire department to such municipalities. 
(Code 1963, § 4.07; Ord. No. 529-O-12, § 6, 2-20-12) 
Sec. 46-25. - Authority of fire chief at scene of fire. 
(a)  The fire chief may prescribe certain limits in the vicinity of any fire within which no persons, excepting firefighters and police officers and those admitted by order of any officer of the department, shall be permitted to come. The chief shall have the power to cause removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of such property from fire or to prevent the spreading of fire or to protect adjoining property, and during the progress of any fire shall have the power to order the removal or destruction of any property necessary to prevent the further spread of the fire. He shall also have the power to cause the removal of all wires or other facilities and the turning off of all the electricity or other services where the same impedes the work of the department during the progress of fire. 
(b)  A firefighter, while acting under the direction of the fire chief or other officer in command, may enter upon the premises adjacent to or in the vicinity of any building or other property then on fire for the purpose of extinguishing such fire. 
(c)  Every person who shall be present at a fire shall be subject to the orders of the fire chief or officer in command and may be required to render assistance in fighting the fire or in removing or guarding property. Such officer shall have the power to cause the arrest of any person refusing to obey such orders. 
(Code 1963, § 4.08(2)-(4)) 
State Law reference- Interfering with firefighting, Wis. Stats. § 941.12. 
Secs. 46-26-46-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 639-O-15, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 2015, repealed § 46-26 in its entirety. Former § 46-26 pertained to ambulance conveyance fees and derived from the Code of 1963, § 4.10(2). 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Fire safety generally, Wis. Stats. § 101.135 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-46. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approval means approval by the chief of the fire department or chief of the bureau of fire prevention in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, as applied to a material, device or mode of construction. 
    Authority having jurisdiction means the authority having jurisdiction is the organization, office or individual responsible for approving equipment, an installation or a procedure. 
    Automatic fire alarm system means a system which automatically detects a fire condition and actuates a fire alarm signal device. 
    Bureau of fire prevention, chief of means the head of the village bureau of fire prevention or a duly authorized deputy. 
    Classes of construction. The classes of construction referenced are set forth in the International Building Code 
(1)  Type I A or B 
(2)  Type II A or B 
(3)  Type III A or B 
(4)  Type IV HT 
(5)  Type V A or B 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms arranged for the use of one or more individuals living together as a single housekeeping unit with cooking, living, sanitary and sleeping facilities. 
    Fire department, chief of means the head of the village fire department, a duly authorized deputy, or the designee of the head of the village fire department. 
    Fire district means the entire village. 
    Fire limits means generally the corporate limits of the village, except those districts defined as residential in article IV of chapter 122 of this Code. 
    Fire resistance rating means the time in hours that the material or construction will withstand the standard fire exposure as determined by a fire test made in conformity with the "Standard Methods of Fire Tests of Building Construction and Materials," ASTM E 119, UL Inc. 263, or NFPA No. 251 and the International Building Code Sections 702.1 and 802.1. 
    Fire resistive means that type of construction in which the structure members, including walls, partitions, columns, floor and roof construction, are of noncombustible materials with fire resistant rating not less than those specified in the International Building Code Chapter 7. 
    Fire resistive construction means the classes of construction specified in the International Building Code Chapter 6. 
    Firewall means a wall which has a fire resistance rating of not less than four hours and subdivides a building or separate buildings to restrict the spread of fire, including a three-foot parapet wall. 
    Multifamily house means the occupancy or use of a building, or portion of a building, containing three or more dwelling units. 
    NFPA means the National Fire Protection Association. 
    Occupancy is as defined in the International Building Code Chapter 3. 
    Occupancy definitions. The following occupancy classifications and their definitions will be used to determine the building, structure or tenant use of any given space. They are referenced from the International Building Code. 
    Assembly (Group A): 
    Group A-1: Assembly uses with seating for the production or viewing of motion pictures or viewing performing arts. 
    Group A-2: Assembly uses intended for the consumption of food or drink. 
    Group A-3: Assembly uses intended for worship, recreation or amusement (Uses not classified elsewhere in Group A). 
    Group A-4: Assembly uses intended for viewing indoor sports events with spectator seating. 
    Group A-5: Assembly uses intended for participation in or viewing outdoor activities. 
    Business (Group B): 
    Group B: The use of a building or portion thereof for office, professional or service type transactions. 
    Educational (Group E): 
    Group E: The use of a building or structure for education purposed by six or more persons at any one time through the 12th grade. Day care used for the education, supervision or personal care of more than five children over the age of two shall be part of this group. 
    Factory and Industrial (Group F): 
    Group F-1: Factory or Industrial uses that pose a moderate hazard (All uses not fitting the F-2 category). 
    Group F-2: Factory or Industrial uses that involve the fabrication or manufacturing of noncombustible materials and the processing or packaging of the finished product does not pose a significant fire hazard. 
    High Hazard (Group H): 
    Group H-1: Buildings or structures that contain materials that pose a detonation hazard. 
    Group H-2: Buildings or structures that contain materials that present a deflagration hazard or hazard from accelerated burning. 
    Group H-3: Buildings or structures that contain materials that readily support combustion or present a physical hazard. 
    Group H-4: Buildings or structures that contain materials that are health hazards. 
    Group H-5: Semiconductor fabrication facilities and comparable research and development. 
    Institutional (Group I): 
    Group I-1: Buildings or structures or portions thereof housing more than 16 persons on a 24-hour where the persons live in a supervised residential care environment basis because of age, mental disease or other reasons. Persons in this group can respond to emergencies without physical assistance. 
    Group I-2: Buildings or structures or portions thereof used for medical, surgical, psychiatric, nursing or custodial care on a 24-hour basis for five or more persons who are not capable of self preservation. A facility is part of this group if the facility is used to provide childcare on a 24-hour basis to more than five children who are two years of age or less. 
    Group I-3: Buildings or structures or portions thereof that are inhabited by more than five persons who are under restraint or security. Persons in this group are usually incapable of self-preservation because of security measures. 
    Group I-4 Buildings or structures or portions thereof occupied by persons of any age who receive custodial care for less than 24 hours by persons other than family in a place other than the home of the person being cared for. 
    Mercantile (Group M): 
    Group M: Buildings or structures or portions thereof used for the display and sale of merchandise (involves stocks of goods, wares or merchandise incidental to such purposes and accessible to the public. 
    Residential (Group R): 
    Group R-1: Residential occupancies where the occupants are primarily transient (less than 30 days). 
    Group R-2: Residential occupancies containing more than two dwelling units where occupants are permanent in nature. 
    Group R-3: Residential occupancies are permanent in nature where building do not contain more than two dwelling units or adult or childcare facilities that provide accommodations for five or less persons of any age for less than 24 hour. 
    Group R-4: Residential occupancy building for residential care/assisted living for more than five but not more than 16. 
    Storage (Group S): 
    Group S-1: Moderate hazard storage. 
    Group S-2: Low hazard storage of noncombustible items (can be on combustible pallets). 
    Utility and Miscellaneous (Group U): 
    Group U: covers all building and structures not covered in any other occupancy chapter. 
    Owner also means his duly authorized agent or attorney, a purchaser, devisee, fiduciary or person having a vested or contingent interest in the property in question. 
(Code 1963, § 22.01(4); Ord. No. 193-O-02, §§ 1-6, 6-27-02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 46-47. - Penalty for violation of article. 
(a)  General . Any person who violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article, or any order made under this article, shall be subject to a forfeiture of $75.00 per violation per day. 
(b)  Enforcement by injunction. Compliance with the provisions of this article may also be enforced by injunction by the village or by one or more owners of real estate situated adjacent to an area affected by the regulations of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 22.10; Ord. No. 880-97, § 6, 6-2-97; Ord. No. 244-O-03, § 2, 8-18-03) 
Sec. 46-48. - Applicability of article provisions. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall apply equally to new and existing conditions not in strict compliance with the terms of this article shall be permitted to continue where the exceptions do not constitute a clear hazard to life or property. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as applying to the transportation of any article or thing shipped under the jurisdiction of and in compliance with the regulations prescribed by the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT), nor as applying to the military forces of the United States. 
(c)  This article shall not apply to one-family and two-family dwellings used solely for the housing of two families or less. 
(Code 1963, § 22.01(3)) 
Sec. 46-49. - Purpose of article. 
    It is the purpose of this article to prescribe regulations consistent with nationally recognized good practice for the safeguarding, to a reasonable degree, of life and property from the hazards of fire and explosion arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, material and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the use or occupancy of buildings or premises within the village.
