Each day of continued violation is a separate offense. While an order issued under section 59-29 is suspended, stayed or enjoined, this penalty does not accrue. 
(2)  Except for the violations referred to in subsection (1), any person who violates Wis. Stats. subch. I of ch. 295, chapter NR 135, Wis. Admin. Code, any reclamation plan approved pursuant to this chapter or an order issued pursuant to section 59-29 shall forfeit not less than $10.00 nor more than $5,000.00 for each violation. Each day of violation is a separate offense. While an order issued under section 59-29 is suspended, stayed or enjoined, this penalty does not accrue. 
(Ord. No. 138-O-01, § 1, 6-18-01) 
Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Courts, ch. 26; law enforcement, ch. 54; traffic and vehicles, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit conduct similar to state criminal statutes, Wis. Stats. § 943.051(2). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Adoption of state penal or criminal laws and of certain administrative regulations by reference. 
(a)  Adoption of state penal or criminal laws. All penal or criminal laws of the state other than those the violation of which is a felony are adopted by reference. It is unlawful to violate any of such laws. 
(b)  Adoption of state administrative code for vehicle equipment and safety standards. 
(1)  Adoption of administrative regulations. The village adopts chs. Trans. 305, 325, 326 and 327, Wis. Adm. Code, as amended, with respect to defining and describing motor vehicle equipment standards and motor carrier safety regulations. 
(2)  Penalty. Upon conviction of a violation of any section of chs. Trans. 305, 325, 326 and 327, Wis. Admin. Code, so adopted, the court shall enter a judgment of forfeitures provided by statute or administrative regulation for violation of such section in addition to applicable court costs and assessments. 
(Ord. No. 525-O-12, § 1, 1-3-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 525-O-12, § 1, adopted Jan. 3, 2012, amended § 62-1 in its entirety. Former § 62-1 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1963, §§ 10.01, 10.02(1), 10.03(2)-10.03(4), 10.05(1). 
Sec. 62-2. - Truancy. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section and in sections 62-3 and 62-4, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Acceptable excuse has the meaning as defined in Wis. Stats. §§ 118.15 and 118.16(4). 
    Act of commission or omission means anything that contributes to the truancy of a student, whether or not the student is adjudged to be in need of protection or services, if the natural and probable consequences of that act would be to cause the student to be truant. 
    Habitual truant means a student who is absent from school without an acceptable excuse for part or all of five or more days on which school is held during a school semester. 
    Truancy means any absence for part or all of one or more days from school during which the school attendance officer, principal or teacher has not been notified of the legal cause of such absence by the parent or guardian of the absent student; intermittent attendance carried on for the purpose of defeating the intent of Wis. Stats. § 118.15 shall also be considered truancy. 
(b)  Prohibition against habitual truancy. Any person attending or required to attend school in the village between the ages of six and 18 years, subject to the exceptions found under Wis. Stats. § 118.15, is prohibited from becoming a habitual truant as the term is defined in this section. Any police officer in the village is authorized to issue a citation to any such person who is determined to be a habitual truant under the terms of this section. 
(1)  Preconditions to issuance of citation. Prior to the issuance of any citation, the village school attendance officer shall provide evidence to the police department that appropriate school personnel in the school in which the student is enrolled has within the school year during which the truancy occurred: 
a.  Met with the child's parent or guardian to discuss the child's truancy or attempted to meet with the child's parent or guardian and received no response or were refused. 
b.  Provided an opportunity for educational counseling to the student and considered curriculum modifications. 
c.  Evaluated the student to determine whether learning problems are the cause of the truancy and, if so, taken steps to overcome the learning problems. 
d.  Conducted an evaluation to determine whether social problems are the cause of the student's truancy and, if so, taken appropriate action or made appropriate referrals. 
(2)  Form of citation. Any citation issued shall be returnable in the Menomonee Falls Municipal Court in the same manner as all other ordinance citations are returnable. The citation is to state on its face that this is a "must appear" citation and no forfeiture amount is to be written on the face of the citation. 
(c)  Finding and disposition. Upon finding the student habitually truant, the municipal court shall enter an order making one or more of the following dispositions: 
(1)  Suspension of operating privileges. Suspend the student's operating privilege as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(40), for not less than 30 days nor more than one year. The court shall immediately take possession of the suspended license and forward it to the state department of transportation, together with a notice setting forth the reason for and the duration of the suspension. 
(2)  Counseling, service or work program. Order the student to participate in counseling, a supervised work program or other community service work under Wis. Stats. § 938.34(5g). The costs of any such counseling, supervised work program or other community service may be assessed against the student, the parents or guardian of the student, or both. 
(3)  In-house restraint. Order the student to remain at home except for the hours in which the student is attending religious worship or a school program, including travel time required to get to and from the school program or place of worship. The order may permit the student to leave the home if the student is accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(4)  Educational program. Order the student to attend an educational program as described in Wis. Stats. § 938.34(7d). 
(5)  Employment permit revocation. Order the department of workforce development to revoke, under Wis. Stats. § 103.72, a permit under Wis. Stats. § 103.70, authorizing the employment of the student. 
(6)  Teen court program. Order the student to be placed in a teen court program if all of the following conditions apply: 
a.  The chief judge of the judicial administrative district has approved a teen court program established in the student's county of residence and the judge determines that participation in the teen court program will likely benefit the student and the community. 
b.  The student and the student's parent, guardian or legal custodian enter into an agreement with the teen court staff admitting to the allegations that the student violated the municipal ordinance enacted under Wis. Stats. § 118.163(2). 
c.  The student has not previously participated in a teen court program before the date of the alleged municipal ordinance violation. 
(7)  Order to attend school. An order for the student to attend school. 
(8)  Forfeiture. A forfeiture of not more than $50.00 plus costs for a first violation, or a forfeiture of not more than $100.00 plus costs for any second or subsequent violation occurring within 12 months of a previous violation, subject to Wis. Stats. § 938.37, and subject to a maximum cumulative forfeiture amount of not more than $500.00 plus costs for all violations committed during a school semester. All or part of the forfeiture may be assessed against the student, the parents or guardian of the student, or both. 
(9)  Conditions. Any other reasonable conditions consistent with this section, including a curfew, restrictions as to going to or remaining on specified premises and restrictions on associating with other children or adults. 
(10)  Supervision. Any order placing the student under formal or informal supervision, as described in Wis. Stats. § 938.34(2), for up to one year. 
(11)  Parental counseling. 
a.  An order for the student's parents, guardian or legal custodian to participate in counseling at the parent's, guardian's or legal custodian's expense or to attend school with the student or both. 
b.  No order to any person under subsection (c)(11)a of this section may be entered until the person is given an opportunity to be heard on the contemplated order of the court. The court shall cause notice of the time, place and purpose of the hearing to be served on the person personally at least ten days before the date of the hearing. The procedure in these cases shall, as far as practicable, be the same as in other cases to the court. At the hearing, the person may be represented by counsel and may produce and cross examine witnesses. Any person who fails to comply with any order issued by a court under subsection (c)(11)a of this section may be proceeded against for contempt of court. 
(Code 1963, § 10.04(3); Ord. No. 61-O-99, § 1, 9-20-99) 
State Law reference- Authority to so provide, Wis. Stats. § 118.163. 
Sec. 62-3. - School attendance. 
(a)  Required. Any person having under such person's control a child who is between the ages of six and 18, subject to the exceptions found in Wis. Stats. § 118.15, shall cause the child to enroll as a student and to attend school regularly during the full period and hours that the public or private school in which the student shall be enrolled is in session until the end of the school term, quarter or semester of the school year in which the student becomes 18 years of age. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  A person will not be found in violation of this section if that person can prove that he or she is unable to comply with the provisions of this section because of the disobedience of the student. The student shall be referred to the court assigned to exercise jurisdiction over juveniles under Wis. Stats. chs. 48 and 938. 
(2)  A person will not be found in violation of this section if such person has a student under such person's control and the student has been sanctioned under Wis. Stats. § 49.50(7)(h). 
(c)  Proof required for exacting a penalty. Before a person may be found guilty of violating this section, the school attendance officer must present evidence to the court that the activities under Wis. Stats. § 118.16(5) have been completed by the school system or were not required to be completed as provided in Wis. Stats. § 118.16(5m). If that evidence has been presented to the court, and if the court finds a person guilty of violating this section, a forfeiture may be assessed as provided in section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 61-O-99, § 2, 9-20-99) 
Sec. 62-4. - Contributing to truancy. 
(a)  Prohibited. Any person 18 years of age or older is prohibited from performing any act of commission or omission, which act encourages or contributes to a student's truancy from school. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  This section does not apply to a person who has under such person's control a student who has been sanctioned under the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 49.26(2)(h). 
(2)  If the person charged with violation of this section proves that he or she is unable to comply with the law because of the disobedience of the child, the action shall be dismissed and the child shall be referred to the court assigned to exercise jurisdiction under Wis. Stats. ch. 48. 
(c)  Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to a forfeiture as provided in section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 61-O-99, § 3, 9-20-99) 
Sec. 62-5. - Smoking on school premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to commit the following acts in any school-owned or school-rented building or on school grounds: 
(1)  Smoke or possess a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or any other instrument with which to smoke tobacco; or 
(2)  Place any tobacco product in one's mouth; or 
(3)  All areas under this section shall be posted with appropriate "no smoking" signs. 
(Code 1963, § 10.03(9)) 
State Law reference- Smoking prohibitions, Wis. Stats. § 101.123. 
Sec. 62-6. - Smoking in village-owned buildings. 
    Smoking, as defined by Wis. Stats. § 101.123(1)(h) is prohibited inside any enclosed, indoor area of a building owned or operated by the village. 
(Code 1963, § 11.09) 
Sec. 62-7. - Assisting escape of prisoner. 
    No person shall intentionally aid any prisoner or person to escape from the lawful custody of a police officer or peace officer of the village. 
(Code 1963, § 10.03(3)) 
State Law reference- Assisting or permitting escape, Wis. Stats. § 946.44. 
Sec. 62-8. - Possession of false identification. 
    No person shall knowingly possess identification that has been altered so as to not be true and accurate, nor shall any person present for identification purposes a document that is not true and accurate identification of such person. 
(Code 1963, § 10.03(6)) 
Sec. 62-9. - Synthetic marijuana. 
(a)  Possession, sale and use prohibited. 
(1)  No person shall possess, purchase, display for sale, attempt to sell, sell, give, deliver, distribute, barter or use any chemical derivative of marijuana, or any other substance, designed to mimic the physical, psychological, intoxicating, narcotic or other effects of marijuana. 
(2)  The substances subject to this section include, but are not limited to, any one or more of the following chemicals whether under the common street or trade names of "Spice", "K2", "Genie", "Yucatan Fire", "Blaze", "Red X Dawn", "Zohia", "Spike Diamond", "Route 69", "Smoke XXXX", "Citron", "fake" or "new" marijuana, or by any other name, label or description: 
a.  (6aR, 10aR)-9-(hydroxymethyl)-6, 6dimethyl-3-(2methyloctan-2-yl)-6a, 7, 10, 10a-tetrahydrobenzo[c]chromen-1-ol-some trade or other names: HU-210; 
b.  1-Pentyl-3-(1-naphthoyl) indole-some trade or other names: JWH-018/spice; 
c.  1-Butyl-3-(1naphthoyl) indole-some trade or other names: JWH-073; 
d.  1-(3{trifluoromethylphenyl}) piperazine-some trade or other names: TFMPP; 
e.  2-(3-hydroxycyclohexyl)-5-(2-methyloctan-2-yl)phenol-some trade or other names: CP 47, 497; 
f.  1-(2-(4-(morpholinyl)ethyl))-3-(1-naphthoyl) indole-some trade or other names: JWH-200; 
g.  1-hexyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole-some trade or other names: JWH-019; 
h.  1-pentyl-3-(2-methoxyphenylacetyl)indole-some trade or other names: JWH-250; 
i.  1-pentyl-3-(4-chloro-1-naphthoyl)indole-some trade or other names: JWH-398; 
j.  (2-methyl-1-propyl-1H-indol-3-yl)-1-naphthalenyl-methanone-or some trade or other names: JWH-015; 
k.  Dexanabinol, (6aS,10aS)-9-(hydroxymethyl)-6,6-dimethyl-3-(2-methyloctan-2-yl)-6a,7,10,10a-tetrahydrobenzo[c]chromen-1-ol-or some trade or other names: HU-211; 
l.  Or any similar structural analogs. 
(3)  Definitions. 
a.  Deliver has the same meaning given in Wis. Stats. § 961.01(6) with respect to a controlled substance or controlled substance analog. 
b.  Distribute has the same meaning given in Wis. Stats. § 961.01(9) with respect to a controlled substance or controlled substance analog. 
(b)  Medical and dental use allowed. Acts prohibited under subsection (a) shall not be unlawful if done by or under the direction or prescription of a licensed physician, dentist, or other medical health professional authorized to direct or prescribe such acts, provided use is permitted under state and federal laws. 
(c)  Penalty. Persons violating this section shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. This section shall not preclude the village from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 497-O-10, § 1, 11-1-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 497-O-10, § 1, adopted November 1, 2010, set out provisions intended for use as § 62-50. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 62-9. 
Sec. 62-10. - Electronic smoking devices. 
(a)  "Vapor products" shall mean noncombustible products, that may or may not contain nicotine, that employ a mechanical heating element, battery, electronic circuit, or other mechanism, regardless of shape or size, that can be used to produce a vapor in a solution or other form including but not limited to an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, or similar product or device. "Vapor products" shall include any vapor cartridge, solution, or other container, that may or may not contain nicotine, that is intended to be used with an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, or similar product or device. "Vapor products" do not include any products regulated by the United States Food and Drug Administration under Chapter V of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. 
(b)  No person under 18 years of age may purchase, attempt to purchase, or possess any vapor products as defined in subsection (a) except as follows: 
(1)  A person under 18 years of age possessing vapor products for the sole purpose of resale in the course of employment during his or her working hours if employed by a retailer. 
(c)  No person, by himself, his servant or agent, or as the servant or agent of any other person, shall sell, give away, or otherwise dispose of, by vending machine or otherwise, any vapor products as defined in subsection (a) to any person under the age of 18 years old. The defenses provided in Wis. Stat. § 134.66(3)(a)-(c) shall be defenses to any prosecution under this subsection. 
(d)  Penalty. Persons violating this section shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-7. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. This section shall not preclude the village from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 719-O-18, § 1, 5-21-18) 
Secs. 62-11-62-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PROPERTY RIGHTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Offenses involving property rights, Wis. Stats. ch. 943. 

Sec. 62-26. - Loitering in off-street parking area. 
    When signs are posted, it shall be unlawful for any person to sit, stand, loiter or remain either in, on or outside of any vehicle for a period of more than 15 minutes in any of the following places: 
(1)  On any village parking lot or on any village park parking lot. 
(2)  On any parking lot under the control of a school district. 
(3)  On any privately owned parking lot which is held open to public use. 
(Code 1963, § 10.05(3)) 
Sec. 62-27. - Unauthorized presence on school property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any student who is under suspension, expulsion, exemption or other discipline excluding him from attending public school or for any person not a student presently enrolled to attend public school or not an employee of such public school, or not a parent or guardian of a student so enrolled or not an otherwise authorized person, to be present within any school building or upon any school grounds under the jurisdiction of a public school without having first secured authorization to be there from the principal or other person in charge of such school building or school grounds, except while in direct route to secure such authorization. The term "authorized person" shall include any person who is present at any school building or school grounds for any purpose previously authorized by the board of education or its designee. 
(b)  Any person shall, upon request of the principal or other person in charge of any school building or upon any school grounds under the jurisdiction of a public school, or upon request of any police officer, display any written authorization to be present which he may have in his possession or otherwise explain his presence or his status as such student, employee, parent or guardian or authorized person referred to in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  All entrances to the school building referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall be posted with a notice stating "Entry into school building by unauthorized persons prohibited." All school grounds referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall be posted with a notice stating "Entry upon school grounds by unauthorized persons prohibited." 
(d)  Unauthorized presence on posted school district property. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in subsection (a) of this section, no person shall enter or remain upon land which is owned or controlled by a school district after having been notified not to enter or remain on such land. For the purpose of this section, notice may be given verbally by an authorized agent of the school district, or posted in the manner prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 943.13(2). Posted notices shall be signed by a duly authorized agent of the school district politic. The requirements for signs posted under this section shall be in addition to the requirements set out in subsection (c) of this section, and shall control to the extent of any conflict. 
(Code 1963, § 10.05(4); Ord. No. 170-O-02, § 1, 1-7-02) 
State Law reference- Trespass, Wis. Stats. § 943.13 et seq. 
Sec. 62-28. - Unauthorized presence on posted government property. 
    No person shall enter or remain upon land which is owned or controlled by a body politic after having been notified not to enter or remain on such land. For the purpose of this section, notice may be given verbally by an authorized agent of the body politic posted in the manner prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 943.13(2). Posted notices shall be signed by a duly authorized agent of the body politic. 
(Code 1963, § 10.05(5)) 
State Law reference- Trespass, Wis. Stats. § 943.13 et seq. 
Sec. 62-29. - Theft of motor fuel from retailer; vehicle owner liability. 
(a)  No person shall leave the premises of any gasoline station or other establishment engaging in the business of retail sale of motor fuel including, but not limited to, gasoline, diesel fuel and ethanol without making payment for the motor fuel obtained at such premises unless with the consent of the owner or operator of such premises. 
(b)  The owner, as defined in Wis. Stat. § 340.01 (42) and § 346.01(2), of a vehicle involved in a violation of subsection (a) of this section shall be liable for the violation as provided in this subsection. 
(1)  Any person who observes a violation of subsection (a) of this section may, within 24 hours after observing the violation, report the violation to the police department. If possible, the report shall contain the following information: 
a.  A description of the violation alleged. 
b.  The approximate time and location of the violation. 
c.  The license number and description of the vehicle involved in the violation. 
d.  A description of the operator and any passengers at the time of the violation. 
e.  Any video recordings or photos of the violation. 
(2)  It shall be no defense to a violation of this subsection (b) that the owner was not operating or in control of the vehicle at the time of the violation. 
(3)  Defenses to a violation of this subsection (b) are as follows: 
a.  A report that the vehicle was stolen was made to a law enforcement agency before the violation occurred. 
b.  The owner of the vehicle provides the police department with the name and address of the person operating the vehicle at the time of the violation and the person so named admits operating the vehicle at the time of the violation. In such case, the person operating the vehicle and not the owner shall be charged under this subsection. 
c.  The vehicle is owned by a lessor of vehicle and at the time of the violation the vehicle was in the possession of a lessee, and the lessor provides the police department with the information required under Wis. Stat. § 343.46(3). In such case, the lessee and not the lessor shall be charged under this section. 
d.  The vehicle is owned by a dealer, as defined in Wis. Stat. § 340.01(11), including the persons specified in Wis. Stat. §§ 340.01(11)(a) to (d), and the dealer provides the police department with the name, address of the person operating the vehicle at the time of the violation and the person so named admits operating the vehicle at the time of the violation. In such case, the person operating the vehicle, and not the dealer, shall be charged under this section. 
(c)  In addition to any penalty imposed for violation of this section, any person convicted under subsection (a) or subsection (b) for an incident that resulted in physical damage to or destroyed any property shall be liable for the costs of replacing or repairing the damaged or destroyed property. The parent or parents of any unemancipated minor child who violates this section may also be held liable for the cost of replacing or repairing such damaged or destroyed property in accordance with Wis. Stat. § 895.035. 
(Ord. No. 618-O-15, § 1, 3-16-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 618-O-15, § 1, adopted March 16, 2015, amended § 62-29 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 62-29 pertained to theft of gas or motor fuel from retailer and derived from the Code of 1963, § 10.05(10). 
State Law reference- Theft, Wis. Stats. § 943.20. 
Sec. 62-30. - Operation of bicycle without owner's consent. 
    No person shall take or operate any bicycle or other nonmotorized vehicle without consent of the owner. For the purpose of this article, the term "vehicle" shall be defined as in Wis. Stats. § 340.01. 
(Code 1963, § 10.05(8)) 
State Law reference- Unauthorized use of vehicle, Wis. Stats. § 943.23. 
Secs. 62-31-62-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC SAFETY[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Public safety offenses, Wis. Stats. ch. 941. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-51. - Sex offender residency restrictions; child safety zones. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. 
(1)  The village finds and declares that sex offenders are a serious threat to public safety. When convicted sex offenders re-enter society, they are much more likely than any other type of offender to be re-arrested for a new rape or sexual assault. Given the high rate of recidivism for sex offenders and that reducing opportunity and temptation is important to minimizing the risk of re-offense, there is a need to protect children where they congregate or play in public places in addition to the protections afforded by state law near schools and daycare centers. The village finds and declares that, in addition to schools and daycare centers, children congregate or play in a number of public places, including public parks and other facilities for children. 
(2)  This section is a regulatory measure aimed at protecting the health and safety of children in Menomonee Falls from the risk that convicted sex offenders may re-offend in locations close to their residences. It is the intent of this section not to impose a criminal penalty but rather to serve the village's compelling interest to promote, protect, and improve the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the village by creating areas around locations where children regularly congregate in concentrated numbers wherein certain sexual offenders and sexual predators are prohibited from establishing temporary or permanent residence; and by creating child safety zones where children regularly congregate in concentrated numbers wherein access by certain sexual offenders and sexual predators to such zones shall be restricted or excluded. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section and unless the context otherwise requires: 
(1)  Crime against children means any of the following offenses set forth within the Wisconsin Statutes, as amended, or the laws of this or any other state or the federal government, having like elements necessary for conviction and involving a person under the age of 18 years, respectively: 
Wisconsin Statute Sections 
940.225(1) First Degree Sexual Assault; 
940.225(2) Second Degree Sexual Assault; 
940.225(3) Third Degree Sexual Assault; 
940.22(2) Sexual Exploitation by Therapist; 
940.30 False Imprisonment-victim was minor and not the offender's child; 
940.31 Kidnapping-victim was minor and not the offender's child; 
944.01 Rape (prior statute); 
944.06 Incest; 
944.10 Sexual Intercourse with a Child (prior statute); 
944.11 Indecent Behavior with a Child (prior statute); 
944.12 Enticing Child for Immoral Purposes (prior statute); 
948.02(1) First Degree Sexual Assault of a Child; 
948.02(2) Second Degree Sexual Assault of a Child; 
948.025 Engaging in Repeated Acts of Sexual Assault of the Same Child; 
948.05 Sexual Exploitation of a Child; 
948.055 Causing a Child to View or Listen to Sexual Activity; 
948.06 Incest with a Child; 
948.07 Child Enticement; 
948.075 Use of a Computer to Facilitate a Child Sex Crime; 
948.08 Soliciting a Child for Prostitution; 
948.095 Sexual Assault of a Student by School Instructional Staff; 
948.11(2)(a) or (am) Exposing Child to Harmful Material-felony sections; 
948.12 Possession of Child Pornography; 
948.13 Convicted Child Sex Offender Working with Children; 
948.30 Abduction of Another's Child; 
971.17 Not Guilty by Reason of Mental Disease-of an included offense; and 
975.06 Sex Crimes Law Commitment. 
(2)  Facility for children means a public or private school, a group home, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 48.02(7), a residential care center for children and youth, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 48.02(15d), a shelter care facility, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 48.02(17), a foster home, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 48.02(6), a treatment foster home, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 48.02(17q), a daycare center licensed under Wis. Stats. § 48.65, a daycare program established under Wis. Stats. § 120.13(14), a daycare provider certified under Wis. Stats. § 48.651, or a youth center, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 961.01(22). 
(3)  Offender means a person who has been convicted of or has been found delinquent of or has been found not guilty by reason of disease or mental defect of a sexually violent offense and/or a crime against children. 
(4)  Permanent residence means a place where the person sleeps, abides, lodges, or resides for 14 or more consecutive days. 
(5)  Sexually violent offense shall have the meaning as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 980.01(6), as amended from time to time. 
(6)  Temporary residence means residence or premise meeting either of the following criteria: 
a.  A place where the person sleeps, abides, lodges, or resides for a period of 14 or more days in the aggregate during any calendar year and which is not that person's permanent residence as defined in (b)(4) above; or 
b.  A place where the person routinely sleeps, abides, lodges, or resides for a period of four or more consecutive or non-consecutive days in any month and which is not that person's permanent residence as defined in (b)(4) above. 
(c)  Residency restrictions. 
(1)  An offender shall not reside within 1,500 feet of real property that supports or upon which there exists any of the following uses: 
a.  Any facility for children; 
b.  A public park, parkway, parkland, park facility; 
c.  A public swimming pool; 
d.  A public library; 
e.  A recreational trail; 
f.  A public playground; 
g.  A school for children; 
h.  Athletic fields used by children; 
i.  A daycare center; 
j.  Any specialized school for children, including, but not limited to, a gymnastics academy, dance academy or music school; or 
k.  Aquatic facilities open to the public; 
(2)  Measurement of distance. The distance shall be measured from the closest boundary line of the real property supporting the residence of an offender to the closest boundary line of the real property that supports or upon which there exists any of the uses enumerated in (c)(1) above. 
(3)  Residency restriction exceptions. An offender residing within 1,500 feet of real property that supports or upon which there exists any of the uses enumerated in (c)(1) above does not commit a violation of this section if any of the following apply: 
a.  The offender is required to serve a sentence at a jail, prison, juvenile facility, or other correctional institution or facility. 
b.  The offender has established a permanent or temporary residence and reported and registered that residence pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 301.45 prior to the effective date of this section. 
c.  The use enumerated in (c)(1) above began after the offender established a permanent or temporary residence and reported and registered that residence pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 301.45. 
d.  The offender is a minor or ward under guardianship. 
(4)  Original domicile restriction. Subject to (c)(3) above, no offender shall be permitted to reside in the Village of Menomonee Falls, unless that person was domiciled in the Village of Menomonee Falls at the time of the most recent offense giving rise to that person's status as an offender. 
(d)  Child safety zones. 
(1)  No offender shall enter or be present upon any real property that supports or upon which there exists any facility used for or that supports any one or more of the following uses: 
a.  A public park, parkway, parkland, park facility; 
b.  A public swimming pool; 
c.  A public library; 
d.  A recreational trail; 
e.  A public playground; 
f.  A school for children; 
g.  Athletic fields used by children; 
h.  A daycare center; 
i.  Any specialized school for children, including, but not limited to a gymnastics academy, dance academy or music school; 
j.  Aquatic facilities open to the public; or 
k.  Any facility for children. 
(2)  Child safety zone exceptions. An offender does not commit a violation of (d)(1) above, and may be allowed on the property used for or supporting a use enumerated in (d)(1) above if any of the following apply: 
a.  The property used for or supporting a use enumerated in (d)(1) above also supports a church, synagogue, mosque, temple or other house of religious worship (collectively "church"), subject to all of the following conditions: 
1.  The offender's entrance and presence upon the property occurs only during hours of worship or other religious program/service as posted to the public; and 
2.  The offender sends advance written notice to an individual designated by the church to be in charge and receives advance approval from that individual allowing the offender's attendance; and 
3.  The offender shall not participate in any religious education programs which include individuals under the age of 18. 
b.  The property used for or supporting a use enumerated in (d)(1) above also supports a use lawfully attended by an offender's natural or adopted child, which child's use reasonably requires the attendance of the offender as the child's parent upon the property, subject to all of the following conditions: 
1.  The offender's entrance and presence by the offender upon the property occurs only during hours of activity related to the use as posted to the public; and 
2.  The offender sends advance written notice to an individual designated by the property owner to be in charge of the property's enumerated use, and receives advance approval from that individual allowing the offender's attendance. 
c.  The property used for or supporting a use enumerated in (d)(1) above also supports a polling location in a local, state or federal election; subject to all of the following conditions: 
1.  The offender is eligible to vote; 
2.  The designated polling place for the person is an enumerated use; and 
3.  The offender enters the polling place, proceeds to cast a ballot with whatever usual and customary assistance is provided to any member of the electorate, and vacates the property immediately after voting. 
d.  The property used for or supporting a use enumerated in (d)(1) above also supports an elementary or secondary school lawfully attended by an offender as a student, subject to the condition that the offender may only enter upon the property supporting the school at which the person is enrolled for such purposes and at such times as are reasonably required for the educational purposes of the school. 
(e)  Penalties and remedies. 
(1)  Forfeitures. Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to a forfeiture as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offence. Neither the issuance of a citation nor the imposition of forfeiture hereunder shall preclude the village from seeking or obtaining any or all other legal and equitable remedies to prevent or remove a violation of this section. 
(2)  Injunction. 
a.  Violation of residency restrictions. If an offender establishes a permanent or temporary residence in violation of subsection (c) above, the chief of police may refer the matter to the village attorney. The referral shall include a written determination by the chief of police that, upon all of the facts and circumstances and the purpose and intent of this section, such violation interferes substantially with the comfortable enjoyment of life, health, safety of another or others. Upon such referral, the village attorney shall bring an action in the name of the village in circuit court to permanently enjoin such residency as a public nuisance. 
b.  Violation of child safety zones. If an offender violates subsection (d)(1) above more than once in any twelve-month period, the chief of police may refer the matter to the village attorney. The referral shall include a written determination by the chief of police that, upon all of the facts and circumstances and the purpose and intent of this section, such violations interfere substantially with the comfortable enjoyment of life, health, safety of another or others. Upon such referral, the village attorney shall bring an action in the name of the village in circuit court to permanently enjoin such violations as a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 380-O-07, § 1, 6-18-07) 
Secs. 62-52-62-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIREWORKS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46. 
State Law reference- Fireworks, Wis. Stats. § 167.10; local regulation of fireworks, Wis. Stats. § 167.10(5). 

Sec. 62-66. - Fireworks defined. 
    Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 167.10(5)(a)1, the term "fireworks" shall be defined as including all items under Wis. Stats. § 167.10(1) (Intro.) and including all items under Wis. Stats. § 167.10(1)(k)-(1)(n). The terms "caps," "toy snakes" and "sparklers," as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 167.10(1)(e), (f) and (i) are excluded from this definition. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(5)(b)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 62-67. - Regulation; state law adopted. 
    The provisions of Wis. Stats. § 167.10 are hereby adopted and incorporated in this division by reference insofar as they are not in conflict with the remainder of this division. In the event of any conflict between this division and this state statute, whichever provision is stricter shall apply. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(5)(a)) 
Sec. 62-68. - Sales. 
    No person shall sell, offer to sell, possess with the intent to sell, or give away fireworks within the village. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(5)(c)) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit sale of fireworks, Wis. Stats. § 167.10(5)(a)2. 
Sec. 62-69. - Use regulated. 
    Except as provided in Wis. Stats. § 167.10(3), no person shall possess, offer to sell or use fireworks without a user's permit issued pursuant to section 62-70. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(5)(d)) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit possession or use of fireworks, Wis. Stats. § 167.10(5)(a)3. 
Sec. 62-70. - User's permit. 
(a)  As provided in Wis. Stats. § 167.10(3), user's permits may be issued for festivals, public or private celebrations after proper application to the village board on forms provided by the village clerk-treasurer. The fee for a user's permit shall be $100.00. The permit application must be received by the village clerk-treasurer not less than 45 days prior to the requested date of use. 
(b)  All applications shall be referred to the fire chief for investigation, and no permit shall be granted unless the village board, from the report of the fire chief, determines that the applicant will use the fireworks in a public or private exhibition, and that all reasonable precautions will be exercised with regard to the protection of the lives and property of all persons and that the display will be handled by a competent operator and conducted in a suitable, safe place and manner. Before granting any fireworks permit, the applicant shall file with the village clerk-treasurer a certificate of liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to write such policies in the state, in the amount of $1,000,000.00 for bodily injury to any one person, in the amount of $5,000,000.00 for injury to more than one person, and in the amount of $2,000,000.00 for damage to property that may arise by reason of use or discharge of fireworks under the permit. The village shall be named as one of the assureds in such policy of insurance. 
(c)  A permit under this section shall specify all of the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the permit holder. 
(2)  The date on and after which fireworks may be purchased. 
(3)  The kind and quantity of fireworks which may be purchased. 
(4)  The date, time and location of permitted use. 
(5)  Other special conditions prescribed by ordinance. 
(6)  Such other information as the village may require from time to time. 
A notice of such permit under this section shall be given to the municipal fire and law enforcement official at least seven days before the date of authorized use. A permit under this section may not be issued to a person under 18 years of age. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(5)(e)) 
State Law reference- Permit, Wis. Stats. § 167.10(3). 
Sec. 62-71. - Use of caps, snakes, sparklers. 
    No unauthorized person may use fireworks, caps, snakes or sparklers at a fireworks display for which a permit has been issued if the display is open to the general public. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(5)(f)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 167.10(3)(a). 
Sec. 62-72. - Storage of fireworks. 
    Storage and handling of fireworks shall be pursuant to the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 167.10(6) and chapter 46 of this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(5)(g)) 
Secs. 62-73-62-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WEAPONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Weapons generally, Wis. Stats. § 941.20 et seq.; local regulation of firearms, Wis. Stats. § 66.092. 

Sec. 62-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Knife means any instrument composed of a blade fixed into a handle, and shall include, without limitation for lack of enumeration, any utility knife, pocket knife, hunting knife, dagger, switchblade, butterfly knife, machete, razor, and other similar equipment capable of being used to cut material. 
    Weapons means and includes all instruments and devices used for the purpose of propelling bullets, shot, arrows or other missiles, either by explosion, compression, tension, gas, spring or any other means, and shall include, without limitation for lack of specific enumeration, all forms of guns, rifles, air rifles and air guns, revolvers, bows and arrows, slingshots and other similar type of equipment or device capable of propelling such bullets, shot, arrows or missiles through the air by reason of discharge therefrom. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(2)(a); Ord. No. 663-O-16, § 1, 4-4-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 62-87. - Possession or carrying a weapon or knife in village buildings prohibited. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (b) below, any person who enters or remains in any building or any part of a building that is owned, occupied or controlled by the Village of Menomonee Falls, or any of its departments, authorities or commissions while possessing or carrying a weapon or knife is guilty of trespassing in violation of this section. 
(b)  Subsection (a) does not apply to the following persons or in the following circumstances: 
(1)  The person leases residential or business premises in the subject building; 
(2)  The person is a duly authorized law enforcement officer; 
(3)  The building is not posted in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 943.13(2)(bm)2.a. 
(4)  A member of the board of trustees who meets the qualifications set forth in subsection a. below as certified by the chief of police pursuant to subsection b. below, and who enters or remains in a building for the purpose of attending a meeting of the board of trustees or committee thereof, or a meeting of the plan commission. 
a.  Required qualifications. To qualify for this exception, the person must meet all of the following: 
1.  Be a current member of the Village of Menomonee Falls Board of Trustees; 
2.  Meet the standards for qualification in firearms training for active law enforcement officers in the state by a certified firearms instructor qualified to conduct a firearm qualification test for active law enforcement officers; and 
3.  Possesses a valid Wisconsin carrying concealed weapon license. 
b.  Certification by the chief of police. 
1.  A person meeting the required qualifications set out above may apply to the chief of police for an exception under this paragraph. The applicant shall file with the application documentation concerning at least the following: 
i.  The type of weapon the applicant is authorized to carry; 
ii.  Documentation showing that the applicant has been found to meet the standards for qualification in firearms training for active law enforcement officers in the state by a certified firearms instructor qualified to conduct a firearm qualification test for active law enforcement officers; and 
iii.  The applicant's Wisconsin carrying concealed weapon license number. 
2.  The police department shall review the application and shall confirm the accuracy of the information contained in the application and any supporting materials filed with the application. If the information is found to be accurate, the chief of police shall certify in writing that the person meets the requirements of this exception. This certification expires either one year from the date of issuance or when the person's term on the board of trustees expires, whichever is earlier. 
(5)  An employee of the village or a contractor of the village carrying a utility knife for the purpose of job-related duties. 
(c)  As used in this section, building means all buildings or any part thereof that are owned or leased by and under the control of the Village of Menomonee Falls; except those buildings or structures located in village parks. 
(Ord. No. 523-O-11, § 1, 12-19-11; Ord. No. 663-O-16, §§ 2, 3, 4-4-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 523-O-11, § 1, adopted Dec. 19, 2011, amended § 62-87 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 62-87 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1963, § 10.02(2)(b); Ord. No. 13-O-98, § 1, adopted July 20, 1998. 
State Law reference- Carrying concealed weapon, Wis. Stats. § 941.23. 
Sec. 62-88. - Prohibited discharge. 
    Subject to Wis. Stats. § 66.0409(3)(b), no person shall fire, discharge or use any weapon as defined in section 62-86 at any time or place within the village except as follows: 
(1)  A duly authorized peace officer in the performance of duty. 
(2)  On a rifle, pistol, trap, skeet or archery range authorized by the village board. 
(3)  The discharge of blank cartridges in a firearm suitable for their safe use when utilized as a starting signal device at competitive events, or as a prop in a stage performance, or as a gun salute as a special function at a parade, funeral or other ceremonial occasion. 
(4)  The use of a weapon for hunting game birds and animals under licenses issued by the state department of natural resources pursuant to Wis. Stats. §§ 29.573, 29.574. 
(5)  The discharge of a firearm as defined by Wis. Stats. § 167.31(1)(c), or bow and arrow under a valid permit pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 29.885 and issued by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources under Administrative Code Chapter NR 12 regarding wildlife damage and nuisance control. The discharge of a firearm will be limited to sharpshooters designated and authorized by the chief of police, under a firearm discharge permit for the village. The chief of police is authorized to promulgate guidelines for the purpose of ensuring the public peace and safety. Guidelines to ensure public safety may include; demonstrated proficiency with the firearm to be discharged, direction and trajectory of bullets, type and caliber of firearm, and minimum distances from buildings or other designated zones such as parks, schools, hospitals, or other locations. Limitations on the discharge of a firearm under this section will be specified on the village permit authorizing the discharge. 
(6)  The discharge of blank cartridges in a firearm suitable for their safe use when utilized in connection with the training of hunting dogs under a license issued by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources pursuant to Wisconsin Statutes § 169.20. 
(7)  The county park and planning commission may establish archery ranges in village or county parks which would otherwise be in violation of this section. 
(8)  Except as provided in this division, this section shall apply to county parks lying within the village. 
(9)  The use of a weapon for hunting game birds and animals in compliance with the remainder of this division 3 and Chapter NR 10 of the Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
(10)  A person acting in self-defense consistent with Wis. Stats. § 939.48. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(2)(c); Ord. No. 13-O-98, § 2, 7-20-98; Ord. No. 283-O-04, §§ 1a, 1b, 10-4-04; Ord. No. 284-O-04, §§ 1a, 1b, 10-18-04; Ord. No. 524-O-11, § 1, 12-19-11; Ord. No. 571-O-13, § 1, 10-21-13; Ord. No. 592-O-14, § 1, 7-7-14) 
State Law reference- Endangering safety by use of dangerous weapons, Wis. Stats. § 941.20. 
Sec. 62-89. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 524-O-11, § 2, adopted Dec. 19, 2011, repealed § 62-89 in its entirety. Former § 62-89 pertained to possession of knives prohibited; exceptions and derived from Ord. No. 28-O-98, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1998. 
Sec. 62-90. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 524-O-11, § 3, adopted Dec. 19, 2011, repealed § 62-90 in its entirety. Former § 62-90 pertained to possession of dangerous weapons and derived from Ord. No. 28-O-98, § 2, adopted Dec. 7, 1998. 
Sec. 62-91. - Use of shotgun or bow and arrow. 
    Except as provided in subsections (2) and (3) of this section, a person may carry and discharge a shotgun or bow and arrow for the purpose of hunting upland birds, waterfowl, small game animals and deer under regulations established by the state department of natural resources, provided that such person has a valid hunting license, stamps and permits issued by the state department of natural resources, and subject to the conditions set forth in subsections (1) and (2) of this section. The use of rifles for hunting within the village is prohibited. Hunting within the village shall be limited to bow, shotguns, crossbows, muzzleloaders, handguns and rimfire rifle use only. 
(1)  Any person engaged in hunting with a shotgun, muzzleloader, handgun or rimfire rifle shall have in that person's possession at all times a registered permit signed by the owner of the land granting such person the privilege to be on the land for hunting purposes. This registered permit shall be on a form provided by the village, and available at the office of the village manager or the police department. 
(2)  No discharge of firearms shall be allowed on any land lying within platted subdivision or any land which is less than five acres in area. No firearm may be discharged within 500 feet of any building, public street, road or highway, nor shall the shot propelled by the discharge be permitted to pass upon the premises of another or upon the public highways or other public grounds. No discharge is permitted on any of the following land: 
All that part of Town 8 North, Range 20 East, Village of Menomonee Falls, Waukesha County, Wisconsin, described as follows: Section 1; Section 2; Section 3; Section 4; all the platted lands in the Northwest one-quarter of Section 5; the Northwest one-quarter and Northeast one-quarter of the Southeast one-quarter of Section 6; the Northwest one-quarter, Northeast one-quarter and Southeast one-quarter of Section 9; the East one-half of the East one-half of the West one-half and the East one-half of the Southwest one-forth of Section 9; all of Section 10, except the Southwest one-quarter of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 10; Section 11; Section 12; Section 13; Section 14; the Northeast one-quarter and Southeast one-quarter of Section 15; the North one-half of the Northeast one-quarter of the Northwest one-quarter of Section 15; the Southeast one-quarter of the Northwest one-quarter of Section 15; the Northeast one-quarter of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 15; the East 30 acres of the Southeast one-quarter of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 15; the Northwest one-quarter, Northeast one-quarter, and the Southeast one-quarter of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 16; the Northeast one-quarter of the Southeast one-quarter of Section 16; all the lands in Section 18 in the Village of Menomonee Falls; all the lands in the Northeast one-quarter of Section 19 in the Village of Menomonee Falls; all the Willow Springs School lands in the Northwest one-quarter of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 19; the South one-half of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 19; all the lands in the Northwest one-quarter of Section 20 in the Village of Menomonee Falls; the Northwest one-quarter of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 20; the East 30 acres of the Southeast one-quarter of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 20; the Northeast one-quarter of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 21 except the Northwest ten acres; the West one-half of the East one-half of Section 21; the West one-half of the Northeast one-quarter and West one-half of the East one-half of the Southeast one-quarter of the Southeast one-quarter of Section 21; all the lands owned by the Village of Menomonee Falls in the Northwest one-quarter of the Southeast one-quarter of Section 21; the West one-half of the West one-half of the Northwest one-quarter of Section 22; the East one-half of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 22; the South ten acres of the Southwest one-quarter of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 22; the Southeast one-quarter of Section 22; the West one-half of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 22; the South one-half of the Southeast one-quarter of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 22; Section 23; Section 24; Section 25; Section 26; the Northwest one-quarter, Southwest one-quarter and the Southeast one-quarter of the Northwest one-quarter of Section 27; the East 20 acres of the Northwest one-quarter of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 27; the Southwest one-quarter of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 27, except the Northwest ten acres; the Southwest one-quarter and Southeast one-quarter of Section 27; the East ten acres of the Northeast one-quarter of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 28; all of the lands owned by the Village of Menomonee Falls in the North one-half of the Southeast one-quarter of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 28; all of the lands owned by the Village of Menomonee Falls in the West one-half of the Northeast one-fourth of Section 28; the South one-half of the South one-half of the Northeast one-fourth of Section 28; the East one-half of the Southwest one-quarter of Section 28; the Southeast one-quarter of Section 28; the Northeast one-quarter of the Northwest one-quarter of Section 30; all the lands North of the Union Pacific Railroad right-of-way in the Northwest one-quarter of the Northwest one-quarter of Section 30; the Southeast two acres of the Southeast one-quarter of the Southeast one-quarter of the Northwest one-quarter of Section 30; all the lands South of the Union Pacific Railroad right-of-way in the Northeast one-quarter of Section 30; the South one-half of Section 30; all platted lands in the Northwest one-quarter of Section 31; all the lands of the Waukesha County Wanaki Golf Course in Section 31; all platted lands in the Southeast one-quarter of Section 32; the Southeast one-quarter of Section 33; the Northeast one-quarter of Section 33; the East one-half of the Southeast one-quarter of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 33; the South one-half of the South one-half of the Southwest one-quarter of the Northeast one-quarter of Section 33; all Marcy School lands in the Southwest one-quarter of Section 33; Section 34; Section 35; all the lands in Section 36 in the Village of Menomonee Falls. 
(3)  No person may hunt with a bow and arrow within the village on land within 100 yards of a building that is used for human occupancy and is located on another person's property. This restriction shall not apply if the person who owns the land on which the building is located allows the hunter to hunt within 100 yards of the building. All persons hunting with a bow and arrow or crossbow within the village must discharge the arrow or bolt from the respective weapon toward the ground. 
(4)  Exceptions. The chief of police may grant exceptions to the restrictions of subsection (2) and allow the discharge of firearms in the areas affected by that subsection. A landowner may apply for an exception upon forms created by the police department. The application forms shall request such information as the chief of police deems appropriate. The chief may grant an exception under this paragraph for a limited time period upon a finding that the discharge of firearms on the particular land and under the circumstances set out in the application can be conducted with due regard for the safety of persons on neighboring properties and for the safety of the general public. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(2)(f); Ord. No. 894-97, § 1, 9-15-997; Ord. No. 147-O-01, 9-4-01; Ord. No. 283-O-04, §§ 2a, 2b, 10-4-04; Ord. No. 284-O-04, §§ 2a, 2b, 10-18-04; Ord. No. 287-O-04, § 1, 11-1-04; Ord. No. 318-O-05, §§ 1-5, 9-6-05; Ord. No. 498-O-10, §§ 1, 2, 11-15-10; Ord. No. 571-O-13, § 1, 10-21-13; Ord. No. 592-O-14, §§ 2, 3, 7-7-14) 
Sec. 62-92. - Shooting bow and arrow; throwing missiles. 
(a)  Throwing of missiles. No person shall throw, shoot or propel by hand or other means any missile at any person, vehicle, building, animal or bird, nor at or into any street, sidewalk, alley, highway, park, playground or other public place within the village. A missile, as used in this section, means without limitation for lack of enumeration, such objects as arrows, stones, snowballs, ice, eggs, apples, tomatoes, pumpkins and other such objects. 
(b)  Exceptions. Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  Any supervised bow and arrow range authorized by the village board of trustees. 
(2)  The village recreation department may, under proper supervision, conduct programs which would otherwise be in violation of this section. 
(3)  To any person engaged in hunting as provided in section 62-91. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(3)) 
Sec. 62-93. - Possession or use by minors. 
(a)  No person shall sell, give, loan or transfer any weapon as defined in section 62-86 or ammunition therefor, to a minor, except when such weapon is being used in target practice on a supervised range. 
(b)  No person under the age of 18 years shall have in his possession a weapon as defined in section 62-86 nor any ammunition therefor. This subsection shall not apply to anyone under 18 years of age who is armed with a weapon under the supervision of an adult when such weapon is being used in target practice on a range licensed under the provisions of section 62-88 or to any person engaged in hunting as provided in section 62-91. 
(Code 1963, § 10.02(2)(d), (2)(e)) 
State Law reference- Dangerous weapons and minors, Wis. Stats. § 948.60. 
Secs. 62-94-62-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC PEACE, ORDER AND MORALS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes against public peace and order, Wis. Stats. ch. 947. 

Sec. 62-116. - Noise. 
(a)  No person shall cause, suffer or allow any loud, excessive or unusual noise in the operation or use of any radio, phonograph or other mechanical or electrical device, instrument or machine within the village which loud, excessive or unusual noise shall disturb the comfort, quiet or repose of persons in the area or in the vicinity. 
(b)  No person occupying or having charge of any building or premises or any part of any building or premises within the village shall do any of the following: 
(1)  Make or assist in making any noise tending to unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of persons in the vicinity, unless the making or continuing of such noise cannot be prevented or is necessary for the protection or preservation of property or of the health, safety, life or limb of some person. 
(2)  Keep or allow to be kept any animal or bird which shall habitually, by any noise, disturb the peace and quiet of any person in the vicinity. 
(3)  Suffer or allow any loud, excessive or unusual noise in the operation or use of any radio, phonograph or other mechanical or electrical device, instrument or machine which loud, excessive or unusual noise shall disturb the comfort, quiet or repose of persons in the area or in the vicinity. 
(Code 1963, § 10.03(2)) 
State Law reference- Authority to so provide, Wis. Stats. § 66.051(1)(c). 
Sec. 62-117. - Obstructing streets and sidewalks. 
    No person shall walk, march, stand, sit, loaf or loiter or engage in any sport or exercise on any public street, sidewalk, bridge or public ground within the village in such manner as to prevent or obstruct the free passage of pedestrian or vehicular traffic thereon or to prevent or hinder free and lawful ingress or egress to or from any private property, residence or place of abode, business or amusement, church, public hall or meeting place. 
(Code 1963, § 10.03(4)) 
Sec. 62-118. - Public drinking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be in possession of any open glass or other container containing a fermented malt beverage, wine or intoxicating liquor of any kind, or to drink any such beverages, whether in or out of a vehicle, in any of the following places: 
(1)  Any village-owned or village-controlled parking lot; 
(2)  Any village park or recreation area, except in areas where such consumption or possession is specifically authorized in a park usage permit, or at any event, or in any area for which a temporary picnic fermented malt beverage license has been issued; 
(3)  Any public street, highway, alley, sidewalk or other similar place in the village; 
(4)  Any privately owned parking lot, driveway or lot used for vehicular traffic with the express or implied permission of the owner for public use, unless expressly authorized in writing by the owner; 
(5)  Any grounds under the control of a public school district; and the grounds of any privately owned and operated school, church, hospital or other institution frequented by the public, unless expressly authorized in writing by the owner. 
(Code 1963, § 10.03(5)) 
Cross reference- Alcohol beverages, ch. 6. 
State Law reference- Intoxicants in motor vehicles, Wis. Stats. § 346.935. 
Sec. 62-119. - Loitering. 
    A person commits a violation if he loiters or prowls in a place, at a time or in a manner not usual for law abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant alarm for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such alarm is warranted, is the fact that the actor takes flight on appearance of a peace officer, refuses to identify himself or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the actor or other circumstances make it impractical, a peace officer shall, prior to any arrest or an offense under this section, afford the actor an opportunity to dispel any alarm which would otherwise be warranted, by requesting him to identify himself and explain his presence or conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the police officer did not comply with the preceding sentence, or if it appears at trial that the explanation given the actor was true and if believed by the peace officer at the time, would have dispelled the alarm. 
(Code 1963, § 10.05(2)) 
Sec. 62-120. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Minor means any person under the age of 17 years. 
    Public place mean any and all public streets, sidewalks, highways, roads, alleys, parks, parking lots held open to the public, public buildings, places of amusement or entertainment, places of employment, vacant lots, or any public area, or any building structure, premise or land held open to the public. 
    Other appropriate adult means an adult to whom the minor's parent or guardian has expressly entrusted the minor's temporary care, custody or control. Such adult must have in his possession written proof that the parent or guardian of such minor has expressly entrusted that adult with the specifically identified minor's temporary care, custody or control. 
(b)  Imposed; hours; exceptions. No minor shall congregate, loiter, wander, stroll, stand or play in or upon any public place within the village, either on foot or in or upon any conveyance being driven or parked thereon, between 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  When the minor is accompanied by such minor's parent, guardian or other appropriate adult. 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by such minor's parent or guardian or other appropriate adult person. 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity or dance. 
(4)  When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the places referenced in this section during the proscribed period of time. 
(5)  When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion. 
(6)  When the minor is engaged in interstate travel with the consent of parent, guardian or other appropriate adult. 
(c)  Parental responsibility. No parent, guardian or other appropriate adult shall suffer, permit or, by inefficient control, allow a minor under that person's care, custody or control to engage in any of the acts set out in subsection (b) of this section; provided, however, that any parent, guardian or other appropriate adult who shall have made a missing person notification to the police department shall not be considered to have suffered or permitted any minor to be in violation of this section. 
(d)  Responsibility of operators of places of amusement or establishments open to the public. No person operating either a place of amusement or entertainment, or any other place open to the public, or any agent, servant or employee of such person, shall permit any minor to enter or loiter in such places in violation of subsection (b) of this section, unless such person is accompanied by his parent, guardian or some other appropriate adult. 
(Code 1963, § 10.04(2)) 
Sec. 62-121. - Public obscene language and sexual conduct. 
(a)  Prohibited acts. No person shall, in any public place, use any obscene language or engage in sexual conduct within the village. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Language means words or sounds or gestures or any combination thereof. 
    Obscene means language which taken as a whole: 
(1)  Appeals to prurient interest in sex; 
(2)  Portrays sexual conduct in a patently offensive way; and 
(3)  Does not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
    Sexual conduct means acts of sexual intercourse between humans, normal or perverted, actual or simulated; acts of masturbation, fellatio, cunnilingus; and acts of excretory function, lewd exhibition of the genitals especially in a stimulated condition and sexual relations between humans and animals. 
(Code 1963, § 10.03(7)) 
State Law reference- Municipality prohibited from punishing obscenity, Wis. Stats. § 66.051(3). 
Sec. 62-122. - Prolonged running of motor vehicle engines prohibited. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (b), no person shall allow the engine of any motor vehicle or refrigeration units associated with such motor vehicle to operate for more than five minutes between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. while located within 300 feet of an area zoned or used for residential purposes. 
(b)  Exceptions. This section does not apply to the following motor vehicles: 
(1)  Motor vehicles with a gross weight of less than 6,000 pounds; 
(2)  Police, fire, rescue, public works or other similar state or local government vehicles when such vehicles are performing or are in use for official functions. 
(3)  Motor vehicles responding to or needed for public safety emergencies. 
(4)  Buses or other similar vehicles of mass transit. 
(5)  Motor vehicles safely operating partially or wholly inside a structure. 
(6)  Motor vehicles needed for or responding to weather related emergencies. 
(7)  Motor vehicles not falling within another exception that are used for snow plowing. 
(Ord. No. 201-O-02, § 1, 8-19-02; Ord. No. 453-O-09, § 1, 7-6-09) 
Chapter 66 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 38; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; vegetation, ch. 114. 
State Law reference- General authority relative to parks, Wis. Stats. §§ 27.13, 61.36. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Board of park commissioners established. 
    There shall be a board of park commissioners. 
(Code 1963, § 1.03) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and authorities, § 2-211 et seq. 
Sec. 66-2. - Membership. 
    The board of park commissioners shall consist of seven members, including one trustee appointed annually by the village board and six citizen members who are village residents appointed by the village president, subject to confirmation by the village board, for terms of three years. The terms of the citizen members shall be staggered so that two such members are appointed each year. 
(Code 1963, § 1.03(4)(a)) 
Sec. 66-3. - Powers and duties. 
    The board of park commissioners shall have only such powers and duties as shall be delegated to it and prescribed from time to time by resolution adopted by the village board. It shall be an advisory body to the village board and village manager. 
(Code 1963, § 1.03(4)(b)) 
Secs. 66-4-66-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC CONDUCT IN PARKS AND PARKWAYS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Park and parkway means, unless otherwise stated, the grounds, buildings thereon, waters therein and any other property which is now or may hereafter be designated "parklands" by the village board. 
    Pet fair means a free to the public event that is sponsored and organized by a nonprofit organization for the purpose of educating the public about the adoption and care of domestic animals and rehabilitation of wild animals. 
(Code 1963, § 19.02; Ord. No. 667-O-16, § 1, 6-6-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-22. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article shall be to protect, in the village, the parks and parkways and appurtenances thereto from fire, abuse and desecration; to provide for the recreational use of these areas; to control and regulate traffic and maintain general order therein; and to further the safety, health, comfort, morals and welfare of all persons while within the limits of the parks and parkways. 
(Code 1963, § 19.01) 
Sec. 66-23. - Police powers. 
    Any peace officer having jurisdiction may without a warrant arrest any offender whom he may detect in a violation of any of the provisions of this article, and take the person so arrested forthwith before a magistrate having competent jurisdiction, and he shall have, at all times, the right to enter the premises of any building, structure or enclosure in any park or parkway, including such grounds, buildings, structures or enclosures which may be leased or set aside for private or exclusive use of any individuals, for the purpose of arresting violators of this article, and may use all necessary means to attain that end. 
(Code 1963, § 19.09) 
Sec. 66-24. - Park closing hours. 
(a)  Parks shall be closed and park activities terminated at one-half hour after sunset each night, except lighted athletic areas which may remain open until 11:00 p.m., and no person shall enter or remain therein until 6.00 a.m. of the next day, except as provided in this section. 
(b)  On the nights of July 3 and 4, the closing hour shall be midnight. 
(c)  When signs are posted at the entrances to any park indicating different and specified hours during which that park shall be closed. 
(d)  In an emergency, the police department is authorized to close any park at any other hour in furtherance of the public peace and safety, and to keep such park closed so long as the emergency continues. 
(Code 1963, § 19.03(1)) 
Sec. 66-25. - Disorderly conduct. 
    No person shall, within any village park: 
(1)  Intentionally cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl, riot or noisy altercation. 
(2)  In any manner unreasonably disturb, harass or interfere with any person, nor with the equipment or property of such person, within any park. 
(Code 1963, § 19.03(2)) 
Sec. 66-26. - Smoking. 
    No person shall be permitted to smoke or to hold a lighted cigarette, cigar or pipe in any building, or section of a building, or in any park or parkway area where officially posted notices so prohibit. 
(Code 1963, § 19.03(3)) 
State Law reference- Smoking in buildings, Wis. Stats. § 101.123. 
Sec. 66-27. - Care of waste. 
    No person shall scatter, drop or leave any rubbish, garbage or litter in any portion of the parks or parkways except in the receptacles provided for that purpose. Any person who breaks a bottle or other glassware in any park or parkway shall immediately pick up the broken pieces and remove the same to a park waste container. 
(Code 1963, § 19.03(4)) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Littering, Wis. Stats. § 287.81. 
Sec. 66-28. - Radios and televisions; loudness. 
    Auto radios, phonographs, recorders, radios and television sets must be turned low at all times so as not to be heard from a distance beyond 20 feet from the instrument. 
(Code 1963, § 19.03(5)) 
Sec. 66-29. - Games and amusements in designated areas. 
    No person shall engage in any sport, game, race or amusement in any park or parkway except upon such portions thereof as may be designated for that purpose, and then only under such rules and regulations as may be established by the village. 
(Code 1963, § 19.03(6)) 
Sec. 66-30. - Throwing of stones or missiles. 
    No person shall throw stones or missiles in or into any park or parkway. 
(Code 1963, § 19.03(8)) 
Sec. 66-31. - Making of fires. 
    No person shall make or kindle a fire for any purpose except in places provided therefor, and then subject to such regulations as may be prescribed. The use of charcoal burners in designated picnic areas shall be permitted, provided that lawns and other vegetation are not damaged, and provided further that all unburned coal or ash are disposed of in such manner as to prevent fire or damage to any park property. 
(Code 1963, § 19.03(9)) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46. 
Sec. 66-32. - Animals. 
(a)  Domestic animals generally. Except for those animals placed in the park or parkways by the village, or as otherwise provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, no domestic animal shall be permitted within the parks or parkways or be allowed to remain therein. 
(b)  Dogs on leash; when excluded. No person having the control or care of a dog shall permit such dog to enter or remain in a public park or parkway unless it is led by a leash of suitable strength and not more than six feet in length, and then only within such areas in parks as have been designated by order of the park board. The park board shall cause signs to be posted in areas wherein dogs or cats are not permitted. Section 14-28 of this Code shall also apply to dogs in public parks and parkways under this section. 
(c)  Pet fairs. Animals placed into a public or parkway by organizations participating in a pet fair, as defined in section 66-21, provided that such animals are limited to and contained in areas designated for the pet fair and approved by the village manager or the village manager's designee. 
(Code 1963, § 10.03(10); Ord. No. 881-97, § 1, 6-16-1997; Ord. No. 667-O-16, §§ 2, 3, 6-6-16) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 
Sec. 66-33. - Waterfowl; game birds. 
    No one shall kill, injure or attempt to injure, or unnecessarily disturb any waterfowl or other birds or animals, wild or domestic, within any of the parks or parkways. Nor shall any person rob or disturb the nest or eggs of any bird or other animal therein. 
(Code 1963, § 19.03(11)) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 
Sec. 66-34. - Injury to vegetation, structures and equipment. 
(a)  No person shall climb any tree, or pluck any flowers or fruit, wild or cultivated, or break, cut down, trample upon, remove, or in any manner injure or deface, write upon, defile or ill use any tree, shrub, flower, flower bed, turf, fountain, ornament, statue, building, structure, fence apparatus, bench, table, official notice, sign, bridge or other property within any park or parkway.
