    An owner of vacant property that is determined to be in violation of a provision of this chapter shall provide local contact information to the village of any individual/s or restoration company that the owner has directed to bring the vacant property into compliance. 
(Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 7(Exh. A), 10-1-18) 
Secs. 71-103-71-109. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - PERSONAL PROPERTY 

Sec. 71-110. - Purpose and intent. 
    This article regulates the manner in which personal property is stored on private property in the village. Personal property that is stored in a manner that is inconsistent with this article constitutes a blighting factor that adversely affects surrounding property values, health safety and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 7(Exh. A), 10-1-18) 
Sec. 71-111. - Prohibited generally. 
    Unless explicitly permitted by chapter 122, no person shall allow personal property to accumulate on private property in the village in a manner that is unnecessary, unorganized, unsightly, or otherwise undesirable. 
(Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 7(Exh. A), 10-1-18) 
Sec. 71-112. - Rubbish and debris. 
    Personal property that the owner intends to throw away, give away, sell or otherwise discard shall not be stored in an area of the property visible to the public for more than five consecutive days. The property shall be stored in a manner that does not harm any vegetation on the property or prevent compliance with any other provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 7(Exh. A), 10-1-18) 
Sec. 71-113. - Firewood. 
    Firewood shall be cut, split and stored in a stacked and orderly manner and in a dry location so as not to attract rodents or vermin. 
(Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 7(Exh. A), 10-1-18) 
Sec. 71-114. - Motor vehicles. 
(a)  Unlicensed or inoperable vehicles. No person shall store an unlicensed or inoperable vehicle on private property in the village in a manner that is visible to the public or neighboring private property owners. Unlicensed or inoperable vehicles must also be stored on a paved surface and in a secure manner. 
(b)  Licensed and operable vehicles. No person may store a licensed and operable vehicle on private property in the village in a manner that constitutes blight. Vehicles shall be maintained and kept in a secure and clean condition. 
(Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 7(Exh. A), 10-1-18) 
Sec. 71-115. - Commercial and industrial material. 
    Unless explicitly permitted by chapter 122, no person shall store equipment and materials relating to a commercial or industrial use in a manner that is visible to the public. 
(Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 7(Exh. A), 10-1-18) 
Sec. 71-116. - Construction sites. 
    The property owners and the prime contractors in charge of a construction site shall maintain the construction site in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried from the premises by the elements. All litter from construction activities or any related activities shall be picked up at the end of each workday and placed in containers which will prevent litter from being carried from the premises by the elements. 
(Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 7(Exh. A), 10-1-18) 
Chapter 72 - PROTECTIVE SERVICES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 72-1-72-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROTECTIVE SERVICES DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 72-21. - Department created. 
    The Department of Protective Services for the Village of Menomonee Falls is hereby created pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 61.66(1)(a). 
Sec. 72-22. - Organization of the department of protective services. 
(a)  The department of protective services shall consist of a police services division, to be known as the village police department, and which is organized under chapter 54 of the Municipal Code; a fire services division, to be known as the village fire department, and which is organized under chapter 46 of the Municipal Code; and such other divisions as determined by the village manager under section 2-87. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the department of protective services to oversee the Police Department and Fire Department of the Village of Menomonee Falls; and of and such other divisions as the village manager may from time to time determine under section 2-87. 
(c)  The department shall have the power to perform any duty currently assigned to the fire department or police department by the Municipal Code that is not required by the Wisconsin Statutes to be exclusively performed by the chief of police or fire chief; and to assign such duties to other divisions as may be created from time to time by the village manager under section 2-87. 
(Ord. No. 529-O-12, § 1, 2-20-12) 
Sec. 72-23. - Director of protective services. 
(a)  Appointment. 
(1)  The appointment of the director of the department of protective services shall be by the board of the police and fire commissioners pursuant to this section. 
(2)  The village manager shall submit a recommendation to the board of police and fire commissioners. The board of police and fire commissioners may appoint the recommended person or decline to appoint the recommended person. If the board of police and fire commissioners declines to appoint the recommended person, it shall notify the village manager and the village manager shall make another recommendation. 
(3)  Director may also hold fire chief or chief of police position. The director of protective services may hold the title of chief of police or fire chief at the same time that person also holds the position of director of protective services, provided the individual is otherwise qualified, but the director of protective services may not be both chief of police and fire chief at the same time. 
(4)  Director may also hold an assistant village manager position. If so appointed by the village manager under section 2-88, the director of protective services may hold a position as an assistant village manager at the same time that person also holds the position of director of protective services. 
(b)  Duties and responsibilities. The director of protective services shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  The director of protective services shall organize, supervise, direct, and manage the department of protective services and its constituent divisions. 
(2)  The director of protective services shall supervise and direct the activities and operations of the chief of police and fire chief. 
(3)  The director of protective services shall prescribe rules and regulations as are necessary to accomplish the good government of the department of protective services, the police department, the fire department and such other divisions of the department of protective services as may be created from time to time. 
(4)  The director of protective services may also take such disciplinary action against subordinates in any of the divisions of the department of protective services as the director shall deem necessary. If the subordinate is subject to the jurisdiction of the board of police and fire commissioners, the director is also authorized to file charges against such subordinates with the board of police and fire commissioners in such cases as the director deems appropriate. 
(5)  If the director of protective services is also the appointed chief of police or fire chief as authorized by subsection 72-3(a)(3) above, the director may take any action or perform any duty currently assigned to that position under the Municipal Code and the Wisconsin Statutes. 
(6)  Absence of director of protective services. Whenever the director of protective services shall be out of the village, or unable to act on account of sickness or any other reason, the director of protective services shall designate in writing a member of the protective services department who shall have and exercise all the powers and duties of the director of protective services. 
(7)  The director of the department of protective services shall also have such other duties, authority and responsibilities as may be assigned from time to time by the village manager. 
(c)  Limitation on authority. The director of protective services, serving as such, shall have no authority to take any action exclusively delegated by the Wisconsin Statutes either to the position of chief of police or to the position of fire chief or reassign any such duties to the position of director of protective services. 
(Ord. No. 529-O-12, § 1, 2-20-12) 
Secs. 72-24-72-29. - Reserved. 
Sec. 72-30. - Emergency medical services fees. 
(a)  The fees as established in section 42-72 shall be charged for persons who are transported by village protective services ambulances or who receive other emergency medical services on scene from protective services department personnel. 
(b)  The village clerk is authorized to collect such fees based on information provided by the village protective services department. 
(Ord. No. 639-O-15, § 2, 12-7-15) 
Chapter 74 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PAWNBROKERS, SECONDHAND ARTICLE AND SECONDHAND JEWELRY DEALERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, secondhand article and secondhand jewelry dealers, Wis. Stats. § 134.71; local ordinances on same, Wis. Stats. § 134.71(14). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-21. - Adoption of state law provisions. 
    The village hereby adopts and incorporates by reference the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 134.71. 
(Code 1963, § 9.13(1)) 
Sec. 74-22. - Penalties for violation of article. 
(a)  Upon conviction for a first offense under this article, a person shall forfeit not less than $50.00, nor more than $1,000.00. 
(b)  Upon conviction for a second or subsequent offense under this article, a person shall forfeit not less than $500.00, nor more than $2,000.00. 
(c)  The issuance of any citation under this article does not preclude the village from exercising any other right or remedy under this article, including suspension or revocation of the licensee's license. 
(Code 1963, § 9.13(12)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 134.71(113) 
Secs. 74-23-74-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 74-41. - Application contents. 
    In addition to the information required by Wis. Stats. § 134.71(5), application forms shall also contain the following: 
(1)  The names, dates of birth, and addresses of all employees and agents. 
(2)  A description of the character of the goods that the applicant proposes to handle. 
(Code 1963, § 9.13(3)) 
Sec. 74-42. - Fees. 
    The fee to be paid to the village for a license under this article shall be as established in section 42-74. 
(Code 1963, § 9.13(4)) 
State Law reference- License fee, Wis. Stats. § 134.71(11). 
Sec. 74-43. - Suspension. 
(a)  Any individual required to be licensed under this article may have his license suspended if the continuance of such license creates a danger to public health or safety, or for any violation of this article for which the village board believes that a revocation of the license may not be necessary. 
(b)  Any individual whose license is suspended under this article shall be entitled to a hearing before the general government committee if the licensee files with the village clerk-treasurer an objection to the licensee's suspension within ten days of such suspension. At the hearing, the licensee shall have the right to counsel and the right to examine witnesses. The general government committee's decision shall be final, unless appealed to the county circuit court within ten days of the general government committee's decision by petition for writ of certiorari. 
(c)  Any licensee whose license is revoked under this article shall be entitled to a hearing before the general government committee, after notice, and shall have the right to counsel and the right to examine witnesses. The general government committee's decision shall be final unless appealed to the county circuit court within ten days of the committee's decision. 
(Code 1963, § 9.13(11)(b)) 
State Law reference- License revocation, Wis. Stats. § 134.71(10). 
Sec. 74-44. - Transfer. 
(a)  Licenses issued under this chapter shall not be transferable from one person to another, nor from one premises to another. 
(b)  As used in the previous subsection, the phrase "transferable from one person to another includes any of the following: 
(1)  The sale, lease, or sublease of the business; 
(2)  The transfer of securities which constitute a controlling interest in the business, whether by sale, exchange or other means; or 
(3)  The establishment of a trust, gift, or other similar legal device which transfers the ownership or control of the business, except for transfer by bequest or other operation of the law upon the death of the person possessing the ownership or control. 
(Ord. No. 560-O-13, § 6, 7-15-13) 
Chapter 78 - SIGNS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, adopted June 4, 2001, amended chapter 78, comprised of §§ 78-1-78-12 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly said sections pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; subdivision and other divisions of land, ch. 94; zoning, ch. 122; zoning regulations for signs, § 122-751 et seq. 

Sec. 78-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the type, construction, image, maintenance and placement of signs as permitted by the zoning regulations of the village, and is intended to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the village; to lessen threats to public safety from poorly constructed and maintained signs; to avoid depreciation of property values through indiscriminate location and design of signs; to protect against hazards to vehicular traffic movement through improper placement of signs and to preserve the townscape and attractiveness of the village. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01) 
Sec. 78-2. - Sign review. 
    The village manager or designee shall review all applicable signs, and shall assess the three-dimensional configuration, design, colors, and materials to be incorporated on a site. The sign review process shall establish a context for development, and follow established guidelines. The sign review process shall set a standard of value, not simply an aesthetic review. The plan commission has the final say for interpretation of chapter 78. 
(1)  The village manager or designee shall have the power to determine what type of sign is appropriate for a particular location. 
(2)  No sign under this chapter shall be erected or altered unless it has received approval from the village manager or designee provided herein. 
(3)  Approval shall be granted only upon determining the following: 
a.  The appearance, color, texture, and materials of the signs being used will preserve or enhance the character of the immediate neighborhood. 
b.  The appearance of the building signage shall not detract from the general harmony of, and is compatible with, the exterior of the building and other buildings already existing in the immediate neighborhood. 
c.  The appearance of the building signage shall not be garish or otherwise offensive to the sense of sight. 
d.  The appearance of the signage on the building exterior will tend to manage or prevent discordant and unsightly surroundings within the village. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 207-O-02, § 1, 11-18-02) 
Sec. 78-3. - Permits and procedures. 
(a)  Sign permit procedure. 
(1)  Permanent signs. 
a.  Submit a complete application to the department of community development. 
b.  Applicant pays all fees to the Village of Menomonee Falls. 
c.  The department of community development reviews the application for compliance with the Municipal Code. 
d.  The village manager or designee reviews, and approves or rejects the proposed sign. 
e.  The building inspector reviews, and approves or rejects the plans and specifications of electrical signs. 
f.  If approved by the village manager or designee and the building inspector, a permit is issued by the department of community development. 
(2)  Temporary signs. 
a.  The applicant submits a complete application to the department of community development. 
b.  The applicant pays all fees to the Village of Menomonee Falls. 
c.  The department of community development reviews the application for compliance with the Municipal Code. 
d.  A permit is issued by the department of community development. 
(b)  Sign permit. No person shall erect, alter or relocate any sign or other advertising structure as provided in this chapter, unless specifically expected [excepted], without first obtaining a sign permit from the department of community development and making payment of the fees required. Electrical permits are required for all illuminated signs. 
(c)  Application. The village manager or designee may prescribe regulations consistent with the provisions of this chapter concerning the form and content of all applications for the various forms of permits herein required. 
(1)  The application for a permit for erection of a sign shall include: 
a.  Survey. A survey by a licensed land surveyor, showing lot lines, existing buildings, existing site features, existing signs, and proposed sign(s) location(s) may be required. 
b.  Drawing. A scaled drawing of the proposed sign(s) showing all dimensions (height, width, depth, etc.). 
c.  Materials. Samples of materials and replications of the exact colors proposed to be used. 
d.  Context. Photographs of or at the quality of 35 mm format shall be submitted showing the existing buildings and existing sign(s). These photographs shall be enlarged to a size sufficient to show all details. A color rendering of proposed buildings and signs shall be submitted for new projects. 
e.  Specifications. A set of construction plans and specifications of the proposed sign is required. The village manager or designee may prescribe regulations consistent with the provisions of this chapter concerning the form and content of all applications for the various forms of permits herein required. 
f.  Permit application fees. See section 42-78. The fee for a sign permit is an application fee and no refunds are allowed. 
(d)  Design review. The village manager or designee shall review all applications for new or altered signs within the village. 
(e)  Issuance of permit. When all applications have been approved, all fees paid, and approval granted by appropriate boards and committees the permit can be issued. A permit will be issued when the process identified in subsection 78-3(a) has been satisfied. 
(f)  Revocation. All rights and privileges acquired under this chapter or any amendment thereto are mere licenses, revocable for cause at any time by the department of community development, and all permits issued hereunder shall so state. If the work authorized under permit has not been completed within six months after date of issuance, the said permit shall become null and void. 
(g)  Exceptions. The provisions of this chapter, except as to safety requirements, shall not apply to: 
(1)  A street, traffic, or directional sign erected or authorized by the village or other street maintaining entity. 
(2)  Any streetscape or seasonal decorations erected or authorized by the village. 
(3)  Any sign located within the village centre overlay district. The provisions of chapter 122, article V, division 2, shall apply to all signage located within the village centre overlay district. 
(4)  Area, height, and quantity restrictions shall not apply to the Community Memorial Hospital or the Menomonee Falls Ambulatory Surgery Center. However, all other provisions of this chapter shall be complied with. 
(5)  Any sign incorporated into the design of a shelter associated with public transportation shelters authorized by state law or the village board. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 207-O-02, §§ 2-15, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 421-O-08, § 1, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 78-4. - Penalties. 
(a)  Forfeiture. Any person, who violates any provision of this chapter or does not comply with the village manager or designee approval, and/or architectural control board motions, and/or plan commission motions, shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-7 of this Municipal Code. Each day a violation exists constitutes a separate violation and is punishable as such. 
(b)  Injunction. Compliance with this chapter may also be enforced by injunction order at the suit of the village or one or more owners of real estate situated within an area affected by the regulations of this chapter. 
(c)  Nuisances. Any sign erected, structurally altered, painted, moved or maintained in violation of this chapter is declared to be a nuisance per se, and the village may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction to restrain or abate such nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 207-O-02, § 16, 11-18-02) 
Sec. 78-5. - Construction standards. 
(a)  Materials. A sign attached to any building shall be attached by metal bolts, anchors, cables or other metal attachments which shall be protected from corrosion to ensure permanent and safe construction, and shall be maintained free from rust or other defects. 
(b)  Installation. Every permanent sign and its support shall be capable of withstanding a wind pressure of 30 pounds to the square foot with a safety factor of 1.6. All signs, if attached parallel to the building, shall be placed in close contact to the walls thereof; if offset from the building, the same shall be attached with an open space of not less than eight inches between any portion of said building, in order to avoid the accumulation of combustible substances. Every permanent sign shall be installed so as to be rigid. 
(c)  Clearance. The lowest part of any sign, support or appurtenance which extends over any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way or place shall be at least ten feet above grade. 
(d)  Standards and posts. Wooden members may be used in the construction of ground signs provided they are secure and erected upon standards and posts at least four inches by four inches square and are embedded in concrete or approved soil cement mixture at least four feet below the natural surface of the ground. The required depth of embedment may vary depending upon sign area, overall height above grade, soil conditions and the number of supporting uprights, but shall be a minimum four feet in depth. All posts and anchors constructed from wood shall be pressure-treated when they rest upon or are in the ground 
(e)  Electric signs. All electric signs shall be grounded and shall comply with the state electrical code. All electrical connections, or wiring to, or within the sign are subject to the provisions of the Wis. Admin. Code of the Department of Commerce, chapter Comm 16, and shall be approved by the listing agency certified by chapter Comm 16. 
(f)  Backs of sign. Freestanding temporary signs proposed to remain in place for more than four weeks shall be painted a neutral color approved by the department of community development. 
(g)  Attachments. No sign, structure, or any part of such structure as contemplated in this article, as well as, any anchor, brace, guide wire or guide rod shall be attached, fastened or anchored to any fire escape, fire ladder or stand pipe. No such structure or any part of such structure, anchor brace, guide wire or guide rod shall be erected, put up, or maintained so as to cover or obstruct any roof, required doorway, required window or other opening of any building so as to prevent or hinder ingress or egress through such required doorway, window, exit or other opening, or so as to prevent or hinder the raising or placing of ladders against such building by the fire department. 
(1)  No advertising or regulatory sign or its structure shall be attached in any way to a tree or landscape feature. 
(2)  Lights may be permitted on signs, provided that any reflective shields concentrate illumination on the sign so as to prevent glare upon streets or adjacent properties. 
(h)  Exceptions. The following types of temporary signs are exempt from the construction requirements: 
(1)  Temporary signs that are less than 12 square feet. 
(2)  Banners obtaining a temporary sign permit. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 207-O-02, §§ 17-19, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 303-O-05, § 6, 4-4-05) 
Sec. 78-6. - General regulations. 
    Except for signs regulated by sections 78-7 or 78-12 of this chapter, the following shall apply: 
(1)  Restricted uses. No sign shall be permitted unless it conforms with the provisions of this chapter. 
a.  Historic area. No sign shall be permitted to obscure an historical monument, shrine or designated natural scenic view; except official signs providing noncommercial directions or information about such place or object. 
b.  Translucent awnings. Awnings permitting the passage of light shall be prohibited. 
c.  Message center. Incandescent or flip style fixtures are prohibited. 
d.  Lighting. Bare bulb florescent, running, blinking, flashing, or other bare bulb signs are prohibited. 
e.  Mobile signs. No sign mounted on wheels, trailers, motor vehicles or any other nonpermanent structure shall be parked within sight of a street for the purpose of advertising. This section does not apply to signs which are incidental to the identification of such motor vehicle. 
f.  Roof signs. No sign, its appurtenances or attachments shall extend above the peak of the roof line. For buildings with multiple types of roof styles (i.e. flat w/parapet and gabled), the sign shall not extend above the portion of the roof the sign is attached to. 
g.  Traffic visibility area. No sign of any kind shall be permitted in the triangular area at intersections established by section 122-601 of the zoning ordinance. 
h.  Signs with moving parts. All signs that have rotating or moving parts are prohibited. 
i.  Pole signs. Pole signs with exposed poles shall be prohibited. 
(2)  Maintenance. All signs and premises surrounding them shall be maintained by the owner in a clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition according to chapter 18 of the Municipal Code. When signs are removed or altered the sign brackets, attachments or other associated equipment shall also be removed or altered so that the appearance of the original sign is not conspicuous or create a blighting factor. 
(3)  Sign design regulations. 
a.  General design regulations. The following items shall apply to all signs: 
1.  Aesthetics. Signage of properties should blend, rather than contrast with the building in terms of coloring, location, font, size, and number. 
2.  Wall signs. 
i.  Area. A wall sign shall not be larger than ten percent of the facade on which it is mounted, except buildings exceeding 200,000 square feet within an approved corporate campus may have two wall signs up to a maximum of 600 square feet each. 
ii.  Height. Appurtenances, attachments, or any portion of a sign shall not extend above the roof line immediately adjacent to the sign location. 
3.  Freestanding signs. 
i.  Area. No freestanding sign face shall exceed 60 square feet in area. 
ii.  Height. Signs, including all illuminations and embellishments shall not extend 15 feet above grade (finished surface). 
iii.  Pole signs. A shroud shall be placed around the supporting element(s) of a freestanding sign. 
iv.  Landscaping. All freestanding signs shall have a landscaping area at the base of the sign approved by the village manager or designee. 
1)  The landscaped area shall be coordinated with the overall landscape of the site. 
2)  If a monument sign is externally illuminated, the light source shall be entirely shielded from view with landscape plantings that will ensure effective year round screening. 
4.  Window sign. 
i.  A sign permit is required for all window signs. 
ii.  All window signs between 30 and 75 percent of the transparent area of the window require a permit and review by the village manager or designee. 
1)  Window signs shall not clutter the area in which they are displayed. 
iii.  The approval of window signs shall be considered an approval of a unique request, and shall not be construed as precedent for any other proposed window sign. 
iv.  In no event shall 75 percent or more of any window be obstructed by any sign not otherwise regulated by this article. 
v.  Area. Window signs consisting of individual letters and symbols affixed to a window shall be measured by the smallest rectangle sufficient to enclose the individual items. 
5.  Number of faces. Signs shall not have more than two faces. The total area of all faces shall not exceed 120 square feet. Wall signs shall not have more than one face. 
6.  Number of signs per street frontage. Except for operational and directional signs, the number of signs shall be limited to: 
i.  One wall sign is permitted per public entry to a building or tenant space. Service doors, emergency exists, and delivery doors shall not be considered public entries. 
ii.  One freestanding sign is permitted per street frontage, with a maximum of two freestanding signs. 
7.  Lighting. All signs in which electrical wiring and connections are to be used shall be subject to the applicable provision of the state or village electrical code. 
i.  No person may erect a sign with exposed electrical cords and wires. 
ii.  The use of unshielded lighting, including exposed incandescent light bulbs hung or strung on poles, wires or any other type of support intended to illuminate a sign or other advertising device is expressly prohibited. 
iii.  All sign lighting shall be so designed, located, shielded or hooded so as to prevent the casting of glare or direct light upon adjacent roadways, surrounding properties, or into the sky. 
b.  Specific sign design regulations. 
1.  Awnings. A sign on an awning may be designated a signable area as an alternative to one on the building facade. Soft weather treated canvas or similar materials, which allow for flexible or fixed installations shall be used. Signage applied to awnings shall be simple and durable. Backlit awnings are prohibited. 
i.  Area. A sign applied to an awning shall not be larger that ten percent of the street facade on which it is mounted, up to a maximum of 60 square feet in area. 
2.  Message boards. The following shall apply to all message boards: 
i.  General. 
1)  A message board shall not exceed 32 square feet on each side. 
2)  A maximum of two faces is permitted. 
3)  Message boards are only permitted when they are a part of a permanent sign. 
4)  Individual manual changeable copy shall be limited to one font color. 
ii.  Electronic message centers (EMC) shall be allowed as a permitted use when the general conditions noted above and the following are met: 
1)  Signs and LED devices may be illuminated. 
2)  LED message centers that incorporate a clock/temperature device shall comply with section 122-672. 
3)  Single stand-alone message centers are prohibited. 
4)  The EMC must be integrated into the sign design: 
a)  The sides of the units cannot be exposed. The unit must be wrapped or have a shroud around the sides that integrate into the main sign's aesthetics. 
b)  Back to back units (double sided) cannot have a visible space between them. There must be one solid constant top, bottom, and side panel enclosing the back to back units. 
c)  There cannot be any exposed wiring for data cables. Only buried data cable or remote units are permitted. 
5)  In no case shall the lighting intensity of any sign exceed 60 foot candles when measured with a standard light meter held perpendicular to the sign face at a distance of ten inches. Documentation of the foot candles shall be provided with the sign application. 
6)  All units must be electrically listed and comply with their listing. 
7)  Any message center that is proposed to be added to a current sign must have the entire sign comply with chapter 78. 
8)  For any EMC with a combination of fixed and changeable LED the entire message area shall be counted towards the maximum square footage. 

Message board 
3.  Minor sign. A sign that is permanent and not electrical. The dimensions of which are not more than six inches in height and two square feet in area on or over the door of a business establishment, announcing without display or elaboration, only the name of the proprietor and/or the nature of the business. The dimensions of signs on a public building or institutional building shall not exceed ten square feet of display giving the name and nature of occupancy and information as to the conditions of use or admission. A minor sign may be used in addition to a wall sign. 
4.  Multi-tenant buildings. Uniform tenant signs shall complement the building and other tenant signs in terms of height, color, form, texture materials, and method of lighting. 
i.  Tenant wall signs. When separate business entities occupy the same commercial or industrial building each entity shall be permitted to display one wall sign, canopy awning, or marquee sign not to exceed 60 square feet in area. 
5.  Projecting signs. No projecting sign shall extend more than 60 inches from the building or supporting member line. Projecting signs shall not be lower than ten feet above an area used by pedestrians. 
6.  Master identification signage. The purpose of a master identification sign is to advertise developments within the C-1, C-3, C-4, C-6, I-1, I-2, I-3, and P-2 Institutional District Zoning Districts. Developments with a minimum of three lots developed, platted, or subdivided all at the same time, may have Master Identification Signage. Such signage shall in addition to the requirements of this chapter comply with the following standards. 
i.  Master identification signs. 
(a)  Location. A master identification sign shall only be located along the intersection of a major arterial [Appleton Avenue, County Line Road Pilgrim Road, Lilly Road (south of Appleton Avenue), Good Hope Road (east of Pilgrim), and Silver Spring Drive] and a collector street; at the intersection of two arterial streets (listed above); or at one driveway entrance onto a major arterial street (indicated above), and located outside the vision triangle. 
(b)  Number. A maximum of one sign per intersection of an arterial or collector, two arterials, or driveway associated with an arterial, with a maximum of four signs per development. 
(c)  Area. The area of master development signage and individual on-site signage shall be allocated based upon the schedule detailed in the following table. 
(i)  [Signage area]. 
Master Identification Sign Individual On-Site Signage Area 80 SF None Permitted Area 60 SF 40 Area 40 SF 60  
(ii)  Allocation of commercial panel sign areas on a commercial development sign shall be as follows: 
Commercial DevelopmentMaster Identification Sign Development Sign Individual On-Site Signage Area Minimum of 50% of total signage Individual tenant signage shall not be more than 50% of the area. Allocation of individual tenant's signage shall be determined at the time of review.  
(iii)  Individual tenant signage panels shall be designed and approved with specific regulations relating to color of field and copy, material, font style, and lighting so all tenant signs are compatible and harmonious. 
(d)  Height. The height of a commercial development sign including all illumination and embellishments shall not extend 15 feet above grade (approved grading plan). 
(e)  Design. The design of the sign shall coordinate with the overall townscape of the community and the overall design of the development. Signage shall not be designed to match any one particular building, but the overall design image of the area, and specific development. 
(f)  Materials. Stone, copper, stainless steel, brick, stucco or any other material approved on a case by case basis by the architectural control board. 
(g)  Lighting. Lighting for commercial development signs shall be limited to ground lights directed at the sign, or routed copy with push through copy. Ground mounted lighting equipment shall be designed not to cause glare onto the adjoining vehicular and pedestrian areas, and shall be screened from view during daylight. 
(h)  Ownership. Ownership of commercial development master identification signage shall be detailed with the application submission. Signage may be located on an out lot, easement, or individual parcel where each parcel has equal responsibility and deed restrictions are placed on the parcel the sign is located on and the parcels that the sign is identifying. 
(i)  Landscaping. Landscaping shall comply with section 78-6(3)a.3.iv. of the Municipal Code. 
(ii)  Directional signage. Directional signage within developments shall comply with the following standards. 
(a)  Location. All directional signage located within a planned development shall be located near intersections unless the sign is designed for pedestrian use, then the sign may be permitted within pedestrian areas of the development. Directional signage however shall not be located within public rights of way or within the vision triangle. 
(b)  Area. Three square feet per each tenant directional indication. Maximum of 20 square feet for all directional text and logos and arrows per sign. 
(c)  Height. Maximum height of directional signs shall be 51/2 feet. 
(d)  Lighting. Directional signs shall be limited to ground lights directed at the sign, or routed copy with push through copy. Ground mounted lighting equipment shall be designed not to cause glare onto the adjoining vehicular and pedestrian areas, and shall be screened from view during daylight. 
(e)  Landscaping. The directional signs shall be incorporated within the landscaping of the development and the parcel on which the sign is located. Landscaping approval for directional signs shall be reviewed on a case-by-case basis. 
(f)  Design. The design of the directional signs shall be complimentary to the main signage of the development. The same architectural features, materials and details shall be used. 
(g)  Materials. Stone, copper, stainless steel, brick, stucco or any other material approved on a case-by-case basis by the architectural control board. 
(iii)  Individual on-site signage reduction. If a development is planned with a master identification sign the individual freestanding signage shall be reduced in size, area, and height complying with the following standards. 
(a)  [Reduction]. 
Master Identification Sign Individual On-Site Signage Area Height 80 SF None Permitted None Permitted 60 SF 40 10 40 SF 60 10  
(b)  Design. At the time of approval of a planned master identification sign it shall be determined by the architectural control board whether the individual on site signage shall match the architecture of each individual building or if all signage within the development shall have a specific design theme. 
(c)  Materials. Stone, copper, stainless steel, brick, stucco or any other material approved on a case-by-case basis by the architectural control board. 
(d)  Lighting. Lighting of all individual on site signage shall be identical to all signage within the development. Lighting may be either internally illuminated routed copy or push through face or ground mounted illumination. Once the architectural control board has determined the standard all other signage lighting must be identical. 
(e)  Landscaping. Landscaping shall comply with section 78-6(3)a.3.iv. of the Municipal Code. 


Example of a Master Identification Sign 
(4)  Setbacks and offsets. In all zoning district[s] listed in chapter 122, except the OVC village centre overlay zoning district and the C-2 community business district, no part of a freestanding sign shall be permitted closer than five feet to any property line. Signs shall conform to the regulations of the applicable zoning district contained in chapter 122 of the Municipal Code. 
(5)  Hazards or nuisances prohibited. Signs or other advertising media creating a hazard or dangerous distraction to vehicular traffic, or a nuisance to adjoining residential property are prohibited. 
a.  Signs that, in the judgment of the chief of police, obscure traffic intersections, or in other ways create hazards to the movement of vehicular traffic shall be removed as provided in section 78-9. 
b.  No sign shall be permitted that by reason of its location, position, shape, color or wording may be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or device, or which makes use of the words "STOP," "LOOK," "DANGER" or any other word, phrase, symbol or character in such manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic. 
c.  No sign, or support structure of any kind shall be permitted in the traffic visibility areas established in section 122-601 of the zoning ordinance. 
(6)  Off-site signs. 
a.  Any sign or other advertising media not directly related to the use of the premises on which it is located is prohibited, except as specified in [subsection] 78-6(10)b. or [section] 78-12. 
b.  Directional signs may be permitted, but only as provided in subsection (10) of this section. 
(7)  Temporary signs. In addition to the permanent signs allowed under this chapter, signs for the purpose of announcing or promoting a new building, development, subdivision, or special event shall be permitted for a limited period of time in any district subject to the following: 
a.  Temporary signs that do not require a permit or fee. 
1.  Real estate signs. Signs not in excess of eight square feet in area for lease or sale of the property on which they are located. 
2.  Political campaign signs. Political campaign signs are subject to the following requirements: 
i.  Reserved. 
ii.  A political campaign sign displayed in a residential zoning district shall not exceed 16 square feet. A political campaign sign shall not exceed 40 square feet in any other zoning district. 
iii.  Political campaign signs shall not be displayed on any buildings, properties, or structures that are owned, operated or maintained by any public agency, or on any village owned pole or traffic control devised, or on any pole, post or appurtenance owned or operated by a utility. Political campaign signs shall not be located in any public right-of-way. 
iv.  Reserved. 
3.  Personal issue signs. Temporary signs used to express a personal view or expression of an individual or group shall not exceed six square feet per sign face. 
4.  Help wanted signs. Temporary signs used to notify the public of employment opportunities shall not exceed six square feet per sign face. 
5.  Seasonal banners. Decorative and seasonal banners may be permitted subject to the village manager or designee approval. Such banners shall be kept in good repair at all times. 
6.  Special event signs for nonprofit organizations. 
i.  Area. Maximum of 16 square feet. 
ii.  Number. One per street frontage. 
iii.  Location. Placed on any private property with permission of the landowner. Sign setback shall be five feet from all property lines. Sign location shall comply with section 78-6(1)g. 
iv.  Time period preceding event. The display of any nonprofit signs shall be limited to a period of 30 calendar days immediately preceding the special event. 
v.  Time period prior to event. The nonprofit organization responsible for the erection or distribution of any such sign shall be jointly and severally liable for the removing the sign within ten business days after the special event to which they sign refers. If such signs are not removed within the prescribed period, the village manager or designee may remove them, and may cite any responsible party. 
b.  Temporary signs that require a permit and fee. 
1.  Signs for promotional events. 
i.  Area. In no event may any temporary sign exceed 40 square feet in area and in no event may any nonaccessory temporary sign exceed the size limitations which would be applicable to an accessory sign erected at its site. 
ii.  Time period. Temporary signs shall be issued for a specific time period. Temporary signs may be issued for a maximum of four weeks. One extension may be granted upon the applicant showing the continued necessity and compliance. 
iii.  Opaque background window coverage shall be considered a temporary sign and in no event shall the sign obstruct more than 75 percent of the window area. 
2.  Signs for real estate including residential developments, and subdivisions. 
i.  Number. One per street frontage. 
ii.  Area. In no event may any temporary sign exceed 40 square feet in area and in no event may any nonaccessory temporary sign exceed the size limitations which would be applicable to an accessory sign erected at its site. 
iii.  Time period. Permits for temporary signs shall be issued for a specific time period, which shall not exceed six months. An extension may be granted upon the applicant showing the continued necessity and compliance. Additional permits may be issued extending the time. 
3.  Signs for industrial, commercial, institutional, office, and subdivision developments. 
i.  Number. One per street frontage. 
ii.  Area. In no event may any temporary sign exceed 100 square feet in area and in no event may any nonaccessory temporary sign exceed the size limitations which would be applicable to an accessory sign erected at its site. 
iii.  Time period. Permits for temporary signs shall be issued for a specific time period, which shall not exceed six months. An extension may be granted upon the applicant showing the continued necessity and compliance. Additional permits may be issued extending the time. 
iv.  Opaque background window coverage shall be considered a temporary sign and in no event shall the sign obstruct more than 75 percent of the window area. 
4.  Special event signs for nonprofit organizations. 
i.  Area. Min. 16,001 square feet with a maximum of 40 square feet. 
ii.  Number. One per street frontage. 
iii.  Location. Placed on parcel in a commercial (C-1, C-2, C-3, C-4, or C-6), industrial (I-1, I-2, or I-3), agricultural (A-1 and A-2), and institutional (P-1 and P-2) districts with the permission of the landowner. Sign(s) shall be setback five feet from all property lines. Sign location shall comply with section 78-6(1)g. 
iv.  Written permission. Written notarized permission from the property owner shall be submitted with the application for the permit. 
v.  Time period preceding event. The display of any nonprofit signs shall be limited to a period of 30 calendar days immediately preceding the special event. 
vi.  Time period prior to event. The nonprofit organization responsible for the erection or distribution of any such sign shall be jointly and severally liable for the removing the sign within ten business days after the special event to which they sign refers. If such signs are not removed within the prescribed period, the village manager of designee may remove them, and may cite any responsible party. 
c.  Temporary signs that are prohibited. 
1.  Inflatable signs. Inflatable signs are prohibited except for: 
i.  Balloons or inflatable figures used in a parade, festival or similar civic event. 
ii.  Novelty balloons less than two feet in diameter and less than three feet in any dimension which are tethered or moored. 
iii.  Registered hot air balloons in use and or moored, but not being used as a sign. 
2.  Promotional pennants, and streamers. No owner or occupant of any property shall install or display any pennant(s), or streamer(s) except for the village, which may place seasonal flags or pennants within the public right-of-way. 
3.  Sandwich boards. Sandwich boards shall be prohibited except as permitted by special ordinance in special districts. 
d.  Removal of temporary signs. Temporary signs shall be removed promptly upon expiration of the term for which permitted. If the term expires or the sign becomes obsolete or physically deteriorated than it shall be removed as provided in section 78-8. 
(8)  National, state, local, or corporate flags. Flags shall not be a distraction or hazard. 
(9)  Public agency signs. All provisions of this chapter shall apply equally to the signs erected by national, state, county or municipal governmental agencies, except for traffic, decorative and informational signs on national, state, county, or municipal rights-of-way. 
(10)  Operational and directional signs. These are signs used for the purpose of directing patrons or attendants to a building or part of a complex. 
a.  Such signs shall be appropriate to the building or complex and shall be located on the premises unless otherwise specified below. The construction and appearance of the sign shall not constitute a safety or sanitation hazard or an economic blight in the location where erected. 
1.  Freestanding. 
i.  Area: Maximum six square feet. 
ii.  Height: Maximum four feet. 
2.  Wall-mounted. 
i.  Area: Maximum six square feet. 
ii.  Height: Maximum 15 feet. 
b.  Off-site direction signs. 
1.  A sign for the purpose of directing patrons or attendees to a place of worship. The sign shall be located within one mile of the location of the institution, and shall not be erected in any residential district. The sign shall be of such construction and appearance as not to constitute a safety hazard or an economic blight. 
1.  Area: Maximum three square feet. 
2.  Height: Fifteen feet. 
(11)  Security signs required by section 34-50 shall not be considered as a window sign as defined by this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 176-O-02, § 4, 3-18-02; Ord. No. 196-O-02, § 1, 8-19-02; Ord. No. 207-O-02, §§ 21-34, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 220-O-03, § 1, 3-3-03; Ord. No. 254-O-03, §§ 1, 2, 12-15-03; Ord. No. 274-O-04, § 1, 7-19-04; Ord. No. 302-O-05, §§ 1, 2, 4-4-05; Ord. No. 303-O-05, §§ 3, 4, 4-4-05; Ord. No. 336-O-06, § 1, 4-17-06; Ord. No. 466-O-09, § 1, 11-16-09; Ord. No. 537-O-12, § 3, 5-21-12; Ord. No. 551-O-13, § 1, 2-18-13; Ord. No. 574-O-13, §§ 2, 3, 11-18-13) 
Sec. 78-7. - Specific regulations for residential, conservancy-wetland, floodland, and agricultural zoning districts. 
    The following conditions and regulations apply to zoning districts identified in chapter 122. 
(1)  Residential, conservancy-wetland, floodland. All signs are prohibited in these districts except the following: 
a.  Signs that do not require a permit or fee. 
1.  Property identification. A sign not in excess of two square feet in area identifying the property or the name of the owner or occupant. 
2.  Warning signs. Warning signs such as: "No hunting", "no trespassing", "no parking", or "no loitering" are permitted. 
3.  Real estate and lease signs. Signs pertaining to the lease or sale of the property, not in excess of eight square feet in area per sign. Each property may have one sign per street frontage. 
4.  Yard sale signs. Yard sale signs located on premises may be in place one day before the event and shall be removed the last day of the event. 
5.  Signs for historic or commemorative places and events. Signs not in excess of two square feet which commemorate or identify a historic building, place, event, landscape, geologic, or archaeological feature. 
6.  Political campaign signs. Political campaign signs shall be regulated under subsection 78-6(7)a.2. 
b.  Signs that require a permit and fee. 
1.  Signs for charitable or religious institutions. Signs for charitable or religious institutions, located on premises, shall not exceed 15 square feet. 
i.  Identification sign. 
Area: Maximum 15 square feet. 
Height: Maximum five feet. 
ii.  Bulletin boards shall not exceed ten square feet in area and may have a maximum of two faces. 
2.  Development name signs. Subdivision, condominium and apartment complex signs shall, in addition to the requirements of this chapter, comply with the following guidelines: 
i.  Area: Maximum 15 square feet. 
ii.  Height: Maximum six feet for freestanding signs and 15 feet for wall signs. 
iii.  Materials: Wood, stone, copper, stainless steel, stucco, brick or any other material approved on a case by case basis by the architectural control board. 
iv.  Lighting: Lighting for subdivision and development signs shall be limited to ground lights directed at the sign. 
v.  Review: Project name signs shall be designed to be integrated into an architectural or landscape feature. The landscape feature shall be approved by the architectural control board. 
3.  Historic inns and bed and breakfasts. Historic inns and bed and breakfast signage shall, in addition to the requirements of this chapter, comply with the following guidelines: 
i.  Area: Maximum ten square feet. 
ii.  Height: Maximum six feet tall. 
iii.  Signage type: Freestanding only 
iv.  Materials: Wood, brick or stone. The materials and colors of the sign must compliment the structure and surrounding properties. 
v.  Lighting: Lighting shall be limited to ground lights directed at the sign. Light may not shine on adjoining properties or create glare conditions. Shielding of lights shall be provided. 
vi.  Landscaping: The sign shall be integrated into the landscape of the property. 
vii.  Side setbacks: Signage shall be located a minimum of five feet from side and rear property lines. 
(2)  Agricultural districts. 
a.  All signs that are permitted under subsection 78-7(1). 
b.  Road side stands. A sign, not exceeding 20 square feet in area, advertising roadside stands selling farm produce. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 281-O-04, § 4, 9-20-04) 
Sec. 78-8. - Nonconforming signs. 
    Signs lawfully existing at the time of adoption or amendment of this article which do not conform to the provisions of this chapter, shall be deemed nonconforming signs. 
(1)  Formal finding. The requirements of this section on nonconforming signs reflect a formal finding of fact on the part of the village's board of trustees. Specifically, that the removal of illegal nonconforming signs and combinations of signs, and the amortization of legal nonconforming signs and legal nonconforming combinations of signs, within the village is appropriate. This action will further the compelling government interests and the village's economic redevelopment efforts by reducing visual clutter and additionally unifying the appearance of the village within a reasonable period of time. 
(2)  Legal nonconforming signs. Legal nonconforming signs and nonconforming combination of signs existing upon the effective date of this article, which do not comply with the standards of this chapter shall be either removed or brought up to the requirements of this chapter within the time period prescribed in subsection a. below dating from the effective date of this article. 
a.  Time period schedule. 
Age of Sign Time Period Erected before or in 1996 10 years Erected in 1997 11 years Erected in 1998 12 years Erected in 1999 13 years Erected in 2000 14 years Erected between Jan. 1, 2001 and June 4, 2001 15 years  
(3)  Change in occupancy. Any change in occupancy or use of premises shall necessitate all individual signage being brought into compliance with this chapter. A change of a tenant sign within a group sign is excluded from compliance with this clause, however all other requirements of this article shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 207-O-02, § 35, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 220-O-03, § 2, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 78-9. - Sign removal. 
(a)  Blighted signs. If the property maintenance compliance committee determines that a sign is blighted, the village manager or designee shall give written notice to the permittee thereof, if known; owner of the sign, if known; and the property owner on which it is located. If the sign and supporting structure are not removed or altered to comply with the standards set forth herein within 30 days after such notice, the village has the authority to remove the sign and supporting structure at the expense of the owner of the property on which it is located. 
(b)  Unsafe signs. After inspection of the sign, the building inspector determines it to be unsafe, the village manager or designee, shall have the authority to remove the sign without notice, at the expense of the owner of the property on which it is located. Any expense incurred by the village while removing the sign under this section may be assessed to the property owner as a special charge under Wis. Stats. § 66. 
(c)  Abandoned signs. If the property maintenance compliance committee determines that a sign is abandoned for 90 days, the village manager or designee, shall give written notice to the permittee thereof, if known; owner of the sign, if known; and the property owner on which it is located. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of record within 30 days of such notice to submit a plan to the village manager or designee or to remove all signs and supporting structures that are not currently appropriate for the building or property. 
(d)  Illegal signs on public property or rights-of-way. Any authorized village employee may summarily and without notice remove any illegal sign from public property or right-of-way. 
(e)  Nonconforming temporary signs. Any temporary sign existing upon the effective date of this article, which does not comply with the standards of chapter 78 may be continued so long as well maintained, for a period not to exceed 60 days after the effective date of this article. 
(f)  Temporary signs. In addition to the penalties provided for the violation of this chapter, if any temporary sign licensee or permittee fails to remove all such signs the village may remove and dispose of all such signs without further notice to the licensee or permittee, and may assess against the permittee, licensee, property owner, sign owner, and/or organization, the actual and reasonable costs of removal and disposal. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 162-O-01, § 7, 12-3-01; Ord. No. 207-O-02, §§ 36-38, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 302-O-05, § 3, 4-4-05) 
Sec. 78-10. - Liability. 
    The acceptance of fees and issuance of permits as provided herein shall not be deemed an assumption of liability by the village. The owner of any building or structure upon which a sign is erected shall be liable for any damages and injuries that may be caused to persons and/or property caused by the sign. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01) 
Sec. 78-11. - Appeals and exceptions. 
(a)  Decision by the village manager or designee. Appeals to the architectural control board may be taken by any person aggrieved by the decision of the village manager or designee. 
(1)  Such written appeals specifying the reason for such appeal shall be filed with the department of community development by the applicant within 30 days, after the date of written decision of the village manager or designee. 
(2)  The department of community development shall forthwith transmit to the architectural control board all papers constituting the record against which the action appealed from was taken. 
(3)  Upon receipt of the record, the architectural control board, in its sole discretion, shall grant the appeal, deny the appeal, or modify and approve the appeal. 
(b)  Decisions by the architectural control board. Appeals to the plan commission may be taken by any person aggrieved by the decision of the architectural control board. 
(1)  Such written appeals specifying the reason for such appeal shall be filed with the department of community development by the applicant within 30 days, after the date of written decision of the architectural control board. 
(2)  The department of community development shall transmit to the plan commission all papers constituting the record against which the action appealed from was taken. 
(3)  Upon receipt of the record, the plan commission, in its sole discretion shall grant the appeal, deny the appeal, or modify and approve the appeal. 
(c)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Authority. The plan commission may determine and vary the regulations of this article in harmony with their general purpose and intent, only in the specific instances hereinafter set forth, where the commission makes a finding of fact based upon the standard hereinafter prescribed, that there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the regulations of this article. 
(2)  All requests for sign exceptions shall be made on forms furnished by the department of community development, and shall include the application fee as established in section 42-78 of the Municipal Code. 
(3)  The department of community development shall transmit the application materials to the plan commission. 
(4)  Hearings. A public hearing shall be held by the plan commission unless the commission determines, with no dissenting vote, that such a hearing is not necessary to protect the public interest. If held, the plan commission shall fix a reasonable time and place for the hearing of appeals and give notice thereof by publication of a class 2 notice, pursuant to Wis. Stats. ch. 985. Notice of the public hearing shall be mailed to the petitioner, the clerk of any municipality whose boundaries are within 1,000 feet of any land included in the petition and the owners of all lands lying within 300 feet of and lands included in the petition. The failure to give any notice to any property owner shall not invalidate the action taken by the plan commission. 
(5)  Standards for exceptions. 
a.  The plan commission shall not vary the regulations of this section as authorized in subsection (c)(1) above unless it shall make findings based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case that all the following conditions are present: 
1.  The particular physical surroundings, shape or topographical conditions of the specific property involved would result in a particular hardship upon the owner as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, if the strict letter of the regulations were to be carried out. 
2.  The conditions upon which the application for an exception is based would not be applicable generally to other property within the same zoning classification. 
3.  The purpose of the exception is not based exclusively upon a desire for economic or other material gain by the applicant or owner. 
4.  The alleged difficulty or hardship is caused by this article and has not been created by any person presently having an interest in the property. 
5.  The granting of the exception will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property or improvements in the neighborhood in which the property is located. 
6.  The proposed exception will not impair an adequate supply of light and air to adjacent property, or substantially increase the congestion in the public streets, or increase the danger of fire, or endanger the public safety, or substantially diminish or impair property values within the neighborhood. 
b.  The plan commission may impose conditions and restrictions upon the premises benefited by an exception as may be necessary to comply with the above standards to reduce or minimize the injurious effect of such exception upon other property in the neighborhood, and to better carry out the general intent of this article. 
c.  Authorized exceptions. Exceptions shall be granted by the plan commission only in accordance with the standards set forth in [subsection] (c)(1) above. Authorized exceptions shall be considered a unique request, and shall not be construed as precedent for any other authorized exceptions. 
d.  Anyone who believes they have a unique condition should file an application with the department of community development for an exception. 
(d)  Sign exception procedure. 
(1)  The applicant submits a complete sign exception application and relevant fees to the department of community development. 
(2)  The proposed sign is reviewed by the department of community development and referred to the plan commission for any exception(s). 
(3)  The plan commission determines if a public hearing should be held. 
a.  If the public hearing is waived, the plan commission shall review the application materials and approve, reject, or modify and approve the sign exception(s). 
b.  If the public hearing is requested, the hearing shall be scheduled for the next available plan commission meeting. After the public hearing is closed, the plan commission shall consider the information presented and approve, reject, or modify and approve the sign exception(s). 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 207-O-02, § 39, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 465-O-09, § 1, 11-16-09; Ord. No. 506-O-11, § 1, 4-18-11) 
Sec. 78-12. - Digital billboard pursuant to a relocation agreement. 
    A sign permit may be issued under this chapter to authorize the installation of a digital billboard to be installed with copy visible from any U.S. or interstate highway. Any permit issued under this section must meet all the following conditions: 
(1)  Each digital billboard shall replace at least two existing off-site sign structures located within the village. 
(2)  The applicant and owner of the digital billboard shall execute a relocation agreement with the village by which the sign owner agrees to: 
a.  Remove the required off-site sign structures as required by subparagraph (1) above; 
b.  Comply with any and all applicable provisions of this section and this Municipal Code; and 
c.  Provide the ability for the village to have advertising copy placed on the digital billboard to promote public service announcements and other village events on a space available basis. 
(3)  A digital billboard shall not have more than two display faces, each one facing in a different direction. 
(4)  The digital billboard display face (excluding all framing, trim and cabinetry) shall not be more than 48 feet in width, 14 feet in height nor exceed 672 square feet in area. 
(5)  The overall height of the advertising structure that includes a digital billboard shall not be more than 70 feet in height as measured from the roadway. 
(6)  No part of a digital billboard shall be permitted closer than five feet to any property line. 
(7)  A digital billboard shall not operate at brightness levels of more than 0.3 footcandles above ambient light, as measured using a footcandle meter at a pre-set distance of 250 feet perpendicular to the digital sign. Each digital billboard shall have a light-sensing device that will automatically adjust the brightness of the digital billboard to meet that footcandle requirement as ambient light conditions change. If operated as set forth in this section shall be deemed not to violate and lighting requirement in this chapter. 
(8)  A digital billboard shall only display a series of still images, and each still image must be displayed for a minimum of six consecutive seconds. Transition time between one still image and the immediate next still image shall not exceed one second. 
(9)  If a digital billboard that is the subject of a sign permit issued under [subsection] 78-6(12) subsequently becomes illegal under state statutes or federal law, the applicant may replace the digital billboard with a non-digital outdoor advertising sign, which sign shall continue as a legal nonconforming use under this chapter for the remaining term of the relocation agreement. 
(10)  All digital billboards and premises surrounding them shall be maintained by the owner in a clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition according to chapter 18 of the Municipal Code. When a digital billboard is removed or altered, the sign brackets, attachments or other associated equipment shall also be removed or altered so that the appearance of the original digital billboard is not conspicuous or creates a blighting factor. 
(11)  All digital billboards shall be subject to the applicable provision of the state or village electrical code. 
a.  Exposed electrical cords or wires shall be prohibited. 
b.  The use of exposed incandescent light bulbs hung or strung on poles, wires or any other type of support intended to illuminate a sign or other advertising device is prohibited. 
c.  All sign lighting shall be so designed, located, shielded or hooded so as to reduce as much as possible the casting of glare or direct light upon adjacent roadways, surrounding properties and the sky. 
(12)  All digital billboards shall conform with the following provisions: 
a.  A digital billboard shall not obscure a historical monument, shrine or designated natural scenic view. 
b.  Incandescent or flip-style fixtures are prohibited. 
c.  Bare bulb (other than LED diodes) and florescent lighting is prohibited. 
d.  Running, blinking or flashing lighting is prohibited. 
e.  A digital billboard or its attachments shall not be connected to a building. 
(Ord. No. 574-O-13, § 4, 11-18-13) 
Sec. 78-13. - Definitions. 
    When used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the specific meaning as herein after defined. Words not listed herein shall have the meaning defined in chapter 122 of this Municipal Code. 
    Arterial street. A street or highway used or intended to be used primarily for fast or heavy through traffic. Arterial stress and highways shall include freeways and expressways as well as arterial streets, highways and parkways. 
    Awning means a rooflike cover consisting of a rigid frame covered with vinyl plastic, or canvas, temporary in nature, which projects from the wall of a building. 
    Awning, internally illuminated consists of a rigid frame covered with vinyl plastic or other translucent material, which is internally illuminated. 
    Building line means a line established by ordinance beyond which no building may extend. 
    Collector street. A street used within residential, industrial, or commercial areas, that carries a relatively high traffic volume and conveys traffic from arterial streets to lower orders streets such as sub collectors, access streets. 
    Digital billboard shall mean any off-site sign that uses digital or electronic message technology and is capable of changing the static message or copy on the sign electronically. A digital billboard may be self-luminous or externally illuminated. Digital billboards shall contain static messages only, and shall not have animation, movement, or the appearance or optical illusion of movement, of any part of the sign structure. Each static message shall not include flashing lighting or the varying of light intensity. Digital billboards shall not be either a message board or an electronic message center. 
    Grade means the finished surface of the ground around the sign. 
    Multi-tenant building means any office, commercial, mixed use, industrial, or institutional use in which a principal building is devoted to two or more individual tenants, occupants, or uses. 
    Nonprofit organization means any person(s) partnership, association, corporation or other group whose activities are conducted for civic, or humanitarian motives, or for the benefit of others, and not for the gain of any private individual or group and may include, but shall not be limited to patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, fraternal, cultural, charitable, scientific, historical, athletic, or medical activities. 
    Operational and directional signs means signs designating entrances or exits, and directing patrons to service areas, parking areas, rest rooms, or other such signs relating to functional operations of the building or premises. 
    Planned development. A planned development is the creation of at least three lots by subdivision or certified survey map. In the case where a right of way is dedicated, and less than three lots are platted, but more than three lots are possible in the future, the development shall be considered a planned development. 
    Roof line means the highest point of the main roof structure or highest point on a parapet, but shall not include cupolas, pylons, projections, architectural ornamentation, flag poles, or minor raised portions of the roof. 
    Sign area is the length multiplied by the height of the overall sign face and frame. Signs consisting of individual letters and symbols affixed to a building or wall, shall be measured using the smallest rectangle sufficient to enclose all of the letters and symbols. 

Sign area-1 

Sign area-2 
    Sign band means a horizontal area of the facade of a building typically located between the top of the first floor windows and the roof line, or second floor windows providing a location for signage. 
    Sign height means the height of a sign determined by the measurement between the grade at the base of the sign and the highest point of the sign or supporting structure. 
    Signage means the total effect of all signs incorporated on the subject site. 
    Signs mean any structure or device displaying advertising, direction, information, or promotion in the form of lettering, pictures, symbols or other media and including any billboard, street clock, awning sign, temporary sign, barber pole, pole sign, or projecting sign or other structure erected for the purpose of advertising or promotion. Temporary team support banners regulated under chapter 66 of the Municipal Code are specifically excluded from the definition of signs set out herein, and from the regulations of chapter 78. 
(1)  Flag means a piece of cloth, or synthetic material varying in size, color, or design used as a symbol, standard, signal, or emblem. 
(2)  Electrical signs mean any sign that has electrical components. 
(3)  Ground sign means a sign placed directly on the ground and not attached to any building or part of a building. 
(4)  Electronic message centers (EMC) means a message center where the message is changed through automated mechanical methods, rather than being changed physically by a person. 
a.  Light emitting diodes (LED) message center means a sign using LED technology where the lighting device uses polymers as the emitting layer within the device, where the message can be changed electronically or through automation. 
b.  Incandescent message center means a sign where incandescent bulb technology is used to change the message. 
c.  Flip style message center means a sign where the copy is fixed to a permanent element that rolls or flips to display combinations of copy using electric or other means of automation. 
(5)  Message board means a portion of a permanent sign with changeable copy. 
(6)  Monument sign means a sign mounted on a base or platform. The base shall be proportionate to the sign, and be constructed out of a solid material such as stone, brick, or metal. The bottom of the sign shall be at or within six inches of the base. 
(7)  Nonconforming sign means a sign that exists at the time of the adoption of this article that does not comply with the regulations herein. 
(8)  Off site sign means a sign or other advertising media not directly related to the use of the premises on which it is located. 
(9)  Projecting sign means a sign attached to a building and extending from the wall of said building more than eight inches beyond the building wall. 
(10)  Pylon sign or pole sign means a sign mounted on one or more poles. 
(11)  Roof sign means a sign on or over the roof of a canopy or a building and supported by uprights and braces anchored to the roof. 
(12)  Wall sign means a sign attached flush with or painted on the wall of a building or structure, with the exposed face of the sign parallel to the plane of said wall, and such face shall not project greater than eight inches from the face of the building. 
(13)  Window sign means a sign attached to, placed upon, or painted on the interior or exterior of a window or door of a building, which is intended for viewing from the exterior of such building. 
    Temporary sign means a sign or banner erected for a limited period of time the purpose of designating a building, new tenant, development, subdivision promotion, announcement of a special event, or similar informational purpose. Temporary team support banners regulated under chapter 66 of the Municipal Code are specifically excluded from the definition of a temporary sign set out herein, and from the regulations of chapter 78. 
(1)  Banner means a sign made of a flexible material such as canvas, sailcloth, or plastic. 
(2)  Inflatable sign means a freestanding or moored graphic that may be filled with air or gas causing it to expand and/or float above the ground. 
(3)  Pennant means a tapered or dove-tailed banner or flag. 
(4)  Sandwich board means a two-sided, portable, hinged temporary sign. 
(5)  Streamer means a series of flags, banners, or other objects used to attract attention or create noise. 
    Townscape means the sum effect of experiencing the buildings, signs, and landscape in a particular locale. 
    Vision triangle. The vision triangle is the area formed by the enforcement of Section 122-601 of the Municipal Code dealing with traffic visibility. 
(Ord. No. 134-O-01, § 2, 6-4-01; Ord. No. 207-O-02, § 40, 11-18-02; Ord. No. 221-O-03, §§ 1, 2, 3-17-03; Ord. No. 254-O-03, § 3, 12-15-03; Ord. No. 274-O-04, § 2, 7-19-04; Ord. No. 303-O-05, § 1, 4-4-05; Ord. No. 574-O-13, § 1, 11-18-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 574-O-13, § 1, adopted Nov. 18, 2013, renumbered § 78-12 as § 78-13. This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Chapter 82 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 58; care of waste in parks, § 66-27; utilities, ch. 110. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Yard waste. 
    No person may place any yard waste in any recycling receptacle or refuse container for collection by the village or its contractor, except as permitted under the terms of any contract between the village and its refuse collection contractor, and as required by the village to clean up wind damage debris, or in writing for any other purpose. 
(Code 1963, § 12.03(6)(e)) 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 114. 
Sec. 82-2. - Authority to enforce. 
    The village police department and the director of public works or the director's designee are authorized to enforce all provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-O-00, § 3, 8-3-00; Ord. No. 116-O-00, § 3, 11-20-00) 
Secs. 82-3-82-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTER CONTROL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Littering, Wis. Stats. § 287.11. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-21. - Dumping in or along streets. 
    No person shall dump or dispose of garbage or rubbish or refuse in or along any public highway within the village. 
(Code 1963, § 12.03(4)) 
Sec. 82-22. - Prohibited acts. 
    No person shall throw any glass, rubbish, paper, waste or filth upon the streets, alleys, highways, public parks or other property of the village or upon any private property not owned by him or upon the surface of any body of water within the village. 
(Code 1963, § 10.05(6)) 
Sec. 82-23. - Operation of vehicles.
