    No contractor or other person shall operate or cause to be operated a vehicle which shall litter or soil any street, alley, sidewalk or other public places within the village. 
(Code 1963, § 7.08(1)) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 106. 
Secs. 82-24-82-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION SITES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 

Sec. 82-41. - Exceptions. 
    This division shall not apply to construction work within the barricaded area of work being done in the street right-of-way pursuant to a village excavation permit authorizing the same, or to emergency or other work being performed within a barricaded area pursuant to a village contract or by village or other emergency forces, provided that excavated material stored temporarily within the barricaded area shall not be scattered or carried or allowed to accumulate outside of such area. 
(Code 1963, § 7.08(7)) 
Sec. 82-42. - Responsibility of contractor. 
    Whenever a contractor is engaged in any construction or maintenance activity, it shall be his responsibility to see that this division is not violated by himself, his agents, employees, subcontractors, or haulers of materials and supplies. If more than one contractor, or any governmental unit is involved in work which contributes to the littering of streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public places in the same site or area, they shall be separately and jointly responsible for the observance of this division. 
(Code 1963, § 7.08(4)) 
Sec. 82-43. - Adjacent to construction sites. 
    All streets, alleys, sidewalks or public places adjacent to any building or construction site shall be maintained in a litter free condition at all times. This shall include such soiling or littering caused by erosion, landslides or general construction activities at any such site. 
(Code 1963, § 7.08(2)) 
Sec. 82-44. - Operation of vehicles out of construction sites. 
    No contractor shall allow any vehicle to operate out of any construction site, regardless of whether the vehicle shall be operated by the contractor, his agents, employees or subcontractors, in such a manner as to dump, scatter or deposit any rubbish, stones, wire, earth, ashes, cinders, sawdust, hay, glass, manure, filth, paper, snow, ice, dirt, grass, leaves, twigs, shrubs, construction waste, garbage or other offensive or nauseous material on any street, alley, or public place. The village manager or designee is empowered to order any contractor to take such precautions as the village manager or designee deems necessary to prevent any such foreign materials from being deposited on the street, alley or public place, and to remove all foreign material on the street, alley or public place. 
(Code 1963, § 7.08(3)) 
Sec. 82-45. - Cleaning up. 
    If a street, alley, sidewalk or public place shall become soiled or littered through any of such means, the persons responsible shall cause such soiling or littering to be cleaned up forthwith. 
(Code 1963, § 7.08(5)) 
Sec. 82-46. - Closing. 
    If the persons responsible fail to comply with any order of the village manager or designee to clean up, or to take such precautions as the village manager or designee deems necessary to prevent foreign materials from being deposited on the street, alley or public place, the village manager or designee or any commanding officer of the police department may order (in writing) all ingress and egress to the site or area involved stopped until compliance with such order is effected. 
(Code 1963, § 7.08(6)) 
Secs. 82-47-82-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-66. - State standards adopted. 
    The state solid waste disposal standards, promulgated pursuant to the authority of Wis. Stats. § 289.06, are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this article as if fully set forth in this section. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any of such standards incorporated in this section by reference is required or prohibited by this article; and wherever powers and duties are conferred upon, or reference is made in such standards to the "department" or "the state department of natural resources," the powers and duties so conferred and imposed by such standards are hereby conferred and imposed upon, or the reference is to, the village manager or designee, unless such is clearly inapplicable, who is hereby given specifically the duty of enforcing the provisions of this article or initiating legal action to enforce the provisions of this article. Whenever reference is made in such standards to "chapter" or "this chapter," it shall be understood and taken to refer to this article of this chapter 82 of this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 12.03(1)(a)) 
Sec. 82-67. - Licenses and permits. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person except the village to establish, maintain, conduct or operate a solid waste disposal operation, except as provided in rules promulgated pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 289.06, without first obtaining an annual license from the village board or to engage in a collecting and transporting service in or into the village, without first obtaining an annual permit from the village manager or designee for each truck used in such service. All such licenses or permits shall terminate on December 31 of each year following the date of issue. 
(b)  Any person desiring a license or permit for an existing solid waste disposal operation or collecting and transporting service shall annually, before January 1, make application to the village board or the village manager or designee, as the case may be, on forms provided by the village. Any person desiring a license for a new solid waste disposal operation or collection and transporting service shall make such application at least 30 days prior to the desired effective date. A separate application shall be submitted for each solid waste disposal operation or collecting and transporting service. The license or permit fee may, at the discretion of the village board, be prorated for the calendar year in which it is issued. 
(c)  Each permit application shall be accompanied by any applicable license fee. 
(d)  Each applicant desiring a license for a solid waste disposal operation shall provide a surety bond conditioned upon compliance with this division, the amount of which shall be determined by the village board, but in no case shall be less than $1,000.00. A copy of the surety bond shall accompany the license application. 
(e)  Each application for a solid waste disposal license shall be accompanied by a plan of operation indicating procedures which will be undertaken to fulfill the requirements of this division. 
(f)  The village board of trustees may revoke any license or permit if it finds that the disposal operation or collecting and transporting service is not operated in conformance with this division. 
(Code 1963, § 12.03(2), (3)) 
Secs. 82-68-82-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS AND PRECOLLECTION PRACTICES 

Sec. 82-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Premises means a parcel of land, composed of one or more village lots, upon which any building or group of buildings is located, and it shall expressly apply when more than one building is located upon a lot under a single ownership or management. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes (excluding ashes), consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding and similar materials. 
(Code 1963, § 12.03(5)(a)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-82. - Requirements. 
(a)  For storage, refuse containers, of a type hereafter defined, must be provided by the owner of each premises. Storage of refuse in nonapproved types of containers is prohibited. 
(b)  No refuse may be placed at a curb for collection more than 24 hours before collection; nor may refuse containers or unaccepted refuse be allowed to remain at the curb more than 24 hours after collection. 
(Code 1963, § 12.03(5)(b)) 
Sec. 82-83. - Types of containers. 
(a)  One- or two-family dwellings. All containers for storage of all refuse for one-family or two-family dwellings shall be metal, rigid plastic or rubber, be watertight and have suitable handles. Except when filling or emptying, all containers shall be kept closed with a tight-fitting cover, shall be verminproof and flyproof, shall be kept in a sanitary condition, and shall be kept in a location not visible from the street or in a suitable enclosure. Use of plastic garbage bags for storage is acceptable only when stored inside a refuse container permitted by this section. A container shall not exceed 30 gallons in size and shall not contain more than 80 pounds in weight. 
(b)  Other premises. On all premises other than lots with one-family or two-family dwellings, including lots with buildings containing more than two residential units and lots with industrial buildings, all refuse must be contained in metal dumpsters with covers, of the type provided by the party with whom the village contracts for refuse collection. 
(c)  Plastic bags. Use of plastic garbage bags is acceptable only when stored inside an approved refuse container of the type described in this division, or when at the curb for pickup. 
(Code 1963, § 12.03(5)(c); Ord. No. 732-O-18, § 6, 10-1-18) 
Sec. 82-84. - Garbage drained and wrapped. 
    No garbage or rubbish shall be placed in the refuse containers provided by this division until all water has been drained from the garbage or rubbish, and it has been securely wrapped in paper. 
(Code 1963, § 12.03(5)(d)) 
Sec. 82-85. - Oversized refuse. 
    Any refuse which cannot be placed in a container due to its size, nature or content, shall be bundled, packaged or otherwise assembled for collection. 
(Code 1963, § 12.03(5)(e)) 
Secs. 82-86-82-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RECYCLING PROGRAM[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Recycling generally, Wis. Stats. ch. 287; local recycling ordinances, Wis. Stats. § 287.09(3)(b); similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 287.01. 

Sec. 82-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bi-metal container means a container for carbonated or malt beverages that is made primarily of a combination of steel and aluminum. 
    Container board means corrugated paperboard used in the manufacture of shipping containers and related products. 
    Drop off recycling center means the site designated by the village for residents to deposit recyclable materials. 
    Foam polystyrene packaging means packaging made primarily from foam polystyrene that satisfies one of the following criteria: 
(1)  Is designed for serving food or beverages. 
(2)  Consists of loose particles intended to fill space and cushion the packaged article in a shipping container. 
(3)  Consists of rigid materials shaped to hold and cushion the packaged article in a shipping container. 
    HDPE means high density polyethylene, labeled by the SPI code # 2. 
    LDPE means low density polyethylene, labeled by the SPI code # 4. 
    Magazines means magazines and other materials printed on similar paper. 
    Major appliance means a residential or commercial air conditioner, clothes dryer, clothes washer, dishwasher, freezer, microwave oven unless the capacitor has been removed, oven, refrigerator, furnace, boiler, dehumidifier, water heater or stove. 
    Multiple-family dwelling means a property containing five or more residential units, including those which are occupied seasonally. 
    Newspaper means a newspaper and other materials printed on newsprint. 
    Nonresidential facilities and properties means commercial, retail, industrial, institutional, and government facilities and properties not used for residential purposes. This term does not include multiple-family dwellings. 
    Office paper means high grade printing and writing papers from offices in nonresidential facilities and properties. Printed white ledger and computer printout are examples of office paper generally accepted as high grade. This term does not include industrial process waste. 
    Other resins or multiple resins means plastic resins labeled by the SPI code # 7. 
    Person means any individual, corporation, partnership, association, local governmental unit, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 66.0131(1)(a), state agency or authority or federal agency. 
    PETE means polyethylene terephthalate, labeled by the SPI code # 1. 
    Plastic container means an individual, separate, rigid plastic bottle, can, jar or carton, except for a blister pack, that is originally used to contain a product that is the subject of a retail sale. 
    Postconsumer waste means solid waste other than solid waste generated in the production of goods, hazardous waste, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 291.01(7), waste from construction and demolition of structures, scrap automobiles, or high-volume industrial waste, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 289.01(17). 
    PP means polypropylene, labeled by the SPI code # 5. 
    PS means polystyrene, labeled by the SPI code # 6. 
    PVC means polyvinyl chloride, labeled by the SPI code # 3. 
    Recyclable materials means lead acid batteries, major appliances, waste oil, yard waste, aluminum containers, corrugated paper or other container board, foam polystyrene packaging, glass containers, magazines, newspaper, office paper, steel containers, waste tires, bi-metal containers, rigid plastic containers including those made of PETE, HDPE, PVC, LDPE, PP, PS and other resins or multiple resins. 
    Solid waste means as specified in Wis. Stats. § 289.01(33). 
    Solid waste facility means as specified in Wis. Stats. § 289.01(35). 
    Solid waste treatment means any method, technique or process which is designed to change the physical, chemical or biological character or composition of solid waste. Treatment includes incineration. 
    Waste oil means used crankcase oil from motor vehicles. 
    Waste tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its original purpose because of wear, damage or defect. 
    Yard waste means leaves, grass clippings, yard and garden debris and brush, including clean woody vegetative material no greater than six inches in diameter. This term does not include stumps, roots or shrubs with intact root balls. 
(Code 1963, § 32.10; Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 26, 11-19-2001) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-107. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote the public health and welfare, and to promote recycling, composting and resource recovery through the administration of an effective recycling program, as provided in Wis. Stats. § 287.11, and Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 544, and to maximize state aids and other resources relating to the village's recycling program. 
(Code 1963, § 32.02) 
Sec. 82-108. - Interpretation. 
    Where a provision of this article is required by state statutes, or by a standard in Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 544, and where this article is required by such state code, and where the article provision is unclear, the provision shall be interpreted in light of the state statutes and the Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 544 standard in effect on the date of the adoption of this article, or in effect on the date of the most recent text amendment to this article. 
(Code 1963, § 32.05) 
Sec. 82-109. - Administration. 
    The provisions of this article shall be administered by the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 32.08) 
Sec. 82-110. - Enforcement. 
(a)  For the purpose of ascertaining compliance with the provisions of this article, any authorized officer, employee, agent or representative of the village may inspect recyclable materials separated for recycling, postconsumer waste intended for disposal, recycling collection sites and facilities, collection vehicles, collection areas of multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties, and any records relating to recycling activities. No person may refuse access to any authorized officer, employee, or agent or representative of the village who requests access for the purposes of inspection, and who represents appropriate credentials. No person may obstruct, hamper or interfere with such an inspection. 
(b)  Any person who violates a provision of this article may be issued a citation by the village to collect forfeitures. Any person receiving a citation may be offered education opportunities deemed appropriate to the offense by the village manager or designee. The issuance of a citation shall not preclude proceeding under any other article or law relating to the same or any other matter. Proceeding under any other ordinance or law relating to the same or any other matter shall not preclude the issuance of a citation under this subsection. 
(c)  Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-7 of this Code, except that the minimum forfeiture for a first offense shall be $50.00, and for a second offense, $200.00. In addition, any person who violates this article shall be, upon conviction of a third or subsequent violation of the same article, forfeit not more than $2,000.00 for each such offense, together with the costs of prosecution. 
(Code 1963, § 32.20) 
Sec. 82-111. - Preparation and collection. 
    Except as otherwise directed by the village manager or designee, occupants of single-family and two to four unit residences and condominiums shall do the following for the preparation and collection of the separated materials specified in section 82-115(5)-(15): 
(1)  Aluminum containers shall be deposited in the recycling bins provided by the village or its contractor, and placed upon the curb on the day designed for collection, or to be delivered to a licensed solid waste facility for recycling. 
(2)  Bi-metal containers shall be deposited in the recycling bins provided by the village or its contractor, and placed upon the curb on the day designated for collection, or be deposited in the designated village dropoff container, or be delivered to a licensed solid waste facility for recycling. 
(3)  Corrugated paper or other container board shall be cut in accordance with the instructions of the village manager or designee, and left for curbside pickup. 
(4)  Glass containers shall be deposited in the recycling bins provided by the village or its contractor, and placed upon the curb on the day designated for collection, or be deposited at the designated village dropoff container, or be delivered to a licensed solid waste facility for recycling. 
(5)  Magazines, newspapers, office paper and junk mail shall be placed in grocery bags on top of or next to the recycling bin provided by the village, and placed upon the curb on the day designated for collection, or be delivered to a licensed solid waste facility for recycling. 
(6)  Rigid plastic containers shall be prepared and collected as follows: 
a.  Plastic containers stamped 1 or made of PETE shall be deposited in the recycling bins provided by the village or its contractor, and placed upon the curb on the day designated for collection or be deposited in the designated village dropoff container. 
b.  Plastic containers stamped 2 or made of HDPE shall be deposited in the recycling bins provided by the village or its contractor, and placed upon the curb on the day designated for collection, or be deposited in the designated village dropoff container. 
c.  Plastic containers stamped 3 or made of PVC shall be deposited in the recycling bins provided by the village or its contractor, and placed upon the curb on the day designated for collection. 
d.  Plastic containers stamped 4 or made of LDPE shall be deposited in the recycling bins provided by the village or its contractor, and placed upon the curb on the day designated for collection. 
(7)  Steel containers shall be deposited in the recycling bins provided by the village or its contractor, and placed upon the curb on the day designated for collection, or be delivered to a licensed solid waste facility for recycling. 
(8)  Waste tires shall be taken to a state department of natural resources-approved solid waste facility for recycling. 
(Code 1963, § 32.15) 
Sec. 82-112. - Responsibilities of owners or designated agents of multiple-family dwellings. 
(a)  Owners of multiple-family dwellings shall contract for collection of recyclable materials independent of the recycling program of the village. 
(b)  Owners or designated agents of multiple-family dwellings shall do all of the following to recycle the materials specified in section 82-115(5)-(15): 
(1)  Provide adequate, separate containers for the recyclable materials; 
(2)  Notify tenants in writing at the time of renting or leasing the dwelling and at least semiannually thereafter about the established recycling program; 
(3)  Provide for the collection of the recyclable materials separated from the solid waste by the tenants and the delivery of such materials to a recycling facility; and 
(4)  Notify tenants of reasons to reduce and recycle solid waste, which materials are collected, how to prepare the materials in order to meet the processing requirements, collection methods or sites, locations and hours of operation, and a contact person or company, including a name, address and telephone number. 
(c)  The requirements specified in subsection (a) of this section do not apply to the owners or designated agents of multiple-family dwellings if the postconsumer waste generated within the dwelling is treated at a processing facility licensed by the state department of natural resources that recovers for recycling the materials specified in section 82-115(5)-(15) from solid waste in as pure a form as is technically feasible. 
(Code 1963, § 32.16) 
Sec. 82-113. - Responsibilities of owners or designated agents of nonresidential facilities and properties. 
(a)  Owners or designated agents of nonresidential facilities and properties shall do all of the following to recycle the materials specified in section 82-115(5)-(15): 
(1)  Provide adequate, separate containers for the recyclable materials; 
(2)  Notify in writing, at least semiannually, all users, tenants and occupants of the properties about the established recycling program; 
(3)  Provide for the collection of the recyclable materials separated from the solid waste by the users, tenants and occupants and the delivery of the materials to a recycling facility; and 
(4)  Notify users, tenants and occupants of: 
a.  Reasons to reduce and recycle; 
b.  Which materials are collected; 
c.  How to prepare materials; 
d.  Collection methods, sites and times; 
e.  A contact person or company, including a current phone number. 
(b)  The requirements specified in subsection (a) of this section do not apply to the owners or designated agents of nonresidential facilities and properties if the postconsumer waste generated within the facility or property is treated at a processing facility licensed by the state department of natural resources that recovers for recycling the materials specified in section 82-115(5)-(15) from solid waste in as pure a form as is technically feasible. 
(Code 1963, § 32.17) 
Sec. 82-114. - Prohibitions on disposal of recyclable materials separated for recycling. 
    No person may dispose of in a solid waste disposal facility or burn in a solid waste treatment facility any of the materials specified in section 82-115(5)-(15) which have been separated for recycling, except waste tires may be burned with energy recovery in a solid waste treatment facility. 
(Code 1963, § 32.18) 
Sec. 82-115. - Separation. 
    Occupants of single-family and two to four unit residences, multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties shall separate the following materials from postconsumer waste: 
(1)  Lead acid batteries; 
(2)  Major appliances; 
(3)  Waste oil; 
(4)  Yard waste; 
(5)  Aluminum containers; 
(6)  Bi-metal containers; 
(7)  Corrugated paper or other container board; 
(8)  Junk mail; 
(9)  Glass containers; 
(10)  Magazines or other material printed on similar paper; 
(11)  Newspaper or other material printed on newsprint; 
(12)  Office paper; 
(13)  Plastic containers; 
(14)  Steel containers; 
(15)  Waste tires. 
(Code 1963, § 32.11) 
Sec. 82-116. - Separation requirements exempted. 
    The separation requirements of section 82-115 do not apply to the following: 
(1)  Occupants of single-family and two to four unit residences, multiple-family dwellings, condominiums and nonresidential facilities and properties that send their postconsumer waste to a processing facility licensed by the state department of natural resources that recovers the materials specified in section 82-115 from solid waste in as pure a form as is technically feasible. 
(2)  Solid waste which is burned as a supplemental fuel at a facility if less than 30 percent of the heat input to the facility is derived from the solid waste burned as supplemental fuel. 
(3)  A recyclable material specified in section 82-115(5)-(15) for which a variance has been granted by the state department of natural resources under Wis. Stats. § 297.11(2m) or Wis. Admin. Code § NR 544.14. 
(Code 1963, § 32.12) 
Sec. 82-117. - Care of separated recyclable materials. 
    To the greatest extent practicable, the recyclable materials separated in accordance with section 82-115 shall be clean and kept free of contaminants such as food or product residue, oil or grease, and other nonrecyclable materials including, but not limited to, household hazardous waste, medical waste and agricultural chemical containers. Recyclable materials shall be stored in a manner which protects them from wind, rain and other inclement weather conditions. 
(Code 1963, § 32.13) 
Sec. 82-118. - Management of lead acid batteries, major appliances, waste oil and yard waste. 
    Occupants of single-family and two to four unit residences, multiple-family dwellings, condominiums, and nonresidential facilities and properties shall manage lead acid batteries, major appliances, waste oil and yard waste as follows: 
(1)  Lead acid batteries shall not be land-filled or incinerated in the village. Lead acid batteries shall be delivered to or picked up by a business which collects lead acid batteries for recycling according to state law. 
(2)  Major appliances shall not be land-filled or incinerated. Major appliances shall be delivered to or picked up by a business which collects major appliances for recycling according to state law. 
(3)  Waste oil shall not be land-filled in the village. Waste oil shall be delivered to or picked up by a municipal or private waste oil collection site or business which collects waste oil for recycling according to state law, and shall be free of materials which would cause the waste oil to be nonrecyclable. 
(4)  Yard waste shall not be land-filled in the village or burned without energy recovery in a solid waste facility per Wis. Stats. § 159.07(2), except as authorized by the state department of natural resources at a licensed wood-burning facility. Yard waste shall be handled in one of the following ways: 
a.  Managing it on the resident's property by composting or source reduction; 
b.  Taking it for composting to the waste management compost site using a village-issued yard waste permit; 
c.  Contracting for private pickup with or delivering it to a business collecting yard waste and managing it according to state law; or 
d.  Burning of leaves at a residential facility when collected from the facility and burned in accordance with rules of the village fire department. 
(Code 1963, § 32.14) 
State Law reference- Disposal of lead acid batteries, major appliances, waste oil and yard waste, Wis. Stats. § 287.07(1m). 
Sec. 82-119. - Recycling receptacles. 
    Each recycling receptacle provided by the village to residential units shall be and remain property of the village. No person may remove from any premises any recycling receptacle provided by the village. Whenever any occupier vacates a residential unit in the village, whether because of a change of ownership or tenancy or for any other reason, such occupier shall at the time of vacating such residential unit, leave the recycling receptacle for such residential unit in the kitchen of such residential unit. 
(Ord. No. 98-O-00, § 1, 8-3-00; Ord. No. 116-O-00, § 1, 11-20-00) 
Sec. 82-120. - Scavenging prohibited. 
(a)  Recyclable materials placed at curbside for collection or in any recycling receptacle placed by the village are the property of the village. No person may collect, pick up or cause to be collected or picked up any recyclable materials or any refuse in a recycling receptacle, unless authorized by the village. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prevent any occupier of premises in the village from donating or selling recyclable materials from his or her own refuse. 
(Ord. No. 98-O-00, § 2, 8-3-00; Ord. No. 116-O-00, § 2, 11-20-00) 
Chapter 86 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessments saved from repeal, § 1-11(a)(11); taxation, ch. 98. 

Sec. 86-1. - Adoption of state law provisions. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the following statutes shall be followed in levying special assessments and imposing special charges for the cost of installing or constructing any public work or improvement by the village, and such statutes are adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter: 
Wis. Stats. § 66.0713 Special improvement bonds; certificates. Wis. Stats. § 66.0703 Special assessments and charges. Wis. Stats. § 66.0717 Lien of special assessment. Wis. Stats. § 66.1109 Business improvements districts. Wis. Stats. § 66.0715(2) Special assessments. Wis. Stats. § 66.0907 Sidewalks. Wis. Stats. § 66.0701 Special assessments. Wis. Stats. § 66.0911 Laterals and service pipes. Wis. Stats. § 66.0725 Assessment of condemnation benefits. Wis. Stats. § 66.0731 Reassessment of invalid condemnation and public improvement assessments. Wis. Stats. § 66.0705 Special assessments for local improvements. Wis. Stats. § 66.0707 Assessment against city, village or town property abutting on improvement. Wis. Stats. § 66.0727 Special assessments against railroad for street improvement. Wis. Stats. § 66.0727(3) Action to recover assessment. Wis. Stats. § 66.0729(1) Improvement of streets by abutting railroad company. Wis. Stats. § 66.0729 Notice to railroad company; time for construction. Wis. Stats. § 66.0729 Construction by municipality; assessment of cost.  
(Code 1963, § 7.11(1); Ord. No. 158-O-01, §§ 27-45, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 86-2. - Other authority retained. 
    It is not intended by the enactment of this chapter to deprive the village board of any power conferred by Wis. Stats. §§ 66.0701-66.0733 and 66.0627, but any limitations contained therein and any procedures prescribed therein for the levy of special assessments shall not apply to the exercise of the special assessment authority contained in this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(14); Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 46, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 86-3. - Levy of assessments. 
(a)  The cost of installing or constructing any public work or improvement by the village may be charged under this chapter, in whole or in part, to the property benefited by such work or improvement, and the village board may make assessment against such benefited property in the manner provided by law. 
(b)  As a complete alternative to all other methods provided by law, the village may, by resolution, levy and collect special assessments under its police powers. The assessments may be made after the completion of the work or improvement. Where the special assessment will be determined after the completion of the work or improvement, the following procedures shall apply: 
(1)  Prior to the exercise of any powers conferred by this chapter and prior to the completion of the work or improvement, the village board shall declare by preliminary resolution its intention to exercise such powers for a stated municipal purpose. The resolution shall describe generally the contemplated purpose, the limits of the proposed assessment district, the number of installments in which the special assessments may be paid, or that the number of installments will be determined at the hearing required in this chapter, and direct the proper village officer or employee to make a report thereon. The resolution may limit the proportion of the cost to be assessed. 
(2)  The report required by subsection (b)(1) of this section shall be made after completion of the work or improvement and shall consist of: 
a.  Final plans and specifications; 
b.  A statement of the entire cost of the work or improvement; 
c.  A schedule of the proposed assessments; 
d.  A statement that the property against which the assessments are proposed is benefited. 
(3)  The provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 66.0701-66.0733 are incorporated by reference into this section. References in Wis. Stats. § 66.60 to subsection (3) shall refer to subsection (b) of this section and references to subsection (2) of the statute shall refer to subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Special assessments received from a business improvement district shall be levied and collected pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.1109. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(2); Ord. No. 158-O-01, §§ 47, 48, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 86-4. - Cost of work or improvement that may be included. 
    The cost of any work or improvement to be paid, in whole or in part, by special assessment on property may include the direct and indirect cost, the damages occasioned thereby, the interest on bonds or notes issued in anticipation of the collection of the assessments, a reasonable charge for the service of the administrative staff of the village and the cost of any architectural, engineering and legal services, and any other items of direct or indirect cost which may reasonably be attributed to the proposed work or improvement. The amount to be assessed against all property for any such proposed work or improvement shall be apportioned among the individual parcels in the manner designated by the village board. The amount assessed against any property for any work or improvement which does not represent an exercise of the police power shall not exceed the value of the benefits accruing to the property therefrom, and for those representing an exercise of the police power, the assessment shall be upon a reasonable basis as determined by the village board. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(3)) 
Sec. 86-5. - Lots already served by any public work or improvement. 
    No assessment for sanitary sewer, storm sewer or water main shall be levied against a parcel of land already served with sanitary sewer, storm sewer or water main, unless such parcel of land may be divided or subdivided in accordance with the zoning chapter (chapter 122) or the subdivision chapter (chapter 94) in which case the assessment shall be computed according to the assessable footage of the new lots which may be created. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(4)(a)) 
Sec. 86-6. - Sanitary sewer main extensions. 
(a)  Assessments for sanitary sewer main extensions shall be levied as follows: 
(1)  Assessments for sanitary sewer main extensions not exceeding 12 inches in diameter shall be levied upon properties benefited by such improvements. 
(2)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, where sanitary sewer main extensions are larger than 12 inches in diameter, the village will assume the difference between the estimated cost of installing a 12-inch sanitary sewer and the actual cost of installing sanitary sewer extensions greater than 12 inches, and the properties benefited by such improvements shall be assessed on the basis of the estimated cost of installing a 12-inch sanitary sewer main. 
(b)  The applicants for a sanitary sewer main extension under section 86-12(f) (customer contributions) shall pay all costs related to the installation of any sanitary sewer main extension installed under the provisions of that section. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(5); Ord. No. 3-O-98, § 1, 5-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Special assessments for sewer laterals and service pipes, Wis. Stats. § 66.625. 
Sec. 86-7. - Water main extensions. 
    Assessments for water main extensions shall be levied as follows: 
(1)  Assessments for water main extensions not exceeding 12 inches in diameter shall be levied upon properties benefited by such improvements. 
(2)  Except as provided in subsection (3) of this section, where water main extensions are larger than 12 inches in diameter, the village will assume the difference between the estimated cost of installing a 12-inch water main and the actual cost of installing water main extensions greater than 12 inches, and the properties benefited by such improvements shall be assessed on the basis of the estimated cost of installing a 12-inch water main. 
(3)  The applicants for water main extensions under section 86-12(f) (customer contributions) shall pay all costs related to the installation of any water main extension installed under the provisions of that section. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(6); Ord. No. 3-O-98, § 3, 5-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Special assessments for water laterals and service pipes, Wis. Stats. § 66.625. 
Sec. 86-8. - Dual systems. 
    Where sanitary sewer mains, water mains and storm sewer mains are located along one side of a street and the mains are so located to service only that side of the street, assessments shall be levied upon properties benefited by such improvements and each parcel may be entitled to such deductions or exemption, if any, as the village board may determine to be reasonable and just under the circumstances in each case and consistent with the policy setout in the special assessment report adopted by the village board as part of the particular special assessment. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(7)) 
Sec. 86-9. - Street construction and improvements. 
    Assessments upon property in a limited and determinable area for special benefits conferred upon such property by new street, road and/or alley construction shall be levied upon properties benefited by such work or improvements, and each parcel of land may be entitled to such deduction or exemption, if any, as the village board may determine to be reasonable and just under the circumstances in each case and consistent with the policy setout in the special assessment report adopted by the village board as part of the particular special assessment. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(8)) 
Sec. 86-10. - Corner parcels. 
    A parcel of land against which has been levied a special assessment for sanitary sewer or water main, laid in one of the streets upon which it abuts, shall be entitled to such deduction or exemption as the village board determines to be reasonable and just under the circumstances of each case, when a special assessment is levied for sanitary sewer or water main laid in the other street upon which such corner lot abuts. The village board may allow a similar deduction or exemption from special assessments levied for any other public improvement. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(9)) 
Sec. 86-11. - Laterals and service pipes. 
(a)  Special assessments. Assessments for all laterals and service pipes, including those for sanitary sewer, water and storm sewer, shall be levied upon properties benefited by such improvements, and shall provide for the payment of all of the cost of the work or improvement. 
(b)  Construction and size. Water laterals and sanitary sewer laterals shall be constructed from the lot line or near the lot line to the main. No water lateral shall be less than one inch in diameter, and no sanitary sewer lateral shall be less than six inches in diameter. 
(c)  Risers. Risers for sanitary sewer laterals shall be considered a part of the sewer main. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(10); Ord. No. 3-O-98, § 2, 5-4-1998) 
State Law reference- Special assessments for sewer laterals or service pipes, Wis. Stats. § 66.625. 
Sec. 86-12. - Payment of assessments. 
(a)  Assessment notice. Upon completion of the work or improvement for which a special assessment is levied and upon certification by the village manager or designee that such work or improvement has been completed, the village clerk-treasurer shall bill the property owner by invoice for the full amount of the assessment. Such invoice shall notify the owner that he may elect within 30 days of the date of the invoice to pay such amount in full without interest or to pay by installments with interest as provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(b)  Cash payment. Payment of the assessment shall be made to the village clerk-treasurer on or before the expiration of 30 days from the date of the assessment notice, without interest. If the amount is not paid within 30 days, and the taxpayer does not notify the village, the full amount of the assessment shall be placed on the tax roll in ten equal installments, one-tenth each year, plus interest on the unpaid balance. 
(c)  Installment payment. 
(1)  If the property owner should so elect, payment of the full assessment may be made in installments on a ten-year plan. On the ten-year plan, the full amount of the assessment shall be paid in ten equal annual installments, one-tenth each year, plus the interest on the unpaid balance. The first installment shall be due and payable at the same date that real estate taxes are due and payable for the current year. The first installment shall include the interest commencing with the date shown on the assessment notice. The remaining annual installments shall be due and payable at the same date that real estate taxes are due and payable for each successive year thereafter. Each remaining installment shall include the interest on the unpaid balance to the year of payment. 
(2)  Special assessments received from a business improvement district pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.1109 may not be paid in installments. 
(d)  Prepayment. If the property owner should so elect, payment in full of the unpaid balance with interest to date of payment, may be paid at any time before the final installment becomes due. 
(e)  Interest. Interest at an annual rate shall be determined from time to time by the village board. 
(f)  Customer contributions. 
(1)  Advance contributions. 
a.  Where the village board has determined that the density of prospective customers does not warrant immediate assessment for water mains, sanitary sewer mains and storm sewer mains, or when a request is made for an extension in advance of the village's schedule for installation, the total cost of the extension will be determined and the total cost will be divided among the applicants for the extension and collected from them in advance as contributions for the extension. 
b.  In cases in which the village board has directed the preparation of a public facilities needs assessment and has enacted an ordinance that imposes impact fees to be used for such extensions, the village board may authorize the utilization of impact fees to pay for that portion of the total cost of the extension as identified in the needs assessment. 
(2)  Reimbursement. 
a.  Where contributions are advanced under (f)(1) above, the village shall impose a special assessment on all abutting properties benefited by the construction of the public improvement funded in whole or in part by the contribution so advanced. The amount of this special assessment shall be determined by the village board and charged in whole or in part and assessed against such abutting properties in such manner as the village board may determine after giving the owners thereof notice and an opportunity to be heard upon such proposed action in the manner set forth for special assessments in Wis. Stats. §§ 66.0703(7) and 66.0703(8). Payment of the special assessment imposed under this subparagraph (f)(2)a may be deferred as provided hereafter. 
b.  The amounts collected pursuant to special assessments imposed against abutting properties under this subsection will be retained by the village and distributed as provided in this subparagraph (f)(2)b. 
1.  Subject to part (f)(2)b,3 below, within 90 days of the date a special assessment payment is due to be paid in full under subsection (f)(2)c below, the village shall pay to the then owner of the property making the advance contribution under paragraph (f)(1) above an amount equal to the payment due. 
2.  The village shall not be required to pay any interest on amounts paid under this subparagraph (f)(2) b. 
3.  As an alternative to the distribution method specified in (f)(2)b 1. above, the owner of the property subject to the original customer contribution may, by agreement with the village at the time of the original customer contribution, designate the persons to whom the distribution will be made, subject to the terms specified by the village in the agreement. 
c.  Subject to subparagraph (f)(2)d below, special assessments imposed upon benefited abutting properties under this paragraph (f)(2) shall be paid at such time as the first of the following events occur: 
1.  The subject property is sold or transferred, or the ownership of the property at the time the special assessment is imposed is altered in any way. This includes, without limitation, transfer of the property by gift, probate, deed, land contract or operation of law. 
2.  The subject property is divided in any manner. Payment shall be due at the time the preliminary plat or preliminary certified survey map is submitted for review by the plan commission. 
3.  A request is made to connect any portion of the subject property to the public improvement for which a special assessment payment has been deferred. Payment is due at the time an application for a building permit or plumbing permit is submitted to the village. 
4.  The village board, by resolution, determines that the property must be served by the public improvement for which the special assessment payment has been deferred. The village board, at its sole discretion, may decide that there is sufficient need for the subject property to be served at such time as (i) the criteria used to defer the special assessment payment have been satisfied, or (ii) as a result of the need for the subject property to be connected to the public improvement for which the special assessment payment has been deferred, or (iii) as a result of the need for the additional extension of municipal services in the area to accommodate additional growth and development; or to promote the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
5.  A period of ten years has elapsed from the date the village board adopts the final resolution that levies the special assessment against the subject property. 
d.  Installment payments. The village board may adopt a resolution allowing the property owner to pay the assessment by installments. Such resolution shall set out the installment terms, including the annual interest rate on any unpaid balance. If the village board permits the assessment to be paid in installments, the assessment shall be paid within the time prescribed. The village shall thereafter collect and retain the installment payments collected from the property owner. 
e.  In the case of property which is used primarily for agricultural purposes by the property owner, not by tenants or others, the property owner may petition the village board to permit additional extension periods of five years. Such petition must show significant financial hardship to the property owner if such additional extension is not granted. If special assessment payment is deferred for an additional period under this subsection, the original amount of the assessment and any accrued interest shall be subject to interest as prescribed by the village board, and the special assessment and interest shall be a lien against the property. 
(g)  Deferring certain assessments. 
(1)  Deferred special assessments. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0715(2), the due date of any special assessment levied against property abutting on or benefited by a public improvement may be deferred on such terms and in such manner as prescribed by the village board while no use of the improvement is made in connection with the property. The special assessments must be paid within ten years of the date of the resolution making the levy, unless provision is made to pay the assessment by installments, in which case the assessment shall be paid within the time prescribed. In the case of property which is used primarily for agricultural purposes by the property owner, not by tenants or others, additional extension periods of five years may be granted by the village board upon petition being made by the property owner and upon a showing of significant financial hardship to the property owner, if such additional extension is not granted. The special assessments shall be subject to interest as prescribed by the village board, and the special assessment and interest shall be a lien against the property. 
(2)  Contingent special assessments. 
a.  The cost of installing or constructing any water main, sanitary sewer main, water and sewer laterals, in or over any property located in a CW-1 conservancy-wetlands district established under the provisions of chapter 122 may be determined by the village board and charged in whole or in part and assessed against properties in such district in such manner as the village board may determine after giving the owners thereof notice and an opportunity to be heard upon such proposed action in the manner set forth for special assessments in Wis. Stats. §§ 66.0703(7)(a) and 66.0703(8). 
b.  The village board may postpone the payment without interest of any such assessment indefinitely or from time to time, until one of the following conditions shall occur: 
1.  The property is rezoned, or devoted to a use not permitted under section 122-347; or 
2.  Use of such public improvement is made in connection with the property. 
c.  If any of the conditions established under subsection (g)(2)b of this section occurs within 20 years from the making of the assessment, the special assessment postponed under this section shall become immediately due and payable and shall be collected in the manner provided for the collection of other special assessments, with interest from the date it is first due. 
(3)  The provisions of this subsection (g) do not apply to special assessments imposed under subsection (f)(2) above. 
(h)  Permits. Prior to the issuance of any building or plumbing permit, the village manager or designee shall refer the application for a permit to the village clerk-treasurer to determine if a special assessment, customer contribution or a deferred assessment is outstanding against the parcel involved. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(11); Ord. No. 3-O-98, § 4, 5-4-1998; Ord. No. 158-O-01, §§ 49-52, 11-19-01; Ord. No. 217-O-03, §§ 1, 3, 2-3-03) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 217-O-03, adopted Feb. 3, 2003 provided for adoption of the policy entitled Policy for Section 86-12(f) Customer Contributions dated January 30, 2003. This policy shall be kept on file in the office of the director of engineering services, or such other person designated by the village manager, and shall be available to the public. This policy may be amended from time to time by ordinance or resolution of the village board. 
Sec. 86-13. - Dividing and subdividing. 
    All public improvements required at the time of dividing or subdividing in accordance with the zoning chapter (chapter 122) or the subdivisions chapter (chapter 94) shall be constructed and paid for as provided in chapter 94, all as contained in this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(12)) 
Sec. 86-14. - Situations not covered. 
    Situations not covered by this chapter in levying special assessments for the installation and construction of public improvements in the village shall be resolved by the village board upon the recommendation of the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 7.11(13)) 
Chapter 90 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street saved from repeal, § 1-11(a)(12); any ordinance establishing the grade of any street or sidewalk saved from repeal, § 1-11(a)(13); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; moving of structures, § 18-241 et seq.; environment, ch. 38; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 58; parks and recreation, ch. 66; peddlers, solicitors and transient merchants, ch. 70; signs, ch. 78; subdivision and other divisions of land, ch. 94; telecommunications, ch. 102; traffic and vehicles, ch. 106; parades, street closing and block parties, § 106-256 et seq.; utilities, ch. 110; vegetation, ch. 114; vehicles for hire, ch. 118; zoning, ch. 122; shoreland-wetland zoning ordinance, app. B. 
State Law reference- Authority to acquire property for streets, Wis. Stats. § 61.34(3); authority to grant street privileges, Wis. Stats. § 66.045. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Street and sidewalk grades. 
(a)  Establishment. The grade of all streets, alleys and sidewalks may be established by resolution by the village board and the same recorded by the village manager or designee in his office. No street, alley or sidewalk shall be worked until the grade thereof is established. The grades of all streets having curb and gutter on the effective date of the ordinances from which this section is derived are established at the level then existing. 
(b)  Alteration of grades. No person shall alter the grade of any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground, or any part thereof in the village, unless authorized or instructed to do so by the village board or the village manager or designee. All such alterations of grade shall be recorded in the office of the village manager. 
(Code 1963, § 7.01) 
Sec. 90-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 747-O-19, § 1, adopted March 18, 2019, repealed § 90-2, which pertained to obstructions and encroachments. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 90-3. - Playing in streets. 
    No person shall play in the streets of the village. 
(Code 1963, § 7.07(1)) 
Sec. 90-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 747-O-19, § 2, adopted March 18, 2019, repealed § 90-4, which pertained to placement of dumpsters or other similar containers within the public right-of-way. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 90-5. - Outdoor cafe permit. 
(a)  The following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them when used in this article: 
(1)  Liquor establishment shall mean an establishment licensed by the Village of Menomonee Falls to sell alcoholic beverages at retail in accordance with the provisions of chapter 6 of this Code. 
(2)  Outdoor cafe shall mean a use of public sidewalk by a food service establishment or liquor establishment, for the serving of food and beverages. The use will be characterized by the outdoor use of tables, and chairs and umbrellas. 
(3)  Outdoor cafes shall be permitted on public sidewalks within the village centre on Appleton Avenue from Roosevelt Drive south to Mill Street and continuing on the east side of Appleton Avenue to the point 270 feet south of Jacobson Drive and on Main Street from the point 160 feet east of Water Street west to Hoyt Drive. 
(4)  Permit area shall mean the public sidewalk area designated on the permit specifying the area of operation of the outdoor cafe. 
(5)  Permittee shall mean the person or entity operating a business or liquor establishment who has received a permit allowing for the operation of an outdoor cafe. 
(b)  Permits required. 
(1)  Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an outdoor cafe on public right-of-way without first obtaining a permit pursuant to this article. 
(2)  Locations. The outdoor cafe permit shall allow a business or liquor establishment located in the area as described in subsection 90-5(a)(4) to operate an outdoor cafe subject to the requirements of this chapter. 
(3)  Trespass. The permit holder shall, as part of the right granted pursuant to the permit, be entitled to remove or exclude persons from the permit area during hours of business operation. Such permittee is authorized to give notice to any such person to prevent entry. No cover charge or minimum purchase may be required for admittance to an outdoor cafe area in the public right-of-way. 
(4)  Duration. The initial term of the outdoor cafe permit shall begin on the date of issuance if after March 1 and expire on November 1. The term of the permit after the initial term shall begin March 1 and end November 1. 
(5)  The application, suspension or revocation of any such permit issued pursuant to this article shall be subject to subsection 90-5(f). 
(c)  Application; fee. 
(1)  An application for an outdoor cafe permit shall be made on forms supplied by the village, and submitted to the department of community development director, together with the fee set forth in chapter 42, and shall, at minimum, include the following: 
a.  The name, address, telephone number, and email address of the owner of the property and also the business establishment related to the permit. 
b.  A scaled drawing of the proposed permit area and which shows the location, size and type of the tables, chairs, trash receptacles and other equipment proposed to be used, location of ingress and egress, the curb line and any existing public or utility-owned equipment facilities in or adjacent to the area proposed which are visible to the eye, including but not limited to, trees, covers and utility poles or openings. 
c.  An operations plan specifying the proposed dates, days and hours of operation of the outdoor cafe, the hours of operation of the adjacent business, scheduled maintenance of the permit area, maximum seating capacity, and method of providing security and maintenance. 
d.  An original certificate of insurance shall be provided in the amount of $1,000,000.00 naming the Village of Menomonee Falls as an insured party in connection with each outdoor cafe seating area. 
e.  Any other information related to the requirements of this chapter that the department of community development director may require. 
f.  If the proposed outdoor cafe extends on to sidewalk areas abutting a property owned by someone other than the applicant, as provided in subsection (1) of subsection (e) of section 90-5 of this chapter, the application shall include a written consent to said extension that includes the signature of the other owner. 
(d)  Review of applications. 
(1)  Review. Department of community development director shall review the application for a sidewalk cafe permit and determine whether to issue the permit. No permit shall be issued pursuant to this Chapter unless the department of community development director has determined the following: 
a.  There are no outstanding fines, fees, taxes or other charges due and owed to the village by the applicant or the owners of the real property on which the establishment is located. 
b.  The applicant has supplied all of the information required on or by the application, and any additional information requested by the department of community development director. 
c.  The applicant shall obtain and amend all applicable licenses and permits associated with the proposed outdoor cafe area. 
d.  All of the requirements of this chapter have been met. 
(2)  Conditions. The department of community development director may impose conditions upon the issuance of a sidewalk cafe permit in order to protect the use of adjacent right-of-way for its intended purpose, to prevent congestion of vehicular or pedestrian traffic flow and to otherwise carry out the purpose and intent of this article and this Code. 
(e)  Regulations. 
(1)  Not in roadway. An outdoor cafe is permitted only on public sidewalks. The permit area shall be immediately adjacent to the establishment requesting the permit, or on public sidewalks contiguous to the public sidewalk adjacent to the establishment. If the proposed cafe area extends to areas abutting the property of another, the consent of that property owner shall be obtained before such area is approved as part of the permit. 
(2)  Hours of operation. The hours when service is permitted at the outdoor cafe shall be during 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(3)  General requirements. Any person making use of an outdoor cafe shall do so in a reasonable manner with due regard for the health and safety of persons and property. No permittee shall make any physical alteration to public property without the written permission of the department of community development director. A permittee shall owe a duty to the Village of Menomonee Falls and third persons to maintain the permit area in a clean, safe and sanitary condition. 
(4)  Litter prohibited. The permittee shall keep the permit area free of litter, cans, bottles and spills at all times. The permittee shall promptly collect and dispose of all litter, trash and other waste materials associated with the outdoor cafe, including waste material in the adjacent public right-of-way. This includes, but is not limited to, cigarette butts, gum, food material, glassware and bodily fluids. The permittee shall dispose of any such waste in their own trash containers only. Permittee shall power wash the permit area as needed to maintain cleanliness of the public sidewalk area. 
(5)  Restoration. Upon the expiration or other termination of an outdoor cafe; use permit or if operation of the business ceases, the permittee shall immediately remove all tables, chairs, furnishings, equipment and other items of personal property from the permit area. Any such items remaining upon the public right-of-way may be removed and disposed of by the Village of Menomonee Falls at the sole cost and expense of the permittee. 
(6)  Equipment allowed-sidewalks. 
a.  Only the following types of furniture or other equipment may be located in an outdoor cafe area: 
1.  Tables and chairs, provided they are of a quality to sustain weather and wear, and shall be of a material other than molded plastic; 
2.  Umbrellas, provided that they are anchored to prevent displacement from a sudden burst of wind; 
3.  Waste receptacles; 
4.  One menu sign or board attached to the building within the permit area. 
b.  Said furniture and other equipment shall be portable and shall not be affixed to the surface of the permit area. Furniture and equipment shall either be removed on a nightly basis or compactly stacked and secured in a manner that furniture cannot leave the sidewalk cafe area. 
(7)  Size and spacing. 
a.  The maximum allowable dimension for tables shall be 48 inches in diameter and 48 inches in width or length. 
b.  Tables shall be freestanding with detached chairs or seating, unless it is determined that another design meets the intent of these regulations and a specific exception is permitted in writing by the department of community development director. 
c.  Umbrellas shall have a maximum diameter of four feet, a weighted base and be fabric covered. No portion of any umbrellas shall extend beyond the boundaries of the cafe. 
d.  Menu boards or signs attached to the building in the permit area shall not exceed six square feet in area. 
e.  Tables, chairs, umbrellas, and other permissible equipment shall be located in the outdoor cafe area so that there remains open, at all times, a longitudinal walking space, of a minimum of four feet in width, which distance may be increased if the department of community development director deems it necessary for pedestrian safety. 
(f)  Temporary nature of use. 
(1)  Revocable permits. The use of a public sidewalk as an outdoor cafe shall be subject to temporary suspension or termination at any time by the village in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare. To the extent that a permit area is needed by the village for the purposes for which it was dedicated, or any other public purpose, the village may immediately terminate the revocable use permit by sending written notice to the permittee and assume full possession and control of the permit area. The permittee shall remove all furniture from the right-of-way within the time specified by the notice. If the furniture is not removed by the permittee, the village shall be authorized to remove all furniture and other objects of permittee from the permit area. 
(2)  Abandonment. If such furniture is not reclaimed by the permittee within seven days after removal by the village, the property shall be presumed abandoned and subject to disposal according to law. 
(g)  Public property. The provisions of this section shall apply only to the locating of outdoor cafes on public property or public right-of-way and shall not apply to any private property. 
(h)  Payment for cleaning or damages. 
(1)  Conditions. As an express condition of the issuance of the permit, the permittee shall agree to, within seven days after the billing date, pay to the village all costs associated with damage to the pavement or other village-owned facilities located in or adjacent to the permit area caused by operation of the food service establishment, or the cleaning of or trash removal from the permit area or adjacent premises occasioned by the failure of the permittee to clean or remove such trash. 
(Ord. No. 624-O-15, § 1, 6-15-15) 
Secs. 90-6-90-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CURB, DRIVEWAY OR SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-21. - Appeal to village board. 
    Whenever an applicant for a permit under this article has been denied an application for a permit under this article, the applicant may appeal from such decision to the village board. 
(Code 1963, § 7.02(7)) 
Sec. 90-22. - Permit required. 
    Prior to cutting any curb or the construction or reconstruction of any curb, driveway and sidewalk in the public highway (the area between the lot line and the traveled portion of the road), a permit for such work shall be obtained from the village manager or designee who will furnish detailed information as to what utilities or other appurtenances are located in the area and as to just how this work must be accomplished. No permit shall be issued unless the village manager or designee is satisfied that such proposed construction will not interfere with existing utilities or other appurtenances located in such areas. 
(Code 1963, § 7.02(1), (4)) 
Sec. 90-23. - Manner of making cut. 
    Where it is necessary to cut through an existing concrete curb of a village street to install a driveway, the old concrete pavement and curb for its full depth and for the full width of flared driveway shall be removed to a point flush with the street side of the curb. The entire portion of curbing removed shall be the confines of the lot which the driveway serves unless agreeable to the adjacent property owners to extend the flare over the lot line. The exact manner of cutting and replacing the curb shall be shown on a sketch furnished the contractor at the time the curb permit is issued. 
(Code 1963, § 7.02(2)) 
Sec. 90-24. - Expansion joints. 
    Where cement sidewalks or driveways are built to the curbs, either at crosswalks or in front of private property, expansion joints made up of one, one-half-inch strip of asphalted felt shall be inserted. 
(Code 1963, § 7.02(3)) 
Sec. 90-25. - Concrete walks. 
    Public walks shall be of Portland cement concrete and built to specifications on file in the office of the village manager. Permeable surfacing, installed in accordance with the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources Conservation Practice Standard 1008, or equivalent technical standard, may be used on private property. All contractors building public walks in this village shall conform to these specifications and to the grades for same as given by the village manager or designee. Public walks, including those built by the village, shall be inspected by the village. 
(Code 1963, § 7.02(4); Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 9, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 90-26. - Curbs and gutters. 
(a)  The village manager or designee, upon receiving a request in writing from a property owner in the village requesting the construction of curb and gutter in front of or along the side of the property owned by such petitioner, may, if practical with respect to alignment and establishment grade, proceed with the installation of such curb and gutter and cause the same to be installed, provided that such property owner deposits with the village manager or designee the estimated cost of such work or signs a waiver waiving all notice required by law to be given to such property owner for the levy of special assessments and consenting to the payment of the cost for such curb and gutter, such payment to be made in full on or before November 1 of the year in which such work is completed, or in three or five equal annual installments, together with such interest as may be determined from time to time by the village board, along with the general real estate taxes, provided "Notice of Election to Pay in Installments" has been given to the village manager or designee prior to November 1 of the year in which the work is completed. All requests for curb and gutter to be constructed under village contract shall be presented to the village manager or designee prior to May 15 of each year. 
(b)  Curb and gutter, other than driveway sections, shall be installed only by the village or under village contract. 
(Code 1963, § 7.02(5)) 
Sec. 90-27. - Driveways. 
(a)  Specifications for standard driveways. The grade and slope of the sidewalk pavement shall not be altered by the construction of a standard driveway; provided, however, that where the sidewalk area is paved to the curb, the provisions of subsection (c) of this section shall apply. 
(b)  Specifications for raised street pavement driveways. The grade and slope of the sidewalk pavement shall not be altered by the construction of a raised street pavement driveway. The pavement of the road at the gutter line shall be tapered toward the crown of the roadway to eliminate any sharp dip. The cost of raising the pavement and providing such drainage facilities as the village manager or designee deems necessary shall be determined by the village manager or designee and paid by the applicant. 
(c)  Specifications and fees for depressed driveways. The grade and slope of the sidewalk pavement may be depressed, provided that: 
(1)  The slope in the longitudinal and transverse shall not exceed one inch vertical in 12 inches horizontal. 
(2)  No part of the driveway or the depression shall encroach on the adjoining lot unless permission in writing has been obtained from the owner of the adjoining lot and filed with the village manager or designee. 
(3)  At street intersections no part of the depressed driveway may extend beyond the lot line of the intersecting street unless permission to do so has been granted by the village manager or designee. 
(4)  The applicant for the permit to construct such depressed driveway across the sidewalk area shall be the owner, and lessee and mortgagee, if any, of the premises served by such driveway. 
(5)  Such applicant shall pay a permit fee in the amount established in section 42-90(a). 
(d)  Restoration of street pavement, curb, gutter and sidewalk. When the improvements on or the use of property, which is being served by a driveway, is so changed that the driveway, in the opinion of the village manager or designee, is not needed, the owner of the property shall restore the street pavement, curb, gutter, and sidewalk to the same condition as the adjoining street pavement, curb, gutter and sidewalk. Upon failure of the owner of the property to so do, the village manager or designee is empowered and directed to perform such restoration and assess the cost to the property. 
(e)  Protection of public utility services. Whenever, in constructing a driveway, it becomes necessary to cut public utility services at the curbline, the cost of cutting such cable or main, shall be done at the expense of the applicant for such permit and under the direction and supervision of the village manager or designee. No permit shall be granted until after a deposit shall be made with the village manager or designee in a sum to be determined by the village manager or designee to cover the cost of protecting such utility services. A similar deposit shall be required to reimburse the village for any cost of relaying pavements, rebuilding, changing or adding additional catchbasins. 
(Code 1963, § 7.02(6)) 
Secs. 90-28-90-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SIDEWALK MAINTENANCE, REPAIR AND REPLACEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 617-O-15, § 2, adopted March 2, 2015, repealed Div. 2 in its entirety and enacted a new Div. 2 to read as set out herein. Former Div. 2, §§ 90-66-90-76, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 40-O-99, § 1(7.06(1)), adopted March 1, 1999; Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 5, adopted Nov. 19, 2001; Ord. No. 393-O-08, § 1, adopted Feb. 18, 2008; Ord. No. 398-O-08, § 2, adopted April 7, 2008; Ord. No. 475-O-10, § 1, adopted Jan. 18, 2010. 

Sec. 90-66. - Inspection and evaluation of existing sidewalks. 
(a)  The village completed an initial evaluation of the condition of all existing sidewalks in the village to identify defects in 1998. The evaluation process will continue in an ongoing basis. 
(b)  The village intends to implement an ongoing program for the repair and/or replacement of defective sidewalks. 
(c)  The village, at its sole discretion, shall determine which sidewalks are defective, and whether these sidewalks will be repaired or replaced. 
(d)  The village will be responsible for the cost to repair and/or replace defective public sidewalks within the public right-of-way. Carriage walks and private walks located within the public right-of-way shall be the responsibility of the abutting property owner. The abutting property owner may request that the village replace a defective carriage walk or private walk in the public right-of-way as an additional work request, subject to section 90-74. 
(e)  The village staff shall identify or list the types of defects which, in the professional judgment of the staff, affect the sidewalk in such a manner as to require the replacement and/or repair of that sidewalk. The director of public works shall keep a written list of these defects on file. 
(f)  All public sidewalk slabs located partially or fully within public rights-of-way which exhibit defects of the type identified on the list entitled "Sidewalk Slab Defects Requiring Repair or Replacement" on file with the director of public works, are to be considered for repair or replacement. 
(g)  Sidewalk repair or replacement shall be made in order to eliminate trip hazards as the first priority and to improve drainage defects. 
(Ord. No. 617-O-15, § 2, 3-2-15) 
Sec. 90-67. - Snow and ice removal. 
(a)  Responsibility of owner, occupant or other person in charge. The owner, occupant or person in charge of each and every building or structure or unoccupied lot in the village fronting or abutting any street shall clean or cause to be cleaned the sidewalk in front of or adjoining each such home, building or unoccupied lot, as the case may be, of snow or ice to the width of such sidewalk within 24 hours after cessation of each snowfall event, and shall cause the sidewalk to be kept clear from ice and snow, provided that when the ice has formed on any sidewalk so that it cannot be immediately removed, the persons referred to in this subsection shall keep the sidewalk sprinkled with salt or sand. 
(b)  Removal by village. If snow or ice is not removed or sprinkled with salt or sand, etc., as required in subsection (a) of this section, the village manager or designee shall cause the same to be done and the cost entered on the next tax roll as a special charge against the benefited property pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0627. 
(c)  Obstructing public ways. No person in the course of removing snow or ice from any private property shall cause or permit such snow or ice to be placed or left on any public way. 
(d)  Penalty. In addition to any special charge or assessment which may be imposed under subsection (b) of this section, any person who violates subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 617-O-15, § 2, 3-2-15) 
Sec. 90-68. - Defective sidewalk adjacent to trees. 
(a)  Removal of tree roots. Where tree roots have caused the sidewalk defect, the visible tree roots shall be completely removed from underneath the defective public sidewalk and up to six inches beyond the front and back edge of sidewalk by means of grinding or sawing to provide for proper grade and alignment of the new sidewalk. 
(b)  Trees located in the public right-of-way. In locations where the director of public works determines that sawing or grinding of the tree roots will jeopardize the health and/or integrity of a tree located in the public right-of-way, or if the tree is determined to be compromised or in poor health, the tree will be scheduled for removal by the village. All costs for removal of trees located within the public right-of-way will be paid for by the village. The village is not obligated to replace trees within the public right-of-way that are removed under this section or are removed for any other reason or cause. 
(c)  Trees not located in the public right-of-way . In locations where the director of public works determines that sawing or grinding of the tree roots will jeopardize the health and/or integrity of a tree that is not located in the public right-of-way, such tree is hereby specifically declared to be a public health nuisance, and the director of public works shall order that such tree be removed. All costs for removal of such trees not located within the public right-of-way will be the responsibility of the owner of the property on which the tree is located. The village will not be responsible for damage to, or removal of, trees located beyond the limits of the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 617-O-15, § 2, 3-2-15) 
Sec. 90-69. - Construction or repair of public sidewalk.
