The regulations of this chapter are made with reasonable consideration, among other things, of the character of the village with a view of conserving the value of the buildings placed upon land, providing the best possible environment for human habitation, and for encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the village. 
(Code 1963, § 18.01) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 236.45(1). 
Sec. 94-3. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to: 
(1)  Transfers of interests in land by will or pursuant to court order; 
(2)  Leases for a term not to exceed ten years, mortgages or easements; 
(3)  The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining property if additional lots are not thereby created and the lots resulting are not reduced below the minimum sizes required by this chapter or other applicable laws or ordinances. 
(Code 1963, § 18.02(3)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 236.45(2)(a). 
Sec. 94-4. - Issuance of permits to nonrecorded land parcels. 
    No building or occupancy permit shall be issued for a new building on a lot which did not exist as a described and recorded parcel prior to the date of this chapter, or was not created by recorded subdivision pursuant to state statute, or by a recorded plat pursuant to provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 18.11) 
Sec. 94-5. - Variances. 
    When, in the judgment of the plan commission or the village board, it would be inappropriate to apply literally a provision of this chapter because the subdivision is located outside the corporate limits or because extraordinary hardship would result, it may waive or vary such provisions so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided that in no event shall the requirement of filing and recording the plat or survey be waived. 
(Code 1963, § 18.12) 
Sec. 94-6. - Enforcement guidelines. 
    The village manager or designee may promulgate regulations or guidelines to implement the provisions of this chapter. No person shall violate such regulations or guidelines. 
Sec. 94-7. - Subdivisions created by successive divisions. 
(a)  Assessor's plat. Where it is not practicable to require that a final plat of a subdivision created by successive divisions be filed in accordance with this chapter, the village board may, in lieu thereof, order an assessor's plat to be made under Wis. Stats. § 70.27, and may assess the cost as provided in such section, or to the subdivider. 
(b)  Compliance required. Regardless of the type of plat filed, any such subdivision shall comply with all provisions of this chapter to the extent that they may reasonably be applied. 
(Code 1963, § 18.09(1)) 
State Law reference- Requirements for assessor's plats, Wis. Stats. § 236.03(2). 
Sec. 94-8. - Existing substandard lots. 
(a)  Procedure for determination of status. In the case of a lot of record on November 16, 1959, which does not conform to the zoning regulations of the village, and which adjoins along a side lot line property held in the same ownership, no such lot shall be conveyed to another owner nor shall a building permit be issued for a structure on such lot except in conformity with the following: 
(1)  Petition. The owner of such substandard lot may, at any time prior to the proposed conveyance of such lot or request for building permit, petition the village for determination as to the status of such lot. 
(2)  Referral. Such petition shall be referred to the plan commission for a study to determine the practical possibility of a redivision of such ownership to provide lots which will be in conformity to the zoning regulations of the village. 
(3)  Plan commission recommendation. The plan commission shall make its recommendation to the village board within 40 days of the date the petition was received, and the village board shall act within 20 days to give the petitioner a determination. 
(4)  Factors to be considered. The plan commission, in making its recommendation, and the village board, in making its determination, shall give consideration among others to the following factors: 
a.  The size, quality and character of existing lots and building development in the immediate area with a view to maintaining compatibility and protecting existing values. 
b.  Where public sewer is not available, the lot size necessary to ensure safe sewage disposal. 
c.  The economic and engineering practicality of any possible redivision. 
d.  The degree of practical hardship which may be imposed upon the owner. 
(5)  Redivision of lots. Such redivision may be accomplished as is most appropriate by: 
a.  Vacation and replatting of all or a part of a recorded plat. 
b.  Combining of lots or parts of lots. 
c.  Redefining of lot lines by a plat of other divisions, as provided by division 3, article II of this chapter. 
(b)  When lots in same ownership. For the purposes of this section, lots and property shall be considered in the same ownership when owned by: the same individual or corporation; an individual and another in joint tenancy, or as tenants in common, and either of such joint or common tenants owns other lots individually or as joint tenant or tenant in common with another; an individual and his spouse, parents, grandparents, children, grandchildren, or the spouse of any child or grandchild, or a brother or sister or spouse of a brother or sister of such person and an individual and a corporation in which such individual is an officer or director or controlling stockholder. 
(Code 1963, § 18.10) 
Sec. 94-9. - Subdivisions. 
(a)  Any division of land within the village or within its extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction which results in a subdivision shall be surveyed and a plat thereof approved and recorded pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and Wis. Stats. ch. 236. 
(b)  The fees required in section 42-94(b) shall accompany a request for approval of a plat within the Village of Menomonee Falls. 
(c)  The fee required in section 42-94(c) shall accompany a request for review of a plat within the extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction of the Village of Menomonee Falls. 
(Code 1963, § 18.02(1); Ord. No. 213-O-02, § 116, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 2, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 94-10. - Other divisions. 
(a)  Any division of land other than a subdivision within the village, of which a plat has not been approved and recorded pursuant to section 94-9, shall be surveyed and a certified survey map of such division shall be approved and recorded as required by division 3, article II of this chapter. 
(b)  The fees required in section 42-94(d) shall accompany a request for approval of other divisions of land within the village. 
(Code 1963, § 18.02(2); Ord. No. 213-O-02, § 117, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 3, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 94-11. - Penalty. 
    In addition to any penalties authorized under Wis. Stats. §§ 236.30 and 236.31, any person who fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-7. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1963, § 18.13) 
Secs. 94-12-94-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 94-31-94-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 94-46. - Application of division provisions. 
    The provisions of this division apply to subdivision plats. 
Sec. 94-47. - Preliminary plat. 
(a)  Required. Before submitting a final plat for approval, the subdivider shall submit a preliminary plat to the plan commission in order that general agreement may be reached on layout and arrangement of streets and lots before a final plat is prepared. The form and data required for plat submittal shall be as designated under sections 94-48 and 94-49. 
(b)  Preliminary consultation. The subdivider shall, before submitting the plat for official filing, meet with the plan commission for preliminary consultation in order to ensure that the plat is acceptable for processing. 
(1)  The fee required in § 42-94(b)(1) shall be paid before scheduling a preliminary consultation. 
(c)  Plan commission action. If the plat is satisfactory, the plan commission may recommend its official filing and act to grant preliminary approval of the plat subject to and effective upon certification of no objection from agencies authorized to object. 
(d)  Official filing. Following the preliminary consultation, the plat, and such copies as may be required, shall be officially filed with the village manager or designee who shall forthwith forward the necessary copies thereof to the director of the planning function in the state department of resource development and, where necessary, to the county park and planning commission, as required by Wis. Stats. § 236.12, retain one copy in the official file, and return two copies to the village manager or designee along with pertinent data applicable thereto. 
(1)  The fee required in §42-94(b)(2) shall accompany a preliminary plat being submitted for official filing. 
(e)  Official approval. The plan commission shall, within 90 days of the official filing, approve conditionally, or reject the plat. The subdivider shall be notified in writing of any conditions of approval or the reasons for rejection. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 236.12, no approval shall be granted until it has been certified that there is no objection to the plat by any agency authorized to object. 
(f)  Significance of approval. Approval of the preliminary plat shall entitle the subdivider to final approval of the layout shown by such plat if the final plat conforms substantially to such layout and conditions of approval have been met. 
_____
(g)  In order to set forth consistent standards for the review of development proposals in Waukesha County each subdivision shall contain the following elements: 
P = Preliminary Review Document 
F = Final Review Document 
a. Development identification.  1. P F Development title.  2. P F Property location (1/4-1/4 section, section, township, range, county).  3. P F Small drawing showing section or a government subdivision of section in which subdivision lies, oriented the same as main drawing.  4. P F Name and address of owner and subdivider.  5. P F Surveyor's certificate signed, dated and sealed and revision dates on all pages.  6. P F Sheet numbers (total number of sheets notation). b. Mapping features.  1. P F North arrow and graphic scale.  2. P F 100-year floodplain limits (elevation and contour) as made available by FEMA and SEWRPC.  3. P F Wetlands, (Preliminary-Identify source of delineation; Final-Field delineation) lakes, streams, channels, ditches on or adjacent to the site.  4. F Bearings and length of exterior boundaries.  5. P F Name and location of all right-of-way.  6. P F Structures existing on-site and within 20 feet adjoining property and use of structures to be retained.  7. P F Existing and proposed easements, their type and dimensions.  8. P F Lot number and dimensions including outlots.  9. F Curve information on curve or in a table, street radius (P only). 10. P F Public dedication parcels and right-of-way dedications. 11. F Historic or cultural features (i.e., Indian mounds). 12. F Survey monumentation and other attributes as required by Wis. Stats. § 236. 13. P F Wells (onsite and within 100 feet of septic or stormwater facilities or as required by DNR Well Code). c. Planning and zoning document consistency.  1. P F Locally adopted comprehensive land use plans.  2. P F Consistency with land use patterns and density standards set forth in the county development plan.  3. P F Street and highway width map.  4. P F Park and open space plan.  5. P F Local zoning.  
(Code 1963, § 18.04(1)(a); Ord. No. 130-O-01, § 2, 4-16-01; Ord. No. 213-O-02, §§ 118, 119, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 458-O-09, § 1, 10-19-09) 
State Law reference- Preliminary plats, Wis. Stats. § 236.11. 
Sec. 94-48. - Preliminary consultation data. 
    The following information shall be provided at the time of the preliminary consultation: 
(1)  Information, including data on existing covenants, land characteristics and available community facilities and utilities; and information describing the subdivision proposal such as number of residential lots, typical lot width and depth, business areas, playgrounds, park area, and other public areas, tree planting, proposed protective covenants and proposed utilities and street improvements. 
(2)  A location map showing the relationship of the proposed subdivision to existing community facilities which serve or would be influenced by it, and including the development name and location, main traffic arteries, title, scale, north arrow and date. 
(3)  A sketch plan showing in simple sketch form the proposed layout of streets, lots and other features in relation to existing conditions. The sketch plan may be a freehand pencil sketch made directly on a print of the topographic survey. 
(Code 1963, § 18.07(1)) 
Sec. 94-49. - Contents of preliminary plat; area to be shown. 
(a)  The preliminary plat shall be drawn with waterproof nonfading black ink or legibly with pencil on tracing cloth, or tracing paper of good quality, to a scale of 200 feet to an inch and shall show correctly on its face: 
(1)  The date, scale and northpoint. 
(2)  The proposed subdivision name, which shall not duplicate the name of any plat previously recorded in the county. 
(3)  The name and address of the owner, the subdivider, and the engineer or surveyor preparing the plat. 
(4)  Location of the subdivision by government lot, quarter-quarter section, section, township, range and county. 
(5)  A small scale drawing of the section or government subdivision of the section in which the subdivision lies with the location of the subdivision indicated thereon. 
(6)  The exact length and bearing of the exterior boundaries of the subdivision. 
(7)  Location and names of adjacent subdivisions and the owners of the adjoining parcels of unsubdivided land. 
(8)  Zoning on and adjacent to the subdivision. 
(9)  Location, widths and names of all existing and platted streets, alleys or other public ways and easements, railroad and utility rights-of-way, parks, cemeteries, watercourses, drainage ditches, permanent buildings, bridges and other pertinent data, as determined by the plan commission. 
(10)  The water elevations of adjoining lakes or streams at the date of the survey and the approximate high and low water elevations of such lakes or streams. 
(11)  If the subdivision borders a lake or stream, the distances and bearing of a meander line established not less than 20 feet back from the ordinary high water mark of the lake or stream. 
(12)  Layout, width and approximate grades of all new streets and rights-of-way, such as alleys, highways, easements for sewers, water mains and other public utilities. 
(13)  Direction and distance to nearest water and sewer mains. 
(14)  Approximate dimensions of and areas of lots. 
(15)  Proposed building lines. 
(16)  Approximate radii of all curves and length of tangents. 
(17)  Approximate location and area of property proposed to be dedicated for public use or to be reserved by deed covenant for use of all property owners in the subdivision with the conditions, if any, of such dedication or reservation. 
(18)  Contours at vertical intervals of not more than five feet, or at more frequent intervals if required by the plan commission for land of unusual terrain characteristics. All pertinent elevations should be shown and shall be based on village datum. 
(19)  The stormwater management facilities shall be designed with the following parameters incorporated into the design: 
a.  The preliminary sizing shall be in accordance with the MMSD Surface Water and Storm Water Rules Guidance Manual guidelines of 0.3 acre-feet of storage per acre of proposed impervious area unless a final design is submitted. 
b.  The preliminary plat shall contain sufficient area to provide this sizing. 
c.  The stormwater management facilities shall be located in an outlot and not in proposed lots. 
(b)  The area for which such data is to be shown shall extend beyond the boundaries of the actual property being platted a distance which will adequately relate the plat to its surroundings. 
(Code 1963, § 18.07(2); Ord. No. 291-O-04, § 1, 12-20-04) 
Sec. 94-50. - Engineering data. 
(a)  Following approval of the preliminary plat and prior to submittal of a final plat, the subdivider shall furnish to the village manager or designee the following engineering data pertaining to utilities and improvements in the plat as is pertinent and as requested by the village manager or designee. 
(1)  Plan and profiles showing existing and established grades for all streets, alleys, public rights-of-way and proposed buildings. 
(2)  Plan and profiles of all storm sewers, culverts and surface water drainage facilities. 
(3)  Plan and profiles of all sanitary sewers including one sanitary sewer lateral per lot to run to lot lines. 
(4)  Plan and profiles of all water distribution lines including stop-boxes and appurtenances including one water lateral per lot to run to lot line. 
(b)  All such plans and profiles shall be approved by the village manager or designee before the final plat shall be deemed acceptable for filing. 
(Code 1963, § 18.04(1)(b)) 
Sec. 94-51. - Ownership data. 
    Following approval of the preliminary plat and at the time of filing the final plat, the subdivider shall submit a certificate from a recognized title company showing the legal interest any one may have in the land being subdivided. 
(Code 1963, § 18.04(1)(c)) 
Sec. 94-52. - Final plat generally. 
(a)  The final plat shall be submitted to the village manager or designee within three years of approval of the preliminary plat. The plan commission may waive this requirement, or formally extend the timeframe. 
(b)  In order to ensure that the plat is acceptable for processing, it shall be submitted initially to the village manager or designee for checking. 
(c)  Upon official filing, the village manager or designee shall forthwith forward the plat to the plan commission and shall forward copies of the plat to the director of the planning function in the state department of resource development, as required by Wis. Stats. § 236.12. The plan commission shall refer the final plat with its recommendation to the village board. The board shall approve or reject the final plat within 60 days of its submission to the village manager or designee unless the time is extended by agreement with the subdivider. Reasons for rejections shall be stated in the minutes of the board meeting, and a copy or a written statement of such reasons shall be supplied the subdivider. 
(d)  If the original of the final plat has been filed with another approving authority, the subdivider may file a true copy of such plat in lieu of the original. However, before approval of the village board will be inscribed on the original of the final plat, the surveyor or the subdivider shall certify the respects in which the original of the final plat differs from the true copy, and all modifications must first be approved. 
(Code 1963, § 18.04(1)(d); Ord. No. 33-O-99, § 1, 1-18-99; Ord. No. 213-O-02, § 120, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 4, 5-17-04; Ord. No. 509-O-11, § 1, 5-16-11) 
Sec. 94-53. - Final plat data. 
(a)  A final plat of subdivided land shall comply with the requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.20, which is hereby adopted by reference. 
(b)  The affidavits and certificates required by Wis. Stats. ch. 236 shall be lettered or printed legibly with black durable ink or typed legibly with black ribbon in the final plat. 
(c)  A duplicate tracing of the final plat shall be filed with the village manager or designee together with copies of such number and size as may be required by the village manager or designee from time to time. 
(Code 1963, § 18.07(3)) 
Sec. 94-54. - Optional processing procedure. 
    Where the developer chooses to follow the optional procedure in processing the plat as provided by Wis. Stats. § 236.12, the village manager or designee and plan commission shall modify their procedure and the wording of the necessary certificate and approval accordingly. 
(Code 1963, § 18.04(1)(e)) 
Secs. 94-55-94-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OTHER LAND DIVISIONS 

Sec. 94-71. - Application of division provisions. 
    The provisions of this division apply to divisions of land other than subdivisions. 
Sec. 94-72. - Preliminary certified survey map. 
(a)  Before submitting a final certified survey map for approval, the subdivider shall submit a preliminary certified survey map according to the procedure designated for a subdivision under section 94-47, except that no state or county agency actions are required. 
(b)  The fee required in section 42-94(d)(1) shall accompany the application for a preliminary certified survey map. 
(Code 1963, § 18.04(2)(a); Ord. No. 213-O-02, § 121, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 5, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 94-73. - Final certified survey map. 
(a)  The final certified survey map shall be submitted according to the procedure designated for a subdivision under section 94-52, except that no state or county agency actions are required. If the certified survey map does not involve dedications, reservations or public easements, only the approval of the plan commission shall be required. Ten copies of the final plat shall be submitted. 
(b)  The fee required in section 42-94(d)(2) shall accompany the application for a final certified survey map. 
(Code 1963, § 18.04(2)(b); Ord. No. 213-O-02, § 122, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 6, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 94-74. - Requirements. 
(a)  To the extent reasonably practicable, the certified survey map shall comply with the provisions of this chapter stated in this section relating to general requirements and design standards and required improvements. 
(b)  The survey shall be performed and the map prepared by a registered surveyor. Such map shall describe the entire ownership involved in the process of division; provided, however, that where the division results in a residual parcel in excess of ten acres not intended for immediate sale or conveyance, the plan commission may waive the requirement for inclusion of the residual parcel, in which case a supplementary map of reasonable accuracy shall be attached showing the relationship to the original ownership of the parcel being severed. 
(c)  All corners shall be monumented in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 236.15(1)(c) and (1)(d). 
(d)  The final certified survey map shall be prepared in accordance with Wis. Stats. §§ 236.20(2)(a), 236.20(2)(b), 236.20(2)(c), 236.20(2)(e), 236.20(2)(f), 236.20(2)(g), 236.20(2)(h), 236.20(2)(j), 236.20(2)(k) and 236.20(2)(l), on durable white paper, 8-1/2 inches wide by 14 inches long. All lines shall be made with nonfading black ink to a scale of 200 feet to an inch. 
(e)  If any lots in the certified survey map are not to be served by municipal sanitary sewer, the applicant shall submit evidence the private onsite wastewater treatment system (POWTS) has been approved for the parcel as required in Comm 83. 
(Code 1963, § 18.04(2)(c); Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 8, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 94-75. - Certificates of affidavits. 
(a)  The certified survey map shall include the certificate of ownership and the affidavit of the surveyor who surveyed and mapped the parcel, typed, lettered or reproduced legibly with nonfading black ink, giving a clear and concise description of the land surveyed by bearings and distances, commencing with some corner marked and established in the U. S. Public Land Survey. Such affidavit shall include the statement of the surveyor to the effect that he has fully complied with the requirements of this division. 
(b)  The certificate of approval of the plan commission or village board as required shall be typed, lettered or reproduced legibly with nonfading black ink on the face of the map. 
(Code 1963, § 18.04(2)(d); Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 8, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 94-76. - Revisions. 
    When village board approval is required, the applicant shall submit a revised certified survey map, meeting all the conditions of the plan commission and suitable for recording, with all applicable certificates signed and executed, to the department of community development, prior to consideration the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1963, § 18.04(2)(e); Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 9, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 94-77. - Recording. 
(a)  The village shall record the certified survey map after all fees required in sections 42-94 and 42-145 are paid, and all conditions of approval have been met. 
(b)  The approval of any certified survey map shall be void if the certified survey map is not offered for record within 12 months after the date of the last approval and within 36 months of the first approval. 
(Ord. No. 270-O-04, § 10, 5-17-04; Ord. No. 664-O-16, § 1, 5-2-16) 
Secs. 94-78-94-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND DESIGN STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-96. - Application of article provisions. 
    This article applies to all subdivisions or other divisions of land. 
(Ord. No. 103-O-00, § 2, 9-18-00) 
Sec. 94-97. - Conformance standards. 
(a)  The village may deny approval of a subdivision or other land division if it is not in conformity with the laws, regulations, guidelines, and polices set out below, or violates the purposes of the subdivision regulations established in section 94-2 of this chapter. 
(1)  The provisions of Wis. Stats. ch. 236; 
(2)  All applicable ordinances of the village; 
(3)  All applicable design and construction standards established by the village; 
(4)  The master plan; 
(5)  The official map; 
(6)  The rules of the department of commerce relating to lot size and lot elevation if the subdivision is not served by public sewer and provision for such service has not been made; 
(7)  The rules of the department of transportation relating to safety of access and the preservation of the public interest and investment in the streets if the subdivision or any lot contained therein abuts on a state trunk highway or connecting street; 
(8)  The special requirements of these regulations and any rules of the Waukesha County Health Department, other appropriate state agencies, and the agency of any subdivision of the state; 
(9)  The standards and regulations adopted by the village engineering department and all boards, commissions, agencies, and officials of the Village of Menomonee Falls; 
(10)  All pertinent standards contained within the planning guides published by the Southeastern Wisconsin Regional Planning Commission and adopted by the Village of Menomonee Falls. 
(b)  Adequate public facilities. No preliminary plat or certified survey map shall be approved unless the plan commission determines that public facilities will be adequate to support and service the area of the proposed subdivision or other land division. 
(1)  The applicant shall, at the request of the plan commission, submit sufficient information and data on the proposed subdivision to demonstrate the expected impact on and use of public facilities by possible uses of said subdivision or other land division. Public facilities and services to be examined for adequacy will include roads and public transportation facilities, sewerage, and water service. 
(2)  The applicant for a preliminary plat or certified survey map must, at the request of the plan commission, submit sufficient information and data on the proposed subdivision to demonstrate the expected impact on, and use of, public facilities and services by possible uses of said subdivision or certified survey map. 
(3)  The applicant for a preliminary plat or certified survey map within the conservation development zoning district shall submit sufficient information and data to demonstrate the expected impact on the water table, soils and general environment. The plan commission may deny the preliminary plat or certified survey map if they conclude the proposed land division causes adverse impacts to the environment. 
(4)  Comprehensive master plan consistency required. Proposed public improvements shall conform to and be properly related to the village's comprehensive plan and all applicable capital improvement plans. 
(5)  Water. All habitable buildings and buildable lots, except those located in the conservation development district, shall be connected to a public water system capable of providing water for health and emergency purposes, including adequate fire protection. 
(6)  Wastewater. All habitable buildings and buildable lots shall be served by an approved means of wastewater collection and treatment. 
(7)  Stormwater management. Drainage improvements shall meet the stormwater management design guidelines approved by the village board of trustees. 
(8)  Roads. Proposed roads shall provide a safe, convenient, and functional system for vehicular, pedestrian, and bicycle circulation; shall be properly related to the comprehensive plan; and shall be appropriate for the particular traffic characteristics of each proposed development. 
(9)  Extension policies. All public improvements and required easements shall be extended through the parcel on which new development is proposed. Streets, water lines, wastewater systems, drainage facilities, electric lines, and telecommunications lines shall be constructed through new development to promote the logical extension of public infrastructure. The Village of Menomonee Falls may require the applicant of a subdivision or certified survey map to extend off-site improvements to reach the subdivision or certified survey map, or oversize required public facilities to serve anticipated future development as a condition of approval. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(1); Ord. No. 103-O-00, § 3, 9-18-00; Ord. No. 573-O-13, § 2, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 94-98. - Alleys. 
(a)  Alleys shall be provided in all commercial and industrial districts, except that the plan commission may waive this section where other definite and assured provision is made for service access such as off-street loading and parking consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(b)  Alleys shall not be approved in residential areas unless necessary because of topography or other exceptional circumstances. 
(c)  The width of alleys shall be not less than 20 feet. 
(d)  Dead-end alleys are prohibited except under very unusual circumstances, and crooked and T alleys shall be discouraged. Where dead-end alleys are unavoidable, they shall be provided with adequate turnaround facilities at the dead end. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(4)) 
Sec. 94-99. - Easements. 
(a)  Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities where required by the plan commission and shall be at least ten feet wide. 
(b)  Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse, and such further width or construction, or both, as will be adequate for the purpose. Wherever possible, it is desirable that the drainage be maintained by an open channel with landscaped banks and adequate width for maximum potential volume of flow. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(5)) 
Sec. 94-100. - Environmental corridors, public sites and open spaces. 
    The protection and management of the resources found in environmental corridors is an important part of preventing serious environmental degradation. Maintenance of wetlands in natural and open space use will provide that the wetlands function in their natural capacity. This function may be wildlife habitat, a spawning ground for fish, filtration of storm water runoff, storage of flood water, or the maintenance of a highly diverse, rare or endangered plant community. Loss of significant areas of woodland may produce serious soil erosion, increased storm water runoff, loss of wildlife habitat, loss of rare or endangered plant communities, and loss of important scenic resources. The Village of Menomonee Falls is interested in having as many environmental corridors as possible protected through public ownership. These environmental corridors include, but are not limited to, the environmental corridors of the Menomonee River and its tributaries; and the Fox River (Illinois) and its tributaries, including the Tamarack Preserve. To assist in the public ownership of environmental corridors, the following provisions are established: 
(1)  Reservation of potential sites. 
a.  In the design of a plat or certified survey map, consideration shall be given to the adequate provision of and correlation with such public sites or open areas. 
b.  Where it is determined by the plan commission that a portion of the plat or certified survey map is required for such public sites or open spaces, the subdivider may be required to reserve such area for a period not to exceed three years, after which the village shall either acquire the property or release the reservation. 
(2)  Dedication of sites. 
a.  Within the corporate limits of the village, where feasible and compatible with the comprehensive plan for development of the community, the subdivider shall provide and dedicate to the public adequate land to provide for the environmental and open space needs of the village. 
b.  The amount of land to be provided shall be determined on the basis of an amount of land equal in value to $1,000.00 per lot created by the land division. The value of the land to be dedicated shall be determined by the village assessor on the basis of full and fair market value of the land. If the owner is not satisfied with such appraisal, he may appeal such determination, in which case an appraisal board consisting of one appraiser selected by the village at its own expense, one selected by the property owner at his own expense and a third selected by the two other appraisers at village expense, shall determine the value. 
(3)  Proportionate payment in lieu of dedication. A proportionate payment in lieu of dedication shall be made in accordance with section 42-94. 
(4)  Excessive street dedication . In the case of major thoroughfares lying within the plat, the subdivider may dedicate the width in excess of that required by this chapter and claim credit for the value of such land in the payment required under subsection (3). 
(5)  Determination of feasibility. The determination as to the feasibility of dedication shall be made by the village plan commission. The subdivider shall however, have the option of choosing to make payment in lieu of dedication. 
(Code 1963, § 18.08; Ord. No. 155-O-01, § 2, 11-5-01; Ord. No. 357-O-06, §§ 3-6, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 479-O-10, §§ 9-11, 5-17-10) 
Secs. 94-101-94-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREETS 

Sec. 94-116. - General consideration. 
    The streets shall be designed and located in relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions and natural terrain features such as streams and existing tree growth, to public convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(a)) 
Sec. 94-117. - Conformance to official map. 
    The arrangement, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the official map and to the street and highway widths established by ordinance. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(b)) 
Sec. 94-118. - Arrangement. 
(a)  Major streets shall be properly integrated with the existing and proposed system of major streets and highways. 
(b)  Collector streets shall be properly related to mass transit routes, to special traffic generating from facilities such as schools, churches and shopping centers; to population densities; and to the major streets into which they feed. 
(c)  Minor streets shall be laid out to conform as much as possible to topography, to discourage use by through traffic, to permit efficient drainage and sewer systems, to require the minimum amount of street necessary to provide convenient, safe access to property. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(c)) 
Sec. 94-119. - Railroad right-of-way or limited access highway. 
    Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way or limited access highway right-of-way, the plan commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land as for park purposes in residential districts or for commercial or industrial purposes in other districts. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(d)) 
Sec. 94-120. - Major streets. 
    Where a subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed major street, the plan commission may require that marginal access streets be provided, that the backs of lots abut the major streets and be provided with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line, that deep lots with rear service alleys be provided or that other provisions be made for the adequate protection of residential properties and the separation of through and local traffic. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(e)) 
Sec. 94-121. - Width. 
    The right-of-way of all streets shall be of the width specified on the official map or master plan or, if no width is specified there, they shall be not less than the width specified as follows: 
Right-of-Way 1. Major streets 100 feet 2. Collector streets  80 feet 3. Local access streets  60 feet 4. Frontage streets  30 feet  
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(f)) 
State Law reference- Minimum street widths, Wis. Stats. § 236.16(2). 
Sec. 94-122. - Grades. 
    The grade of major and collector streets shall not exceed six percent, and the grade of all other streets shall not exceed ten percent, unless necessitated by exceptional topography and approved by the plan commission. The minimum grade of all streets shall be no less than one-half of one percent, and such minimum shall not be permitted for long sustained distances. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(g)) 
Sec. 94-123. - Horizontal curves. 
    A minimum sight distance with clear visibility, measured along the centerline, shall be provided of at least 300 feet on major streets, 200 feet for collector streets, and 100 feet on minor streets. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(h)) 
Sec. 94-124. - Vertical curves. 
    All changes in street grades shall be connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equivalent to 15 times the algebraic difference in the rate of grade for major streets and collector streets, and one-half of this minimum length for all other streets. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(i)) 
Sec. 94-125. - Tangents. 
    A tangent at least 100 feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on major and collector streets. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(j)) 
Sec. 94-126. - Street names. 
    New street names shall not duplicate the names of existing streets, but streets that are continuations of others already in existence and named shall bear the name of the existing streets. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(k)) 
Sec. 94-127. - Cul-de-sac or dead-end streets. 
    Streets designed to have one end permanently closed shall not normally exceed 500 feet in length and shall terminate with a turnaround as follows: 
(1)  Cul-de-sac without an interior island: A cul-de-sac without an interior island shall not have less than a 60-foot radius (120-foot diameter) of right-of-way and a roadway of not less than a 35-foot radius (70-foot diameter) to the edge/flange of pavement. 
(2)  Cul-de-sac with an interior island: A cul-de-sac with an interior island shall not have less than a 70-foot radius (140-foot diameter) of right-of-way and a roadway of not less than a 54-foot radius (108-foot diameter) to the outside edge/flange of pavement and not less than a 30-foot radius (60-foot diameter) to the inside edge/flange of pavement. Planting of the islands shall be determined as part of the subdivision landscaping plan. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(l); Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 10, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 94-128. - Reserve strips. 
    Reserve strips controlling access to streets shall be prohibited except where their control is definitely placed in the village under conditions approved by the plan commission. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(m)) 
Sec. 94-129. - Existing half-streets. 
    Where a half-street exists adjacent to the subdivision, the other half of the street shall be dedicated by the subdivider. Platting of new half-streets along property lines shall not be permitted except by approval of the plan commission. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(2)(n)) 
Sec. 94-130. - Intersections. 
(a)  Streets shall intersect as nearly as possible at right angles and not more than two streets shall intersect at one point unless approved by the plan commission. 
(b)  Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a radius of 15 feet or of a greater radius where the plan commission considers it necessary. 
(c)  Street jogs with centerline offsets less than 125 feet shall be avoided. Where streets intersect major streets, their alignment shall be continuous. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(3)) 
Sec. 94-131. - Blocks. 
(a)  The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be such as are appropriate for the locality and the type of development contemplated. 
(b)  Pedestrian crosswalks not less than 15 feet wide may be required by the plan commission where deemed desirable to provide convenient pedestrian circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation and other community facilities. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(6)) 
Secs. 94-132-94-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LOTS 

Sec. 94-146. - Generally. 
    The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(7)(a)) 
Sec. 94-147. - Dimensions. 
(a)  Lot dimensions shall conform to the requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Residential lots to be served by private sewage disposal facilities shall comply with the rules of the department of commerce as well as with any local ordinance appropriate thereto. 
(c)  Depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for commercial and industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated. 
(d)  Residential lots abutting on major streets and highways shall be platted with sufficient depth to permit adequate separation between the buildings and such trafficways. 
(e)  Lots shall be designed with a suitable proportion between width and depth. Neither long, narrow nor wide, shallow lots are normally desirable. Normal depth shall not exceed 21/2 times the width nor be less than 100 feet where served by sewer or 150 feet where individual sewage disposal facilities are provided. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(7)(b)) 
State Law reference- Minimum lot width and area, Wis. Stats. § 236.16. 
Sec. 94-148. - Access to public streets. 
    Every lot shall front or abut on a public street. Lots with an access only to private drives or streets shall be permitted only with plan commission approval. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(7)(d)) 
Sec. 94-149. - Lots at right angles. 
    Lots at right angles to each other shall be avoided wherever possible, especially in residential areas. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(7)(e)) 
Sec. 94-150. - Lot lines. 
    Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(7)(f)) 
Sec. 94-151. - Large lots. 
    Where lots are created of a size larger than normal for the area, the plan commission may require that the plat be so designed as to allow for the possible future resubdivision of such lots into normal size lots compatible with the area. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(7)(g)) 
Sec. 94-152. - Municipal boundaries. 
    Lots shall follow municipal boundary lines whenever practicable, rather than cross them. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(7)(h)) 
Sec. 94-153. - Double frontage. 
    Double frontage and reversed frontage lots shall be avoided except where necessary to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(7)(i)) 
Sec. 94-154. - Corner lots. 
    Corner lots shall be designed to permit full setback on both streets as required by the applicable zoning district requirements. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(7)(c)) 
Sec. 94-155. - Placement of electric, telephone and other lines of communication; and utility pads, pad-mounted transformers and pedestals. 
(a)  In proposed subdivisions all electric, telephone, and communication distribution lines and laterals (including CATV cables) shall be placed underground. Upon receipt of a recommendation as part of the village staff report filed with the plan commission, the plan commission may waive this section where conditions exist which make such underground facilities technically or economically infeasible. Refer to section 122-648 for main intermunicipal transmission facilities requirements. 
(b)  Prior to the submission of the final plat or of a final certified survey map requiring a development agreement, the subdivider shall file with the village engineer a report containing a mapped description of the proposed route of overhead and underground electric and/or telephone or communication lines. The report shall identify the proposed location of any poles, towers, including wires, manholes and/or underground conduit and cable, their appurtenances, and any pad mounted transformers and pedestals. The report shall identify and consider the conditions set out in subsection (c) below. The failure to file such a report that complies with this subsection prior to the submission of the final plat or certified survey map requiring a development agreement, shall be grounds for denial of the proposed final plat or certified survey map. 
(c)  The village engineer shall make a recommendation to the plan commission and the village board concerning the location of all pad-mounted transformers and pedestals in proposed subdivisions created by a subdivision plat or by a certified survey map requiring a development agreement. The recommendation shall be part of the village staff report filed with the plan commission and shall consider the following factors or conditions: 
(1)  Subject to the remaining provisions of this subsection (c), the preferred location of the pad-mounted transformers and pedestals shall be in the side or rear yard of a lot. 
(2)  The recommendation shall consider a report timely filed that complies with subsection (b) above. 
(3)  The recommendation shall consider the following conditions: drainage, preservation areas, environmentally protected areas, natural features, stormwater drainage, other utility locations, prohibitive soil conditions, slope of the lot, endangered and threatened species and their associated habitats, groundwater levels, adjacent uses, aesthetics and cost of implementation. 
(Code 1963, § 18.05(8); Ord. No. 658-O-16, § 1, 4-4-16) 
Secs. 94-156-94-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 94-171. - Subdivisions to be monumented. 
    The subdivisions shall be monumented as required by Wis. Stats. § 236.15, which is hereby adopted by reference. 
(Code 1963, § 18.06(1)) 
Sec. 94-172. - Facilities and improvements. 
(a)  Required to be installed. Before the final plat of a subdivision located within the corporate limits will be approved, the subdivider shall provide and dedicate the following facilities and improvements, all of which facilities and improvements must be within the time required by the village board, but in no event to exceed two years: 
(1)  Water and sanitary sewer mains and storm sewers and laterals to the lot line, where deemed necessary by the village board and where connection to existing systems can be reasonably provided. 
(2)  All new streets graded and surfaced, according to established standards of the village as directed by the village manager or designee, and additional right-of-way along existing streets in conformity with the established street width map of the village. Except for cul-de-sacs and streets boulevarded for center strip drainage, no required dedication shall exceed 100 feet in width. Where principal thoroughfares lie within the plat, the subdivider shall not be required to provide improvements in excess of those normally required to serve the development itself. 
(3)  Sidewalks where deemed necessary by the village board, and curb and gutter or such other facility necessary to provide adequately for surface water drainage as directed by the village manager or designee. 
(4)  Street trees on both sides of all roadways. Such trees shall have a trunk diameter of not less than 11/2 inches at the point one foot above the root system. The species and quality of tree to be planted and the location shall be approved by the village manager or designee. 
(5)  Where municipal water is not provided, adequate fire cisterns, the number, size and location of which shall be determined by the plan commission after consultation with the fire chief, and a paved roadway providing access to such cistern, in accordance with standards established by the village manager or designee. 
(6)  Street signs at all intersections, which signs shall be in conformity with standards as established by the village board. 
(7)  All open cuts of ground shall be returfed in a satisfactory manner. Sod shall be provided for any open cut subject to excessive erosion, which sod shall be laid in strips at intervals and at right angles to the flow of water in order to prevent erosion. 
(b)  Work to be done by village contract. All work to be done by the subdivider under this section in installing the such facilities and improvements shall be done by the village on behalf of and for the account of the subdivider or under contract let by the village on behalf of and for the account of the subdivider and all costs thereof paid by the subdivider. The terms of any such contract shall be within the sole discretion of the village board, and the board may waive compliance with any provision of such contract including, without liability, waiver of any penalty for late completion of such contract. 
(Code 1963, § 18.06(2)) 
Sec. 94-173. - When bond required. 
    If such facilities and improvements have not been fully installed at the time the plat is submitted for final approval, the subdivider shall file with the village manager or designee a surety bond executed by the subdivider as principal and a responsible bonding company duly licensed and authorized to do business in the state as surety, payable to the Village of Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin, and conditioned upon the faithful performance and payment of any and all work to be performed pursuant to this chapter; or other satisfactory financial guarantee for this purpose. Such bond or other financial guarantee shall be approved by the village attorney and shall be of an amount determined by the village manager or designee to amply cover the cost of completing such facilities and improvements. 
(Code 1963, § 18.06(3)) 
Sec. 94-174. - Adequacy of improvements to be approved by village manager or designee. 
    The adequacy of such facilities and improvements and their proper installation shall be subject to approval of the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 18.06(4)) 
Sec. 94-175. - Dedication and guarantee. 
    All facilities and improvements installed prior to the final approval of the plat shall be considered dedicated along with streets and other public areas upon the approval of the plat. Facilities and improvements completed under bond or other financial guarantee after the approval of the plat shall be considered dedicated upon their approval and acceptance and release of the bond or other guarantee. The required improvements in the subdivision shall be guaranteed for a period of one year following the completion and acceptance of such improvements. In order to ensure the good quality of materials, workmanship and maintenance of all sanitary sewers, water mains, storm sewers, streets and all appurtenances thereto, the subdivider shall provide a guarantee bond or other satisfactory financial guarantee to the village in the amount of 20 percent of the total installation cost of such improvements, as determined by the village manager or designee, for a period of one year after completion of construction and written acceptance by the village manager or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 18.06(5)) 
Sec. 94-176. - Partial improvement. 
    In all instances where it shall appear to the satisfaction of the village board that the whole of a platted subdivision cannot immediately be fully improved with respect to the installation of all storm and sanitary sewers and related facilities, water mains and related facilities and street improvements, by reason of unavoidable delay in the acquisition of lands necessary for such improvements, or by reason of the unavoidable delay in obtaining necessary engineering data and information, or for some other good reason or cause, the village board may, in its sole discretion, authorize the subdivider to proceed with the installation of improvements required under this division on a portion or part of such subdivision, and, in such event, the requirements of this division shall apply to that portion or part thereof, authorized for immediate improvement. 
(Code 1963, § 18.06(6)) 
State Law reference- Authority to condition plat approval upon improvements, Wis. Stats. § 236.13(2). 
Chapter 98 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not codified in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-11(a)(15); administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-161 et seq.; businesses, ch. 22; fees, ch. 42; special assessments, ch. 86. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 98-1-98-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM PROPERTY TAXATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- General property taxes, Wis. Stats. ch. 70. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 98-21-98-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF REVIEW[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Board of review, Wis. Stats. § 70.46 et seq. 

Sec. 98-36. - Established. 
    There shall be a board of review. 
(Code 1963, § 1.03(7)); Ord. No. 80-O-00, § 1(1.03(7)(a)), 4-17-00) 
Sec. 98-37. - Membership and term. 
(a)  Membership. The board of review shall consist of five members, who shall be appointed by the village president, subject to confirmation by the village board. 
(b)  Term. Members shall be appointed for five year terms, and shall serve until a successor has been appointed and qualified, unless such member's term is vacated earlier because of change of residence, removal, resignation or death. 
(c)  Vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment of the village president and confirmation by majority vote of the village board. A person appointed to fill a vacancy shall serve the remainder of the term. 
(Code 1963, § 1.03(7)(a)); Ord. No. 80-O-00, § 1(1.03(7)(b)), 4-17-00; Ord. No. 265-O-04, §§ 1, 2, 4-26-04) 
State Law reference- Authority to so provide, Wis. Stats. § 70.46(1). 
Sec. 98-38. - Alternate members. 
    The village president shall appoint, subject to confirmation by the village board, two alternate members for terms of five years, except that of those first appointed one shall serve for two years and another shall serve for three years. The alternate shall act when a member of the board is absent. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-00, § 1(1.03(7)(c)), 4-17-00) 
Sec. 98-39. - Filing and electronic transmission. 
(a)  Manner of filing. Filing documents with the clerk of the board of review may be accomplished in person, by mail, by facsimile transmission or by e-mail transmission. The party transmitting the document or message is solely responsible for ensuring its timely and complete receipt and filing. 
(b)  Time of filing. A document is deemed to be filed if it is complete and (i) it is actually received by the clerk in-hand in the case of in-person delivery, mail or facsimile; or (ii) it is opened by the clerk in the case of e-mail. No document transmitted by facsimile transmission or by e-mail transmission while the board of review is in session shall be deemed filed with the clerk during the session. Any message left orally by telephone voice recording or other electronic means, similarly, is not deemed to be received until such message is actually heard by the clerk. 
(Ord. No. 569-O-13, § 1, 9-16-13) 
Secs. 98-40-98-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL AND MOTEL ROOM TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Room tax, Wis. Stats. § 66.75. 

Sec. 98-61. - Definitions. 
    In this article, the terms "transient," "hotel" and "motel" have the meanings set forth in Wis. Stats. § 77.52(2)(a)1. 
(Code 1963, § 3.07(1)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 66.75(1). 
Sec. 98-62. - Imposition; rate. 
    For the privilege of furnishing, at retail, rooms or lodging to transients by hotel keepers, motel operators or other persons furnishing accommodations that are available to the public, irrespective of whether membership is required for use of the accommodations, a tax is imposed upon the retailers at the rate of eight percent of the gross receipts from the lease or rental of such accommodations, rooms or lodging within the village on or after October 1, 2008. 
(Code 1963, § 3.07(1); Ord. No. 413-O-08, § 1, 9-2-08, eff. 10-1-08) 
State Law reference- Authority to impose tax, Wis. Stats. § 66.75(1m)(a). 
Sec. 98-63. - Quarterly report of gross receipts. 
    Each retailer engaged in furnishing such accommodations, rooms or lodging shall submit a quarterly report to the village clerk-treasurer's office showing the gross receipts from furnishing such accommodations, rooms or lodging, along with a copy of his state sales tax report for the business, along with the eight percent tax for the gross receipts as reported, by not later than 30 days from the end of each calendar quarter for the receipts of that past calendar quarter. 
(Code 1963, § 3.07(3); Ord. No. 448-O-09, § 1, 6-1-09) 
Sec. 98-64. - Unpaid tax; interest rate; late filing penalty. 
    All unpaid taxes shall bear interest at the legal rate from the date of the return. Failure to pay the tax, or delinquent payment of such taxes, shall be, subject to a $10.00 late filing penalty in addition to the interest imposed in this article. 
(Code 1963, § 3.07(4)) 
Sec. 98-65. - False or fraudulent return; penalty. 
    If a false or fraudulent return is filed with the intent in either case to defeat or evade the tax imposed by this article, a penalty of 50 percent of the tax due shall be paid in addition to the tax, interest and late filing penalty. 
(Code 1963, § 3.07(5)) 
Chapter 102 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 110. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 102-1-102-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of cable television companies, Wis. Stats. § 66.082. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 102-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any individual, partnership, corporation or association which shall have filed a written application for a franchise under this article. 
    Board means the board of trustees of the village. The term "board" shall include the persons designated by the board to act on its behalf. 
    Cable Access Corporation means the nonprofit entity established by the village board to manage and operate the public access channel. 
    Cable communication system means any system whose function is to receive and amplify the broadcast signals of one or more television and radio stations or to provide signals for additional closed circuit programming, and to redistribute such signals to members of the public who subscribe to such service or to whom redistribution of such signals is required by this article, by means of wires, cables, conduit, microwaves, satellites or other means. 
    General government committee means the general government committee of the village board. 
    Grantee means any applicant receiving the grant of any franchise under this article and shall include any lawful successor to the interest of a grantee when consent to such succession has been granted by the board. 
    Gross revenues mean all compensation received by the grantee, its affiliates or subsidiaries from and in connection with the operation of the cable communication system in the village, as that term is defined by the FCC or a court of competent jurisdiction, and shall include compensation in whatever form, exchange or otherwise from all sources including, without limitation, revenues from advertising, channel leasing, data transmission and per program charges, in addition to the subscribers' regular monthly payments for all services. Excluded from gross revenues will be licensing fees for pay programs and sales tax. 
    Reasonable notice means the provision of notice of contemplated action delivered at least 48 hours prior to such action. 
    Streets means all streets, roadways, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places, squares, curbs, sidewalks, easements, rights-of-way or other public ways in the village which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so designated by law. 
    Subscriber means a recipient of cable communication system service. 
(Code 1963, § 23.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 102-22. - Severability. 
    If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this article is held unconstitutional, or otherwise invalid by any court or the FCC, such infirmity shall not affect the validity of the remainder of this article, and such section or part of a section shall be renegotiated by the village and the grantee. 
(Code 1963, § 23.20) 
Sec. 102-23. - Duties of general government committee. 
    The duties and powers of the general government committee are as follows: 
(1)  Resolving disputes or disagreements between subscribers and the grantee after investigation should the subscriber and the grantee not first be able to resolve their dispute or disagreement. 
(2)  Reviewing and auditing reports submitted to the village as required by this article and such other correspondence as submitted to the village concerning the operation of the system so as to ensure that the necessary reports are completed and filed pursuant to the terms of this section. Review rules and regulations set by grantee as permitted by this article. 
(3)  Ensuring that all tariffs and rules pertinent to the operation of the system in the village are made available for inspection by the public at reasonable hours and upon reasonable request. 
(4)  Conferring with the grantee and advising on the interconnection of the village's cable system with other cable and communication systems. 
(5)  Soliciting, reviewing and providing recommendations to the board to ensure compliance with this article. 
(6)  Making recommendations to the grantee of the system and the Cable Access Corporation. 
(7)  Ensuring that the Cable Access Corporation and/or the grantee makes the public access channel available to all residents of the village on a nondiscriminatory basis and advising the grantee on procedural rules for this purpose. 
(8)  Ensuring that the operation of the public access channel is free of program censorship consistent with FCC standards. 
(9)  Overseeing compliance with the requirements of this article including representations made in the application. 
(10)  Performing such other duties and functions as may be assigned from time to time by the board. 
(Code 1963, § 23.21) 
Sec. 102-24. - Prohibited use of streets. 
    No individual, partnership, corporation or association shall use the streets for or in connection with a cable communication system except as may be specifically permitted by the board. No cable or other equipment or device installed in, over or under the streets under a franchise granted under this article shall be used for any purpose except for a cable communication system or other services described in the application of grantee or approved by the board. 
(Code 1963, § 23.03) 
Sec. 102-25. - Cable monitoring. 
    Neither the grantee, nor any governmental bureau, department, unit, agency or entity, at the federal, state, county or local level, nor any other person or entity, shall monitor, or arrange for the monitoring of, any cable, line, signal input device, or subscriber outlet or receiver for any purpose whatsoever, except with the permission of the subscriber or homeowner or as may be agreed upon between grantee and the board or its designee. This article shall not prevent the grantee from undertaking monitoring activities essential to the operation of the system, i.e., billing, nor shall it prevent the introduction of additional services agreed upon, i.e., two-way communications and security system. 
(Code 1963, § 23.22) 
Sec. 102-26. - Rights of residents. 
(a)  An owner or operator of an apartment building, condominium, nursing home, or any other rental facility may not interfere with or charge a fee for the installation of cable facilities for the use of a lessee of such property or premises, except that such owner or operator may require: 
(1)  Installation to conform to reasonable conditions necessary to protect the safety, appearance and functioning of the premises; 
(2)  The grantee, occupant or tenant to pay for the installation, operation or removal of such facilities; or 
(3)  The grantee, occupant or tenant to agree to indemnify the owner or operator for any damages caused by the installation, operation or removal of such facilities. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the grantee to reimburse or offer to reimburse any person, or for any person to demand or receive reimbursement from the grantee, for the placement upon the premises of such person of grantee's facilities necessary to connect such person's premises to the distribution lines of the grantee to provide CATV service to such premises. 
(c)  A landlord may not discriminate in the amount of rent charged to tenants or occupants who receive cable services and to those who do not. 
(d)  The grantee may not take actions which would diminish or interfere with the privilege of any tenant or other occupant of any such building to use or avail himself of master or individual antenna equipment. 
(Code 1963, § 23.23) 
Sec. 102-27. - Cable Access Corporation. 
(a)  To achieve utilization of the public access channel that is in the best public interest, it is the intent of the grantor to vest the governance of any public access channel on any franchised cable communications system in an independent, nonprofit Cable Access Corporation. Such corporation shall be established by the board as soon as practicable, and shall have responsibility for administration of program production for and management of the access channel. The grantee shall fund the Cable Access Corporation via a direct payment of two percent of gross revenues as per section 102-56(a). In carrying out its responsibilities, the Cable Access Corporation shall: 
(1)  Encourage the use of public access among a wide range of individuals, groups and institutions within the village. 
(2)  Ensure that the public access channel is made available to all residents of the city on a nondiscriminatory, first-come, first-served basis. 
(3)  Ensure that no censorship or control over program content of the channel exists, except as necessary to comply with FCC regulations. Such prohibitions currently include material that is obscene, contains commercial advertising, or conducts a lottery. 
(4)  Devise, establish and administer all rules, regulations and procedures pertaining to the use and scheduling of access programs and the access channel. 
(5)  Prepare such regular or special reports as may be requested by the board. 
(6)  Hire and supervise staff and make purchases of materials and equipment that may be required. 
(7)  Develop additional sources of funding, such as foundation or federal or state grants to further community programming. 
(8)  Supervise the use of the cable production studio and production equipment. 
(9)  Perform such other functions relevant to the access channel as may be appropriate. 
(b)  The village reserves the right to designate the entity responsible for the administration and management of public access, or to return that responsibility to the grantee throughout the term of the franchise agreement. 
(Code 1963, § 23.24) 
Sec. 102-28. - Enforcement. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this article, fines and forfeiture amounts shall be those prescribed in section 1-7 of this Code subject to amendments, renumbering or replacement, as the case may be. Costs and attorney's fees incurred in the enforcement of the provisions of this article against the grantee shall be paid by the grantee. Violation of sections 102-76(a), 102-56, 102-82, 102-83 or 102-26 shall be punishable by fines or forfeitures pursuant to this article; however, violations of those sections may also be considered when making a determination under section 102-58. 
(Code 1963, § 23.26) 
Sec. 102-29. - Protections afforded the grantee. 
(a)  A person who willfully or maliciously damages, or causes to be damaged, any wire, cable, conduit, apparatus or equipment of the grantee, or who commits any act with intent to cause damage to any wire, cable, conduit, apparatus or equipment of the grantee, or who taps, tampers with, or connects any wire or device to a wire, cable, conduit or equipment of the grantee with intent to obtain a signal or impulse therefrom without authorization of the grantee, shall be subject to a forfeiture as determined by the appropriate court, but this article shall not prevent a public utility from removing, disconnecting or otherwise rendering inoperable any of the grantee's apparatus or equipment attached or in any way connected to such public utility's facilities, if done for reasonable cause. 
(b)  The grantee or its agents shall not, in an action for slander or for publishing a libel, be held liable, in damages, for or on account of any defamatory matter uttered, telecast, cablecast or published over the facilities of the grantee by any person whose utterance, telecast, cablecast or publication is not, under the provisions of any law of the United States of any regulation, ruling or order of the Federal Communications Commission, subject to censorship or control by the grantee. 
(Code 1963, § 23.25) 
State Law reference- Damage to property, Wis. Stats. § 943.01; theft of cable television service, Wis. Stats. § 943.46. 
Secs. 102-30-102-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FRANCHISE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to grant cable television franchise, Wis. Stats. § 66.082(3)(b). 

Sec. 102-46. - Required. 
    No individual, partnership, corporation or association shall install, maintain or operate a cable communication system, or solicit subscriptions for such system, without first having applied for and obtained a franchise from the village in accordance with this article. Any failure to secure such a franchise prior to the commencement of operations or the soliciting of any subscription from any subscriber for such service shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 23.02) 
Sec. 102-47. - Application. 
    The application for a franchise shall be submitted to the board in writing, and shall contain the following: 
(1)  For individuals: The applicant's name, address, occupation and principal place of business. 
(2)  For partnerships: The applicant partnership's name, business, and principal place of business; along with the names, addresses, occupations, and principal place of business of each of the partners. 
(3)  For corporations (or associations): The applicant corporation's name, principal business and principal place of business; the state of incorporation; the names and addresses of its registered agent; the number of shareholders, including the names and residence of shareholders holding, controlling, or having a beneficial interest in more than ten percent of the outstanding shares, identifying their interests, along with a statement indicating any intention to change of such interests during the term of the franchise. If the corporation is a foreign corporation, a certificate of authority to transact business in this state shall accompany the application. 
(4)  A statement as to any other cable communication systems owned or operated by or in which the applicant has any interest. Such statement shall list by name and address each and every municipality in the United States in which the applicant operates a cable communication system or has been granted a franchise so to do. 
(5)  A detailed explanation of the nature, extent and scope of operation of the proposed system (including any present legal, financial, technical or other qualifying matter which may in any way relate to the ability of the applicant to perform the proposed system.) 
(6)  A complete, sworn financial statement of the applicant. 
(7)  The estimated cost of installing the system. 
(8)  The method of financing the system. 
(9)  A listing of channels which the applicant will provide and the type of program or service to be provided on each channel. 
(10)  A schedule of the applicant's rates for installation, monthly service charges and any other charges to subscribers, together with a proposed rental or service agreement with subscribers which details the rights and obligations of subscribers to the system. The schedule of proposed rates shall also indicate whether or not a charge will be made to a subscriber for the removal of service. 
(11)  A list of equipment to be used in the total system, together with specifications therefor. The application will agree that the board may require review of adequacy of equipment by a third-party qualified consultant whose fee shall be paid by the applicant. 
(12)  The estimated construction schedule. 
(13)  A statement that the applicant will abide by and conform to all of the provisions of this article and amendments thereto, and, that the applicant will pay at the time required any franchise fees prescribed in this article. 
(14)  Such additional detailed information which the board may require. 
(15)  A nonrefundable application fee in an amount determined under section 42-102 shall accompany the application. 
(Code 1963, § 23.04) 
Sec. 102-48. - Grantee's application incorporated. 
    The grantee's application and supplemental correspondence shall be deemed incorporated by reference and made a part of this article. In the event of a conflict between proposed services listed in such application and the provisions of this article, that provision which provides the greatest benefit to the village, in the opinion of the board, shall prevail. 
(Code 1963, § 23.17) 
Sec. 102-49. - Grant. 
(a)  The board may grant a nonexclusive franchise to an applicant, thereafter referred to as grantee, for a period of 15 years from the date the franchise is awarded for the right and privilege to install, operate and maintain a system in the village under the restrictions and conditions of this article. No property right in this franchise shall vest in the grantee, and such franchise shall not be construed to create, any right beyond that set forth in this article. 
(b)  An application approval fee in the amount established in section 42-102 shall be paid by the grantee to the village within ten days after the granting of the franchise to the grantee. 
(Code 1963, § 23.05(1), (2)) 
Sec. 102-50. - Transfer of ownership or control; notice. 
(a)  A cable operator shall give the village at least 90 days' advance written notice of the cable operator's intention to transfer ownership or control of a cable television system. During the term of a franchise agreement, a cable operator may not transfer ownership or control of a cable television system without the approval of the village. The village may not withhold approval of an ownership transfer or a transfer of control without good cause. If a hearing is necessary to determine if a transfer may have an adverse effect, the village may schedule a hearing to take place within 45 days after the date on which the village receives the notice. If a village withholds approval of an ownership transfer or transfer of control, the village shall state its objections to the transfer in writing within 60 days after the date on which the village receives the notice. Under this subsection, a transfer of control is presumed to occur if 40 percent or more of the ownership interest in a cable television system is transferred. 
(b)  If ten percent or more of the ownership interest in a cable television system is transferred, the cable operator shall inform the village of the transfer in writing within 30 days after the date of transfer. 
(c)  The provisions of this section do not apply to a written franchise agreement that is entered into, renewed, extended or modified after May 14, 1992, that contains provisions to the contrary. 
(Code 1963, § 23.05(3), (4)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 66.082(5). 
Sec. 102-51. - Encumberment. 
    The grantee shall not assign, mortgage, pledge, hypothecate or otherwise encumber the franchise or all or any part of the cable, wires or other equipment located within the village, nor permit the same to occur, nor permit a prior assignment, mortgage, pledge, hypothecation or encumbrance to continue, without prior notice to and approval by the board. 
(Code 1963, § 23.05(5)) 
Sec. 102-52. - Notification by grantee of foreclosure or other judicial sale of system. 
    Upon the foreclosure or other judicial sale of all or a substantial part of the system, or upon the termination of any lease covering all or a substantial part of the system, the grantee shall immediately notify the board of such fact, and such notification shall be treated as a notification that a change in control of the grantee has taken place, and the provisions of this section governing the consent of the board to such change in control of the grantee shall apply. 
(Code 1963, § 23.05(6)) 
Sec. 102-53. - Grantee subject to police power of village. 
    The grantee shall, at all times during the operation of this franchise, be subject to all lawful exercise of the police power as may be hereafter provided by the village or the board. 
(Code 1963, § 23.05(7)) 
Sec. 102-54. - Availability of service.
