    Cable communication system service shall be made available to the entire village in accordance with the construction timetable. If territories are annexed to the village, such service shall be made available within one year of the date of annexation. 
(Code 1963, § 23.05(8)) 
Sec. 102-55. - Uniform franchising. 
    Should the grantor determine that it is in the best interest of the village to grant an additional cable television franchise, it may so do, provide that the franchise is granted under terms or conditions that are neither more favorable or less burdensome to the applicant than those required under the existing cable television franchise. Such terms shall include, but are not limited to, conditions pertaining to the territorial extent of the franchise, system design, technical performance standards, construction schedules, performance bonds, standards for construction and installation of cable television facilities, service to subscribers, public educational and governmental access channels and facilities, liability and indemnification, insurance requirements and franchise fees. 
(Code 1963, § 23.05(9)) 
Sec. 102-56. - Payment to the village and Cable Access Corporation. 
(a)  For the use of the streets and other facilities of the incorporated area of the village for the operation of the cable communications system and for its supervision by the village, and the operation of access facilities, the grantee shall pay a franchise fee equal to the maximum percentage permitted by law of the grantee's gross revenues from the operations of the cable communications system in the village during the calendar year. Such maximum is five percent. The grantee shall pay an amount equal to five percent of the grantee's gross revenues to the village. If there is no such maximum permitted by law, the parties shall agree upon a rate. If the village and the grantee cannot reach agreement on a rate, either party may request that the matter be resolved by arbitration procedures as set forth in Wis. Stats. ch. 298. Both parties shall then fully cooperate in such arbitration procedures. The annual sum to the village shall be payable one-half at the end of each semiannual period. The semiannual anniversary shall be June 30 and December 31 of each year, and each semiannual payment shall be paid within 60 days thereafter. 
(b)  The grantee shall also file, within 120 days following the conclusion of each fiscal year of the grantee, an annual report prepared and audited by an independent certified public accountant, showing the yearly total gross revenues and payments to the village and any further relevant financial information in regard to the grantee as may be required by the board. 
(c)  The village shall have the right to inspect the grantee's income records and the right to audit and to recompute any amounts determined to be payable under this article; provided, however, that such audit shall take place within 12 months following the close of each of the grantee's fiscal years. Any additional amount due to the village as a result of the audit shall be paid within the 30 days following written notice to the grantee by the village, which notice shall include a copy of the audit report. 
(d)  If any franchise payment, recomputed amount or other payment is not made on or before the applicable dates heretofore specified, interest shall be charged from such date at a rate of two percent above the average local bank prime rate. 
(e)  Payments of compensation made by the grantee to the village pursuant to the provisions of this article shall not be considered in the nature of a tax but shall be in addition to any and all taxes which are now or hereafter required to be paid by any law of the United States, the state, the county or the village. 
(Code 1963, § 23.09; Ord. No. 372-O-07, § 2, 5-7-07) 
State Law reference- Authority to require franchise fee, Wis. Stats. § 66.082(3)(c). 
Sec. 102-57. - Renewal. 
(a)  This franchise may be renewed by the board upon application of the grantee pursuant to the procedure established in this section, and in accordance with the then applicable law. 
(b)  At least 18 months prior to the expiration of the franchise, the grantee shall inform the board in writing of its intent to seek renewal of the franchise. 
(c)  After giving public notice, the board shall proceed to determine whether the grantee has satisfactorily performed its obligations under the franchise. To determine satisfactory performance, the board shall consider technical developments and performance of the system, programming, other services offered, cost of services, and any other matters relevant to the operation and performance by grantee. The board shall consider the grantee's annual reports made to the village and the FCC and industry performance on a national basis. Provision shall be made for public comment. 
(d)  A four-month period shall be provided to determine the grantee's eligibility for renewal. 
(e)  The board shall then prepare, within two months of the expiration of that period, any amendments to this article that it believes necessary. 
(f)  If the board finds the grantee's performance satisfactory pursuant to section 102-76, a new franchise may be granted pursuant to this section, as amended, for a period to be determined by the board. 
(g)  If the grantee is determined by the board to have performed unsatisfactorily, new applicants shall be sought and evaluated and a franchise award shall be made by the board according to franchising procedures which have been or may be adopted by the board. 
(Code 1963, § 23.06) 
Sec. 102-58. - Right of revocation. 
(a)  The board shall have the right to rescind or revoke the franchise granted upon violation by the grantee of any material obligation or requirement contained in this article, or upon the refusal to comply with any reasonable request made by the board concerning compliance with this article, after written notice by the committee to the grantee, the continuation of such violation or refusal to comply by the grantee. An accumulation of violations, which if each is taken alone would not constitute a violation of a material obligation or requirement, may be deemed a violation of a material obligation or requirement. Such written notice to the grantee shall specify precisely the manner in which the grantee is in violation with respect to the franchise. The notice shall specify a reasonable amount of time within which the grantee must correct the violation, but in no event shall the time period be less than 30 days from the date of receipt of the notice to the grantee. 
(b)  The board may declare this franchise granted in this division to be forfeited and terminated upon the happening or discovery of any of the following events: 
(1)  The grantee adjudicated a bankrupt; 
(2)  The grantee becomes insolvent; 
(3)  The grantee is placed in receivership; 
(4)  The grantee violates the right of privacy of subscribers; 
(5)  The grantee fails to meet the construction timetable without good cause for such failure; 
(6)  The grantee practices fraud or deceit upon the village, its agents, and employees or upon the subscribers; 
(7)  The grantee makes material misrepresentations in its application; 
(8)  The grantee fails to comply with material requirements of its application or the village ordinances; 
(9)  The grantee fails to provide uninterrupted service to more than ten percent of its subscribers for ten consecutive days or for 30 days in any one calendar year. 
(c)  The board may establish or adopt additional rules and regulations which provide for fines to be levied against the grantee when, in the judgment of the hearing body, the grantee has failed to satisfactorily perform according to the terms of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 23.15) 
State Law reference- Authority to revoke cable television franchise, Wis. Stats. § 66.082(3)(b). 
Secs. 102-59-102-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION REQUIREMENTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate cable television systems, Wis. Stats. § 66.082(3)(e). 

Sec. 102-76. - Conditions and restrictions. 
(a)  A grantee shall be subject to the following restrictions and conditions with regard to the operation of the system, which conditions and restrictions shall be in addition to any other subsections of this section or other sections of this Code: 
(1)  Cable, wires and other equipment in connection with such system shall only be installed and operated on or under the streets upon the poles, or in underground conduit and equipment of the existing utilities within the village where conduits exist and where space in installed conduits is available. Installation of any additional poles, conduit or other equipment for the installation of cables, wires and other overhead equipment and underground equipment in streets in connection with such system shall not be authorized and is expressly forbidden except as such additional authorization may be secured by the special permission of the board; provided, however, that in no event may installation of poles be authorized along a public street. In reaching a decision as to such additional poles or equipment, the suggestions, if any of the public utility company or companies servicing or planning to serve such area may be considered. Installation over or on private property shall be subject to prior utility easement and prior notification by mail or personal service to property owners. 
(2)  Such wires, cables and other underground or overhead equipment shall be located as may be required of telephone companies or power lines by the state public service commission. All equipment shall be grounded in the same manner as required by the electrical code of the village for electrical services. 
(3)  In case it becomes necessary for grantee to open or otherwise disturb any streets, the grantee shall first secure a permit from the director of public works of the village. The charge for restoring the premises shall be determined by the fee schedule of the village. The grantee shall pay the charge therefor to the village in advance of the work. The work of restoring the street shall be performed by the village. As an alternative regarding restoration, the village may allow the grantee to restore the street, providing prior approval is granted by the village and inspection and approval of the restoration is given by the village. 
(4)  The grantee shall, at its own expense, protect, support, temporarily or permanently disconnect, relocate in the same street, or remove from any street, any property owned or used by the grantee when required by the village manager or designee, by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street vacation, freeway and street construction, change or establishment of street grade, installation of sewers, drains, water pipes, power lines and tracks or any other type of structures or improvements by governmental agencies when acting in a governmental or proprietary capacity, or any other structures or public improvements. 
(5)  The grantee shall, upon the request of any person holding a building moving permit issued by the village, temporarily raise or lower its lines or disconnect or take them down to permit the moving of buildings. The expense of such removal, raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the person requesting the same, and the grantee shall be given not less than 48 hours' advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
(6)  All installations by the grantee of cables and incidental equipment shall comply in all respects with all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of the Federal Communications Commission, the state, or any agency or department thereof, and of the village or any agency or department thereof, now or hereafter in effect. 
(7)  The grantee shall provide and maintain its equipment in such condition and of such quality so that none of its service will adversely affect radio and television reception. 
(8)  Installation and maintenance of equipment shall be such that standard color signals shall be transmitted with reasonable fidelity to any subscriber consistent with FCC standards. 
(9)  The grantee shall not either directly or indirectly engage in the servicing or repair of television receivers in the village, nor directly or indirectly require of any subscriber the patronage of any designated person or company engaged in such service or repair business. The foregoing shall not apply to the repair or adjustment of equipment which is part of the system of the grantee. 
(10)  The grantee shall submit to inspections by duly authorized personnel of the village and shall make available to such inspectors or duly authorized personnel its facilities and equipment. The village reserves the right to enact reasonable regulations regarding the installation and maintenance of the facilities of the grantee. 
(11)  The village shall have the right, during the life of this franchise, free of charge, where aerial construction exists, to maintain upon the poles of the grantee within the village limits wire and pole fixtures necessary for a police and fire alarm system, such wires and fixtures to be constructed and maintained to the satisfaction of the grantee and in accordance with its specifications. 
(12)  The village, in its use and maintenance of such wires and fixtures shall at all times comply with the rules and regulations of the grantee so that there may be a minimum danger of contact or conflict between the wires and fixtures of the grantee and the wires and fixtures used by the village. 
(13)  The grantee, subject to prior approval of the village manager or designee shall have the authority to trim trees upon and overhanging streets of the village so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires and cables of the grantee, except that at the option of the village, such trimming may be done by it or under its supervision and direction at the expense of the grantee. 
(14)  In all areas of the village where the cables, wires or other like facilities of public utilities are now placed underground, the grantee shall place its cables, wires or other like facilities underground. Where both aboveground and underground installations are present, the installation may be placed either above ground or underground. In all areas of the village where cables, wires or other like facilities or public utilities are in the future placed underground, the grantee shall at such time place its cables, wires or other facilities underground. Unless other determined by the board, upon termination of its franchise by revocation, nonrenewal or any other event the grantee shall remove or cause to be removed its plant, structures and equipment. 
(15)  In removing its plant, structures and equipment, the grantee shall refill at its own expense, any excavation that shall be made by it and shall leave all public ways and places in as good condition as that prevailing prior to the company's removal of its equipment and appliances, without affecting the electric or telephone cables, wires or attachments. Such obligations shall be met by grantee within 12 months of the date of revocation, termination or other future date fixed by the board. Any property not so removed shall be deemed abandoned, and the village may dispose of such property as it sees fit. Any cost for such removal or disposal incurred by the village shall be reimbursed by the grantee. The board shall inspect and approve the condition of the public ways and public places and wires, cables, attachments and poles after removal. Liability insurance and indemnity required to be provided under section 102-80 shall continue in full force and effect during the period of removal. The period of removal shall end only after inspection of the removal results and upon issuance of an approval of the grantee's removal results by the board. The grantee shall provide a performance bond in an amount to be set by the board to ensure payment for such removal. The board may require the grantee to continue operating for a period of 12 months from the date of any determination to revoke or not renew. 
(16)  In the event of a failure by the grantee to complete any work required by the provisions of this section or any work required by village law or ordinance within the time established and to the satisfaction of the village, the village may cause such work to be done, and the grantee shall reimburse the village the costs of such work within 30 days after receipt of an itemized list of such costs. 
(17)  It shall be the right of all subscribers to receive all available services insofar as their financial and other obligations to the grantee are honored. If the grantee elects to overbuild, rebuild, modify or sell the system, or the board gives notice of intent to terminate or fails to renew this franchise, the grantee shall act so as to ensure that all subscribers receive continuous, uninterrupted service regardless of the circumstances. 
(18)  The grantee may be required to interconnect its system with any other compatible broadband communications facility. Such interconnection shall be made within the time limit established by the board. The interconnection shall, at the board's discretion, be accomplished according to the method and technical standards determined by the board, in a manner consistent with the applicable FCC standards. 
(19)  The grantee shall provide a full color local origination production facility within the village limits or at such other location approved by the board. The grantee shall submit its construction plan for this studio to the board for approval. This production facility shall be made available to persons and organizations using the public, educational and government access channels on the grantee's cable system, subject to reasonable rules and regulations to be established by the Cable Access Corporation described elsewhere in this article, or by any other entity designated by the village board to operate the cable access studio and channel. The grantee shall provide reasonable technical and purchasing assistance (such as bulk discounts) to the Cable Access Corporation, and shall provide up to a maximum of $500.00 per year of maintenance on production equipment, and shall make available such additional production facilities as may be reasonably needed by the Cable Access Corporation to carry out its responsibilities. 
(20)  If the board determines not to reissue the franchise for reasons other than a material breach of the franchise or reasons unrelated to the performance of the franchise holder, or upon receipt of an application for assignment of the franchise, or upon change of de facto control, the grantee shall first offer the system for sale to the village at a fair and just market value of the system as a going concern including the franchise itself and the rights and privileges granted by the village. 
(b)  When the franchise is revoked or expires and is not renewed because of a material breach of the franchise, the grantee shall first offer the system for sale to the village at a fair and just market value, which value shall not include any value for the franchise itself or for any of the rights or privileges granted by the village. 
(c)  If the determination of fair market value cannot be negotiated or determined, such value shall be determined by an impartial arbitration procedure pursuant to Wis. Stats. ch. 298, wherein the grantee and the village shall each choose an arbitrator and the arbitrators chosen shall choose the third. The valuation determined by such arbitrators shall be considered the fair market value at which the system will be offered to the village. The determination of the value of the system shall be decreased by the amount of any damages sustained by the village in connection with revocation or expiration including, without limitation, payment made by the village to another person or entity to operate the system for a temporary period after revocation. The cost of the arbitration procedure shall be shared equally by the village and the grantee. 
(d)  The village shall have 90 days to exercise the right of first refusal to purchase the system, such 90 days commencing on the day the fair market value of the system is determined either through negotiation or the arbitration procedure. If the village does not exercise its option to purchase, and the system is not sold to another operator who has obtained a franchise from the village in a reasonable period of time, the grantee, upon request by the village, shall promptly remove all its plant, structures and equipment; provided, however, that if the village determines not to exercise its right of first refusal it shall not unreasonably refuse to renew or grant a cable television franchise during a reasonable interim period. While transfer of the system and franchise is being negotiated, arranged or ordered, the grantee may be required to continue service to the public unless for reasons beyond the control of the grantee such operation will be economically unfeasible to the grantee. 
(Code 1963, § 23.07) 
Sec. 102-77. - Broadband cable communications service. 
(a)  The cable communications system permitted to be installed and operated under this article shall be operated in conformance with the FCC'S Technical Standards, 47 CFR 76.601 et seq. The system shall be capable of delivering all National Television Systems Committee color and monochrome standard signals, developed and presented to the Federal Communications Commission on July 21, 1953, to standard Electronic Industries Association approved television receivers without noticeable degradation. The system shall meet all performance criteria over the ambient temperature range prevailing in the franchise area from the normal daily minimum temperature in February to the normal daily maximum temperature in August. The grantee shall continue, throughout the term of the franchise, to maintain the technical standards and quality of service set forth in this article and consistent with the then existing state of the art. Should the board reasonably find that the grantee has failed to maintain these technical standards and quality of service, and should it specifically enumerate improvements to be made, the grantee shall make such improvements. 
(b)  The system shall be capable of initially delivering to subscribers a minimum of 54 channels. 
(c)  The grantee shall carry, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Milwaukee Metropolitan Area channels 4, 6, 10, 12, 18, 30, 36 and 58. 
(2)  A minimum of two independent nonarea channels. 
(3)  The signals of other TV stations pursuant to the present and future regulations and requirements of the FCC. 
(4)  One grantee controlled and provided additional fee channel for special programs and events. 
(5)  One access channel for a use to be determined by the village board with a right reserved to the village to obtain a second access channel when traffic so dictates. Access channel production facilities and equipment will be provided by the grantee or by the municipal users, based upon the provisions as set forth in this section and in the grantee's application. 
(6)  Such additional channels, programs and production equipment as the grantee has included in his application. 
(d)  The grantee shall at no charge: 
(1)  Furnish and install a cable service drop or connection to each school (public, private and parochial), the village hall, library, police department and fire department. 
(2)  Provide two-way capability and furnish the necessary line amplifiers and return modules when required by the village. 
(3)  Provide for program interruption to allow the village to advise its residents of emergency situations. 
(Code 1963, § 23.10) 
Sec. 102-78. - Complaint procedure; service standards. 
(a)  The grantee shall maintain a business office and telephone listing in the Milwaukee Metropolitan Area for the purpose of receiving inquiries and complaints from its customers and the general public. The grantee shall investigate all complaints from its customers and the general public. The grantee shall investigate all complaints within 24 hours of their receipt and shall in good faith attempt to resolve them within 24 hours after notice. The grantee shall maintain records of complaints including action taken thereon and shall keep such records in the local business office. The grantee shall make the records available to the board upon request. In no event shall grantee remove or destroy such records without prior approval of the board. If more stringent complaint handling standards are described in the application or correspondence, such standards shall replace those provided in this section. 
(b)  In the event of the failure by the grantee to resolve complaints, the board may review complaints, other than those relating to program content. Failure of the grantee to resolve complaints may also be cause for revocation of franchise. 
(c)  In all brochures and other written material, the grantee shall state the fact that a complaint procedure has been established, and state the mailing address and telephone number of the office handling inquiries and complaints. 
(d)  When there have been similar complaints made or where there exists other evidence which, in the judgment of the committee casts doubt on the reliability or quality of cable service, the board shall have the right and authority to compel the grantee to test, analyze and report on the performance of the system, at the expense of the grantee. Such tests shall be made, and the reports of such tests shall be delivered to the village no later than 14 days after the board formally notifies the grantee. Such report shall include the following information: The nature of the complaints which precipitated the special tests; what system component was tested; the equipment used and procedures employed in such testing; the results of such tests; and the method in which such complaints were resolved. Any other information pertinent to the special test shall be recorded. 
(1)  Such tests and analyses shall be supervised by a professional engineer, not on the permanent staff of the grantee. The engineer should sign all records of special tests and forward to the village such records with a report interpreting the result of the tests and recommending actions to be taken by the village. 
(2)  The village's right under this section shall be limited to requiring of tests, analyses and reports covering specific subjects and characteristics based on such complaints or other evidence when and under such circumstances as the village has reasonable grounds to believe that the complaints or other evidence require that tests be performed to protect the public against substandard cable service. The cost of any such tests, analyses and report required as part of the complaint procedure outlined in this section shall be borne by the grantee. 
(e)  Standards of service to customers to be met by the grantee include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  A problem that poses a safety hazard or otherwise is likely to cause property damage or bodily injury shall be fixed immediately, regardless of time. A problem that affects five or more customers will be repaired immediately except between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. A problem that is caused by employee shall be fixed immediately except between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. Any other problems shall be responded to within 24 hours. 
(2)  Maintenance and major equipment change-outs which require shutting off service to five or more customers will be accomplished, if at all possible, after midnight. If a shutdown of service is required while the cable system is transmitting signals, a notice will, if possible, be placed on the weather or message channel to the effect that repairs are being made. The notice will be posted at least ten minutes before shutdown occurs. 
(3)  For the convenience of customers, an answering service will be provided outside all normal business hours so that complaints may be registered at any time, 24 hours a day. The answering service will have the ability to dispatch a service technician to resolve the problem. 
(4)  Customers requesting service will be connected as soon as practical after the request is made. Appointments will be made, confirmed and kept insofar as possible. When an appointment cannot be kept, an effort will be made to contact the customer to change the appointed time. 
(5)  Nonpay disconnects will not be scheduled on a Friday or on a day before a holiday. 
(6)  Installers will be trained in procedures for installation and customer relations before they are placed in a working environment. 
(Code 1963, § 23.11) 
Sec. 102-79. - Construction schedule. 
(a)  The grantee shall, within 60 days of the date of the award of the franchise, perform and submit all required registrations and applications with the appropriate governmental agencies regulating cable systems. 
(b)  The grantee shall, within 90 days of the date of the award of the franchise, furnish to the board complete plans and specifications for the construction of its plant and distribution system for approval by the board. 
(c)  The grantee shall, within one year of the approval of the plans and specifications by the board, complete the construction necessary to make cable system service available to at least 50 percent of the homes in the village. Installation of an institutional loop shall be completed within one year of the time its need is determined by the board. 
(d)  The grantee shall, within 18 months of the approval of the plans and specifications by the board, complete all of the construction of its plant and distribution system throughout the village. 
(e)  Completion of construction under subsections (c) and (d) of this section shall include not only the required installation of equipment, but shall be interpreted to also require the satisfactory receipt of all signals by all subscribers and all facilities on an institutional loop. 
(f)  Failure to comply with any of the time limits set forth in subsections (a), (b), (c) and (d) of this section (unless such time limits are extended by the board prior to the expiration of the applicable time period and only for delays beyond the control of grantee) shall be grounds for revocation of franchise. In addition, as and for liquidated damages for failure to comply with any time limit set forth in this article, the application and correspondence, or made a part of the contract with the village, the grantee shall pay to the grantor the sum of $200.00 per day for each day of noncompliance beyond the time limit specified. 
(g)  At the end of 18 months (as established under subsection (d) of this section, the grantee shall make cable system service available to all residences or commercial establishments within the village, within 60 days after the filing of written applications by such potential subscribers for such service and payment of the connection fee. 
(h)  The grantee shall make no material change in the operation of the system from that approved by the board in granting the franchise except upon prior approval by the village. At least two weeks prior to making request for a material change in operations, the grantee shall cause to be published in the official village newspaper a prominent notice of the request, including a description of the nature of the changes and a concise statement for the reasons therefor. 
(i)  The standard customer service drop is defined as a maximum of 200 feet from the distribution point. Customers needing a drop in excess of 200 feet shall be charged for the excess on a per foot basis. 
(Code 1963, § 23.12) 
Sec. 102-80. - Liability of grantee. 
(a)  The grantee shall indemnify and save the village, its agents and employees harmless from and against all loss, liability, damage and expenses, including attorney's fees, sustained by the village, its agents and employees, on account of any suit, judgment, execution, claim or demand arising out of the installation, operation or maintenance of the cable communication system authorized in this article, whether or not any act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this article and any franchise granted under this article; including, but not limiting such indemnity to, claims for personal injuries, libel, slander, death or property damages, expenses of investigation and litigation of claims and suits arising under this article, and claims based on copyright violation or infringements or violation of proprietary rights. 
(b)  The grantee shall carry and at all times maintain on file with the village clerk-treasurer, and at all times keep in force a public liability policy of insurance, insuring such grantee and the village against any and all liability arising from such installation and/or operation, with limits of liability of not less than $2,000,000.00 for property damage and $4,000,000.00 for any one person for personal injury, death or other damages attributable to the installation and/or operation of the cable communication system. Such policies of insurance or certificate of such insurance by a company licensed to do business in the state, shall be filed with the village clerk-treasurer prior to the commencement of installation. Such policy or certificate shall provide that the village shall be notified 30 days in advance of the cancellation or termination of the policy. The board reserves the right to approve the policy and to periodically increase minimum limits of liability based upon inflationary factors and based upon experience. 
(c)  The grantee, upon receipt of due notice in writing from the village, shall defend at its own expense any action or proceeding against the village in which it is claimed that injury or damages arose from the grantee's activities or failure to act in the installation, maintenance or operation of its cable communication system. 
(Code 1963, § 23.13) 
Sec. 102-81. - Additional requirements. 
(a)  The grantee shall comply with all conditions imposed by the Federal Communications Commission and by the state. Failure to obtain any required licenses or to comply with all such conditions shall be grounds to revoke the franchise without liability assigned to the village. Copies of all documents pertaining to the village filed with other government bodies including, but not limited to, the FCC and the state, shall be available to the village. 
(b)  The grantee shall make available at no charge to all subscribers a lockout device which will allow maximum subscriber control over pay channel programming received into the home or place of business. 
(Code 1963, § 23.14) 
Sec. 102-82. - Preferential or discriminatory practices. 
    The grantee shall not, as to rates, charges, service, services facilities, rules, regulations, employment, or in any other respect, make or grant any undue preference or advantage to any party, nor subject any party to any prejudice or disadvantage because of race, creed, religion, sex, age, marital status or national origin. 
(Code 1963, § 23.16) 
Sec. 102-83. - Right of privacy. 
    The grantee shall not reveal to any third party any information or data concerning any specific subscriber except as required by law. Any information or data revealed to third parties shall be limited to gross data relating to all subscribers without identification of individual subscribers; provided, however, that the grantee may make revelations consistent with activities directly related to the business of operating a cable communication system, i.e., mailing of information and billing statements. Upon request the board shall be furnished with subscriber information. 
(Code 1963, § 23.18) 
Sec. 102-84. - Evaluation session. 
(a)  Generally. The board and the grantee shall hold scheduled evaluation sessions within 30 days of the fifth and tenth anniversary dates of the granting of this franchise. All such evaluation sessions shall be open to the public and announced in an official village newspaper of general circulation at least five days before each session. 
(b)  Special evaluation sessions. Special evaluation sessions may be held at any time during the term of the franchise, provided that both the board and the grantee shall mutually agree on the time, the place and the topics to be evaluated. All such evaluation sessions shall be open to the public and announced in a newspaper of general circulation at least five days before each session. 
(c)  Topics to be evaluated. The following topics shall be discussed at every scheduled evaluation session: 
(1)  Service rate structures; 
(2)  Free or discounted services; 
(3)  Application of new technologies; 
(4)  System performances; 
(5)  Services provided; 
(6)  Programming offered; 
(7)  Customer complaints; 
(8)  Privacy and human rights; 
(9)  Amendments to this article; and 
(10)  Judicial and FCC rulings. 
Topics in addition to those listed may be added if agreed upon by both parties. Members of the general public may add topics either by working through the negotiating parties, or by presenting a petition. If such a petition bears the valid signatures of 50 or more qualified electors of the village, the proposed topics shall be added to the list of topics to be discussed at the evaluation session. 
(Code 1963, § 23.19) 
Chapter 106 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance providing traffic or parking regulations for specific locations or routing buses in a manner not inconsistent with this Code saved from repeal, § 1-11(a)(16); courts, ch. 26; law enforcement, ch. 54; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62; traffic regulations in parks, § 66-37; litter control on operation of vehicles, § 82-23; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; trees and shrubs obstructing view at intersections, § 114-25; vehicles for hire, ch. 118; traffic visibility, § 122-601; zoning regulation of traffic, parking and access, § 122-686 et seq. 
State Law reference- Vehicles and traffic generally, Wis. Stats. chs. 340-350; powers of local authorities, Wis. Stats. ch. 349. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 106-1. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
(a)  The penalty for violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a forfeiture as provided in this section, together with the cost of prosecution imposed as provided in Wis. Stats. §§ 345.20-345.53. 
(b)  Forfeitures for violation of any provision of Wis. Stats. chs. 341-348 shall conform to forfeitures for violation of the comparable state offense, including any variation for second offenses. 
(c)  Forfeitures for violation of article III, division 2 of this chapter; article VII of this chapter; article III, division 1 of this chapter; and article V of this chapter shall not be less than $10.00 nor more than $100.00 for the first offense and not less than $20.00 nor more than $200.00 for the second offense within two years. 
(d)  Parking. The forfeiture for violation of parking regulations in article IV of this chapter, except sections 106-154 and 106-132(b) shall be not less than $5.00, nor more than $50.00. Forfeitures for violation of section 106-154 shall not be less than $10.00, nor more than $100.00 for the first offense and not less than $50.00, nor more than $200.00 for the second offense within two years. Any person convicted of violating section 106-132(b) shall be required to forfeit $30.00; and, in addition, shall pay any charges for moving or towing the vehicle, or for any storage involved. 
(Code 1963, § 6.75; Ord. No. 880-97, §§ 2, 3, 6-2-1997) 
Sec. 106-2. - Provisions of state law adopted by reference. 
(a)  State traffic laws adopted. 
(1)  Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, the statutory provisions in Wis. Stats. chs. 340-348 describing and defining regulations with respect to vehicles and traffic, exclusive of any provisions therein relating to penalties to be imposed and exclusive of any regulations for which the statutory penalty is a fine or term of imprisonment, are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth in this section. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute incorporated in this section by reference is required or prohibited by this chapter. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the statutes incorporated in this section are intended to be made a part of this chapter in order to secure uniform statewide regulation of traffic on the highways, streets and alleys of the state. 
(2)  Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, the regulatory provisions of Wis. Admin. Code chs. Trans 301-315 and 325-327 are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth. 
(b)  Snowmobile laws adopted. Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, the statutory provisions in Wis. Stats. ch. 350 describing and defining regulations with respect to snowmobiles, exclusive of any provision therein relating to penalties to be imposed and exclusive of any regulations for which the statutory penalty is a fine or term of imprisonment are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth in this section. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute incorporated in this section by reference is required or prohibited by this chapter. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the statutes incorporated in this section are intended to be made a part of this chapter in order to secure uniform statewide regulation of snowmobiles in the state. 
(Code 1963, § 6.01; Ord. No. 111-O-00, § 1, 10-18-00) 
State Law reference- Authority to incorporate Wis. Stats. chs. 348 and 350, Wis. Stats. § 349.06. 
Secs. 106-3-106-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-21. - Enforcement. 
    This chapter shall be enforced in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 345.20-345.53, Wis. Stats. ch. 800 and Wis. Stats. § 66.0114. 
(Code 1963, § 6.80; Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 57, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 106-22. - Traffic officers. 
    For purposes of directing vehicular and pedestrian traffic on public or private property or in the right-of-way areas of the village, duly appointed police aides are hereby designated as "traffic officers" within the meaning of Wis. Stats. §§ 340.01(70) and 346.04 and are hereby authorized to direct and control vehicular and pedestrian traffic as assigned through the village police department. 
(Ord. No. 470-O-09, § 2, 12-7-09) 
Sec. 106-23. - Abandoned vehicles. 
(a)  This section does not apply to abandoned vehicles that have been stolen. 
(b)  Pursuant to the authority contained in Wis. Stats. § 342.40, vehicles left unattended under the following circumstances shall be deemed abandoned and constitute a public nuisance: 
(1)  Any vehicle found under circumstances prohibited in section 106-156 shall be deemed to be abandoned property. 
(2)  Any vehicle found under circumstances prohibited in section 106-89 shall be deemed to be abandoned property. 
(c)  Whenever abandoned vehicles are found, the police department shall attempt to locate the owner or operator and require him to remove such vehicle. 
(d)  In the case of abandoned vehicles, if after a reasonable attempt the police department is unable to notify the owner or operator of an abandoned vehicle, the department shall cause the vehicle to be removed pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 342.40(3)(a). 
(e)  The village, any employee of the village, or any agent of the village engaged in the removal of any vehicle under this section shall not be held liable for any damage, real or alleged, caused to the property in the removal or storage process. 
(Code 1963, § 6.30; Ord. No. 470-O-09, § 1, 12-7-09; Ord. No. 675-O-16, § 3, 8-15-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 470-O-09, § 1, adopted December 7, 2009, renumbered the former section 106-22 as section 106-23. The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Secs. 106-24-106-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC SIGNS, SIGNALS, DEVICES AND MARKINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic signs, signals and markings, Wis. Stats. § 346.37 et seq.; local traffic signs, signals and markings generally, Wis. Stats. § 340.094; obedience to traffic signs, signals and devices, Wis. Stats. § 346.04. 

Sec. 106-41. - Permanent. 
(a)  Permanent traffic regulations shall be in effect in such locations as established and authorized by the village board, and the procurement, erection and maintenance of appropriate standard traffic signs, signals and markings giving notice of such traffic regulations shall be under the authority and direction of the village manager or designee. 
(b)  All traffic signs, signals devices and markings in place in the adoption date of this code, are ratified and confirmed. 
(Code 1963, § 6.40(4)) 
Sec. 106-42. - Temporary. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby authorized and directed to establish such temporary traffic control measures as may be required as a result of street, bridge, highway or utility construction projects, or any other project or cause which requires temporary traffic control. Such temporary measures shall include, but are not limited to, the establishment of traffic routes; one-way streets and alleys; turning requirements and prohibitions, parking, speed and trucking regulations; installation of traffic control signals and stop signs; the painting of pavement markers; and the barricading of streets. 
(b)  The chief of police or his agent shall have the authority to procure and erect such signs, markings and barricades as are necessary pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  When practical, the chief of police shall consult with the village manager or designee and the implementing of subsection (a) of this section shall be a coordinated activity. 
(Code 1963, § 6.40(1)-(3)) 
Sec. 106-43. - Removal of unofficial signs and signals. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority granted by Wis. Stats. § 349.09, and is hereby directed to order the removal of a sign, signal, marking or device placed, maintained or displayed in violation of this chapter or Wis. Stats. § 346.41. Any charge imposed on a premises for removal of such an illegal sign, signal or device shall be reported to the village board at its next regular meeting for review and certification. 
(Code 1963, § 6.40(6)) 
Secs. 106-44-106-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 106-61. - Stipulation of guilt or no contest. 
    Stipulations of guilt or no contest may be made by persons arrested for violations of this chapter in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 66.0114(1)(b), whenever the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 345.27 are inapplicable to such violations. Stipulations shall conform to the form contained on the uniform traffic citation and complaint under Wis. Stats. § 345.11, and may be accepted within ten days of the date of the alleged violation. Stipulations may be accepted by the village police department, as provided in section 106-65. 
(Code 1963, § 6.80(1); Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 58, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 106-62. - Deposits. 
    Any person stipulating guilt or no contest under section 106-61 must make the deposit required under Wis. Stats. § 345.26 or, if the deposit is not established under such statute, shall deposit a forfeited penalty as provided in the schedule established by the chief of police and approved by the village board. Deposits shall be brought or mailed to the office of the police department as directed by the arresting officer. Deposits for parking or nonmoving violations shall be mailed or brought to the police department. 
(Code 1963, § 6.80(2)) 
Sec. 106-63. - Notice of demerit points and receipt. 
    Every officer accepting a forfeited penalty or money deposit under this chapter shall receipt therefor in triplicate as provided in Wis. Stats. § 345.26(3)(b). Every officer accepting a stipulation under the provisions of this chapter shall comply with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 343.27, 343.28, 345.26(1)(a) and 345.27(2), and shall require the alleged violator to sign a statement of notice in substantially the form contained on the uniform traffic citation and complaint promulgated under Wis. Stats. § 345.11. 
(Code 1963, § 6.80(3)) 
Sec. 106-64. - Forfeitures in treasury. 
    Any officer accepting deposits of forfeited penalties under this chapter shall deliver them to the village clerk-treasurer within 20 days of receipt. 
(Code 1963, § 6.80(4)) 
Sec. 106-65. - Stipulation procedure. 
(a)  The chief of police or other member or employee of the police department designated by him, upon request of any person charged with a violation of this chapter, may accept a written stipulation of guilt and required penalty of such person in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Any person to whom a traffic citation has been issued for violating any section of this Code as set forth in this section may appear at the police station in the village in answer to the charges set forth in such citation and, upon payment of the amount provided, may be permitted to enter into a stipulation with the village, represented by the village, for a disposition of the alleged violation stated in the citation. Such stipulation may provide for a plea or stipulation of guilt, nolo contendere, or for a forfeiture of a deposit of money as a penalty as provided in this section. A copy of such stipulation shall be given the violator and he shall be required to confirm, in writing, that he has been informed that his driving record will be charged with points in the case of a moving violation and the number of points which is cause for revocation of an operator license. Whenever a person stipulates to a traffic violation which is required by law to be processed through court, the stipulation and the deposit received therewith shall be without delay filed and deposited with the clerk of the court having jurisdiction of the alleged violation for such further disposition as the court may direct. If such stipulation is vacated by the court, the provisions of this section shall not apply. 
(2)  Whenever the stipulation covers a violation which is not required by law to be filed in court, it and the amount of deposit or penalty received therewith shall be filed and deposited with the village clerk-treasurer who shall furnish a receipt to the chief of police or his designee for the stipulations and money paid over to him. Such deposit shall be made at least once in each seven days. If a stipulation is not entered into within ten days commencing at 6:00 p.m. on the day a citation is issued, the penalty shall be increased as provided in this section, unless, for good cause shown, the village attorney, chief of police or his designee, extends such time limit. The deposit or penalty for all violations shall be paid in cash, money order or bank check, payable to the village. Neither the chief of police nor any officer or village employee shall be personally or officially responsible for the payment of any dishonored check received in payment of any penalty. If the person receiving a citation for an alleged violation transmits the stipulation by messenger or mail to the police station, such person shall place his post office address, his operator's license number and the date of his birth upon such stipulation as appropriate. For the purpose of this section, a nonmoving violation or offense is any parking or standing of a vehicle in violation of a traffic ordinance and any violation, while the vehicle is not in motion, of any ordinance enacted pursuant to law or Wis. Stats. chs. 340-349, 351. A pedestrian violation of any traffic ordinance shall be deemed a nonmoving violation. 
(b)  A deposit for all nonmoving violations set forth in this chapter shall be $20.00 except for violations of section 106-154 (snow emergency section), section 106-132(b) (tow-away zone section) and section 106-133(9) (handicapped parking section). The deposit or forfeiture for violations of section 106-154 (snow emergency section) and section 106-132(b) (tow-away zone section) shall be $30.00, and does not include any towing charge, which may be imposed in addition to this forfeiture deposit. The deposit or forfeiture for violations of section 106-133(9) (handicapped parking section) shall be $50.00. No court costs or fees shall be added. A deposit for all moving violations set forth in this chapter shall be in accordance with the Uniform Traffic Deposit Schedule adopted pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 345.26(2)(a), plus court costs or fees, and indicated in section 1 of such schedule. 
(c)  If a deposit is made after ten days have expired without good cause shown, as provided in this section, the deposit or penalty shall be $30.00 for all nonmoving violations set forth in this chapter, except section 106-154 (snow emergency section), section 106-133(9) (handicapped parking section) and section 106-132(b) (tow-away zone section). The deposit or forfeiture for violations of section 106-154 (snow emergency section) and section 106-132(b) (tow-away zone section) shall be $40.00, and does not include any towing charge which may be imposed in addition to this forfeiture deposit. The deposit or forfeiture for violations of section 106-133(9) (handicapped parking section) shall be $60.00. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall apply to all violations of the Wisconsin Statutes except Wis. Stats. §§ 346.62(1) and 346.63(1), as adopted by reference in this chapter, and enumerated in section I of the Uniform State Traffic Deposit Schedule but do not apply to violations of the Wisconsin Traffic Code enumerated in section II of such deposit schedule which constitute criminal actions. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the right of the proper authorities to accept bail bond, deposits of certificates or money deposits as provided in Wis. Stats. § 66.0111. 
(Code 1963, § 6.81; Ord. No. 880-97, §§ 4, 5, 6-2-1997; Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 59, 11-19-2001) 
Secs. 106-66-106-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL RULE OF VEHICLE OPERATION[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Vehicle operation generally, Wis. Stats. ch. 346. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-86. - Self-propelled devices. 
(a)  Defined. The term "self-propelled device," as used in this section means any device which is internal combustion engine driven or electric motor driven, and in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn. It includes, without limitation for lack of enumeration, such devices commonly known as automobiles, trucks, tractors, mini-bikes, go-carts, snowmobile, motor bicycle, garden tractor and similar devices. 
(b)  Registration required. No person shall operate any self-propelled device upon any of the sidewalks, streets, alleys, public highways or parkways in the village unless such vehicle is registered as prescribed in Wis. Stats. ch. 341, or its operation is specifically permitted by statute. 
(c)  Operation on private property. No person shall operate any self-propelled device upon any private property without the express permission of the owner or person in lawful control. In the absence of the owner or person in lawful control, the operator of the device shall have in his possession written proof of such permission. 
(d)  Operation on village property. No person shall operate any self-propelled device upon any property owned by or under the control of the village, including parks, parkways, bicycle ways, bicycle lanes, or pedestrian ways, except emergency or maintenance vehicles without a written permit approved by the village board or its designated agent. 
(e)  Operation by minors. No parent or guardian of any child under the age of 18 years shall authorize or permit such child to violate any of the provisions of this section. 
(f)  Connection not to be reported. No conviction under this section is to be reported to the state for the purpose of driver's license suspension or revocation. Court proceedings and enforcement of this section shall be as provided in section 106-1. 
(Code 1963, § 6.20(1), (2), (10)) 
Sec. 106-87. - Squealing of tires. 
(a)  Prohibited acts. No operator of a motor vehicle shall at any time cause, by excessive and unnecessary acceleration, tires of the vehicle to emit loud noise by spinning wheels on the surface of any roadway, or parking lot within the village. 
(b)  Penalty for violation of section. No conviction under this section is to be reported to the state for the purpose of driver's license suspension or revocation. Court proceedings and enforcement of this section shall be as provided in section 106-1. 
(Code 1963, § 6.20(3), (10)) 
Sec. 106-88. - Racing engine. 
(a)  Prohibited acts. No operator or person in control of a motor vehicle shall cause or permit by excessive or unnecessary acceleration or increasing the revolutions per minute of the engine either while standing or moving, any loud noise such as would disturb the public peace and quiet within the village. 
(b)  Penalty for violation of section. No conviction under this section is to be reported to the state for the purpose of driver's license suspension or revocation. Court proceedings and enforcement of this section shall be as provided in section 106-1. 
(Code 1963, § 6.20(4), (10)) 
State Law reference- Unreasonable noise, Wis. Stats. § 947.01. 
Sec. 106-89. - Parking without registration plate. 
(a)  Prohibited generally. No person shall park, stop, or leave standing upon any public street, highway, alley or municipal parking lot in the village any vehicle required to be registered under Wis. Stats. ch. 341, unless such vehicle has properly attached to it a registration plate as required by such chapter. 
(b)  Penalty for violation of section. No conviction under this section is to be reported to the state for the purpose of driver's license suspension or revocation. Court proceedings and enforcement of this section shall be as provided in section 106-1. 
(Code 1963, § 6.20(5), (10)) 
Sec. 106-90. - Cruising. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cruising means driving a motor vehicle in the same direction past a traffic control point in a designated area more than twice in any two-hour period between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. Passing a designated control point a third time under such conditions shall constitute unnecessary repetitive driving and cruising. 
    Designated area means the following: all that portion of Appleton Avenue between Main Street and Stadium Boulevard within the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  Traffic control point means a reference point within or adjacent to a designated area selected by a police officer for the purpose of determining unnecessary repetitive driving and cruising. 
(c)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in cruising. For the purposes of this section, the person having control or ownership of a motor vehicle shall be considered the person cruising, without regard as to whether that person was actually driving the motor vehicle each time it passed the traffic control point. Having control or ownership of a motor vehicle shall mean either the owner of the vehicle, if present in the vehicle at the time of the violation, or, if the owner is not present, the person operating the vehicle at the time of violation. 
(d)  Exemptions. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any publicly owned vehicle of any city, county, state, federal or other governmental unit, while the vehicle is being operated for official purposes of the governmental unit. 
(2)  Any authorized emergency vehicle. 
(3)  Any taxicabs for hire, public transit buses or other vehicles being operated for business purposes. 
(e)  Penalty for violation of section. Any person who violates this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to the following forfeitures, together with the costs of prosecution, and, in default of payment, be confined in the county jail or house of correction until such forfeiture and costs are paid, but not to exceed eight days: 
(1)  Not more than $50.00 if the person has not committed a previous violation within 12 months of the violation. 
(2)  Not more than $100.00 if the person has committed a previous violation within 12 months of the violation. 
(3)  Not more than $200.00 if the person has committed two or more violations within 12 months of the violation. 
(Code 1963, § 6.095) 
Secs. 106-91-106-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Size and weight limits, Wis. Stats. ch. 348; authority to restrict heavy traffic, Wis. Stats. § 349.17. 

Sec. 106-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Heavy traffic means all vehicles designed or used for the purpose of transporting material of any nature when the gross weight of such vehicle shall be 6,000 pounds or greater or any vehicle not operating completely upon pneumatic tires. 
    Weights means: 
(1)  The net weight of a vehicle is the weight of the vehicle equipped for service. 
(2)  The tare weight of a vehicle is that weight which the vehicle is equipped to carry as a load. 
(3)  The gross weight of a vehicle is the sum of the net and tare weights. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public street or highway. 
(Code 1963, § 6.08(1)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 106-107. - General heavy traffic regulations. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) below, no person shall operate any vehicle within the classification of heavy traffic over any of the bridges, streets or highways designated by ordinance; provided, however, that nothing in this division shall prohibit the least possible ordinary use of any such streets or highways for the purpose of obtaining orders for and delivering or moving supplies or other necessary commodities to or from any residence or place of business fronting on such streets or highways. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Notwithstanding subsection (a), vehicles owned or operated by Waukesha County shall not be subject to heavy truck traffic regulations applicable to Main Street between Elder Lane and Pilgrim Road when those vehicles are in use for snowplowing operations. 
(2)  Subsection (a) and village ordinances adopting regulations pursuant to that subsection or to Wis. Stats. § 349.17 shall not apply to vehicles owned or operated by the Village of Menomonee Falls. 
(Ord. No. 699-O-17, § 1, 10-16-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 699-O-17, § 1, adopted Oct. 16, 2017, repealed § 106-107 in its entirety and enacted a new § 106-107 to read as set out herein. Former § 106-107 pertained to exception and derived from the Code of 1963, § 6.06(2). 
Sec. 106-108. - Heavy traffic on bridges. 
    No vehicle having a gross weight of 6,000 pounds or more shall be operated on or over any of the bridges designated by ordinance. 
(Code 1963, § 6.08(3)) 
Sec. 106-109. - Other weight restrictions. 
    No vehicle having a gross weight of 12,000 pounds or more shall be operated on or over any of the bridges designated by ordinance. 
(Code 1963, § 6.08(4)) 
Secs. 106-110-106-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, Wis. Stats. § 346.50 et seq.; authority to regulate stopping, standing and parking, Wis. Stats. § 349.13. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-131. - Exceptions to article provisions in state law. 
    The provisions of this article are subject to the exceptions set forth in Wis. Stats. § 346.50. 
(Code 1963, § 6.09) 
Sec. 106-132. - Stopping or parking prohibited in specified places. 
(a)  No person shall stop or leave any vehicle in any of the places mentioned in subsection (b) of this section except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading or in receiving or discharging passengers and while the vehicle is attended by a licensed operator so it may promptly be moved in case of an emergency or to avoid obstruction of traffic. 
(b)  No vehicles shall be left or stopped upon any portion of a street or highway which has been designated as a "tow-away zone." Such areas shall be identified by signs posted in appropriate places in each such area to inform the public of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1963, § 6.09(1)) 
Sec. 106-133. - Parking on certain streets restricted. 
    When signs are erected in any block giving notice thereof, no person shall park any vehicle or permit any vehicle to remain standing on certain streets and highways within the boundaries therein designated except for the length of time during the hours specified in this section. Specific locations to which these subsections apply are to be found in the minutes of the village board, the official record on file in the village clerk-treasurer's office and the police department. 
(1)  Thirty-minute parking; 
(2)  Sixty-minute parking; 
(3)  Ninety-minute parking; 
(4)  Two-hour parking; 
(5)  Loading zones; 
(6)  Miscellaneous parking restrictions; 
(7)  Angle parking required; 
(8)  Bus stops; 
(9)  Handicapped parking. 
(Code 1963, § 6.09(2)) 
Sec. 106-134. - Fire lanes and zones. 
(a)  Authority to establish. The chief of the fire department may establish fire lanes in lots, areas or other accommodations which are open to public use, with or without charge, for the parking of vehicles off the street or highway. The chief of the fire department may establish fire zones in lots or areas adjacent to buildings or structures used for public accommodations such as hospitals, nursing homes, schools, auditoriums, hotels, motels, dancehalls, theaters, shopping centers, places of employment or any other use where in his judgment a danger to human life exists in the event of fire. Such fire lanes or zones as are established in accordance with this subsection shall be posted with signs by the owner of the property involved in accordance with the instructions of the chief of the fire prevention bureau. 
(b)  Parking prohibited generally; exception. No person shall stop or leave any vehicle in any established fire lane or zone except temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, loading or unloading, or in receiving or discharging passengers and while the vehicle is attended by a licensed operator so it may be promptly moved in case of emergency. 
(c)  Notice; removal of unlawfully parked vehicle. Whenever any vehicle is found parked in an established fire lane or zone, a village police officer shall attach to such vehicle a notice to the owner or operator of such vehicle setting forth that the vehicle has been parked unlawfully; provided, however, that if such unlawful parking constitutes an immediate hazard or danger to human life or interferes with firefighting operations, it may be towed or removed to another portion of the lot or area, all at the expense of the owner of the vehicle. 
(d)  Presumed to be operator. In any prosecution or proceeding for unlawful parking in a fire lane or zone, the registered owner of the vehicle so parked shall be presumed to be the operator of such vehicle. 
(e)  Penalty for violation of section. 
(1)  Except as provided in subsection (e)(2) of this section, any person convicted of violating subsection (b) of this section shall be required to forfeit not less than $10.00, nor more than $100.00; and, in addition, shall pay any charges for moving or towing the vehicle, or for any storage involved. 
(2)  If a deposit is made within ten days as provided for in section 106-65, the deposit for violations of subsection (b) of this section shall be $30.00. No court costs or fees shall be added. An amount may be imposed in addition to this forfeiture deposit for a towing charge. If a deposit is made after ten days have expired without good cause shown, as provided in this section, the deposit or penalty shall be $40.00; and does not include any towing charge, which may be imposed in addition to this forfeiture deposit. 
(Code 1963, §§ 22.05(1)-(5), 22.10(b); Ord. No. 880-97, § 6, 6-2-1997) 
Sec. 106-135. - Sale of used motor vehicles from or on residential properties. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) below, no person may offer, advertise, sell, exchange or deal in used or second hand motor vehicles from or on any property used or zoned for residential purposes in the village. 
(b)  Motor vehicles may be offered, advertised or sold on any property used or zoned for residential purposes by the resident owner of said property or by an authorized and resident tenant or lessee of said property provided that the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The motor vehicle must be titled to said owner, tenant or lessee of the property or a resident member of the immediate family of said owner, tenant or lessee; 
(2)  Not more than one vehicle may be sold at any one time; 
(3)  Not more than four vehicles may be sold in any one calendar year; 
(4)  Vehicles may be offered for sale for not more than 30 days; 
(5)  The vehicle may not be parked on the front, back or side yards of the property. The vehicle may be parked upon a paved or unpaved driveway leading directly from a street to a garage, or to a parking lot or parking stall. 
(Ord. No. 88-O-00, § 1, 5-15-00; Ord. No. 96-O-00, § 1, 6-29-00) 
Sec. 106-136. - Parking on lawns prohibited. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no motor vehicle as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(35), no trailer as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(71), no mobile home as defined in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(29), or any boat of any kind, may be parked upon premises zoned as or used for residential purposes, including the front, back, or side yard of such premises, unless it is within a garage, within a parking stall on a paved parking lot of a multi-family dwelling, or upon a paved or unpaved driveway leading directly from the roadway to a garage or to a parking stall. 
(b)  Exceptions: 
(1)  The owner or occupant of a residential property may obtain a 24-hour exemption from the provisions of subsection (a), above, for a specific social or other event by advising the police department of the date and time of the event in advance of the commencement of the event. In the event such notice is received, the department shall refrain from enforcing subsection (a) for the period requested, unless in its sole discretion, the department determines that the preservation of public safety at and around that particular residential property requires continued enforcement of subsection (a). Notice of such events shall be given to the police department by the owner or occupant on a form to be provided by the police department. 
(2)  The restrictions set out in subsection (a) of this section shall not apply on any statewide legal holiday provided in Wis. Stats. § 895.20; or on any legal holiday as designated by the federal government. 
(Ord. No. 154-O-01, § 1, 10-15-01) 
Secs. 106-137-106-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ALL-NIGHT PARKING 

Sec. 106-151. - Prohibited generally; exception. 
    No person shall permit any vehicle to be parked on any public street, highway, alley or parking lot of the village for more than 30 minutes between 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., except as otherwise restricted or permitted in this division. 
(Code 1963, § 6.09(4)(a)) 
Sec. 106-152. - Special privilege parking permit. 
(a)  Required in congested areas. In congested areas as designated by the police department and where, in the judgment of the department, no available off-street parking exists, vehicles may be parked during the hours described in section 106-151, provided that the owners shall first obtain a special privilege permit from the police department after filing an application with such department and paying a permit fee to the police department as required under this section, and shall be parked as authorized by such permit. 
(b)  Fees. The fee for the special privilege parking permit shall be as enumerated in section 42-106(a). 
(c)  Temporary emergency special permission. When, in the judgment of the police department, there exist conditions and circumstances making it impractical or impossible for vehicle owners or operators to comply with section 106-51, the police department may grant, without a fee, temporary emergency privilege to such owners or operators; provided, however, that they shall obtain such permission prior to the time a violation has occurred, and provided that no such permission shall be valid for any one period of more than six months. It shall be discretionary with the police department whether to grant a permit under this subsection in printed form or verbally. 
(d)  When section provisions not in effect. The provisions of this section shall not be effective and in force on the morning of January 1 (New Year's Day), last Monday in May (Memorial Day), July 4 (Independence Day), first Monday in September (Labor Day), fourth Thursday in November (Thanksgiving Day) and December 25 (Christmas Day). Further, this section shall not supersede any of the provisions of section 106-154 relating to parking during a declared snow emergency. 
(e)  Ineligible vehicles. Motor trucks over 8,000 GVW, motor buses, motorcycles, motor delivery wagons, trailers, semitrailers, cabin trailers, tractors, motor homes and recreational dwellings shall not be eligible for such special privilege parking permits. 
(f)  Display of permit. Any permit issued pursuant to subsections (a) or (c) of this section shall apply only to the vehicle described therein and shall be valid only for the period of time and the location indicated on the permit, provided that such permit is exhibited in plain view through the windshield of the vehicle when parking in exception to section 106-151. 
(Code 1963, § 6.09(4)(b)-(4)(g); Ord. No. 384-O-07, § 1, 8-20-07) 
Sec. 106-153. - Alternate side parking. 
    Any vehicle parked pursuant to the provisions of subsections (a) or (c) of section 106-152 shall be parked only on the even-numbered side of the street on those nights bearing an even calendar date during the portion thereof before midnight and on the odd-numbered side of the street on those nights bearing an odd calendar date during the portion thereof before midnight, except that where parking is normally permitted only on one side of the street, vehicles parked pursuant to such provisions may be parked on that side of the street only on every night of the week. 
(Code 1963, § 6.09(4)(h)) 
Sec. 106-154. - Declaration of emergency during heavy snowstorms and establishing parking regulations. 
(a)  There is hereby declared an emergency to exist in the village by reason of a heavy snowstorm whenever snow falls to a depth of three inches or more in that such storm constitutes a serious public hazard impairing transportation, the movement of food and fuel supplies, medical care, fire, health and police protection and other vital facilities of the village. Such emergency is declared to continue for a period of 48 hours or until such earlier time as snowplowing operations have been declared completed by the village manager or designee. 
(b)  Whenever such an emergency exists and the village manager or designee shall have caused announcement of the emergency to be made by not less than two radio or television broadcast stations whose normal operating range covers the village, no person shall park, stop or leave standing, or suffer to be parked, stopped or left standing, any vehicle of any kind or description for a period of time not longer than three minutes for actual loading or unloading of passengers or 30 minutes for actual loading or unloading of property; provided further that no other ordinance restricting parking as to place or time is violated thereby. 
(c)  Whenever any traffic officer shall find a vehicle parked, stopped or standing upon a street, alley or highway in violation of this section, he may move such vehicle, or cause to be moved such vehicle, or require the operator in charge of the vehicle to move such vehicle to a position either on or off a street, alley or public highway so as not to interfere with the intent of this section. 
(d)  Whenever any traffic officer shall find a vehicle parked, stopped or standing upon a street, alley or highway in violation of this section, he may move such vehicle, or caused to be moved such vehicle, or require the operator in charge of the vehicle to move such vehicle to a position either on or off a street, alley or public highway so as not to interfere with the intent of this section. 
(Code 1963, § 6.09(6); Ord. No. 398-O-08, § 1, 4-7-08) 
Sec. 106-155. - Parking in certain areas restricted. 
(a)  The operator of a vehicle shall not park such vehicle upon the driveway, service road, service area, parking area or other place not a part of the public highway but adjacent and accessible thereto, contained within or forming a part of any property owned by the village, if there is in plain view a "no parking without permit" sign, or if there is in plain view a sign indicating that parking is prohibited, limited or restricted during specified periods of time; except that any person shall be authorized to park if his vehicle displays proper identification furnished by the appropriate department in charge of such premises. 
(b)  No person shall park, stop or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, and whether temporarily or otherwise, in any of the following places: Any place subject to an easement, public or private, for the use of pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1963, § 6.09(7)) 
Sec. 106-156. - Twenty-four hour parking. 
    No owner or operator of a vehicle shall park, stop, or leave standing such vehicle upon any public street, highway, alley, or on any parking lot without the owner's permission, in the village continuously for more than a 24-hour period. All persons holding all-night parking permits shall be notified by the police department of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1963, § 6.09(8)) 
Secs. 106-157-106-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Bicycles, Wis. Stats. § 346.77 et seq.; authority to regulate bicycles, Wis. Stats. § 349.18(2). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-176. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
