    Bicycle means every device propelled by the feet acting upon pedals and having wheels any two of which are not less than 14 inches in diameter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 340.01(5). 
    Bicycle way means any path or sidewalk, or portion thereof, designated for the use of bicycles by the village board of trustees. 
    Driver/operator means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a bicycle. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot, or any person in a wheelchair, either manually or mechanically propelled, or other low-powered, mechanically propelled vehicle designed specifically for use by a disabled person. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 340.01(43). 
    Registration tag means a metal plate or sticker indicating that a bicycle is registered. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, constructed for use of pedestrians. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 340.01(58). 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(1)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 106-177. - Unclaimed or unidentified. 
    All abandoned or unidentified bicycles shall be delivered to the police department for storage, and all such bicycles shall be retained for a period of one year. After one year if such bicycles are unclaimed they shall be sold at public auction. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(4)) 
Sec. 106-178. - Operating rules. 
    Every person operating a bicycle upon any highway, bicycle way or sidewalk within the village is granted all the rights and is subject to all the duties of the provisions of all ordinances and state laws applicable to the operator of any vehicle, except those provisions which by their express terms apply only to motor vehicles or which by their very nature would have no application to bicycles. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(5)) 
Sec. 106-179. - Responsibility of parent or guardian for violation of article provisions. 
    No parent or guardian of any child shall authorize or permit such child to violate any of the provisions of this article and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a forfeiture as provided in section 106-1(c). Each violation and each day a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(9)) 
Sec. 106-180. - Towing with bicycle. 
    No person driving or operating a bicycle shall tow, drag or cause to be drawn behind the bicycle, any animal, person on roller skates, coaster, sled or any other type of conveyance not designed to be towed by a bicycle. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(5)(b)) 
State Law reference- Bicycles clinging to other vehicles, Wis. Stats. § 346.79(4). 
Sec. 106-181. - Riding on sidewalk. 
    No person 13 or more years of age shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk in this village except when a sidewalk has been designated as a "bicycle way" pursuant to section 106-183. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(5)(b)) 
State Law reference- Driving vehicle on sidewalk, Wis. Stats. § 346.94(1). 
Sec. 106-182. - Yielding right-of-way to pedestrians. 
    Whenever any person is operating a bicycle upon any sidewalk or bikeway, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(5)(b)) 
Sec. 106-183. - Designation of bicycle lanes and bicycle ways. 
(a)  Bicycle lanes and bicycle ways are herewith designated. 
(b)  Whenever so designated, such bicycle lanes and bicycle ways shall be reserved for the use of bicycles, pedestrians and other nonmotorized vehicles. 
(c)  The specific locations to which this applies are found in the minutes of the village board, the official record on file in the village clerk-treasurer's office and the police department. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(6)) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate bicycle lanes and bicycle ways, Wis. Stats. § 349.23. 
Secs. 106-184-106-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 106-201. - Required. 
    No person who resides within the village shall drive or propel a bicycle on any streets, alleys, sidewalks or upon any public path set aside for the use of bicycles unless such bicycle has been registered as provided in this division. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(2)(a); Ord. No. 504-O-11, § 1, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 106-202. - Exemption. 
    Any nonresident may operate a bicycle which is duly registered in any municipality without obtaining local registration. Nonresidents from a municipality that does not require registrations may also operate without local registration. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(3)) 
Sec. 106-203. - Application. 
    Application for bicycle registration shall be made by filing an application with the chief of police via the department website or on a form provided by the police department, giving the name, address, telephone number of the owner and a complete description of the bicycle, including the name of the manufacturer, style, model and frame serial number. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(2)(b); Ord. No. 504-O-11, § 2, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 106-204. - Equipment certification. 
    Every person over 18 years of age, and a parent of every child under 18 years of age, upon application for a bicycle registration, shall certify that the serial number of the bicycle is correctly stated on the application and that the bicycle is equipped with a red reflector and adequate brakes. If such bicycle has no serial number, a serial number shall be stamped on the frame of the bicycle at the police headquarters. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(2)(c); Ord. No. 504-O-11, § 3, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 106-205. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 504-O-11, § 4, adopted Mar. 7, 2011, repealed § 106-205 in its entirety, which pertained to fee and derived from the Code of 1963, § 6.50(2)(d); Ord. No. 501-O-11, § 3, adopted Jan. 17, 2011. 
Sec. 106-206. - Period of validity. 
    All bicycle registrations shall be issued for a period of five years, commencing on January 1 and expiring on December 31 of every succeeding fifth year. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(2)(e)) 
Sec. 106-207. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 504-O-11, § 5, adopted Mar. 7, 2011, repealed § 106-207 in its entirety, which pertained to tag and derived from the Code of 1963, § 6.50(2)(f). 
Sec. 106-208. - Unsafe bicycles. 
    No bicycle shall be registered which is found to be in an unsafe condition. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(2)(g)) 
Sec. 106-209. - Change of ownership. 
    All bicycles must be registered within ten days of purchase. Within ten days after any bicycle registered as provided in this division is sold or transferred to a new owner, the person in whose name the bicycle is registered shall report such information to the police department. The police department shall thereupon cancel the registration of the bicycle, and the new owner shall be responsible for obtaining a new registration. This section does not apply to intra-family changes of ownership, providing the family members reside at the same address. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(2)(i)) 
Sec. 106-210. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 504-O-11, § 6, adopted Mar. 7, 2011, repealed § 106-210 in its entirety, which pertained to removal and alteration of registration tabs and derived from the Code of 1963, § 6.50(2)(j). 
Sec. 106-211. - Record. 
    The chief of police shall keep a record of the issuance of each registration. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(2)(h); Ord. No. 504-O-11, § 7, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 106-212. - Suspension and removal. 
    The chief of police shall have authority to suspend the registration of any bicycle operated contrary to any state law or village ordinance for a period not to exceed 30 days. Such suspension shall be in addition to other penalties provided under this article. 
(Code 1963, § 6.50(7); Ord. No. 504-O-11, § 8, 3-7-11) 
Secs. 106-213-106-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VEHICLE NOISE[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 38. 

Sec. 106-231. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Terminology. All terminology used in this article, not defined in this section, shall be in conformance with applicable publications of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) or its successor body. 
    A-weighted sound level means the sound pressure level in decibels as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level so read is designated dB(A) or dBA. 
    Light motor vehicle means, without limitation for lack of enumeration, such devices commonly known as automobiles, vans, motorcycles, motor-driven cycles, motor scooters, mini-bikes, go-carts, snowmobiles, motor bicycles or light trucks with gross vehicular weight of less than 8,000 pounds. 
    Modified exhaust system means an exhaust system in which: 
(1)  The original noise abatement devices have been physically altered causing them to be less effective in reducing noise; 
(2)  The original abatement devices have been either removed or replaced by noise abatement devices which are not as effective in reducing noise as the original devices; or 
(3)  Devices have been added to the original noise abatement devices, such that noise levels are increased. 
    Noise means any sound which annoys or disturbs humans or which causes or tends to cause any adverse psychological or physiological effect on humans. 
    Noise level means the A-weighted sound level produced by a light motor vehicle. 
    Person means any individual, association, partnership or corporation, and includes any officer, employee, department, agency or instrumentality of a state or any political subdivision of a state. 
    Residential area means as defined under article V, chapter 122 of this Code. 
    Sound level meter means an instrument which includes a microphone, amplifier, RMS detector, integrator or time averager, output meter, and weighing networks used to measure sound pressure levels. The instrument shall comply with the standards for type 1 or type 2 sound level meters as specified in American National Standard ANSI S1.4-1971 or its successor. 
    Sound pressure level means 20 times the logarithm to the base ten of the ratio of the RMS sound pressure to the reference pressure of 20 micropascals. The sound pressure level is expressed in decibels. 
(Code 1963, § 6.60(2)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 106-232. - Scope of article. 
    This article shall apply to the control of all noise caused by light motor vehicles and origination within the limits of the village. 
(Code 1963, § 6.60(1)) 
Sec. 106-233. - Stationary test. 
    At the request of the operator of the light motor vehicle, the officer can administer a stationary motor vehicle noise test as outlined in the Code of Recommended Practices on file with the police department. If the officer cannot administer the test at the time of the request, he will notify the operator when and where the operator may have his vehicle tested. The stationary motor vehicle noise test can provide information as to the extent of defectiveness of the exhaust system or as to whether excessive noise levels were caused by improper operation of the light motor vehicle. 
(Code 1963, § 6.60(5)) 
Sec. 106-234. - dBA noise limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause noise levels from the operation of a light motor vehicle in excess of 80 dBA at any location within the corporate limits of the village. Measurement can be made at any distance greater than or equal to 15 feet from the closest approach to the vehicle. 
(Code 1963, § 6.60(3)) 
Sec. 106-235. - Excessive noise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a light motor vehicle such as to cause excessive noise levels as a result of a defective or modified exhaust system, or as a result of unnecessary rapid acceleration, deceleration, revving or tire squeal, or as the result of the operation of audio devices such as, but not limited to, radios, phonographs and tape players. 
(Code 1963, § 6.60(4)) 
State Law reference- Mufflers, Wis. Stats. § 347.39. 
Sec. 106-236. - Signaling devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any horn or other audible signaling device on any motor vehicle except in an emergency or when required by law. Burglar alarms on light motor vehicles shall only be of the electronic signaling type which transmit a nonaudible signal to a receiver which can be carried by the owner or operator of the vehicle. 
(Code 1963, § 6.60(6)) 
Sec. 106-237. - Compression brakes prohibited. 
(a)  Definition. A compression brake, commonly referred to as a "Jacobs" brake, "Jake" brake, engine brake or dynamic braking device, means a device primarily on trucks for the conversion of the engine from an internal combustion engine to an air compressor for the purpose of braking without the use of or in addition to wheel brakes. 
(b)  Use prohibited. No person shall use a motor vehicle within the Village limits where the compression brake is in any way engaged or activated on such motor vehicle or any unit a part thereof, except for the aversion of imminent danger. 
(Ord. No. 74-O-00, § 1(6.60(7)), 3-20-00) 
Secs. 106-238-106-255. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STREET CLOSINGS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 698, § 9, adopted Oct. 16, 2017, changed the title of Art. VII from "Parades, street closings and block parties" to "Street closings". 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-256. - Street closing. 
    No person, firm, corporation, organization or group of any kind shall encroach upon or in any way obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk, or public way so as to interfere with the free movement of pedestrian or vehicular traffic except as follows: 
(1)  In conformity with section 90-2 of this Code. 
(2)  The person, firm, corporation, organization or group obtains a special event license under chapter 10 of the Municipal Code. 
(Code 1963, § 6.10(2); Ord. No. 698, § 14, 10-16-17) 
Secs. 106-257-106-270. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 698, § 7, adopted Oct. 16, 2017, repealed § 106-2257 in its entirety. Former § 106-257 pertained to neighborhood block parties and derived from the Code of 1963, § 6.10(3). 
Chapter 110 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; electrical code, § 18-121 et seq.; plumbing code, § 18-271 et seq.; businesses, ch. 22; environment, ch. 38; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 58; solid waste, ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; subdivision and other divisions of land, ch. 94; telecommunications, ch. 102; zoning regulations for utility lines, poles and towers, § 122-648. 
State Law reference- General authority relative to utilities, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.34(3), 66.065, 66.069; state regulation of utilities, Wis. Stats. ch. 196. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 110-1-110-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SYSTEM[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Waterwells, § 38-86 et seq.; well head protection, § 122-781 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-21. - Connection to municipal system. 
(a)  Compulsory. Except as set forth in this article, when a water main becomes available to any building used for human habitation, such building shall be connected thereto within six months from the date the water main first becomes available. When calculating the six-month period for compulsory connection, the months of December, January, February and March shall not be included in the computation. 
(b)  Disconnection from private water supply. As part of the connection to the municipal water system required in subsection (a) of this section, the private water supply shall be totally disconnected from the building and from all faucets or fixtures inside the building. All such inside faucets or fixtures shall be connected only to the municipal water supply. The existing private water supply may be retained only for outside water use, and may be connected only to those outside hose connections which have no further connection to the building. 
(c)  Standby charges. Water charges are hereby imposed and shall be collected from the owner of each improved property required to be connected to the municipal water system. A standby charge shall be assessed against any such property not connected to the municipal water system by the compulsory connection date. Standby charges shall commence as of the compulsory date of connection of each improved property to the water system. Such charges shall be determined by the village and shall be payable quarterly. 
(d)  Deferral. The compulsory connection to the municipal water system may be deferred for such period of time as the village board may direct from time to time in each instance where a water main has been installed to serve the property and the payment of the assessment therefor has been deferred pursuant to section 86-12(g), or when, in the opinion of the village board, other facilities for furnishing water to such properties are available. 
(e)  In addition to any other penalty or remedy provided in this or any other article, any person who shall violate section 110-21 shall be subject to the following penalties: If any person fails to comply with section 110-21 for more than ten days after notice in writing to do so, the village may cause connection to be made to the water main and the expense thereof shall be assessed as a special tax. The owner of a property may, within 30 days after the completion of the work file a written option with the village clerk-treasurer stating that he cannot pay the amount in one sum, and asking that it be levied in not to exceed five equal annual installments, and the amount shall be so collected with interest at a rate of 15 percent per year from the date of completion of the work. The unpaid balance shall be a special tax lien. 
(Code 1963, §§ 8.01(31), 8.04(2)(b)) 
Sec. 110-22. - Compliance with rules. 
    All persons now receiving a water supply from the village water department, or who may hereafter make application therefor, shall be considered as having agreed to be bound by the rules and regulations as filed with the state public service commission. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(1)) 
Sec. 110-23. - No claims for damages. 
(a)  No person shall enter a claim for damages against the village as a water utility, or any officer therefor for damage to any pipe, fixture or appurtenance by reason of interrupted water supply, or variation of pressure, or for damage of any nature whatsoever caused by the turning off, or turning on, either wholly or partially, of the water supply for the extension, alteration or repair of any water main or premises supply, or for the discontinuance of the premise water supply or for the violation of any rules or regulations of the village water department. No claims shall be allowed against the village, on account of the interruption of the water supply caused by the breaking of pipes or machinery or by stoppage for repairs, on account of fire or other emergency, and no claims shall be allowed for any damage caused by the breakage of any pipe or machinery. 
(b)  See the applicable provisions of Wis. Admin. Code § PSC 185.16 on dispute provisions, which provisions have been incorporated by reference in section 110-22. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(2)) 
Sec. 110-24. - Inspection of premises. 
    Any officer or authorized employee of the utility shall have the right of access during reasonable hours to the premises supplied with service, for the purpose of inspection or for the enforcement of the utility's rules and regulations. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(28)) 
Sec. 110-25. - Handling water mains and service pipes in sewer or other trenches. 
    Where excavating machines are used in digging sewers, all water mains shall be maintained at the expense of the contractor. Contractors must ascertain for themselves the existence and location of all service pipes. Where they are removed, cut or damaged in the construction of a sewer, the contractor must, at his own expense, cause them to be replaced or repaired at once. He must not shut off the water service pipes from any consumer for a period exceeding six hours. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(3)) 
Sec. 110-26. - Backfilling water main or service trenches. 
(a)  All trenches excavated within the property lines of any street shall have the topsoil and clay removed and hauled away and the pipes properly bedded and backfilled with select aggregate backfill approved by the village manager or designee. In special cases where water main and services are laid in trenches not within the right-of-way of a platted street or within the right-of-way of an ungraded street, and such street will not be constructed for three years after the installation of the water main and service trenches, the trenches may be backfilled with moist clay or water tamped clay. Backfilling with topsoil muck, or stones larger than four inches in size shall not be permitted. The use of topsoil and sod to backfill the top one foot of a trench which does not lie within the right-of-way of a village street is permitted. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the village manager or designee to see that all open ditches for water mains, hydrants, and service pipes are properly guarded to prevent accident to any person or vehicle and the proper signs, signals and barricades are erected and maintained and that such excavations are properly lighted with red or amber danger and warning signals and lights displayed in such a manner as will, as far as possible, ensure safety to the public. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(4)) 
Sec. 110-27. - Applications for service. 
    Application for the original installation of a supply from the village water main, or for any extension or alteration of any existing supply from the curbline, or within the street property line, shall be filed in writing with the village manager or designee on a form provided by him. The signing of the application shall constitute a contract for water supplied and its specific use, which contract embodies the regulations of this article as a part of the contract. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(5)(a)) 
Sec. 110-28. - Service connections. 
(a)  Each applicant for water service shall at the time of making application for such service, execute and deliver to the utility a contract for such water service, agreeing to put in the service pipe from the curbline to each piece of water-using property existing at that point and owned by him where such water is desired, at the expense of such applicant, and to commence the payment for such water service when a bill is rendered for the same. 
(b)  No service shall be installed to any lot or parcel of land not now being served unless such lot or parcel of land has a frontage on a regularly platted street or public strip in which a cast iron or other long life water main has been laid and unless the water service connection therewith is made between the property lines, extended to the main. 
(c)  The service pipe shall be laid not less than six feet below the surface of an established or proposed grade line. When laid in a combined sewer and water trench, the service shall be laid on a shelf of solid ground not nearer than 12 inches to the side wall of the sewer trench. 
(d)  No division of the water service of any lot or parcel of land shall be made for the extension and independent meterage of the supply to an adjoining lot or parcel of land. No division of a water supply service shall be made at the curb for separate supplies therefrom for two or more separate premises having frontage on any street or public service strip whether owned by the same or different parties. 
(e)  In duplex residential buildings, each living unit shall have a separate water service, water stop valve, water meter and other appurtenances from the curb stop at the right of way line into the living unit. 
(f)  No water service shall be laid through any trench having cinders, rubbish, rock or gravel fill, or any other material which may cause injury to or disintegration of the service pipe, unless adequate means of protection are provided by sand filling or such insulation as may be approved by the village manager or designee. Service pipes passing through curb or retaining walls shall be adequately safeguarded by the provision of a channel space or pipe casing, not less than twice the diameter of the service pipe. The space between the service pipe and the channel or pipe casing shall be filled and lightly caulked with oakum, mastic cement, or other resilient material, and made impervious to moisture. 
(g)  When a change of direction of a service is made on either side of a curb or retaining wall, the fittings shall be securely braced to prevent loosening or blowing out. The bracing shall be made by concrete backing, or by clamp rods extending from the fitting bell or fitting to the next bell or by clamp rods securely anchored in the wall. Such clamp rods shall be not less than five-eighths of an inch in diameter and, when buried in soil, should be protected against corrosion by painting with tar asphaltum or other suitable means. Set screws for fastening clamp rods to the pipe will not be permitted. 
(h)  In backfilling the pipe trench, the service must be protected against injury by carefully tamping the ground filling, free from hard lumps, rocks, stones, or other injurious material, around and at least six inches over the pipe. 
(i)  All water supplies shall be of undiminished size from the street main to and including the outlet valve of the water meter. Beyond the meter outlet valve the piping shall be sized and proportioned to provide, on all floors, at all times, an ample and equitable distribution of water supply for the greatest probable number of fixtures or appliance units operating simultaneously. 
(j)  In case it is necessary to install a new or larger service to replace an existing small diameter service pipe, the customer shall pay 100 percent of the cost of the new or larger service. 
(k)  Fire protection service lines shall be reviewed by the village manager or designee and: 
(1)  May be constructed from PVC meeting AWWA C-900 or C-905. 
(2)  Shall have a gate valve located at the right of way line that shall be the responsibility of the property owner to operate and maintain. 
(3)  See section 110-29 [Meters] for requirements of metering the fireline. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(5)(b); Ord. No. 157-O-01, §§ 1-4, 11-5-2001) 
Sec. 110-29. - Meters. 
(a)  Location. 
(1)  If the meter is to be installed in a building, the water service piping shall be less than 300 feet from the property line to the meter. The meter shall be installed in the basement or ground floor of the building in accordance with the discretion of the village manager or designee. Unless the village manager or designee specifically approves another location, the meter shall be located near the front wall of the building where the service enters the building. 
(2)  If the water service or fire protection piping is 300 feet or more from the property line to the meter, or if fixtures and appurtenances for the withdrawal of water are installed in open grounds free from buildings or structures, and is not metered, a meter shall be installed in a meter pit at the property line as prescribed by the village manager or designee. However, if the water service piping is continuous (non-jointed) polyethylene, the meter pit requirement shall be reviewed by the village manager or designee and may be waived. 
(b)  Installation of meter. 
(1)  Meters will be furnished and installed by the water utility and are not to be disconnected or interfered with by the consumer. 
(2)  All buildings constructed or subject to remodeling in the general location of the water meter shall afford adequate space for the installation of water meters; the repair, maintenance and servicing of the water meters or strainers; the replacement of the meters; the installation of a bypass line, if required; and any attendant appurtenant valves, fittings, piping or other devices that may be necessary for water service and metering facilities. The planimetric and profile drawing of meter room space provided shall be approved by the utility before water system connection will be permitted and be in accordance with standards on file in the utility office. 
(3)  The consumer shall also install valves before and after the meter, and shall keep these valves operational and in good working order at all times. 
(4)  The consumer is responsible for supplying and installing all piping within the building. 
(5)  All new multifamily and condominium buildings, and all commercial, industrial and public customers of the utility shall provide access via a telephone jack located within five feet of the water meter via phone lines connected directly to the local telephone service access terminate ("dial tone") of each metered tenant (or one tenant in single metered, multitenant, commercial, industrial or public customer buildings) being served to accommodate the automated meter reading equipment installed or to be installed by the utility. Access shall mean availability of outside telephone line connectivity with "dial tone" to accommodate use by the AMR system equipment. 
(6)  If a consumer wishes to have additional meters installed, the consumer shall pay for all piping, and shall also pay an amount sufficient to cover the cost of maintenance and depreciation of each additional meter. 
(c)  Service piping for meter settings. In installing new service piping (or changing service piping where consumers have been on a flat rate) if meters are to be set, the consumer shall, at his own expense, provide the proper connections for the meter. Where it is impossible to set meters in the basement, a short nipple shall be inserted after the stop and waste cock, then a union and then another nipple and coupling of the proper length. The nipple attached to the union and coupling shall be cut to a standard length provided by the plans of the village manager or designee (who may require a horizontal run of 18 inches in such pipe line) which may later be removed for the insertion of the meter into the supply line. No permit will be given to change from metered to flat rate service. 
(d)  Remote reading registers. Remote register water meter attachments will be installed by the utility, the cost to be borne by the utility. The location of these attachments is to be determined by the utility. The utility shall determine the priority of such installations, for the purpose of efficiency, as follows: 
(1)  All new construction. 
(2)  Presently difficult places to read. 
(3)  Residences where occupants habitually or necessarily are absent. 
(4)  All other installations desirable for the benefit of the utility. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(6)(a)-(6)(c), (6)(e); Ord. No. 157-O-01, § 5, 11-5-2001) 
Sec. 110-30. - Turning on water. 
    The water cannot be turned on for a consumer except by a duly authorized employee of the utility. When a plumber has completed a job he must leave the water turned off. This does not prevent him from testing his work. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(6)(d)) 
Sec. 110-31. - Protective devices. 
(a)  In general. The owner or occupant of every premises receiving water supply shall apply and maintain suitable means of protection of the premises supply, and all appliances thereof, against damage arising in any manner from the use of the water supply, variation of water pressure, or any interruption of water supply. Particularly, consumers or occupants must protect water cooled compressors for refrigeration systems by means of high pressure safety cutout devices. There shall likewise be provided means for the prevention of the transmission of water ram or noise of operation of any valve or appliance through the piping of their own or adjacent premises. 
(b)  Relief valves. On all "closed systems" (i.e. systems having a check valve, pressure regulator, or reducing valve, water filter or softener) an effective temperature relief valve shall be installed either in the top tapping or the upper side tapping of the hot water tank, or on the hot water distributing pipe connection at the tank. A three-quarter-inch drainpipe shall be connected to the relief valve for discharge on the floor or into a sink or open drain. No stop valve shall be placed between the hot water tank and the relief valve or on the drainpipe. Where water pressure in the main is excessive it shall be the responsibility of the property owner to install pressure reducing devices to protect his installations. 
(c)  Air chambers. An air chamber or approved shock absorber shall be installed at the terminus of each riser, fixture branch, or hydraulic elevator main for the prevention of undue water hammer. The air chamber shall have a diameter not less than that of the pipe it serves and a length not less than 15 diameters of such supply pipe. Where possible, the air chamber should be provided with a valve and drain cock at its base for water drainage and replenishment of air. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(7)) 
Sec. 110-32. - Repairs. 
(a)  Service. The service pipe from the main to the curbstop will be maintained and kept in repair at the expense of the utility. The consumer shall maintain the service pipe from the curbstop to the point of use and can be billed for any water which has not passed through the meter and has been wasted by leakage of defective pipes and fixtures, as estimated by the village manager or designee. If a consumer fails to repair a leaky or broken service pipe from curbstop to point of metering or use within such time as may appear reasonable to the superintendent of the utility after notification has been served on the consumer by the superintendent, the water will be shut off and will not be turned on again until the repairs have been completed. 
(b)  Mains. The utility reserves the right to shut off the water in the mains temporarily, to make repairs, alterations or additions to the plant or system. When the circumstances will permit a sufficient delay, the utility will give notification by newspaper publication or otherwise, of the discontinuance of the supply. No rebate or damages will be allowed to consumers for such temporary suspension of supply. 
(c)  Frozen services. See the applicable provisions of Wis. Admin. Code § PSC 185.89 on frozen laterals, which have been incorporated by reference in section 110-22. Following the freezing of a service, the utility shall take such steps and issue such instructions as may be necessary to prevent the refreezing of the same service. No charge will be made for rethawings if the instructions are followed. In case it is necessary to allow the water to flow to prevent its refreezing, the consumer must make proper provision for proper disposal of the water waste. For the period in which the water is allowed to run, the consumer will be billed according to his meter readings but in no event to exceed the average amount paid in the corresponding billing periods of the previous two years. A new consumer will be charged the average bill for other consumers of the same class receiving service under comparable conditions. 
(d)  Meters. Meters will be repaired by the village manager or designee, and the cost of such repairs caused by ordinary wear and tear will be borne by the utility. Repair of any damage to a meter resulting from the carelessness of the owner of the premises, his agent, tenant, or of the negligence of any one of them to properly secure and protect the meter, including any damage that may result from allowing a water meter to become frozen or to be injured from the presence of hot water or steam in the meter, shall be paid for by the consumer or the owner of the premises. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(9)-(12)) 
Sec. 110-33. - Stop boxes. 
    The consumer shall protect the stop box in his terrace and shall keep the stop box free from dirt and other obstructions. The utility shall not be liable for failure to locate a stop box and shut off the water in case of a leak on the consumer's premises. The deposit for such a box is as provided in section 42-18(a)(2) of this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(12)) 
Sec. 110-34. - Water for construction, cisterns, wagons, tractors or boilers. 
(a)  Permit required. When water is wanted for construction purposes, or for filling cisterns, tanks or tank wagons, steam tractors or boilers, or portable steam boilers, an application therefor shall be made to the village manager or designee, in writing, upon application provided for that purpose at the village hall, giving a statement of the amount of construction work to be done, or the size of the cistern, boiler, tank or tank wagon to be filled. Payment for the water for construction shall be made in advance at the scheduled rates. No connection with the service pipe at the curb shall be made without special permission from the village manager or designee. In no case will any employee of the utility turn on water for construction work unless the contractor presents a permit. Upon completion of the construction work, the contractor must return the original permit to the village manager or designee, together with a statement of the actual amount of the construction work performed. 
(b)  Use of hydrants. In cases where no other supply is available, permission may be granted by the village manager or designee to use a hydrant. No hydrant shall be used until it is equipped with a sprinkling valve or a meter. A charge will be made for setting a valve or meter, or for removing either or both from one hydrant to another. 
(c)  Advance deposit. Before a valve or meter is set, payment must be made for its setting and for the water to be used at the scheduled rates. When the contractor has finished using the hydrant, he must notify the village manager or designee to that effect. There will be a minimum charge for the use of water from the hydrant and for setting the valve or meter. The charge shall be established and approved by the water utility superintendent. 
(d)  Equipment. Any equipment installed by the water utility under this section or section 110-57 is the property of the water utility. The applicant for water under this section shall be responsible for any damage to or loss of any meter or equipment temporarily installed by the water utility. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(21)) 
Sec. 110-35. - Operation of valves and hydrants. 
    No person shall, without authority of the village manager or designee, operate any valve connection with the street or supply mains, or open any fire hydrant connected with the distribution system, except for the purpose of extinguishing a fire, or shall wantonly injure or impair the same. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(22)) 
Sec. 110-36. - Damage to hydrants by motor vehicles. 
    Owners or operators of motor vehicles will be held for the cost of repair of any hydrant damaged by being hit by a motor vehicle, and the village manager or designee will not be responsible for the damage to the motor vehicle by reason of such accident. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(23)) 
Sec. 110-37. - Hydrant connections. 
    In the use of a fire hydrant supply, the hydrant valve will be set at the proper opening by the village manager or designee when the sprinkling valve is set, and the flow of water must be regulated by means of the sprinkling valve. If the water is to be used through iron pipe connections, all such pipe installations shall have a swing joint to facilitate quick disconnection from the fire hydrant. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(24)) 
Sec. 110-38. - Right to open hydrants. 
(a)  Only such persons as shall be authorized by the water utility superintendent shall be permitted to open any fire hydrant. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be subject to a forfeiture as provided in section 1-7, and shall also be responsible for all costs incurred by the water utility as a result of the violation. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(25)) 
Sec. 110-39. - Vacation of premises. 
    When premises are to be vacated, the utility shall be notified in writing at once, so that it may remove the meter and shut off the supply at the curb cock. The owner of the premises shall be liable to prosecution for any damage to the property of the village manager or designee by reason of failure to notify the utility of vacancy. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(29)) 
Secs. 110-40-110-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATES AND CHARGES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Utility charges, Wis. Stats. § 66.069. 

Sec. 110-56. - Established; approval. 
    The rates, charges and fees to be paid to the village for services rendered by the water utility or in connection with the same shall be as established by the village board and approved (if required) by the state public service commission. 
Sec. 110-57. - Temporary metered supply; meter and deposits. 
(a)  An applicant for temporary water supply on a meter basis shall make and maintain a monetary deposit for each meter installed, as security for payment for use of water and for such other charges which may arise from the use of the supply. The deposit schedule shall be established and approved by the water utility superintendent. 
(b)  All monies deposited as security for payment of charges arising from the use of temporary water supply on a metered basis, or for the return of a sprinkling valve, wheel or reducer, if the water is used on an unmetered basis, will be refunded to the depositor on the termination of the use of the water, the payment of all charges levied against the depositor and the return of the wheel and reducer. 
(c)  Any equipment installed by the water utility under this section or section 110-34 is the property of the water utility. The applicant for temporary water supply under this section shall be responsible for any damage to or loss of any meter or equipment temporarily installed by the water utility. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(26), (27)) 
Sec. 110-58. - Charges for water waste due to leaks. 
    When the meter registers losses due to pipe leaks, the utility shall determine whether or not the defect in the piping or equipment was known to the consumer, or being known, he has used his best efforts to correct the condition. If the utility is satisfied that the loss occurred without the consumer's knowledge, or having known about it he has tried to correct the condition, the utility may determine as nearly as possible what is the amount of the loss by comparison with the use of the water during a like period, and the excess may be billed at the lowest step in the rates. If, however, the consumer knew of the leak and failed to give proper attention to it, the utility will bill for the total consumption shown by the meter at regular rates. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(20)) 
Sec. 110-59. - Failure to read meter. 
(a)  Where the utility is unable to read a meter after two consecutive attempts, the fact shall be plainly indicated upon the bill, the minimum charge assessed and the difference adjusted when the meter is again read, that is, the bill for the succeeding quarter will be computed with the gallons or cubic feet in each block of the rate schedule doubled and credit will be given on that bill for the amount of the minimum bill paid the preceding month. 
(b)  If the meter is damaged or fails to operate for any reason, the utility will render a bill for the current period, based on an average of the last two quarters, provided that there is no particular reason why the use during that period has not been normal. In case the last two periods cannot be properly used, then the bill shall be estimated by some equitable method. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(19)) 
Sec. 110-60. - Billing procedure. 
    The billing procedure for water utility bills shall comply with Wis. Admin. Code § PSC 185.33 as it currently exists, or as it shall be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(14)) 
Sec. 110-61. - Surreptitious use of water. 
    When the utility has reasonable evidence that a consumer is obtaining his supply of water, in whole or in part, by means of devices or methods used to stop or interfere with the proper metering of the utility service being delivered to his equipment, the utility reserves the right to estimate and present immediately a bill for service unmetered as a result of such interference. Such bill shall be payable subject to a 24-hour disconnection of service. When the utility shall have disconnected the consumer for any such reason, the utility will reconnect the consumer upon the following conditions: 
(1)  The consumer will be required to deposit with the utility an amount sufficient to guarantee the payment of the consumer bills for utility service to the utility. 
(2)  The consumer will be required to pay the utility for any and all damages to its equipment on the consumer's premises due to such stoppage or interference with its metering. 
(3)  The consumer must further agree to comply with reasonable requirements to protect the utility against further losses. 
The provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 98.26 and 943.20, as relating to water service, are hereby adopted and made a part of this section. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(18)) 
Sec. 110-62. - Deposit and guarantee rules. 
(a)  Property owners. A deposit may be required if the credit of consumer has not been established satisfactorily to the utility. 
(b)  Renters. Either of the following alternatives shall be used: 
(1)  A deposit may be required of all renters using water service to guarantee the payment of the water bill of the renter. 
(2)  A deposit may be required of renters where property owners have notified the utility in writing that they preferred to have the water bills paid by the renter. 
(c)  Deposit. 
(1)  The amount of deposit required may be a sum not exceeding the estimated gross bills for all water service, both billed and unbilled, which can be supplied before the utility's filed disconnect rule becomes applicable. The amount to be deposited may be a minimum of $5.00 per month for each class of water furnished. 
(2)  The deposit may be returned upon request of the customer after two years' service with payments within the prompt payment period, and, without such request, shall be refunded voluntarily by the utility after three years' service, with payments within the prompt payment period. In no case, however, will a deposit be refunded if the customer's credit standing is not satisfactory to the utility. 
(3)  A new and additional deposit may be required upon reasonable written notice of the need for such a requirement in any case where a deposit has been refunded or is found to be inadequate, or where the customer's credit standing is not satisfactory to the utility. The water service of any customer who fails to comply with these requirements may be disconnected upon five days' written notice. 
(d)  Guarantee. 
(1)  The utility may accept in lieu of a cash deposit, a contract signed by a guarantor satisfactory to the utility, whereby payment of a specified sum not exceeding the cash deposit requirements is guaranteed. The term of such contract shall be indeterminate, but it shall automatically terminate when the customer gives notice to the utility of discontinuance of service at the location covered by the guarantee agreement or six months after discontinuance of service, or at the guarantor's request upon 30 days' written notice to the utility. 
(2)  Upon termination of a guarantee contract or whenever the utility deems the same insufficient as to amount or surety, a cash deposit or a new and additional guarantee may be required upon reasonable written notice to the consumer. The water service of any customer who fails to comply with these requirements may be disconnected upon five days' written notice. 
(3)  The guarantor shall receive copies of all final disconnect notices sent to the customer whose account he has guaranteed. 
(4)  If the utility is not able to collect any bill for water service even though deposit and guarantee rules are on file, the bill may be put upon the tax roll as provided in Wis. Stats. § 66.0809. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(15); Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 60, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 110-63. - Reconnection charge. 
    Where service has been disconnected at the request of the customer and his account is not delinquent and he requests reconnection at the same location or some other location, a reconnection charge, payable in advance, shall be collected. A reconnection charge shall also be required from consumers whose services are disconnected because of nonpayment of bills (not including disconnection for failure to comply with deposit or guarantee rules). A consumer shall be considered as the same customer, provided that the reconnection is requested for the same location by any member of the same family, or if a place of business, by any partner or employee. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(16)) 
Sec. 110-64. - Complaint meter tests. 
    If a consumer demands that a test be made of his meter in addition to the periodic or installation test, he shall pay a test fee. If the meter is found fast in excess of two percent, the payment of the test will be refunded and the usual adjustment made in the past bills. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(17)) 
Sec. 110-65. - Tapping charge. 
    A tapping charge applies to all new services installed or supervised by the water utility. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(30)) 
Secs. 110-66-110-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 110-81. - Defined. 
    The term "cross connection control" shall be defined as any physical connection or arrangement between two otherwise separate systems, one of which contains potable water from the village water system, and the other, water from a private source, water of unknown or questionable safety, or steam, gases or chemicals, whereby there may be a flow from one system to the other, the direction of flow depending on the pressure differential between the two systems. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(32)(a)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 110-82. - Inspections. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the village manager or designee to cause inspections to be made of all property served by the public water system of the village where cross connections with the public water system is deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the village manager or designee and as approved by the state department of natural resources. 
(b)  Upon presentation of his credentials, a representative of the water utility shall have the right to request entry at any reasonable time to examine for cross connections any property served by a connection to the public water system of the village. If entry is refused, such representative shall obtain a special inspection warrant under Wis. Stats. § 66.0119(1), (2). The owner, lessee or occupant of any property who is served with a special inspection warrant shall furnish to the inspecting representative upon that representative's request any pertinent information regarding the piping systems on such property. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(32)(d), (e); Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 61, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 110-83. - Prohibited connections. 
    No person shall establish or maintain, or suffer or permit to be established or maintained, any cross connection to or upon any property served by the public water system of the village. No interconnection shall be established whereby potable water from a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the village may enter the supply or distribution system of the village, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and the use of such supply shall be approved by the village water utility and by the state department of natural resources in accordance with Wis. Admin. Code § NR 811.09, as that administrative code section is currently constituted or as it may be revised or renumbered in the future. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(32)(b)) 
Sec. 110-84. - Drawings of system; availability. 
    Excluding single-family dwellings, all other owners of buildings served by the village water utility shall maintain at a reasonable scale legible up-to-date, as-built drawings of all water main distribution systems within their property showing the location and size of the water mains identifying domestic service lines, fire lines, process water lines, and all protection devices installed in the plumbing system. These drawings shall be available on-site for viewing by water utility personnel to aid in the inspection process to eliminate cross connections as defined by the Wisconsin Administrative Code and village policies or ordinances. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(32)(c)) 
Sec. 110-85. - Discontinuance of service upon violation. 
    The village water utility is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of this division is found to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water system. Except as provided in section 110-86, water service shall be discontinued only after reasonable notice and opportunity for hearing under section 110-87. Water service to such property shall not be restored until any or all cross connections have been eliminated in compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(32)(f)) 
Sec. 110-86. - Immediate discontinuance of service upon written finding of danger to public health, safety or welfare. 
    If it is determined by the village water utility that a cross connection or an emergency endangers public health, safety or welfare and requires immediate action, and a written finding to that effect is filed with the clerk-treasurer of the village and delivered to the customer's premises, service may be immediately discontinued. The customer shall have an opportunity for a hearing under section 110-87 within ten days of such emergency discontinuance. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(32)(g)) 
Sec. 110-87. - Appeals. 
    Any property owner or lessee aggrieved by a decision of the village manager or designee to discontinue water service under sections 110-85 or 110-86 may appeal that decision to the water utility committee of the village board as provided in the following: 
(1)  Any appeal of such decision of the village manager or designee must be in writing and must be filed with the village clerk-treasurer within applicable time periods set out in subsections (2) and (3) of this section, respectively. The written appeal request shall contain the following: 
a.  The appellant shall set forth all reasons why the appellant believes the determination should be reversed or modified. 
b.  The appeal request contains all information or documents which the appellant wishes the water utility committee to consider when making its determination. 
c.  If the appellant wishes to present testimony or argument, the appeal request shall so indicate, and shall identify any such witnesses whom the appellant will have testify. At any such hearing, the appellant and the village manager or designee may be represented by an attorney, may present evidence and call and examine witnesses and cross examine the witnesses of the other party. Such witnesses shall be sworn by the committee chairman. 
(2)  Appeals under section 110-85 shall be filed with the village clerk-treasurer within seven business days of the determination by the village manager or designee to discontinue water services under that section. The water utility committee of the village board shall hold a hearing on the appeal within 14 business days of the filing of the appeal request with the village clerk-treasurer. Notice of that hearing shall be sent to the village manager or designee and to the appellant. 
(3)  Appeals under section 110-86 shall be filed with the village clerk-treasurer within 72 hours of the determination by the village manager or designee to discontinue water services under that section. Upon receipt of the request, the water utility committee of the village board shall hold a hearing on the appeal within seven business days of the filing of the petition with the village clerk-treasurer. Notice of that hearing shall be sent to village manager or designee and to the appellant. 
(4)  The water utility committee may make a decision at the close of the evidence of the hearing, or within one week thereof. Minutes of the hearing, together with any determination, including the reasons therefor, shall be mailed to the village manager or designee and to the person aggrieved. 
(5)  Any person participating in a proceeding before the water utility committee of the village board under this section may seek review of the committee's determination by certiorari to the circuit court within 30 days of receipt of the final determination of the committee. 
(Code 1963, § 8.01(32)(i)) 
Secs. 110-88-110-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 110-111-110-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE CHARGES IN METROPOLITAN MILWAUKEE SEWERAGE DISTRICT 

Sec. 110-126. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commission means the Sewerage Commission at the City of Milwaukee. 
    District means the Metropolitan Sewerage District of the County of Milwaukee. 
    FRWPCC means the Fox River Water Pollution Control Center. 
    Local operation and maintenance costs means those costs which are required to properly operate and maintain the wastewater works within the village limits. These costs include replacement costs. 
    Metropolitan commission means the Metropolitan Sewerage Commission of the County of Milwaukee. 
    Replacement costs means the expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the collection system to maintain the capacity and performance for which such system was designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
    Village user charge means a charge levied on users of a collection system for the user's proportional share of the cost of operation, maintenance and replacement. 
    Water utility means the village water utility. 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(1)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 110-127. - Incorporation of district rules and regulations, article XVII. 
(a)  The following sections and related appendices of the district rules and regulations, article XVII, promulgated by the commission, the metropolitan commission and the district, as now in effect and as the same may be amended from time to time hereafter, are hereby incorporated by reference and shall be of full force and effect as though set forth in their entirety in this section. 
Section 1701.020 Definitions Section 1701.040 Municipal Transfer of Data Section 1701.041 Estimated Volume of Discharge Section 1701.050 User Transfer of Data Section 1701.051 Discharge Factor Certification Section 1701.052 Wastestrength Certification Section 1701.053 Certification Procedures Section 1701.054 Verification Section 1701.055 Audit Control of User Connections Section 1701.056 Appeal Provision Section 1702.010 Purpose of the User Charge System Section 1702.020 User Charge Billing Basis Section 1702.030 Wholesale User Charge Billing Basis Section 1702.040 Unit Costs of Treatment  
(b)  For purposes of this section, the term "residential structure" as defined in district rules and regulations, article XVII, shall mean any building accommodating exclusively one, two, three or four residential units. 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(2)) 
Sec. 110-128. - Calculation of sewer service charge rates. 
    There is hereby imposed a charge on each sewer in this village who discharges wastewater, directly or indirectly, into the wastewater system operated by the commission and FRWPCC. Such charges for each separate entity shall be combined, and an average rate for all users in this village shall be established and calculated based upon the following formulas: 
(1)  Village user charge. There is hereby imposed a village user charge on each user. Such charge shall be levied to recover the total cost for sanitary sewer local operations and maintenance costs, as established by the village's sewer utility annual operating budget for the forthcoming year and shall be calculated as follows: 
a.  A volumetric charge shall be calculated by dividing the village user charge portion of the annual budget which the village determines to be attributable to sewer user effluent by the total volume of water consumed by sewer users. 
b.  A connection charge shall be calculated by dividing the village user charge portion of the annual budget which the village determines to be attributable to inflow and infiltration by the number of sewer connections in the village. 
(2)  Sewage treatment capital charge. There is hereby imposed a sewage treatment capital charge on each user. Such charge shall be levied to recover the sum of the total cost of the commission's capital recovery charge to the village. FRWPCC capital charges to the village, legal expenses, contribution to the village's water pollution control reserve, and any other sewer capital costs as determined by the village board as established by the village's sewer utility annual operating budget for the forthcoming year and shall be calculated as follows: 
a.  A volumetric charge shall be calculated by dividing the sewage treatment capital charge portion of the annual budget which the village determines to be attributable to sewer user effluent by the total volume of water consumed by sewer users. 
b.  A connection charge shall be calculated by dividing the sewage treatment capital charge portion of the annual budget which the village determines to be attributable to inflow and infiltration by the number of sewer connections in the village. 
(3)  Sewer treatment user charge. There is hereby imposed a sewer treatment user charge on each user. Such charge shall be levied to recover the sum of the total cost of the commission's and FRWPCC user charges billed directly to the village, as established by the village's sewer utility annual operating budget for the forthcoming year and shall be calculated as follows: 
a.  A volumetric charge shall be calculated by dividing the sewer treatment user charge portion of the annual budget which the village determines to be attributable to sewer user effluent by the total volume of water consumed by sewer users. 
b.  A connection charge shall be calculated by dividing the sewer treatment user charge portion of the annual budget which the village determines to be attributable to inflow and infiltration by the number of sewer connections in the village. 
c.  Sewer treatment user charges for certain classes of commercial and industrial users are billed directly to the village from the commission. This amount is passed on directly to the specific user. These users do not also receive the charges defined in subsection (3)a and (3)b of this section. Billing of these users is explained in section 110-129(5)-(9). 
(4)  Total sewage service charge. The sum total of each component established in subsections (1)-(3) of this section is added together to arrive at a total volumetric charge and a total connection charge for each sewer user. Specific calculations for billing each user class are defined within section 110-129. 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(3)) 
Sec. 110-129. - Calculation of sewer service billing charges. 
    There is hereby imposed a charge on each user in this village who discharges wastewater, directly or indirectly, into the wastewater system operated by the commission and FRWPCC. Such charges for each separate entity shall be combined, and an average rate for all users in this village shall be established as described in section 110-128(4) and levied to users based upon the classes of users described as follows: 
(1)  Residential users connection to the water utility. The residential user charge shall be based upon the volumetric charge plus a connection charge calculated as follows: Individual residential users shall be calculated by multiplying the user's volume of water consumption times the volumetric charge, plus the user's number of residential structures times the connection charge. 
(2)  Residential users not connected to the water utility. The residential charge shall be the product of the residential occupancy factor for the village, as established by the commission, times the equivalent residential unit, as established by the commission, to result in an average volume of water consumption upon which to base the volumetric charge. Individual residential user charges shall be calculated by multiplying this average volume of water consumption times the volumetric charge, plus the user's number of residential structures times the connection charge. 
(3)  Noncertified commercial users connected to the water utility. The retail noncertified commercial user charge shall be based on a volumetric charge and a connection charge calculated as follows: Individual residential user charges shall be calculated by multiplying the user's volume of water consumption times the volumetric charge, plus the user's number of residential structures times the connection charge. 
(4)  Noncertified commercial and industrial users not connected to the utility. The charge for noncertified commercial and industrial users connected to the water utility shall be the product of that user's estimated volume of discharge, as calculated using the commission's procedures and regulations, times the unit volumetric charge, plus the user's number of residential structures times the connection charge. 
(5)  Discharge certified commercial users. Each retail discharge certified commercial user charge shall be equal to each wholesale discharge certified commercial user charge submitted to the village pursuant to district rules and regulations, article XVII. 
(6)  Wastestrength certified commercial users. Each retail wastestrength certified commercial user charge shall be equal to each whole wastestrength certified commercial user charge submitted to the village pursuant to district rules and regulations, article XVII. 
(7)  Noncertified industrial users. Each retail noncertified industrial charge shall be equal to each wholesale noncertified industrial user charge submitted to the village pursuant to district rules and regulations, article XVII. 
(8)  Discharge certified industrial users. Each retail discharge certified industrial user charge shall be equal to each wholesale discharge certified industrial user charge submitted to the village pursuant to district rules and regulations, article XVII. 
(9)  Wastestrength certified industrial users. Each retail wastestrength certified industrial user charge shall be equal to each wholesale wastestrength certified industrial user charge submitted to the village pursuant to district rules and regulations, article XVII. 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(4)) 
Sec. 110-130. - Credit for unused water. 
    If a portion of the water furnished to any premises is not discharged into the sanitary sewer system, the amount of such water will be ascertained and determined by either of the two methods set forth in this section and deducted in computing the sewer service charge, as follows: 
(1)  For users connected to the water utility. By measuring the actual amount of water not being discharged into the sewer system, by the use of a meter installed by the property owner who shall first make written application therefor and payment for connection thereof to the village manager or designee. 
(2)  For users not connected to the water utility. By measuring the actual amount of water not being discharged into the sewer system by an industrial user of water, by the use of scientific or engineering tests approved by and conducted under the direct supervision of the village manager or designee, all at the expense of the property owner, who shall first make written application therefor and payment thereof to the village manager or designee. The village may, at any time it deems necessary, order such tests to be made. 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(5)) 
Sec. 110-131. - Billing. 
(a)  Charges as set forth in sections 110-128 and 110-129 shall be billed on a quarterly basis. Payment of such bills shall be made within ten days after mailing by the village. If such bill is not paid when due, a penalty of three percent, but not less than $0.30 shall be added thereto. 
(b)  All bills shall be payable at the office of the Village Clerk-Treasurer, Municipal Building, W156 N8480 Pilgrim Road. 
(c)  If a user fails to certify data or if a user's certification is materially inaccurate or if there has been a substantial change in data since the date of the user's last certification, the commission shall notify the user that the verification data determined by the commission pursuant to section 1701.054 of district rules and regulations, article XVII, shall be used to determine the charge due for the current billing period and all future billing periods until the user submits a new certified statement. 
(d)  Should inspection or verification by the commission reveal that any statement certified by a user is materially inaccurate, the commission shall redetermine the proper charge due and forward the new computation to the village in order that a bill for the deficiency may be sent. This deficiency billing shall be retroactive to the dates when the bills based upon the inaccurate certification were originally due and interest charges shall be applied to each deficiency as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(e)  All unpaid charges shall be a lien upon the property served and shall be enforced as provided in Wis. Stats. § 66.0821(4)(d). 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(6); Ord. No. 158-O-01, § 62, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 110-132. - Establishment of rates. 
    The amounts of all sewer user charges described in this division shall be established from time to time by village board resolution. 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(7)) 
Sec. 110-133. - Discontinuance of service. 
    If the sewer service charge for any lot, parcel of land, building or premises located outside the corporate village limits shall not have been paid when due as provided in this division, and in addition to the penalty provided in section 110-129(2), the village manager or designee may, after approval by the village board, disconnect from the village sewer mains, the sewer lateral or laterals furnishing such sewer service outside of the corporate village limits, thereby discontinuing such sewer service. 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(8)) 
Sec. 110-134. - Disposition of revenue. 
    The amount received from the collection of the charges authorized by this division shall be credited to a sanitary sewer system. When appropriated by the village board, the credits to such account shall be available for the payment of the requirements for capital recovery, operation, maintenance and repairs of the sewer system. Any surplus in such account shall be available for the payment of principal and interest of bonds issued and outstanding, or which may be issued, to provide funds for such sewer system, or part thereof, and all or a part of the expenses for additions and improvements and other necessary disbursements or indebtedness, and the village board may, by resolution, pledge such surplus or any part thereof for any such purpose. 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(9)) 
Sec. 110-135. - Previous agreements. 
    This division shall take precedence over any terms or conditions of agreements or contracts between the village and its users which are inconsistent with this division. 
(Code 1963, § 8.02(10)) 
Secs. 110-136-110-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STORM WATER SYSTEM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-201. - Purpose. 
    The village board hereby finds, determines and declares the necessity of providing facilities for the drainage and control of storm and surface waters within the village. These facilities may be acquired and maintained in order that storm and surface waters may be properly drained and controlled and that the health, property, safety and welfare of the village and its inhabitants may be safeguarded and protected. 
(Ord. No. 214-O-02, § 1, 12-16-02) 
Sec. 110-202. - Creation and authority. 
    The village board hereby establishes the Village of Menomonee Falls Storm Water Utility. This public utility is not a public service subject to regulation by the Wisconsin Public Service Commission. The village, through the storm water utility, may acquire, construct, lease, own, operate, maintain, extend, replace, clean, dredge, repair, conduct, manage and finance such facilities as are deemed by the village to be reasonably necessary for a system of storm and surface water management. 
(Ord. No. 214-O-02, § 1, 12-16-02) 
Sec. 110-203. - Management. 
(a)  Pursuant to Village Ordinance section 2-87 and subject to subsection (b) of this division, the day-to-day operation, management and control of the storm water utility is vested in the village manager. The village manager or the village manager's designee shall keep all records of the storm water utility in the Village Hall or other officially designated place. 
(b)  The rules, regulations and rates hereinafter set forth shall be considered part of the regulations applicable to every individual or entity owning property in the village. Such rules, regulations and rates may be changed from time to time as determined by the village board of trustees and the right is reserved to make special rates and contracts in all proper cases. 
(c)  On an annual basis, the village manager or the manager's designee shall prepare a storm water utility budget. The budgeted revenues shall be sufficient to cover projected operation, maintenance and debt service costs of the storm water utility. 
(d)  The village manager or the manager's designee shall cause an annual audit of the books of the storm water utility to be made and shall make the books and records relating to the storm water utility available for inspection during regular business hours. 
(e)  Subject to approval by the village board, the storm water utility shall be able to utilize the full authority provided in § 66.0821, Wisconsin Statutes, with respect to financing methods and other matters therein dealt with, and shall have all legal authority permitted for municipal utilities to charge reasonable rates for services. 
(Ord. No. 214-O-02, § 1, 12-16-02) 
Sec. 110-204. - Application. 
    The application of this article, its rules, regulations and rates shall apply to all individuals, firms, corporations and institutions owning property within the corporate limit of the village. 
(Ord. No. 214-O-02, § 1, 12-16-02) 
Sec. 110-205. - Rules and regulations. 
    All users of the village storm water management system are subject to the regulations for erosion and storm water runoff control contained in chapters 38 and 122 of the Municipal Code, and incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 214-O-02, § 1, 12-16-02) 
Sec. 110-206. - Accounts and funds. 
(a)  The village manager or the manager's designee is authorized to establish an enterprise fund to be called the storm water utility fund, which shall be used for collection of revenues and payment of expenses relating to the operation and management of the storm water utility. A separate accounting shall be maintained for the storm water utility fund. 
(b)  The village manager or the manager's designee may establish segregated funds (e.g. debt service fund, capital reserve fund) as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 214-O-02, § 1, 12-16-02) 
Secs. 110-207-110-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COMMERCIAL PARKING UTILITY 

Sec. 110-301. - Utility created. 
    The Menomonee Falls Commercial Parking Utility ("utility") is created pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0829. Such utility shall acquire, construct, manage and operate parking facilities for the benefit of commercial areas within the Village of Menomonee Falls for the benefit of the users of such areas, and to lessen the impact of parking from commercial areas on nearby residential and institutional uses. 
(Ord. No. 518-O-11, § 1, 7-18-11) 
Sec. 110-302. - Administration. 
(a)  The village board shall manage and operate the utility. The village manager shall be responsible for administration of the utility subject to direction from the village board. 
(b)  Prior to village board action concerning the establishment, vacation, or alteration of a district hereunder, notice must be provided and a hearing conducted as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 66.0703(7)(a). Upon completion of such hearing, the village board may approve, reject, modify, or re-refer the plan or plans and the annual assessment proposed by the village manager, and may establish districts as proposed. The district's boundaries may be altered by the village board upon notice and hearing as set forth above. 
(c)  The village board and village manager, on behalf of the utility may also avail themselves of the special assessment procedures provided in Wis. Stats. § 66.0703. 
(Ord. No. 518-O-11, § 1, 7-18-11) 
Sec. 110-303. - Utility districts. 
(a)  The village manager may cause to be prepared and submitted to the village board a plan or plans ("plan") for establishment and development of commercial parking utility districts ("districts") and specific parking utility projects ("projects") and facilities ("facilities") intended to benefit commercial areas within the village and the users of those areas. Village board approval shall be required for any such district, plan, project or facility to be put into effect or constructed. 
(b)  Prior to village board approval of any plan, district, project, or facility located within any tax increment district, community development authority review and recommendation shall be required. Failure of the community development authority to make a recommendation within 90 days of referral from the village board shall constitute a recommendation for approval as submitted. 
(c)  Any districts established by the village board may be amended from time to time by the village board to add or subtract territory. Such districts may contain zones in which the annual assessment determined under section 110-306 below may vary according to the relative benefit derived from the commercial properties therein in terms of mathematical parking space ratios provided. 
(Ord. No. 518-O-11, § 1, 7-18-11) 
Sec. 110-304. - Village investment. 
(a)  Costs involved in acquisition and development of commercial parking districts, projects, and facilities may be born by the village or its instrumentalities and may be considered as the village's investment and capital contribution to the utility. Additional costs incurred in expanding or contracting a district shall be considered an increment to such investment.
