    Any person, firm, company or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects, or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. Each violation and each day that a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. Every structure, fill or development placed or maintained on floodland in violation of this chapter is a public nuisance and the creation of such nuisance may be enjoined and maintenance of a public nuisance may be abated by action at suit of the state, village or any citizen thereof. This section shall not preclude the village from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.027) 
State Law reference- Authority to provide penalties, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(f)B1; misdemeanor penalty for certain violations, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(8). 
Sec. 122-4. - Declared nuisances. 
    Any building erected, structurally altered, or placed on a lot, or any use carried on in violation of the provisions of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance per se, and the village may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction to restrain or abate such nuisance. 
(Code 1963, § 17.027(2)) 
Sec. 122-5. - Enforcement by injunction. 
    Compliance with the provisions of this chapter may also be enforced by injunctional order at the suit of the village or one or more owners of real estate situated within or adjacent to an area affected by the regulations of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.027(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(f)2. 
Sec. 122-6. - Purpose of chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to promote the health, safety, morals, prosperity, aesthetics and general welfare of this community. 
(Code 1963, § 17.012) 
State Law reference- Purpose of zoning ordinances, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(c). 
Sec. 122-7. - Intent of chapter. 
    It is the general intent of this chapter to regulate and restrict the use of all structures, lands and waters; regulate and restrict lot coverage, population distribution and density, and the size and location of all structures so as to: lessen congestion in and promote the safety and efficiency of the streets and highways; secure safety from fire, flooding, panic and other dangers; provide adequate light, air, sanitation and drainage; prevent overcrowding; avoid undue population concentration; facilitate the adequate provision of public facilities and utilities; stabilize and protect property values; further appropriate use of land and conservation of natural resources; preserve and promote the beauty of the community; and implement the community's comprehensive plan or plan components. In addition, the floodland zoning regulations set forth in this chapter have been adopted to prevent and control erosion, sedimentation, and other pollution of surface waters; to further the maintenance of safe and healthful water conditions and prevent flood damage to persons and property; and to minimize expenditures for flood relief and flood control projects. To this end, it is further intended to provide for the administration and enforcement of this chapter and to provide penalties for its violation. 
(Code 1963, § 17.013) 
Sec. 122-8. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
    It is not intended by this chapter to repeal, abrogate, annul, impair or interfere with any existing easements, covenants, deed restrictions, agreements, chapters, rules, regulations or permits previously adopted or issued pursuant to laws. However, whenever this chapter imposes greater restrictions, the provisions of this chapter shall govern. 
(Code 1963, § 17.014) 
State Law reference- Conflicts with zoning ordinances, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(g). 
Sec. 122-9. - Interpretation. 
    In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be minimum requirements and shall be liberally construed in favor of the village and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other power granted by the state statutes. 
(Code 1963, § 17.015) 
Sec. 122-10. - Jurisdiction. 
    The jurisdiction of this chapter shall include all lands and waters within the corporate limits of the village. The jurisdiction of this chapter shall also extend to those lands and waters lying within the unincorporated areas within 11/2 miles of the corporate limits that are approved by a majority of the members of the appropriate joint extraterritorial zoning committee pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7a). 
(Code 1963, § 17.021) 
Sec. 122-11. - Compliance. 
(a)  No structure, land or water shall hereafter be used and no structure or part of a structure shall hereafter be located, erected, moved, reconstructed, extended, enlarged, converted, or structurally altered without a zoning permit and without full compliance with the provisions of this chapter and all other applicable local, county and state regulations. 
(b)  Architectural control board approval shall be obtained as provided in subdivision II, division 4, article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.022) 
Sec. 122-12. - Municipalities and state agencies regulated. 
    Unless specifically exempted by law, all cities, villages, towns and counties are required to comply with this chapter and obtain all required permits. State agencies are required to comply as provided in Wis. Stats. § 13.48(13). The construction, reconstruction, maintenance, and repair of state highways and bridges by the state department of transportation are exempt from compliance when Wis. Stats. § 30.12(4)(a) applies. 
(Code 1963, § 17.0231) 
Sec. 122-13. - Nonliability. 
    The village does not guarantee, warrant or represent that only those areas designated as floodlands on the zoning district map or those lands contained within the conservancy-wetland zoning district will be subject to periodic inundation and hereby asserts that there is no liability on the part of the village board, its agencies or employees for any flood damages that may occur as a result of reliance upon and conformance with this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.016) 
Secs. 122-14-122-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 122-36. - Zoning administrator. 
(a)  The administration of this chapter shall be carried out by the village manager and his duly appointed representative, who shall be entitled zoning administrator. 
(b)  The zoning administrator shall investigate all complaints, give notice of violations, and enforce the provisions of this chapter. The zoning administrator and his duly appointed deputies may enter at any reasonable time any public or private lands or waters to make a zoning inspection. 
(c)  The zoning administrator shall maintain a permanent record of all permits issued and shall record the lowest floor elevation (including the basement) of any structure erected or placed in a floodland district. 
(Code 1963, §§ 17.021, 17.022(2), (3)(e)) 
Sec. 122-37. - Actions regarding permits, approvals or similar actions by village officers. 
    Whenever under this chapter a permit, approval or similar action by a village officer is required: 
(1)  The function of the officer is to determine, after on-site investigation, whether the proposed action complies with all of the requirements of this chapter, and all other applicable chapters, laws and regulations. The officer shall determine to his satisfaction that all applicants for permits in floodland districts have secured all necessary permits from those governmental agencies required to issue permits by state and federal law. After such determination, the officer shall issue all required permits and approvals, or deny approval in writing stating the reason for denial. 
(2)  In any case the officer may require the applicant to submit such information or documentation of his plan or proposal and in such form, including verified form, as the officer reasonably determines to be necessary in order to enable him to reach a fully informed and considered decision. Enumeration in this chapter of the information or documentation to be submitted, or the absences of any such enumeration, is not exclusive. If the applicant fails within reasonable time to supply requested information or documentation, the officer shall reject the application on that grounds without concluding as to its merits and without prejudice to the right of the applicant to resubmit a new application. 
(3)  The village officer may also refer to the plan commission for its determination any matter concerning this chapter pending before him for decision. In any such event, the determination of the plan commission shall be advisory to the officer. Whether or not he adopts the determination of the plan commission, the final decision shall be that of the officer, and any further appeal, whether to the board of appeals or otherwise, shall be from the decision of the officer. 
(4)  In any case in which approval or other favorable action of the plan commission is required or permitted under this chapter, the plan commission may grant such approval subject to submission to and approval by the village officer of particular details or final documentation. It shall be understood that the officer shall grant or withhold his approval based upon applicable requirements of this chapter and of other applicable chapters, laws or regulations and upon his understanding of the intention and decision of the plan commission; and that if the applicant and the officer fail to agree, the matter shall be returned to the plan commission for its determination. 
(Code 1963, § 17.022(3)(a)-(3)(d)) 
Sec. 122-38. - Zoning permit. 
    Applications for a zoning permit shall be made in duplicate on forms furnished by the zoning administrator and shall include the following where applicable: 
(1)  Names and addresses of the applicant, owner of the site, architect, professional engineer and contractor. 
(2)  Description of the subject site by lot, block and recorded subdivision or by metes and bounds; address of the subject site; type of structure; existing and proposed operation or use of the structure or site; number of employees; and the zoning district within which the subject site lies. 
(3)  Plat of survey prepared by a registered land surveyor showing the location, boundaries, dimensions, elevations, uses and size of the following: subject site; existing and proposed structures; existing and proposed easements, streets and other public ways; off-street parking, loading areas and driveways; existing highway access restrictions; existing and proposed street, side and rear yards. In addition, the plat of survey shall show the location, elevation, and use of any abutting lands and their structures within 100 feet of the subject site. 
(4)  Such additional information as may be required by the village plan commission, or village. 
(5)  Fee receipt from the village clerk-treasurer for fees required by section 42-122(1). 
(Code 1963, § 17.023) 
Sec. 122-39. - Occupancy permit. 
(a)  No vacant land shall hereafter be occupied, used or developed; and no building shall hereafter be located, moved, reconstructed or structurally altered; and no nonconforming use shall be maintained, renewed or changed until an occupancy permit has been approved by the zoning administrator and issued by the village. Such permit shall show that the building or premises or part thereof and the proposed use are in conformance with the provisions of this chapter. Application for an occupancy permit shall be made in the same manner as a zoning permit, pursuant to section 122-38. The fee for issuance of any occupancy permit shall be set by the village board. 
(b)  The zoning administrator may approve and the village may issue a temporary occupancy permit for part of a building. 
(c)  No vacant land in a floodland shall be filled, excavated or developed until an occupancy permit has been approved by the zoning administrator and issued by the village. In addition to the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, the application for an occupancy permit shall include a certification by a registered professional engineer or land surveyor that the floodland regulations set forth in this chapter have been fully complied with. 
(d)  A fee in the amount established in section 42-122(2) shall be paid prior to the issuance of such a permit. 
(Code 1963, § 17.028) 
Sec. 122-40. - Other permits. 
    It is the responsibility of the permit applicant to secure all other necessary permits required by any state, federal or local agency. 
(Code 1963, § 17.029) 
Secs. 122-41-122-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AMENDMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Amendments, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(d). 

Sec. 122-56. - Authority. 
(a)  Whenever the public necessity, convenience, general welfare or good zoning practice require, the village board of trustees may, by ordinance, change the district boundaries or amend, change or supplement the regulations established by this chapter or amendments thereto. 
(b)  Such change or amendment shall be subject to the review and recommendation of the village plan commission. 
(Code 1963, § 17.111) 
Sec. 122-57. - Initiation. 
    A change or amendment may be initiated by the village board, village plan commission or by a petition of one or more persons having an interest in property within or abutting the area proposed to be changed. 
(Code 1963, § 17.112) 
Sec. 122-58. - Petitions. 
    Petitions for any change to the district boundaries or amendments to the regulations shall be filed with the village manager, describe the premises to be rezoned, or the regulations to be amended, list the reasons justifying the petition, specify the proposed use and have attached the following: 
(1)  A plot plan drawn to a scale of one inch equals 100 feet showing the area proposed to be rezoned, its location, its dimensions and the location and classification of adjacent zoning districts and the location and existing use of all lots or parcels of record any part of which is within 300 feet of the area proposed to be rezoned. 
(2)  The owner's names and addresses of all properties lying within 300 feet of the area proposed to be rezoned. 
(3)  Additional information required by the village plan commission, joint extraterritorial zoning committee, where constituted, or the village board. 
(4)  Fee receipt from the village clerk-treasurer in the amount set out in subsection 42-122(g). 
(Code 1963, § 17.113; Ord. No. 467-O-09, § 1, 11-16-09) 
Sec. 122-59. - Recommendations. 
(a)  The village plan commission shall review all proposed changes and amendments and shall recommend to the village board that the petition be granted as requested, modified or denied. The recommendation shall be made at a meeting of the plan commission subsequent to the meeting at which the petition is first submitted, unless the plan commission determines, with no dissenting vote, that waiting until a subsequent meeting to make its recommendation is not necessary. The recommendation of the plan commission shall be made in writing to the village board. 
(b)  The appropriate joint extraterritorial zoning committee, when constituted, and the village plan commission shall review all proposed changes and amendments within the extraterritorial zoning jurisdiction, but only the members of the appropriate joint committee shall vote on matters relating to their zoning jurisdiction. 
(Code 1963, § 17.114) 
Sec. 122-60. - Hearing. 
    The village board shall hold a public hearing upon each plan commission recommendation, giving public notice thereof by publication of a class 2 notice, pursuant to Wis. Stats. ch. 985. Notice of the public hearing shall be mailed to the petitioner and to the clerk of any municipality whose boundaries are within 1,000 feet of any lands included in the petition. The village board may, in its sole discretion, mail notice of the public hear ing to the owners of all lands lying within 300 feet of any lands included in the petition. The failure to give any notice to the clerk of any municipality whose boundaries are within 1,000 feet of any lands included in the petition or to the owner of any property, except the owner of lands included in the petition, shall not invalidate the action taken by the village board. 
(Code 1963, § 17.115) 
Sec. 122-61. - Village board's action. 
    Following such hearing and after careful consideration of the village plan commission's and appropriate joint extraterritorial zoning committee's recommendations, when existing, the village board shall act to approve, modify and approve or disapprove the proposed change or amendment. Approval shall be by appropriate ordinance, and necessary changes in the official zoning map or text shall be made promptly. Should the board not concur in the recommendation of the plan commission, it shall re-refer the matter to the commission for reconsideration before taking final action. 
(Code 1963, § 17.116) 
Sec. 122-62. - Floodland district boundary changes limited. 
    The village board shall not permit changes to the floodland district boundaries that are inconsistent with the purpose and intent of this chapter or in conflict with the applicable rules and regulations of the state department of natural resources (DNR), the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), and the Milwaukee metropolitan sewer district (MMSD). In addition: 
(1)  Changes in the floodland district boundaries shall not be permitted where the change will increase the flood stage elevation by one one-hundredth foot or more, unless the petitioner has made appropriate legal arrangements with all affected units of government and all property owners affected by the stage increase. In no event shall a change be permitted that would increase the flood stage elevation by more than one foot unless a waiver is granted by FEMA. Petitions for floodland district changes shall show the affects of the change within the associated flood fringe, and shall provide adjusted water surface profiles and adjusted floodland limits to reflect the increased flood elevations. 
(2)  Removal of land from any floodland district shall not be permitted unless the land has been filled to an elevation at least two feet above the elevation of the 100-year recurrence interval flood and further provided that such land is contiguous to lands lying outside of the floodlands. 
(3)  Amendment of floodlands which were delineated by approximate methods shall not be permitted unless the petitioner provides the village with engineering data showing the flood profile, necessary river cross sections, flood elevations, and any effect the establishment of a floodway/floodfringe will have on flood stages. The effects shall be limited as set forth above for changes in subsections (1) and (2). If the approximate flood zone is less than five acres in area, and where the cost of the proposed development is estimated to be less than $125,000.00, the DNR will assist the petitioner in determining the required flood elevations. 
(4)  No river or stream shall be altered or relocated until a floodland zoning change has been applied for and granted in accordance with the requirements of this section, and until all adjacent communities have been requested to review and comment on the proposed alteration or relocation. The flood-carrying capacity of the altered or relocated watercourse shall not be reduced to less than the flood-carrying capacity before the watercourse was altered or relocated. 
(5)  A copy of all notices for amendments or rezoning in the floodland districts shall be transmitted to the DNR and MMSD at least ten days prior to the public hearing. No amendments to the floodland district boundaries or regulations shall become effective until approved by the DNR. In the case of floodland district boundary changes, an official letter of map amendment from the FEMA may also be required. 
(Code 1963, § 17.117; Ord. No. 212-O-02, § 1, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 435-O-09, § 1, 2-16-09) 
Sec. 122-63. - Protest. 
    In the event of a protest against such district change or amendment to the regulations of this chapter, duly signed and acknowledged by the owners of 20 percent or more either of the areas of the land included in such proposed change, or by the owners of 20 percent or more of the land immediately adjacent extending 100 feet therefrom, or by the owners of 20 percent or more of the land directly opposite thereto extending 100 feet from the street frontage of such opposite land, such changes or amendments shall not become effective except by the favorable vote of three-fourths of the members of the village board voting on the proposed change. 
(Code 1963, § 17.118) 
Secs. 122-64-122-69. - Reserved. 
Sec. 122-70. - Comprehensive plan. 
(a)  The village shall make and adopt a comprehensive plan as provided in Wis. Stats. § 66.1001. The comprehensive plan shall be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated and harmonious development of the village which will, in accordance with the existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety or general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development. 
(b)  Applications for amendments may be initiated by the village board of trustees, village plan commission, or by a petition of one or more persons having an interest in property within or abutting the area proposed to be changed. Such application shall contain: 
(1)  The legal description of the area to be re-classified; 
(2)  Reasons justifying the request; 
(3)  The application fee as set out in subsection 42-122(p). 
(c)  Plan commission. All comprehensive plan amendments shall be referred to the plan commission for a recommendation to the village board. Prior to making its recommendation, the plan commission shall hold a public hearing. The public hearing shall be preceded by a class 1 notice under Wis. Stats. ch. 985, published at least 30 days before the hearing is held. After closing the hearing, the plan commission shall recommend to the village board that the application be granted as requested, modified or denied. This recommendation, made by a majority vote, shall be in the form of a resolution. 
(d)  Village board action. The village board shall consider the resolution regarding an amendment to the comprehensive plan, and shall act to approve, modify or deny the request. Approval shall be by appropriate ordinance, and necessary changes to the comprehensive plan shall be made promptly. Should the board not concur in the recommendation of the plan commission, it shall re-refer the matter to the commission for reconsideration before taking final action. 
(e)  Notification of amendment. A copy of all adopted amendments to the comprehensive plan shall be sent to the following: 
(1)  The department of administration. 
(2)  Waukesha County. 
(3)  The appropriate school district-Hamilton and/or Menomonee Falls. 
(4)  The clerk of the following adjacent communities: 
a.  Village of Richfield; 
b.  Town of Lisbon; 
c.  Village of Sussex; 
d.  City of Pewaukee; 
e.  Town of Brookfield; 
f.  City of Brookfield; 
g.  Village of Butler; 
h.  City of Milwaukee; 
i.  Village of Germantown; 
j.  Village of Lannon. 
(5)  The Southeastern Wisconsin Regional Planning Commission. 
(6)  The Menomonee Falls public library. 
(Ord. No. 467-O-09, § 2, 11-16-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 467-O-09, § 2, adopted November 16, 2009, amended section 122-70 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, section 122-70 pertained to the land use plan, and derived from Ord. No. 269-O-04, § 1, adopted May 17, 2004. 
Secs. 122-71-122-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - NONCONFORMING USES, STRUCTURES AND LOTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Nonconforming uses, Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7)(h). 

Sec. 122-81. - Existing nonconforming uses. 
(a)  Any established use of land, a dwelling, or a building that existed lawfully before the current zoning ordinance was enacted or amended, but that does not conform with the use restrictions in the current ordinance, shall be classified as a legal nonconforming use. 
(b)  The lawful nonconforming use of a building, premises, structure, fixture, land or water may be continued, although the use does not conform with the provisions of this chapter. However: 
(1)  Only that portion of the land or water in actual use may be so continued, and the structure considered nonconforming based upon its use may not be extended, enlarged, reconstructed, substituted, moved or structurally altered except when required to do so by law or order so as to comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Total lifetime structural repairs or alterations to a structure that is used for, or supports a nonconforming use, shall not exceed 50 percent of the assessed value of the structure as equalized unless the structure is permanently changed to conform to the use provisions of this chapter. 
a.  As used in this section, the phrase "assessed value of the structure" shall mean the assessed value based upon the assessment made at the time the structure became a nonconforming use. 
b.  As used in this section, the phrase "structural repairs or alterations" shall mean any change in or repair to the supporting members of a structure, such as foundations, bearing walls, columns, beams or girders; and shall not mean mere aesthetic alterations or repairs which do not affect the supporting members of a structure. 
(3)  Substitution of new equipment shall be permitted if such equipment will reduce the incompatibility of the nonconforming use. 
(c)  If such nonconforming use is discontinued or terminated for a period of 12 months, any future use of the building, premises, structure, fixture, land or water shall conform to the provisions of this chapter. When a structure is classified as legal nonconforming because of its use, and is damaged by fire, explosion, flood, the public enemy or other calamity to the extent of more than 50 percent of its current equalized value, it shall not be restored except so as to comply with the use provisions of this chapter. When such structure is damaged to the extent of less than 50 percent of its current fair market value, the repairs and alterations required for the continued use of this structure shall include floodproofing to a height two feet above the elevation of the 100-year recurrence interval flood, as determined through the use of flood profiles and accompanying hydrologic and hydraulic engineering data contained in the "Village of Menomonee Falls Flood Insurance Study," prepared by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, to those portions of the building or structure involved in such repairs or alterations. Certification of floodproofing shall be made to the village manager or designee and shall consist of a plan or document certified by a registered professional engineer or architect that the floodproofing measures are consistent with the flood velocities, forces, depths and other factors associated with the 100-year recurrence interval flood level for the particular area. 
(Code 1963, § 17.081; Ord. No. 397, § 1, 4-7-08; Ord. No. 550-O-13, § 1, 1-21-13) 
Sec. 122-82. - Existing nonconforming structures. 
(a)  Any established structure that conforms with the use of the zoning district it is located in, and was classified as "legal conforming" prior to the adoption or amendment of this chapter, but does not conform with the lot, yard, height, parking and loading, or access provisions of the zoning district it is located in shall be classified and considered a lawful nonconforming structure. 
(b)  The lawful nonconforming structure existing at the time of the adoption or amendment of this section may be continued although its size or location does not conform with the lot, yard, height, parking and loading, and access provisions of this section. Additions and structural alterations to the structure are permitted provided they comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  If a lawful nonconforming structure is damaged or destroyed in part or in whole by violent wind, vandalism, fire, flood, ice, snow, mold, or infestation, such structure may be reconstructed in such a manner that its nonconforming aspects do not exceed those existing prior to the damage or destruction, unless a larger size is required to comply with applicable State or Federal requirements. If such structure is not to be rebuilt in the exact same size, character, appearance or location as the original dwelling, such rebuilding must receive the approval of the village architectural control board. 
(Ord. No. 550-O-13, § 3, 1-21-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 550-O-13, § 3, adopted Jan. 21, 2013, amended § 122-82 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 122-82 pertained to abolishment or replacement and derived from the Code of 1963, § 17.082; Ord. No. 167-O-01, § 1, adopted Dec. 17, 2001; Ord. No. 397-O-08, § 2, adopted April 7, 2008. 
Sec. 122-83. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 550-O-13, § 4, adopted Jan. 21, 2013, repealed § 122-83 in its entirety, which pertained to existing conforming and non-conforming structures and derived from the Code of 1963, § 17.083; Ord. No. 82-O-00, § 2(17.083), adopted May 15, 2000; Ord. No. 397-O-08, § 3, adopted April 7, 2008. 
Sec. 122-84. - Changes and substitutions. 
    Once a nonconforming use or structure has been changed to conform, it shall not revert back to a nonconforming use or structure. 
(Code 1963, § 17.084) 
Sec. 122-85. - Substandard lots. 
(a)  Residential. A one-family detached dwelling and its accessory structures may be erected, in any residential district, on any legal lot or parcel of record in the county register of deeds office before February 5, 1973 (the effective date of this ordinance), or of any amendment which makes the lot standard. 
(1)  All the district requirements shall be complied with insofar as practical and subject to the following: 
Lot Width Minimum 50 feet Area Minimum 5,000 square feet Building Area Minimum 1,000 square feet with at least 800 square feet on the first floor Height Maximum 35 feet Yards Street Minimum 30 feet; the second street yard on corner lots shall be not less than 10 feet Rear Principal structure Minimum 25 feet Accessory structure Minimum 10 feet(A-234) Side Minimum 40 percent of the frontage for both sides combined, but not less than 10 feet on any one side.  
(2)  Variances may be permitted only as specified in section 122-2. 
(b)  Agricultural. In any agricultural district a one-family detached dwelling and its accessory structures may be erected on a parcel with an area of less than three acres, subject to the parcel being on record in the county register of deeds office before February 5, 1973, or of any amendment which makes the lot substandard. 
(1)  All the district requirements shall be complied with insofar as practical and subject to the following: 
Building Area Minimum 1,800 sq. ft. Height Maximum 35 ft. Yards Street Minimum 75 ft. Rear Principal Structure - Minimum 30 ft. Accessory Structure - Minimum 20 ft. Side Minimum 20 ft.  
(2)  Variances may be permitted as specified in section 122-2. 
(Code 1963, § 17.085; Ord. No. 63-O-99, § 1(17.085), 11-15-99) 
Sec. 122-86. - Conditional use status. 
    Subject to the provisions of article VI, any such nonconforming use, except those in the floodland districts, may be reclassified as a conditional use. 
(Code 1963, § 17.086; Ord. No. 435-O-09, § 2, 2-16-09) 
Sec. 122-87. - Floodland nonconforming uses. 
    Floodland nonconforming uses repaired or altered under the nonconforming use provisions of this chapter shall provide for floodproofing to those portions of the structure involved in such repair or alteration. Certification of floodproofing shall be made to the zoning administrator and shall consist of a plan or document certified by a registered professional engineer that the floodproofing measures are consistent with the velocities, forces, depths, and other factors associated with the 100-year recurrence interval flood. 
(Code 1963, § 17.087) 
Secs. 122-88-122-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ARCHITECTURAL CONTROL BOARD AND ARCHITECTURAL CONTROLS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Secs. 122-106-122-120. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Architectural Control Board[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and authorities, § 2-211 et seq. 

Sec. 122-121. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established an architectural control board for the village for the purpose of promoting compatible development, aesthetics, stability of property values, and to prevent impairment or depreciation of existing developments. 
(Code 1963, § 17.091) 
Sec. 122-122. - Membership. 
(a)  Number; appointment. The architectural control board shall consist of seven members appointed by the village president and confirmed by the village board. 
(b)  Composition. Composition of the architectural control board is to be as follows when practicable: 
(1)  Four of the architectural control board members shall be residents of the village. 
(2)  Two of the architectural control board members should be registered architects or landscape architects. 
(3)  One of the architectural control board members should be a real estate broker or appraiser. 
(4)  One of the architectural control board members should be a builder, contractor or developer. 
(c)  Terms. Terms shall be for staggered three-year terms and shall be initially appointed as follows: 
(1)  Two for terms ending on the third Tuesday in April of 1998. 
(2)  Three for terms ending on the third Tuesday in April of 1999. 
(3)  Two for terms ending on the third Tuesday in April of 2000. 
(d)  Chairman. The chairman shall be appointed by the village president. 
(e)  Oaths. Official oaths shall be taken by all members in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 19.01 and within ten days of receiving notice of their appointments. 
(f)  Vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired terms in the same manner as appointments for the full term. 
(Code 1963, § 17.093) 
Sec. 122-123. - Organization. 
    The architectural control board shall organize and adopt rules for its own government in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(1)  Meetings. Meetings shall be held once a month, or when requested by the director of community development, or when requested by the chairman of the architectural control board. 
(2)  Minutes. Minutes of the proceedings and a record of all actions shall be kept by the secretary, showing the vote of each member upon each question, the reasons for the board's determination, and its finding of facts. These records shall be immediately filed in the office of the board and shall be a public record. 
(3)  Quorum. A quorum shall be three members, and all actions shall require a majority of those members present. 
(Code 1963, § 17.094; Ord. No. 109-O-00, § 1, 10-16-00) 
Sec. 122-124. - Powers. 
    The architectural control board shall have the following powers: 
(1)  Hear and decide applications for permission to erect, move, reconstruct, extend, alter or change the exterior of all structures referred to them. All commercial, industrial and multifamily structures shall be referred to them. 
(2)  Approve, deny or conditionally approve the application and may request such modifications as they may deem necessary to carry out the purpose of this section. 
(3)  The architectural control board may request assistance from other municipal officers, departments, boards and commission, or may seek outside professional opinion and pay for same provided funds for such consultation services are made available by the village board. 
(4)  Require the applicant to furnish additional information when necessary. 
(Code 1963, § 17.095) 
Sec. 122-125. - Decisions and appeals. 
(a)  The architectural control board shall decide all applications within 30 days after the final hearing and shall transmit a signed copy of their decision to the applicant and file a copy with the zoning administrator. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by any decisions of the architectural control board may appeal the decision to the proper court as provided by law. 
(Code 1963, § 17.099) 
Secs. 122-126-122-140. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Controls 

Sec. 122-141. - Compliance. 
    All proposed commercial, industrial and multifamily structures, including duplexes, shall be referred to the architectural control board. Other structures, proposed to be erected, moved, reconstructed, extended, enlarged, or have its exterior altered or changed, may be referred to the architectural control board by the plan commission or director of community development. Building permits shall not be issued for any structure referred to, but not approved by the architectural control board. 
(Code 1963, § 17.092) 
Sec. 122-142. - Applications. 
    Applications for approval by the architectural control board shall be made to the department of community development and shall be accompanied by the application form provided by the department of community development and such other information as required by the form. 
(Code 1963, § 17.096) 
Sec. 122-143. - Hearings. 
    The architectural control board shall schedule a reasonable time and place for the hearing. The applicant may appear in person, by agent, or by attorney. 
(Code 1963, § 17.097) 
Sec. 122-144. - Findings. 
    The architectural control board shall not approve any application unless they find beyond a reasonable doubt after viewing the site (viewing of the site may include: a site visit, submitted photographs, staff photographs, videos of the site, or other similar means) that the following facts and conditions exist: 
(1)  The site plan is functional and is compatible with the overall urban design of the area. 
(2)  The elements of the proposed application are not unsightly or obnoxious and is not disharmonious or so similar to existing neighboring developments that substantial depreciation of neighboring property or development will be caused by the applicant's proposal. 
(3)  A motion of approval shall constitute a finding by the board that the above facts and conditions exist. 
(Code 1963, § 17.098; Ord. No. 168-O-01, § 1, 12-17-01) 
Sec. 122-145. - Termination. 
    Approvals by the architectural control board shall terminate if the associated building permit has not been issued within one year following such approval. 
(Ord. No. 485-O-10, § 1, 6-21-10) 
Secs. 122-146-122-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS, APPEALS AND VACANCIES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and authorities, § 2-211 et seq. 
State Law reference- Board of appeals, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(e). 

Sec. 122-161. - Zoning board of appeals. 
(a)  Establishment. There is hereby established a zoning board of appeals for the village for the purpose of hearing appeals and applications, and granting variances and exceptions to the provisions of this chapter in harmony with the purpose and intent of this chapter. 
State Law reference- Board of appeals required, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(e)1. 
(b)  Membership. The zoning board of appeals shall consist of five members appointed by the village president and confirmed by the village board. 
(1)  Terms. Terms shall be for staggered three-year periods. 
(2)  Chairman. The chairman shall be designated by the village president. 
(3)  Alternate members. The village president shall appoint, for staggered terms of three years, two alternate members of such board, in addition to the five members above provided for. Annually, the village president shall designate one of the alternate members as 1st alternate and the other as 2nd alternate. The 1st alternate shall act, with full power, only when a member of the board refuses to vote because of interest or when a member is absent. The 2nd alternate shall so act only when the 1st alternate so refuses or is absent or when more than one member of the board so refuses or is absent. The above provisions, with regard to removal and the filling of vacancies, shall apply to such alternates. 
(4)  Qualification required by professional member. One member, if feasible, shall be a registered architect, registered professional engineer, builder or real estate appraiser. 
(5)  Secretary. The secretary shall be the village manager or designee. 
(6)  Village manager. The village manager or his designee shall attend all meetings and present the position of the officer appealed from. 
(7)  Oaths. Official oaths shall be taken by all members in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 19.01 within ten days of receiving notice of their appointment. 
(8)  Vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as appointments for a full term. 
State Law reference- Board of appeals membership, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(e)2. 
(c)  Organization. The zoning board of appeals shall organize and adopt rules of procedure for its own government in accordance with the provisions of law and of this chapter. 
(1)  Meetings. Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the board may determine and shall be open to the public, except as provided for in the statutes of the state. 
(2)  Minutes. Minutes of the proceedings and a record of all actions shall be kept by the secretary, showing the vote of each member upon each question, the reasons for the board's determination, and its findings of facts. These records shall be immediately filed in the office of the board and shall be a public record. 
(3)  Vote. If a quorum is present, the zoning board of appeals may take action by a majority vote of the members present. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(e)3, 62.23(7)(e)9; organization and meetings of board of appeals, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(e)3. 
(d)  Powers. The zoning board of appeals shall have the following powers: 
(1)  Errors. To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is an error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the zoning administrator or village manager or designee. 
(2)  Variances. To hear and grant appeals for variances as will not be contrary to the public interest, where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement will result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship, so that the spirit and purposes of this chapter shall be observed and the public safety, welfare and justice secured. Use variances shall not be granted. 
(3)  Permits. The board may reverse, affirm wholly or partly, modify the requirements appealed from, and may issue or direct the issue of a permit. 
(4)  Assistance. The board may request assistance from other village officers, departments, commissions and boards. 
(5)  Oaths. The chairman may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. 
State Law reference- Powers of board of appeals, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(e)7. 
(Code 1963, §§ 17.101-17.104; Ord. No. 334-O-06, §§ 1, 2, 3-20-06) 
Sec. 122-162. - Appeals. 
    Appeals from the decision of the zoning administrator or the village manager or designee concerning the literal enforcement of this chapter may be made by any person aggrieved or by an officer, department, board or bureau of the village. Such appeals shall be filed with such officer within 30 days after the date of written notice of the decision or order of the zoning administrator or village manager or designee. Applications may be made by the owner or lessee of the structure, land or water to be affected at any time and shall be filed with the secretary. Such appeals and applications shall include the following: 
(1)  Name and address of the appellant or applicant and all abutting opposite property owners of record, and owners within 300 feet of the property in question. 
(2)  Plat of survey prepared by a registered land surveyor showing all of the information required under sections 122-36 and 122-37 for a zoning permit. 
(3)  Additional information required by the village. 
(4)  A fee receipt from the village clerk-treasurer in the amount set out in section 42-122(6) of this Code. 
(Code 1963, § 17.105) 
State Law reference- Taking of appeals, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(e)5; fee for appeal authorized, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(ea). 
Sec. 122-163. - Hearings. 
    The zoning board of appeals shall fix a reasonable time and place for the hearing of appeals and give notice thereof by publication of a class 2 notice, pursuant to Wis. Stats. ch. 985. Notice of the public hearing shall be mailed to all parties in interest at least ten days before the hearing. Parties in interest shall be defined as the petitioner, the clerk of any municipality whose boundaries are within 1,000 feet of any land included in the petition and the owners of all lands lying within 300 feet of and lands included in the petition. The failure to give any notice to any property owner shall not invalidate the action taken by the zoning board of appeals. 
(Code 1963, § 17.106) 
Sec. 122-164. - Notice to DNR and MMSD. 
    The zoning board of appeals shall transmit a copy of each application for a variance to floodland regulations, and a copy of all floodland district appeals, to the state department of natural resources (DNR), and the Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewer District (MMSD) except for action within the Fox River watershed, for review and comment. Final action on the application shall not be taken for 30 days or until the DNR and MMSD have made their recommendation, whichever comes first. A copy of all decisions to floodland appeals shall be transmitted to the DNR and MMSD within ten days of the effective date of such decision. 
(Code 1963, § 17.1061; Ord. No. 212-O-02, § 2, 12-16-02) 
Sec. 122-165. - Floodland mapping disputes. 
    Whenever the board of appeals is asked to interpret a floodland boundary where an apparent discrepancy exists between the federal flood insurance study and actual field conditions, the following procedure shall be used: The floodland boundary shall be determined by use of the flood profiles contained in an engineering study, or where such information is not available, by experience flood maps or any other evidence available to the board of appeals. The person contesting the location of the district boundary shall be given the opportunity to present his own technical evidence. Where it is determined that the floodplain is incorrectly mapped, the board of appeals shall advise the village plan commission of its findings and the plan commission shall proceed to petition the village board for a map amendment. 
(Code 1963, § 17.1062) 
Sec. 122-166. - Findings. 
(a)  No variance to the provisions of this chapter shall be granted by the board unless it finds upon a preponderance of the evidence that the conditions of section 122-161(d)(2) are satisfied and that the following facts and conditions exist and the board so indicates in the minutes of its proceedings: 
(1)  A literal enforcement of the zoning regulations would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship. 
a.  The property owner shall bear the burden of proving practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship. 
b.  The difficulty or hardship cannot be self-created. 
c.  Economic loss or financial hardship shall not justify a variance. 
d.  Only the minimum variance that would alleviate the difficulty or hardship may be granted. 
(2)  The difficulty or hardship is due to unique property limitations. 
a.  The difficulty or hardship shall be based on conditions unique to the property rather than considerations personal to the property owner. 
(3)  The variance shall be in harmony with the public interest. 
a.  The spirit of the ordinance shall be observed and public safety and welfare secured. 
(b)  No variances shall be granted where: 
(1)  Filling and development contrary to the purpose and intent of the Floodland Districts would result. 
(2)  A change in the boundaries of the Floodland Districts would result. 
(3)  A lower degree of flood protection than a point two feet above the 100-year recurrence interval flood for the particular area would result. 
(4)  Any action contrary to the provisions of Wis. Admin. Code NR ch. 116 would result. 
(c)  In addition to the criteria in this section, to qualify for a variance in the Floodland Districts under FEMA regulations, the following criteria must be met; 
(1)  The variance may not cause any increase in the regional flood elevation; 
(2)  The variance can only be granted for lots that are less than one-half acre and are contiguous to existing structures constructed below the Regional Flood Elevation (RFE). 
(3)  The variance shall only be granted upon a showing of good and sufficient cause, shall be the minimum relief necessary, shall not cause increased risks to public safety or nuisances, shall not increase costs for rescue and relief efforts and shall not be contrary to the purpose of the ordinance. 
(Code 1963, § 17.107; Ord. No. 277-O-04, § 1, 8-16-04; Ord. No. 295-O-05, § 1, 2-7-05; Ord. No. 420-O-08, § 3, 10-20-08) 
Sec. 122-167. - Decision. 
(a)  The zoning board of appeals shall decide all appeals and applications within 30 days after the public hearing and shall transmit a signed copy of the board's decision to the appellant or applicant, zoning administrator and the village plan commission. 
(b)  Conditions may be placed upon any building permit ordered or authorized by this board. 
(c)  Variances, substitutions or use permits granted by the board shall expire within six months unless substantial work has commenced pursuant to such grant. 
(d)  Applicants receiving variances in floodlands shall be notified, in writing, by the board of appeals that increased flood insurance premiums and risk to life and property may result from the granting of the variance. The board shall keep a record of the notification in its files. 
(Code 1963, § 17.108) 
State Law reference- Decisions of board of appeals, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(e)6. 
Sec. 122-168. - Review by court of record. 
    Any person aggrieved by any decision of the zoning board of appeals may further appeal in the manner prescribed by law. 
(Code 1963, § 17.109) 
State Law reference- Appeals from decisions of board of appeals, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(e)10. 
Secs. 122-169-122-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ZONING DISTRICTS ESTABLISHED; ZONING MAP 

Sec. 122-191. - Districts established. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the village is hereby divided into the following zoning districts: 
R-1 single-family residential district R-2 single-family residential district R-3 single-family residential district R-3.5 single-family residential district R-4 single-family residential district R-5 single-family residential district R-6 single-family and two-family residential district PRD planned residential development district RM-1 multifamily residential district RM-2 multifamily residential district C-1 neighborhood business district C-2 community business district C-3 planned commercial-residential development district C-4 suburban retail business district OC-5 commercial service overlay district C-6 office district I-1 light industrial district I-2 heavy industrial district I-3 executive office/light industrial district A-1 agricultural district A-2 agriculture/urban fringe district FW floodway district FF floodfringe district GFP general floodplain district SW shoreland-wetland district CW-1 conservancy-wetlands district OVC village centre overlay district P-1 park and open space district P-2 institutional district PID planned infill development overlay district PDD No. 1 planned development district number one PDD No. 2 planned development district number two  
(Code 1963, § 17.031; Ord. No. 353-O-06, § 1, 11-20-06; Ord. No. 435-O-09, § 3, 2-16-09) 
State Law reference- Districts authorized, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(b). 
Sec. 122-192. - District boundaries and interpretation of map. 
(a)  Boundaries of these districts are hereby established as shown on the maps entitled, "Zoning - Village of Menomonee Falls, Waukesha County, Wisconsin," and Waukesha County Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM), panel numbers 55133C0083F, 55133C0084F, 55133C0091F, 55133C0092F, 55133C0093F, 55133C0094F, 55133C0103F, 55133C0104F, 55133C0111F, 55133C0112F, 55133C0113F, 55133C0114F, 55133C0206F, 55133C0207F, 55133C0226F, and 55133C0227F, dated November 19, 2008; with corresponding profiles that are based on the Flood Insurance Study (FIS) dated November 19, 2008, volume number 55133CV001A-003A. These maps accompany and are made a part of this chapter by reference. All notations and references shown on the maps are as much a part of this chapter as though specifically described in this section. This chapter hereby incorporates any future changes or any later zoning maps that may be adopted by ordinance of the village board. A certified copy of these maps shall bear upon their face the authentication of the village president, and the village clerk-treasurer and shall be maintained in the department of community development. Copies of the zoning maps may be published and shall be available to the public in the village hall. 
(b)  Changes to the general zoning districts, subsequent to the adoption of this chapter, shall not be effective until entered and attested on the certified copy. Changes in the FW Floodway District, FF Floodfringe District, GFP General Floodplain District, or SW Shoreland-Wetland district shall not become effective until approved by the state department of natural resources (DNR) and/or the Federal Insurance Administration (FIA). 
(c)  The district boundaries in all districts, except the OC-5 Commercial Service Overlay District Floodway District, FW Floodway District, FF Floodfringe District, GFP General Floodplain District, SW Shoreland-Wetland District, and the CW-1 conservancy-wetlands district, shall be construed to follow: corporate limits; U.S. public land survey lines; lot or property lines; centerlines of streets, highways, alleys, easements and railroad rights-of-way or such lines extended. 
(d)  Additional CW-1 Conservancy-Wetlands District boundaries are based upon topography established by aerial survey maps and change in flora as exhibited on aerial photographic mosaics and the boundaries of soil types, as exhibited in the SEWRPC Operational Soil Survey and are intended to represent the edge of swamps, marshes, and other lands not adequately drained or otherwise unsuited for development by reason of adverse soil conditions or extreme topography or which should be conserved in order to preserve valuable wetland resources, and shall be finally determined by the actual field conditions in each specific situation; provided, however, that along a stream or flowing watercourse such line shall not be less than 25 feet from the ordinary highwater mark of such stream or watercourse. 
(e)  Vacation of public streets and alleys shall cause the vacated land to be automatically placed in the same district as the abutting side to which the vacated land reverts. 
(f)  Annexations to or considerations with the village subsequent to February 5, 1973, shall be placed in the A-1 Agricultural District, unless the annexation ordinance temporarily places the land in another district. Within one year, the village plan commission shall evaluate and recommend a permanent classification to the village board. Annexations containing floodlands and shorelands shall be governed in the following manner: 
(1)  Annexations containing floodlands shall be governed by the provisions of the county shoreland zoning ordinance until such time that the state department of natural resources (DNR) certifies that amendments to this chapter meet the requirements of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR116. 
(2)  Annexations containing shorelands. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 59.692(7), any annexation of land after May 7, 1982, which lies within shorelands shall be governed by the provisions of the county shoreland zoning ordinance until such time that the village adopts a chapter which is at least as restrictive as the county shoreland zoning ordinance. Such regulations shall be administered and enforced by the village zoning administrator. 
(Code 1963, § 17.031; Ord. No. 353-O-06, § 18, 11-20-06; Ord. No. 435-O-09, § 4, 2-16-09; Ord. No. 477-O-10, § 1, 3-15-10) 
Secs. 122-193-122-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DISTRICT REGULATIONS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- District regulations authorized, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(b). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 122-216-122-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 122-231. - R-1 single-family residential district. 
(a)  Intent. This R-1 district is intended to provide for large single-family residences on large lots in areas consistent with existing development. 
(b)  Principal uses. Principal uses in the R-1 district are one-family dwellings; agricultural when not involving animals or poultry, nor the selling of produce on the premises. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the R-1 district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the R-1 district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Regular deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the R-1 district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a single-family residential district. 
(8)  Those uses permitted in the R-1 residential district listed in sections 122-561 or 122-562. 
(f)  Lot. Lot width and area in the district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Width: minimum 200 feet. 
(2)  Area: minimum one acre. 
(g)  Building. Building area and height in the R-1 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area: minimum 1,800 square feet; 1,200 square feet on first floor. 
(2)  Height: maximum 42 feet. 
(h)  Yards. Yard dimensions in the R-1 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street: minimum 75 feet. 
(2)  Rear: 
a.  Principal structure: minimum 30 feet. 
b.  Accessory structure: minimum 20 feet. 
(3)  Side: minimum 20 feet. 
(i)  Additional requirements. See sections divisions 1 and 3 of article VII of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(1); Ord. No. 211-O-02, § 1, 12-16-02) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-232. - R-2 single-family residential district. 
(a)  Intent. This R-2 district is intended to provide for medium sized single-family residences on medium sized lots in areas consistent with existing development. 
(b)  Principal uses. Principal uses in the R-2 district are one-family dwellings; agriculture, when not involving animals or poultry, nor the selling of produce on the premises. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the R-2 district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the R-2 district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the R-2 district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a single-family residential district. 
(8)  Those uses permitted in the R-2 residential district listed in sections 122-561 or 122-562. 
(f)  Lot. Lot width and area in the R-2 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Width: minimum 150 feet. 
(2)  Area: minimum 30,000 square feet. 
(g)  Building. Building area and height in the R-2 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area: minimum 1,600 square feet; 1,200 square feet on first floor. 
(2)  Height: maximum 42 feet. 
(h)  Yards. Yard dimensions in the R-2 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street: minimum 50 feet. 
(2)  Rear: 
a.  Principal structure: minimum 30 feet. 
b.  Accessory structure: minimum 20 feet. 
(3)  Side: minimum 20 feet. 
(i)  Additional requirements. See sections divisions 1 and 3 of article VII of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(2); Ord. No. 211-O-02, § 2, 12-16-02) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-233. - R-3 single-family residential district. 
(a)  Intent. This R-3 district is intended to provide for development similar in character to the R-2 district, but with slightly smaller size lots and smaller residences in areas consistent with existing development and in vacant areas adjacent and between areas of similar sized development. 
(b)  Principal uses. The principal use in the R-3 district is one-family dwellings. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the R-3 district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the R-3 district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the R-3 district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a single-family residential district. 
(8)  Those uses permitted in the R-3 residential district listed in sections 122-561 or 122-562. 
(f)  Lot. Lot width and area in the R-3 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Width: minimum 110 feet. 
(2)  Area: minimum 20,000 square feet. 
(g)  Building. Building area and height in the R-3 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area: minimum 1,400 square feet total with 1,100 square feet on first floor except that if the total building area is not less than 1,500 square feet and an attached garage of at least 300 square feet is provided, then the first floor area may be reduced to 850 square feet. 
(2)  Height: maximum 42 feet. 
(h)  Yards. Yard dimensions in the R-3 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street: minimum 40 feet. 
(2)  Rear: 
a.  Principal structure: minimum 30 feet. 
b.  Accessory structure: minimum 15 feet. 
(3)  Side: minimum 15 feet. 
(i)  Additional requirements. See divisions 1 and 3 of article VII of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(3); Ord. No. 211-O-02, § 3, 12-16-02) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-234. - R-3.5 single-family residential district. 
(a)  Intent. This R-3.5 district is intended to provide for development similar in character to the R-3 district, with similar lot width but of less area and with similar sized residences in areas capable of being serviced by municipal sewer and water and in areas reasonably isolated from existing development or subdivisions containing R-3 or greater district regulations. 
(b)  Principal use. The principal use in the R-3.5 district is one-family dwellings. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the R-3.5 district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the R-3.5 district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the R-3.5 district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a single-family residential district. 
(8)  Those uses permitted in the R-3.5 residential district listed in sections divisions 1 and 3 of article VII of this chapter. 
(f)  Lot. Lot width and area in the R-3.5 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Width: minimum 110 feet. 
(2)  Area: minimum 15,000 square feet. 
(g)  Building. Building area and height in the R-3.5 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area: minimum 1,400 square feet total with 1,100 square feet on first floor, except that if the total building area is not less than 1,500 square feet and an attached garage of at least 300 square feet is provided, then the first floor area may be reduced to 850 square feet. 
(2)  Height: maximum 42 feet. 
(h)  Yards. Yard dimensions in the R-3.5 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street: minimum 30 feet. 
(2)  Rear: 
a.  Principal structure: minimum 30 feet. 
b.  Accessory structure: minimum 15 feet. 
(3)  Side: minimum 15 feet. 
(i)  Additional requirements. See sections divisions 1 and 3 of article VII of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(4); Ord. No. 211-O-02, § 4, 12-16-02) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-235. - R-4 single-family residential district. 
(a)  Intent. This R-4 district is intended to provide for development similar in character to the R-3 district, but with slightly smaller sized lots and smaller residences in areas consistent with existing development and in vacant areas adjacent and between areas of similar sized development. 
(b)  Principal use. The principal use in the R-4 district is one-family dwellings. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the R-4 district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the R-4 district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Regular deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the R-4 district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a single-family residential district. 
(8)  Those uses permitted in the R-4 residential district listed in sections 122-561 or 122-562. 
(f)  Lot. Lot width and area in the R-4 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Width: minimum 90 feet. 
(2)  Area: minimum 15,000 square feet. 
(g)  Building. Building area and height in the R-4 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area: minimum 1,200 square feet total with 1,000 square feet on the first floor except that if the total building area is not less than 1,500 square feet and an attached garage of at least 300 square feet is provided, then the first floor area may be reduced to 750 square feet. 
(2)  Height: maximum 42 feet. 
(h)  Yards. Yard dimensions in the R-4 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street: minimum 30 feet. 
(2)  Rear: 
a.  Principal structure: minimum 30 feet. 
b.  Accessory structure: minimum 15 feet. 
(3)  Side: minimum 15 feet. 
(i)  Additional requirements. See sections divisions 1 and 3 of article VII of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(5); Ord. No. 211-O-02, § 5, 12-16-02) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-236. - R-5 single-family residential district. 
(a)  Intent. This R-5 district is intended to provide for the smaller type of individual single-family residence on small lots in areas consistent with existing development and in vacant areas adjacent and between areas of similar sized development. 
(b)  Principal use. The principal use in the R-5 district is one-family dwellings. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the R-5 district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the R-5 district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the R-5 district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a single-family residential district. 
(8)  Those uses permitted in the R-5 residential district listed in sections 122-561 or 122-562. 
(f)  Lot. Lot width and area in the R-5 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Width: minimum 75 feet. 
(2)  Area: minimum 9,000 square feet. 
(g)  Building. Building area and height in the R-5 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area: minimum 1,100 square feet total with 900 square feet on first floor, or the first floor may be reduced to 800 square feet and the total increased to 1,200 square feet and attached garage and/or carport of at least 300 square feet in area must be provided. 
(2)  Height: maximum 35 feet. 
(h)  Yards. Yard dimensions in the R-5 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street: minimum 25 feet. 
(2)  Rear: 
a.  Principal structure: minimum 25 feet. 
b.  Accessory structure: minimum 12 feet. 
(3)  Side: minimum 12 feet. 
(i)  Additional requirements. See sections divisions 1 and 3 of article VII of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(6)) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-237. - R-6 single-family and two-family residential district. 
(a)  Intent. This R-6 district is intended to provide for the smallest type of individual single-family residences and two-family residences on small lots in areas served by municipal sewer and water facilities on parcels of land contained within a planned residential development only, where the platting of small lots can be successfully accomplished without affecting detrimentally the neighboring districts. It is recommended that, wherever possible, the development under this section be of the "cluster development" type of grouped lot layout and house placement with private access drive off of a public feeder street. 
(b)  Principal uses. The principal uses in the R-6 district are one-family and two-family dwellings. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the R-6 district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc.
