(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the R-6 district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Regular deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the R-6 district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a single-family residential district. 
(8)  Those uses permitted in the R-5 residential district listed in sections 122-561 or 122-562. 
(f)  Lot. Lot width and area in the R-6 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Single-family: 
a.  Width: minimum 60 feet. 
b.  Area: minimum 7,200 square feet. 
(2)  Two-family: 
a.  Width: minimum 80 feet. 
b.  Area: minimum 9,600 square feet. 
(g)  Building. Building area and height in the R-6 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area: 
a.  Single-family: minimum 900 square feet total with 750 square feet minimum on first floor. No garage requirements at time of initial construction, but size and location of possible future attached or detached garage must be shown on site plan when applying for building permit. Minimum size garage: 250 square feet per dwelling unit. 
b.  Two-family: minimum 900 square feet per family, with 550 square feet minimum per family on first floor if side by side, and minimum of 900 square feet on first floor and on second floor, if upper and lower flats. Same garage requirements for each dwelling unit as for single-family. 
(2)  Height: maximum 35 feet. 
(h)  Yards. Yard dimensions in the R-6 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street: minimum 25 feet. 
(2)  Rear: 
a.  Principal structure: minimum 25 feet. 
b.  Accessory structure: minimum ten feet, except that storage sheds less than 150 square feet in area may be located three feet from the rear lot line; see also section 122-622(2). 
(3)  Side: 
a.  Single-family: 
1.  Principal structure: minimum 12.5 feet, unless one side is zero feet with neighboring property easement rights for maintenance purposes, then other side yard shall be 15 feet minimum. 
2.  Accessory structure: minimum ten feet, except that storage sheds less than 150 square feet in area may be located three feet from the side lot line; see also section 122-622(2). 
b.  Two-family: 
1.  Principal structure: minimum 15 feet. 
2.  Accessory structure: minimum ten feet except that storage sheds less than 150 square feet in area may be located three feet from the side lot line. 
c.  Cluster developments: 
1.  Street, rear and side yard requirements for the cluster as a whole shall be 25 feet minimum. 
2.  Lot size and individual yard requirements within the cluster may vary from the above requirements, provided that for the entire cluster, the total yard area is no less than that which would have resulted from the application of the individual lot requirements for the total aggregate number of dwelling units in the cluster complex. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(7)) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-238. - RM-1 multifamily residential district. 
(a)  Intent. This RM-1 district is intended to provide for medium density residences in the form of duplexes, row houses and apartments in areas especially adaptable for small families, single persons, the elderly, etc., as well as those who prefer the conveniences and services available in multifamily living or the compactness and ease of maintenance in row house living, in areas easily served by commerce and transportation. 
(b)  Principal uses. Principal uses in the RM-1 district are multifamily dwellings, attached single-family dwellings, semidetached single-family dwellings, and single-family dwellings existing on February 5, 1973; community living arrangements as defined in Wis. Stats. § 46.03(22) for nine to 15 persons. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the RM-1 district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the RM-1 district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Regular deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the RM-1 district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a multifamily residential district. 
(8)  Those uses permitted in the RM-1 multifamily residential district listed in sections 122-561 or 122-562. 
(f)  Lot. Lot width and area in the RM-1 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Width: minimum 120 feet. 
(2)  Area: minimum 18,000 square feet for two or more families with no less than the following per dwelling type: 
a.  Efficiency apartment: 2,700 square feet. 
b.  One bedroom apartment: 2,950 square feet. 
c.  One and one-half bedroom apartment: 3,500 square feet. 
d.  Two bedroom apartment: 4,200 square feet. 
e.  Two and one-half bedroom apartment: 4,800 square feet. 
f.  Three bedroom apartment: 5,400 square feet. 
g.  Two bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 4,300 square feet. 
h.  Three bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 5,500 square feet. 
(g)  Building. Building area and height in the RM-1 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area: minimum net area per dwelling type: 
a.  Efficiency apartment: 400 square feet. 
b.  One bedroom apartment: 500 square feet. 
c.  One and one-half bedroom apartment: 750 square feet. 
d.  Two bedroom apartment: 900 square feet. 
e.  Two and one-half bedroom apartment: 1,000 square feet. 
f.  Three bedroom apartment: 1,100 square feet. 
g.  Two bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 1,000 square feet. 
h.  Three bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 1,200 square feet. 
(2)  Height: maximum 35 feet. 
(3)  For the purpose of this chapter a half bedroom shall be any room 100 square feet or less not designated as a bedroom but capable of being used as a bedroom. Any room over 100 square feet in area, other than the principal living room, bathroom or kitchen, shall be considered a bedroom. 
(h)  Yards. Yard dimensions in the RM-1 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street: minimum 30 feet. 
(2)  Rear: minimum 30 feet. 
(3)  Side: minimum 15 feet. 
(i)  Open space. Minimum open space in the RM-1 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Efficiency apartment: 1,500 square feet. 
(2)  One bedroom apartment: 1,650 square feet. 
(3)  One and one-half bedroom apartment: 2,000 square feet. 
(4)  Two bedroom apartment: 2,500 square feet. 
(5)  Two and one-half bedroom apartment: 3,000 square feet. 
(6)  Three bedroom apartment: 3,500 square feet. 
(7)  Two bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 2,500 square feet. 
(8)  Three bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 3,500 square feet. 
(j)  Allowable reductions in lot area and open space. In multiunit individual projects (not planned development projects), the following reductions in both lot area and open space requirements only will govern: 
(1)  Up to four dwelling units: full area requirements. 
(2)  Five to eight dwelling units: allowable reduction ten percent. 
(3)  Nine to 16 dwelling units: allowable reduction 20 percent. 
(4)  Seventeen to 32 dwelling units: allowable reduction 30 percent. 
(5)  Over 32 dwelling units: allowable reduction 40 percent. 
(k)  Additional requirements. See sections divisions 1 and 3 of article VII of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(9)) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-239. - RM-2 multifamily residential district. 
(a)  Intent. This RM-2 district is intended to provide for development similar in character to the RM-1 district, but with higher density. RM-2 districts are intended to be located within an approved sanitary sewer service area. RM-2 multifamily residential districts are likely to have more direct impact on neighborhood property values, neighborhood health, safety and traffic than RM-1 districts because of the closer location of the multifamily use to neighboring nonmultifamily uses. 
(b)  Principal uses. Principal uses in the RM-2 district are dwellings existing on February 5, 1973, including multifamily and single-family structures whether attached or detached; community living arrangements as defined in Wis. Stats. § 46.03(22) for nine to 15 persons. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the RM-2 district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the RM-2 district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the RM-2 district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 17.041). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Multifamily dwellings, attached single-family dwellings, semidetached single-family dwellings, and single-family dwellings. 
(2)  Barber shops. 
(3)  Beauty shops. 
(4)  Insurance offices. 
(5)  Photographic studios. 
(6)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(7)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(8)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a multifamily residential district. 
(9)  Those uses permitted in the RM-2 residential district listed in sections 122-561, 122-562 and 122-563. 
(f)  Lot. Lot width and area in the RM-2 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Width: minimum 100 feet. 
(2)  Area: minimum 12,000 square feet with no less than the following per dwelling type: 
a.  Efficiency apartment: 2,375 square feet. 
b.  One bedroom apartment: 2,625 square feet. 
c.  One and one-half bedroom apartment: 3,075 square feet. 
d.  Two bedroom apartment: 3,550 square feet. 
e.  Two and one-half bedroom apartment: 4,125 square feet. 
f.  Three bedroom apartment: 4,700 square feet. 
g.  Two bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 3,700 square feet. 
h.  Three bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 4,900 square feet. 
(g)  Building. Building area and height in the RM-2 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area: minimum net area per dwelling type: 
a.  Efficiency apartment: 400 square feet. 
b.  One bedroom apartment: 500 square feet. 
c.  One and one-half bedroom apartment: 750 square feet. 
d.  Two bedroom apartment: 900 square feet. 
e.  Two and one-half bedroom apartment: 1,000 square feet. 
f.  Three bedroom apartment: 1,100 square feet. 
g.  Two bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 1,000 square feet. 
h.  Three bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 1,200 square feet. 
(2)  Height: maximum 120 feet; for every two feet in height in excess of 35 feet, the yard requirements shall be increased by one foot. 
(3)  For the purpose of this chapter a half bedroom shall be any room 100 square feet or less not designated as a bedroom but capable of being used as a bedroom. Any room over 100 square feet in area, other than the principal living room, bathroom or kitchen, shall be considered a bedroom. 
(h)  Yards. Yard dimensions in the RM-2 district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street: minimum 30 feet. 
(2)  Rear: minimum 25 feet. 
(3)  Side: minimum ten feet. 
(i)  Open space. Minimum open space per dwelling unit type is as follows: 
(1)  Efficiency apartment: 1,500 square feet. 
(2)  One bedroom apartment: 1,650 square feet. 
(3)  One and one-half bedroom apartment: 2,000 square feet. 
(4)  Two bedroom apartment: 2,500 square feet. 
(5)  Two and one-half bedroom apartment: 3,000 square feet. 
(6)  Three bedroom apartment: 3,500 square feet. 
(7)  Two bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 2,500 square feet. 
(8)  Three bedroom attached or semidetached single-family dwelling: 3,500 square feet. 
(j)  Allowable reductions in lot area and open space. In multiunit individual projects (not planned development projects), the following reductions in both lot area and open space requirements only will govern: 
(1)  Up to four dwelling units: full area requirements. 
(2)  Five to eight dwelling units: allowable reduction ten percent. 
(3)  Nine to 16 dwelling units: allowable reduction 20 percent. 
(4)  Seventeen to 32 dwelling units: allowable reduction 30 percent. 
(5)  Over 32 dwelling units: allowable reduction 40 percent. 
(k)  Additional regulations. See divisions 1 and 3, article VII of this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(10)) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Secs. 122-240-122-255. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - PRD Planned Residential Development District 

Sec. 122-256. - Applicability of subdivision provisions. 
    The provisions of this subdivision apply to the PRD planned residential development district. 
Sec. 122-257. - Purpose of subdivision. 
    This subdivision is adopted to establish the special districts provided for in Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(b). 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(s)) 
Sec. 122-258. - Intent. 
    This PRD district is intended to allow for greater development flexibility and greater design freedom consistent with the most advanced development techniques in use today, both in building types and in the mixing of building types and in accepted current development techniques that can be achieved under existing residential district regulations. In keeping with current economic considerations and the utilization of condominium laws, this PRD district is specifically intended to allow for increased density through greater utilization of the land and in a more efficient manner, and at a lower cost than by applying the now existing standards. By applying recently conceived, but proven, new development techniques in areas that are served by municipal sewer and water facilities, the community can again provide viable housing, consistent with the economy of the times, and thoroughly beneficial to the general welfare and economic prosperity of the village. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)) 
Sec. 122-259. - Principal uses. 
    The principal uses in the PRD district are one-family, two-family and multifamily dwellings and mixes of the same; community living arrangements as defined in Wis. Stats. § 46.03(22) for nine to 15 persons. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(a)) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-260. - Accessory uses. 
    Accessory uses in the PRD district are as follows: 
(1)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
(2)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(3)  Noncommercial recreational, sport and service facilities such as playgrounds, swimming pools, tennis courts, health facilities, etc., community meeting halls and similar uses designed as an integral accessory amenity or service facility to the planned residential development. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(b)) 
Sec. 122-261. - Prohibited uses. 
    The following uses are prohibited in the PRD district: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Regular deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(c)) 
Sec. 122-262. - Conditional uses. 
    The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the PRD district. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this section, receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a residential district. 
(8)  Those uses permitted in the PRD planned residential development district listed in sections 122-561 or 122-562. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(d)) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment, foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-263. - Lot. 
    Lot width and area in the PRD district are as follows: three acres minimum development area. For planning purposes and for parcels or lots to be sold off outright or condominiumized, the requirements of the R-6 residential district shall apply to all single-family and two-family dwellings, and the requirements of the RM-2 multifamily district shall apply to all multifamily dwellings, including the allowable reduction in lot area and open space based on the total number of dwelling units proposed as provided for in the RM-2 residential district. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(e)) 
Sec. 122-264. - Building. 
    Building area and height in the PRD district shall be as follows: 
(1)  Area. The area requirements of the R-6 residential district shall apply to all single-family and two-family dwellings, and the requirements of the RM-2 multifamily district shall apply to all multifamily structures, including attached single-family dwelling units (townhouses). 
(2)  Height. The maximum height is 42 feet. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(f); Ord. No. 211-O-02, § 6, 12-16-02) 
Sec. 122-265. - Yards. 
    The following yard restrictions shall apply for all planned residential development: 
(1)  Where a project boundary line is on the centerline or directly abuts a public street in another residential district, the first tier of lots shall meet all of the requirements of the district next smaller to that on the opposite side of the street and shall front on that street. Alternative solutions for project boundary areas may be proposed provided they meet the intent of these regulations herein enumerated and that they provide adequate protection from/to adjacent properties. 
(2)  Where a project boundary line is on the centerline or directly abuts a public street in another residential district, or the proposed continuation of a public street, the first tier of lots on the same side of the street shall meet all of the requirements of that adjoining district, and shall front on that public street. 
(3)  Where a project boundary line is coincident with the rear lot lines of another adjoining residential district, the requirements of the planned residential development district may be reduced to meet the requirements of the district two smaller to that in size of lot and buildings areas (i.e., from R-1 to R-3, or from R-3 to R-5, etc.). 
(4)  Where a project boundary line is coincident with a side yard line of a lot in another adjoining residential district, and has no frontage on an existing public street, or the proposed continuation of a public street, the minimum side yard offset shall be 20 feet. 
(5)  Where unusual or difficult circumstances exist in the determination of applicable requirements along project boundary lines, the stipulations which will apply shall be worked out cooperatively between the zoning administrator, the planning consultant, the village engineer and the developer at the time of preliminary submittal. 
(6)  Where a project boundary line abuts a district other than residential, the abutting yard shall be a minimum of 20 feet. 
(7)  Inside of project boundary areas. The yard requirements of the R-6 residential district shall apply to all single family and two family dwellings, and the requirements of the RM-2 multi-family residential district shall apply to all multi-family dwellings, unless unusual or difficult circumstances come to exist, then these requirements may be mitigated as in section 122-263. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(g); Ord. No. 256-O-04, § 1, 1-5-04) 
Sec. 122-266. - Open space. 
    The minimum open space per dwelling type shall be as follows: 
(1)  Single-family and two-family dwellings, as provided for in the R-6 residential district minimum lot and building areas. 
(2)  Multifamily dwellings and single-family attached dwellings (townhouses), as provided for in the RM-2 multifamily residential district regulations, including allowable reductions in lot area and open space based on the number of units as provided for in the RM-2 residential district regulations. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(h)) 
Sec. 122-267. - Parking. 
    The minimum number of parking stalls for a planned residential development shall be as follows: 
(1)  Off-street parking shall be provided for as required by subdivision II, division 4, article VII of this chapter. 
(2)  Except that for one bedroom units and studio apartments, the number of stalls per unit may be reduced to 1.5 stalls per dwelling unit. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(i)) 
Sec. 122-268. - Procedure to secure approval of project. 
(a)  Procedure to initiate. The following shall govern any request for the approval of a planned residential development: 
(1)  Prepetition conference. Prior to official submittal of a petition for consideration of a PRD project, the petitioner shall meet with the plan commission for a preliminary discussion as to the scope and nature of the proposed development. 
(2)  Petition. Following the preliminary consultation with the plan commission and upon receiving therefrom a favorable response, the plan commission shall give a conceptual preliminary approval, or it shall reject the proposal. Upon receiving a conceptual preliminary approval, a formal petition for a PRD project shall be submitted to the zoning administrator by the owner, or his agent, of the property proposed for such development and for the approval of a specific plan with a specified density factor under the provisions of the regulations of this subdivision. Such petition shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount established in subsection 42-122(c)(1), encompassed within the planned residential development, and the following information: 
a.  A statement describing the general character of the intended development and the desirability of applying the regulations of this PRD district on this particular site. This statement shall include: 
1.  Statistical data on total size of project area, area of open space, density computation and proposed number and types of residential units, economic analysis, market analysis, impact upon municipal services and any other similar data pertinent to a comprehensive evaluation of the proposed development. 
2.  The proposed timetable for the project development and completion. 
3.  A statement indicating the names of the principal officers of the development organization. 
4.  A general outline of intended organizational structure related to a property owner's association, deed restrictions and private provision of common services. 
b.  A general development plan of the proposed project showing the following information or such additional information as may be required by the plan commission or the village board: 
1.  An accurate map of the project area including its relationship to surrounding properties and adjoining streets. 
2.  The size, arrangement and location of all lots, blocks and of all proposed buildings or building groups. 
3.  The pattern of public roads, driveways and parking facilities for all dwelling units, and the intended design standards for each. 
4.  The type, size, height and location of all structures. 
5.  Preliminary architectural drawings and sketches illustrating the design and character of all proposed structures. 
6.  The location of recreational and open space areas and areas reserved or dedicated for use by the residents. 
7.  General landscape treatment, with particular attention given to the treatment and creation of a buffer zone between the proposed PRD and any adjacent development whether residential or otherwise. 
8.  The location of sanitary sewer and water facilities. 
9.  Existing topography and storm drainage pattern and proposed storm drainage system showing basic topographic changes and proposed grading elevations. 
(b)  Referral to plan commission. The zoning administrator shall, within 30 days after receipt of the petition, determine whether the petition fulfills the requirements of this chapter. If the zoning administrator determines that the petition is complete and fulfills the requirements of this chapter, he shall refer the petition to the plan commission. If the zoning administrator determines that the petition is not complete and does not fulfill the requirements of this chapter, he shall return the petition to the applicant. When the petition meets with the zoning administrator's approval, it shall be referred to the planning consultant, the village manager or designee and other appropriate village departments for their report and recommendations. Upon completion of necessary study and investigation, the plan commission shall make its recommendation to the village board, subject to the recommendations of the architectural control board, as to the appropriateness and desirability of the proposed project with the density factor requested, the suitability of the proposed development plans, and any changes or additional conditions applicable to such plans which it may feel necessary and appropriate. 
(c)  Referral to architectural control board. Following the recommendation of the plan commission, and prior to its being received by the village board, the petition shall be referred to the architectural control board for its recommendations. 
(d)  Basis for approval. The plan commission and the architectural control board, in making their recommendations, and the village board in making its determinations, shall give consideration to and be satisfied as to the following: 
(1)  That the proposed development is consistent with the spirit and intent of this chapter and would not be contrary to the general welfare and economic prosperity of the village, but rather that the benefits derived utilizing the most modern residential development techniques, justifies the resultant increase in density that the PRD district requirements provide, and is in keeping with current economic and social considerations and justifies the application of the PRD district requirements. 
(2)  That such development will create an attractive and satisfying residential environment of sustained desirability and economic stability beneficial to the village. 
(3)  That the plan will result in the preservation of open land in a manner which will enhance the total environmental setting and desirability of the development, and that adequate guarantee is provided for permanent retention as "open space" of the residual open land areas resulting from the application of the regulations of this subdivision, either by private preservation as an enhancement to the development, or by dedication to the municipality as determined by the village board. 
(4)  Ownership and tax liability of private open space reservation areas shall be established in a manner acceptable to the village board and made a part of the conditions of the specific plan approval. 
(5)  If the plan commission recommends to the village board that a particular PRD petition be denied, the plan commission shall enumerate in writing its reasons for denying the petition, and such listing of reasons shall accompany its recommendation to the village board. 
(e)  Determination. The village board, after due consideration, may deny the petition, approve the petition as submitted, or approve the petition subject to additional conditions. Such approval shall be by ordinance and shall constitute approval to permit this PRD for the specific project development plan proposed, and no other. The following requirements must be met: 
(1)  The approval of the petition for a planned residential development shall be based on and include as conditions thereto, the building, site and operations plans for the development as approved, as well as all other commitments offered or required as to project value, character or other factors, pertinent to an assurance that the proposed development will be carried out basically as presented in the official submittal plan. Detailed construction and engineering plans need not necessarily be completed at the time of petition submittal, but the approval of such preliminary plans are conditioned upon the subsequent submittal to and approval by the plan commission, the architectural control board and the village board of more specific and detailed plans as the development progresses, and no building permits shall be issued prior to such plan commission approval of the final detailed plans. 
(2)  The requirements of the subdivision control chapter respecting improvements shall be complied with by the developer unless specific modifications have been recommended by the village manager or designee. The village manager or designee is encouraged to accept modifications that will not adversely affect the health and safety of the residents, recognizing that excessive engineering requirements can seriously hamper the viability of a project. The village board shall be the sole judge as to the applicability of those provisions of the subdivision control chapter or any departmentally recommended modification relating to improvements after recommendation by the plan commission and appropriate municipal departments, if a question arises concerning their applicability to the project. 
(3)  The village board shall require the developer to furnish a bond, or an irrevocable letter of credit, to guarantee the completion of the infrastructure in such amount and containing such terms as shall be required by the village board. 
(4)  After the approval of the PRD by the village board, the developer shall, at the time of application for building permits, pay a zoning fee to the village clerk-treasurer as established in subsection 42-122(c)(2). 
(f)  Changes. Any subsequent changes or additions to an approved plan shall first be submitted for recommendation to the plan commission. The plan commission, after receiving recommendations from the architectural control board, when applicable, shall make its recommendation to the village board. If, in the opinion of the plan commission, such change or addition is substantial, it shall make its recommendation to the village board. Without limitation to the village board's right to determine any other change substantial, a change in any of the following respects may be construed to be as substantial: 
(1)  An increase of more than five percent in the total number of dwelling units from that shown in the approved project plan, i.e., a change in density. 
(2)  A significant change in the size, value of type of structures from that indicated in the approved project plan. 
(3)  The addition of any principal uses not included in the approved project plan. 
(4)  A change in the basic concept of the site development which would significantly alter detrimentally the relationship of uses or open space, either within the project or as it may affect adjoining properties. 
(g)  Compliance. Upon any question as to compliance of an approved PRD with the conditions and regulations as established in this subdivision and as made specifically applicable to such development, the appropriate responsible party shall be given at least 15 days' notice to appear before the plan commission to answer such charge of noncompliance. If the plan commission finds the charge substantiated and does not receive adequate assurance that the situation will be corrected within a reasonable time, as determined by the plan commission, it shall recommend to the village board appropriate action to secure compliance or to revoke the approval of the development plan. Upon such revocation, no building permits shall be issued within the project until approval has been reinstated in whole or in part. In the case of failure to resolve the problem or to complete the development for any reason, the village board may require revision of the development plan to whatever degree is deemed necessary to achieve modified development with consideration of the specific problems of adjustment to the surrounding neighborhood consistent with the spirit and intent of this chapter and of the original grant of the PRD approval. 
(h)  Transferability. The original grant of a PRD approval shall be nontransferable at any time between initial approval and total completion of the project without first obtaining the written consent of the village board which may require such proof of character and financial responsibility as it deems advisable. However, individually developed lots, or groups of buildings, may be sold outright or condominiumized at any time after initial approval, if fully in accordance with the approved plan. 
(Code 1963, § 17.033(8)(j)-(8)(q); Ord. No. 324-O-05, §§ 1-2, 11-7-05; Ord. No. 396-O-08, §§ 1-3, 4-7-08) 
Secs. 122-269-122-274. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Cluster Developments 

Sec. 122-275. - Conservation development district (CDD). 
(a)  Intent. The purpose of the CDD is to preserve natural resource areas and other large areas of open land, while permitting residential development at low densities, in an open space setting, located and designed to reduce the perceived intensity of development and provide privacy for dwellings. Specific objectives are as follows: 
(1)  To maintain and protect the village's character by preserving important landscape elements, including those areas containing unique and sensitive natural features such as woodlands, hedgerows, stream corridors, wetlands, floodplains, shorelands, steep slopes, critical species habitat, and natural areas by setting them aside from development. 
(2)  To allow single-family residential development on lots with private wells and sewage systems where it can be determined that the proposed development will not adversely affect water wells in the area. 
(3)  To minimize views of new development from existing streets. 
(4)  To provide for the unified and planned development of parcels 35 acres or larger in size for clustered, low density residential uses, incorporating large areas of permanently protected common space. 
(5)  To provide for greater design flexibility in the siting of dwellings and other development features than would be permitted by the application of standard district regulations in order to minimize the disturbance of rural landscape elements, scenic quality and overall aesthetic value of the landscape. 
(6)  To create groups of dwellings with direct visual and physical access to common open space. 
(7)  To permit active and passive recreational use of common open space. 
(8)  To reduce erosion and sedimentation by retaining existing vegetation and minimizing development on steep slopes. 
(9)  To permit various means for owning common open space and for protecting it from development in perpetuity. 
(10)  To create an attitude of stewardship, or caring, for the land within common open space by requiring a land management, or stewardship, plan for the common open space. 
(11)  To implement the objectives of the village's comprehensive plan. 
(b)  Principal uses. Principal uses in the CDD are as follows: 
(1)  Single-family residential uses. 
(2)  Open space uses, primarily passive in nature, including wildlife sanctuaries, forest preserves, nature centers, trails, picnic areas, and similar uses. 
(3)  Recreational facilities. 
(4)  Conservation of natural features in their existing state. 
(5)  Essential services, such as: 
a.  Water supply and sewerage facilities for individual lots, groups of lots, or the entire development. 
b.  Utility and street rights-of-way except that their land areas shall not count toward minimum open space requirement. 
c.  Parking areas where necessary to serve recreational facilities. 
(c)  Accessory uses. Accessory uses in the CDD are as follows: 
(1)  Attached and detached private garages and storage structures, provided that the total area of all accessory structures is less than 60 percent of the area of the principal structure. 
(2)  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, or vendors. 
(3)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
(d)  Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the CDD: 
(1)  Auto body repair or maintenance. 
(2)  Auto or small engine repair or maintenance. 
(3)  Regular deliveries by semitrailer truck. 
(4)  Group classes or schools, attended by nonresident persons, operated within single-family residential structures. 
(e)  Conditional uses. The following uses may be permitted with a conditional use permit in the CDD. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-566). Conditional use permits for home occupations may be issued for a specific time period, do not constitute a covenant running with the land and shall automatically terminate upon the sale or transfer of the property. 
(1)  Barber shops. 
(2)  Beauty shops. 
(3)  Insurance offices. 
(4)  Photographic studios. 
(5)  Home businesses that involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors or frequent (more than once a week) pickup or delivery, etc. 
(6)  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is the principal office of the professional's business. 
(7)  Other uses, not otherwise listed in this subsection (e), receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in a single-family residential district. 
(f)  Density and dimensional standards. The following standards shall apply within the CDD: 
Minimum Development Area 35 acres Maximum Density 1 dwelling unit per 3 net buildable acres Minimum Lot Area 1 acre Minimum Lot Width 200 feet Minimum Street Yard 75 feet Minimum Rear Yard Principal Structure 50 feet Accessory Structure > 120 square feet 30 feet Accessory Structure = 120 square feet 20 feet Minimum Side Yard Principal Structure 30 feet Accessory Structure > 120 square feet 20 feet Accessory Structure = 120 square feet 5 feet Minimum Common Open Space 40% of Development Area Maximum Height Principal Structure 42 feet Accessory Structure > 120 square feet 42 feet Accessory Structure = 120 square feet 15 feet  
(g)  Design standards. The following standards shall apply to all cluster groups: 
(1)  All dwelling units shall be grouped into cluster groups, which shall be adjacent to common open space. 
(2)  A plat may contain one or more cluster groups. 
(3)  Cluster groups shall be defined by the outer perimeter of contiguous lotted areas. 
(4)  The outer boundaries of each cluster group shall meet the separation distance requirements specified in subsection (h). 
(5)  Cluster groups shall be defined and separated by common open space in order to provide direct access to common open space and privacy to individual lot or yard areas. 
(6)  Cluster groups containing 11 or more dwelling units must provide a connection from the road to internal open space. 
a.  The open space shall have a minimum street frontage of 60 feet. 
(7)  Cluster groups shall be located to minimize the disturbance to woodlands, hedgerows, and individual mature trees. 
(h)  Separation distances for cluster groups. 
(1)  All separation areas for cluster groups along existing streets shall be landscaped in accordance with subsection (k), in order to block views of new residential development, preserve scenic views, and protect rural landscape character. 
(2)  The outer boundaries of all cluster groups shall conform to the following separation distances: 
a.  From existing or proposed arterial street rights-of-way: 100 feet. 
b.  From all perimeter subdivision boundaries: 50 feet. 
c.  From other cluster groups: 100 feet. 
d.  From active recreation areas, such as playgrounds, courts or playing fields: 100 feet. 
(3)  The separation distances from arterial streets may be reduced to no less than 50 feet if the applicant can demonstrate that existing vegetation and topography form an effective visual screen. 
(4)  All other separation distances may be reduced by 50 percent if the applicant can demonstrate to the satisfaction of the plan commission that such reduced setbacks improve the plan's compliance with the cluster group design standards in subsection (g), the intent of this subdivision, and the objectives of the village comprehensive plan. 
(i)  Calculation of site capacity. 
(1)  The calculation of site capacity, or the number of dwelling units permitted in a CDD, shall be based on net developable acreage. Net developable acreage shall be determined by subtracting the acreage of lands located in a floodplain and wetland from the gross acreage of the site. When the floodplain and wetland lands overlap, the overlapping acreage shall only be counted once. 
(2)  The maximum dwelling units permitted in a CDD shall be determined by dividing the net developable acreage by three, and rounding to the nearest whole number. 
(j)  Common open space. All common open space shall be a part of a larger continuous and integrated open space system within the parcel being developed. 
(1)  Common open space shall, to the greatest extent possible, protect primary and secondary environmental corridors, isolated natural resource areas, and other significant natural and cultural resources identified in the site inventory and analysis described in subsection (l). 
(2)  Natural features shall be maintained in their natural condition, but may be modified to improve their appearance, or restore their overall condition and natural processes, as recommended by a natural resource professional. 
(3)  All wetlands, floodplains, lowland environmental corridors, and slopes over 25 percent shall be contained in common open space. 
(4)  A minimum of 75 percent of upland primary environmental corridors shall be contained in common open space. 
(5)  The common open space shall maximize common boundaries with existing or future open space on adjacent lands, as shown in the village comprehensive plan. 
(6)  The boundaries of common open space shall be marked by natural features, such as hedgerows, edges of woodlands, streams, or individual large trees, wherever possible. Where no such natural demarcation exists, additional plantings, fences, or other landscape features should be added to enable residents or the public to distinguish where common open space ends and private lot areas begin. Where structural demarcations are used, they shall be the minimum needed to accomplish this objective. 
(7)  Trails located within 50 feet of homes shall be identified by plantings, fences, or other landscape features. 
(8)  Common open space shall be distributed appropriately throughout the development to properly serve and enhance all dwelling units, cluster groups and other common facilities. 
(9)  Safe and convenient pedestrian access, and access for maintenance purposes, shall be provided to common open space areas. 
(k)  Landscaping. 
(1)  For the purpose of conserving the natural landscape and in recognition of the time value of existing vegetation, the preservation of existing vegetation shall always be preferred to the installation of new plant material. 
(2)  A planted buffer area at least 25 feet in width shall be established between external streets and cluster groups to provide privacy. 
(l)  Inventory and site analysis. The following steps must be taken prior to the submission of a preliminary plat under chapter 94 of the Municipal Code. 
(1)  The submittal of a general "location map", showing vegetative cover, topography, soils, and floodplain information on the subject site and all lands within 2,000 feet. 
a.  This map shall be utilized to make decisions regarding the design of the interconnected open space network. 
(2)  An "existing resources and site analyses map", showing the primary and secondary environmental corridors, isolated natural resource areas, wetlands, floodplains, location of trees having a caliper greater than 12 inches, areas containing slopes greater than 25 percent, and historic and cultural resources such as farmhouses, barns, silos, wells, stone walls, trails and hedgerows. 
a.  This map shall be utilized to make decisions regarding the areas of land to be preserved as common open space. 
(3)  After the "location map" and "existing resources and site analysis map" are submitted, the applicant shall schedule a site walk with the director of community development or designee to observe the terrain and any natural or cultural features, and coordinate areas to preserve. 
(4)  After discussing layout issues with the village planning staff, a "sketch plan" shall be submitted showing preserved open space areas, trails, lot and road layouts, that conform with the requirements of section 122-275. 
(m)  Ownership and maintenance. To ensure adequate planning for ownership, operation, and maintenance of common open space, recreation facilities, stormwater management facilities, common parking areas and driveways, private streets, and other common or community facilities, the following regulations shall apply: 
(1)  Maintenance and operation of common facilities. 
a.  A plan and narrative for the use, maintenance, and insurance of all common facilities, including provisions for funding, shall be approved by the village board prior to final plat approval. This submittal shall: 
1.  Define ownership. 
2.  Establish necessary regular and periodic operation and maintenance responsibilities. 
3.  Estimate staffing needs, insurance requirements, and other associated costs and define the means for funding the same on an ongoing basis. 
b.  Each individual lot owner within the subdivision shall have an undividable fractional ownership in the common open space contained in the final plat. In the event that the association established to own and maintain the common areas and facilities, or any successor organization thereto, fails to properly maintain all or any portion of the aforesaid common areas or facilities, the village may serve written notice upon each individual lot owner within the subdivision setting forth the manner in which the association has failed to maintain the aforesaid common areas and facilities. Such notice shall set forth the nature of corrections required and the time within which the corrections shall be made. Upon failure to comply within the time specified, the association, any successor organization, or each individual lot owner within the subdivision, shall be considered in violation of this subdivision. In this case, the village shall have the right to enter the premises and take the needed corrective actions. The costs of corrective actions by the village shall be assessed against each individual lot owner within the subdivision. 
(2)  Conservation. Common open space shall be restricted in perpetuity from further subdivision and/or land development by deed restriction, conservation easement, or other agreement. 
(Ord. No. 573-O-13, § 4, 11-4-13) 
Secs. 122-276-122-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUSINESS DISTRICTS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Sec. 122-286. - C-1 neighborhood business district. 
(a)  Intent. This district is intended to provide for the development at appropriate locations of needed commercial services consisting primarily of retail stores, shops, offices and individual service establishments catering to the daily needs of the surrounding local community area. 
(b)  Principal uses. Retail, service, and office uses compatible with, but not limited to: antique shops; appliance stores; bakeries; barber and beauty shops; business offices; medical and dental clinics; clothing stores; confectioneries; craft supply stores; day care centers; delicatessens; department stores; doctors' offices; drug stores; depository and non-depository financial institutions without drive-in/through facilities; fish markets; florists; fruit stores; furniture stores; gift stores; grocery stores; hair styling salons; hardware stores; hobby shops; certified massage therapists; meat markets; music stores; nail salons; office supply stores; optical stores; photographic supply stores; offices, class "A" restaurants; self-service and pickup laundry; dry cleaning establishments without drive-in/through facilities; soda fountains; sporting goods stores; supermarkets; tanning studios; tobacco stores; variety stores; and vegetable stores. There shall be no outside storage. Waste containers, such as dumpsters, may be permitted when placed within a waste enclosure approved by the architectural control board. The outside display of merchandise is permitted during community wide promotional events. The temporary outside storage of merchandise may be permitted with a conditional use permit. 
(c)  Conditional uses. The following uses and/or structures require a conditional use permit. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial. 
(1)  The temporary outside storage of merchandise. 
(2)  Combined business and residential uses on the same lot or in the same building provided all residential uses shall comply with all provisions of the RM-1 residential district. 
(3)  Facilities for sales to the general public by auction. 
(4)  The uses permitted in sections 122-561 public and semi-public uses, and 122-566 recreational uses. 
(5)  Personal care service establishments other than: hair styling, barber and beauty shops, nail salons, certified massage therapists, and tanning shops, which are principal uses. 
(6)  Businesses that are permitted as principal uses in the C-1 district with drive-in, drive-up or drive-through facilities. 
(7)  Animal hospitals, animal clinics, animal shelters, kennels, and pet shops. 
(8)  Any establishment that is open for business for any period during the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 am. 
(9)  Any commercial building proposed to be constructed within 100 feet of the boundary line of a single-family residential zone. 
(10)  Other structures and/or uses, not otherwise listed herein, receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in the C-1 district. 
(d)  Overlay Zoning Districts. The OC-5 Commercial Service Overlay District or the PID Planned Infill Development Overlay Zoning District may be used in conjunction with the C-1 Neighborhood Business District, as described in section 122-290 or section 122-466 of the Municipal Code. 
(e)  Lot. 
(1)  Width-Minimum 110 ft. 
(2)  Area-Minimum 20,000 sq. ft. 
(f)  Building. All structures require approval of the building and site plans by the plan commission and architectural control board. 
(1)  Height-Maximum 35 ft. 
(2)  Area-Maximum 20,000 square feet gross floor area. 
(g)  Yards. 
(1)  Street-Minimum 30 ft. 
(2)  Rear-Minimum 30 ft. 
(3)  Side-Minimum 30 ft., except that no side yard will be required for simultaneously constructed buildings having common or adjoining wall construction when both buildings are entirely within this district, and in this instance there must be zero side yard. Accessibility to the side and rear yard of each structure for fire protection shall be in compliance with the requirements of the Wisconsin Administrative Code ILHR § 51 and § 54, and is obtained directly from a legally established public thoroughfare or all-weather hard surface area 30 feet or more in width that is accessible to fire fighting equipment. When a lot in this district adjoins a single-family residential district, the commercial use must provide a minimum of a 100-foot side or rear yard. A planting screen, approved by the architectural control board, 15 feet in depth and at least six feet high shall be placed within the commercial district along the district boundary. 
(h)  Lot coverage ratio. There shall be a maximum of 70 percent coverage of the lot area with impervious surfaces, including but not limited to the building foot print, parking lot, driveways, and sidewalks. A minimum of 30 percent of the lot area shall be greenspace and landscaped in accordance with a plan approved by the architectural control board. The landscape standards section 122-731 shall be used as a minimum requirement. Depending on plan approval jurisdiction, the plan commission, architectural control board, and/or the village board of trustees may require additional landscaping over and above the minimum requirements. 
(Code 1963, § 17.034; Ord. No. 82-O-00, § 1(17.034), 5-15-00; Ord. No. 289-O-04, § 1, 11-15-04; Ord. No. 356-O-07, §§ 1-3, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 403-O-08, § 1, 5-19-08; Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 12, 9-2-14; Ord. No. 631-O-15, §§ 1, 2, 10-19-15) 
Sec. 122-287. - C-2 community business district. 
(a)  Intent. This district is intended to provide for those retail, office, service, and residential facilities when combined with the retail office and/or service uses, described in the village centre master plan, adopted October 15, 1990, which allow for good pedestrian interrelationships with the existing uses and offer destinations for both commuter traffic and the local community trade area. Also, there are specific requirements and modifications for parts of the C-2 district in article V of this chapter. 
(b)  Principal uses. All uses permitted in the C-1 neighborhood business district. There shall be no outside storage. Waste containers, such as dumpsters, may be permitted when placed within a waste enclosure approved by the architectural control board. The outside display of merchandise is permitted during communitywide and/or village centre promotional events. 
(c)  Conditional uses. The following uses and/or structures require a conditional use permit. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial (section 122-536). 
(1)  Combined business and residential uses on the same lot or in the same building provided all residential uses shall comply with all the provisions of the RM-2 residential districts with the following exceptions: 
a.  Lot width and area may conform to the C-2 district requirements. 
b.  No apartments or residential living quarters may be on or below the ground level floor. 
c.  Open space requirements do not apply. 
(2)  The uses permitted in sections 122-561 public and semi-public uses, and 122-566 recreational uses. 
(3)  The temporary outside storage of merchandise. 
(4)  Facilities for sales to the general public by auction. 
(5)  Personal care service establishments other than: hair styling, barber and beauty shops, nail salons, certified massage therapists; and tanning shops that are permitted uses. 
(6)  Businesses that are permitted as principal uses in the C-2 district with drive-in, drive-up, or drive-through facilities. 
(7)  Animal hospitals; clinics; shelters; kennels; or pet shops. 
(8)  Any establishment that is open for business, for any period, during the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 am. 
(9)  Other structures and/or uses receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in the C-2 district. 
(d)  Overlay Zoning Districts. The OC-5 Commercial Service Overlay District or the PID Planned Infill Development Overlay Zoning District may be used in conjunction with the C-2 Community Business District, as described in section 122-290 or section 122-466 of the Municipal Code. 
(e)  Lot. 
(1)  Width: Minimum 40 ft. 
(2)  Area: 6,400 sq. ft. 
(f)  Building. All structures shall meet the requirements of the O-VC village centre overlay district (art. V, div. 2) where applicable. All structures require the approval of the building and site plans by the plan commission and architectural control board. 
(1)  Height: Maximum 120 ft. 
(2)  Area: Maximum 20,000 square feet gross first floor area 
(g)  Yards. 
(1)  Street: Minimum, no restrictions. 
(2)  Rear: Minimum, no restrictions. 
(3)  Side: Minimum 10 ft. 
Exception: No side yard will be required for simultaneously constructed buildings having common or adjoining wall construction when both buildings are entirely within this district, and in this instance there must be zero side yard. Accessibility to the side and rear yard of each structure for fire protection shall be in compliance with the requirements of the Wisconsin Administrative Code ILHR § 51 and § 54, Fire and is obtained directly from a legally established public thoroughfare or all-weather hard surface area 30 feet or more in width that is accessible to fire fighting equipment. When a lot in this district adjoins a single-family residential district, the commercial use must provide a minimum of a 100-foot side or rear yard. A planting screen, approved by the architectural control board, 15 feet in depth and at least six feet high shall be placed along the district boundary. 
(h)  Lot coverage ratio. There shall be a maximum of 80 percent coverage of the lot area with impervious surfaces, including but not limited to the building foot print, parking lot, driveways, and sidewalks. A minimum of 20 percent of the lot area shall be greenspace and landscaped in accordance with a plan approved by the architectural control board. The landscape standards section 122-731 shall be used as a minimum requirement. Depending on plan approval jurisdiction, the plan commission, architectural control board, and/or the village board of trustees may require additional landscaping over and above the minimum requirements. 
(Code 1963, § 17.034; Ord. No. 82-O-00, § 1(17.034), 5-15-00; Ord. No. 356-O-07, §§ 4-6, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 403-O-08, § 2, 5-19-08; Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 13, 9-2-14; Ord. No. 631-O-15, § 3, 10-19-15) 
Sec. 122-288. - C-3 planned development district. 
(a)  Declaration of intent. It is the intent of this ordinance to regulate development standards in the C-3 planned development district, and to create the specific planned development district (PDD). Specific objectives are as follows: 
(1)  Encourage development of a retail, service, office, housing, public facilities, open space, and recreational uses interwoven within a neighborhood. 
(2)  Provide employment and housing centers that have accessibility to major roads and office and industrial centers within the community. 
(3)  Encourage the location of residential and commercial uses within proximity to one another. 
(4)  Encourage the location of office and commercial structures within proximity to one another. 
(5)  Provide a single architectural scheme with appropriate landscaping and open space. 
(6)  Prohibit incongruous architectural styles, excessive buildings or excessive impervious ground coverage. 
(7)  Encourage well-integrated, well-designed office, retail, and residential developments, which provide amenities and services for employees and residents in the area. 
(8)  Encourage the creation of public spaces, such as squares, plaza, greens, boulevards, landscaped streets, preserves, greenbelts, and parks woven in to the pattern of the neighborhood, integrated with the stormwater management plan for the neighborhood, and dedicated to the collective social activity, recreation, and visual enjoyment of the populace. 
(9)  Creation of neighborhoods that are limited in size and oriented toward pedestrian activity. 
(10)  Provide a network of interconnecting streets and blocks that maintains respect for the topography. 
(11)  Provide a coordinated transportation system with a hierarchy of appropriately designed facilities for pedestrians, bicycles, and automotive vehicles 
(12)  Protect abutting residential districts from adverse visual and traffic impacts by encouraging development with an appearance that complements the existing development pattern. 
(13)  Encourage pedestrian connections throughout the district and adjacent areas. 
(14)  The size and location of projects within the district shall be based upon such factors as satisfactory traffic impact, satisfactory municipal services and its potential contribution to the welfare of the community. 
(b)  Components of a planned development district. 
(1)  Development size. A planned development district shall not be smaller than 20 gross acres. The planned development district shall not be more than 640 acres. 
(2)  Infrastructure and open space in a planned development district. 
a.  Streets and other infrastructure. A planned development district is designed to be pedestrian oriented. To accomplish this goal, street pattern and design is used to reduce vehicle travel speeds and encourage pedestrian activity. Interconnected network of streets with hierarchy of streets is required. Traffic calming techniques and other design components are encouraged. The integration of stormwater management features such as infiltration areas, and permeable surfacing along buildings is encouraged outside of the village rights-of-way. Streets may be smaller than in conventional development and more varied in size and form to control traffic and give character to the neighborhood. Infrastructure may be public or private, as determined in the review process. 
b.  Open space. Open space is a significant part of a planned development district. Formal and informal open spaces are required. These serve as areas for community gatherings, landmarks, and as organizing elements for the neighborhood. Open space includes squares, plazas, greens, preserves, parks, greenbelts, boulevards, etc. Open space shall be located in each area, and each open space area shall be connected to one another by some linking open space element, for example a preserve linked by a boulevard to an elementary school playground. 
(3)  Areas within the planned development district (PDD). A PDD shall be divided into at least two types of areas, and each type of area shall have different land uses and site development regulations. A PDD may have a neighborhood center area, mixed residential area, neighborhood edge area, or a workshop area. These areas are defined as follows: 
a.  Neighborhood center area. A neighborhood center area serves as the focal point of a planned development district, containing retail, commercial, civic, and public services to meet the daily needs of community residents. A neighborhood center is pedestrian oriented, and it is designed to encourage pedestrian movement, between a mixed use residential area and a neighborhood center area. A square is required in a neighborhood center area. Retail and commercial uses should generally be located adjacent to a square. 
b.  Mixed residential area. A mixed residential area includes a variety of residential land uses including single-family residential, duplex, townhouse and multi-family. A mixed residential area includes open space including small squares, pocket parks, community parks, and greenbelts. A mixed residential area promotes pedestrian activity through well-designed and varied streetscapes that also provide for the safe and efficient movement of vehicular traffic. 
c.  Neighborhood edge area. A neighborhood edge area is the least dense portion of a planned development district, with larger lots and greater setbacks than the rest of the neighborhood. A neighborhood edge area is appropriate along the perimeter the neighborhood. A portion of a planned development district that adjoins existing or platted conventional suburban density housing must be designed as a neighborhood edge area. 
d.  Workshop area. A planned development district may have a workshop area. Commercial and light industrial used that are not appropriate for a neighborhood center area or a mixed residential area, but which serve the local residents may be located in workshop area. Large office use may be also be located within a workshop area. The scale and architectural conventions of a planned development district apply to a workshop area. 
(4)  Uses. No use shall be permitted in the C-3 planned development district except when in conformance with a specific and precise development plan pursuant to the procedural and regulatory provisions herein set forth. 
a.  Neighborhood center area uses. 
1.  Permitted uses. 
i.  Retail shops 
ii.  Restaurants without drive-though facilities 
iii.  Personal and professional services 
iv.  Banks without drive-through 
v.  Hotels 
vi.  Community centers 
vii.  Professional offices 
2.  Accessory uses. 
i.  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
ii.  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
3.  Conditional uses. The following uses and/or structures require a conditional use permit. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial. 
i.  The temporary outside storage of merchandise. 
ii.  Combined business and residential uses on the same lot or in the same building provided all residential uses shall comply with all provisions of the RM-1 residential district. 
iii.  Facilities for sales to the general public by auction. 
iv.  The uses permitted in sections 122-561, public and semi-public uses, and 122-566, recreational uses. 
v.  Personal care service establishments other than: hair styling, barber and beauty shops, nail salons, certified massage therapists, and tanning shops, which are principal uses. 
vi.  Animal hospitals; animal clinics; animal shelters; kennels; and pet shops. 
vii.  Any establishment that is open for business for any period during the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
viii.  Those uses listed in subsection 122-367(b). 
ix.  Other structures and/or uses, not otherwise listed herein, receiving a positive recommendation from the plan commission and approved by the village board of trustees as being specifically appropriate in the C-3 district. 
b.  Mixed residential area uses. 
1.  Permitted uses. 
i.  Residential dwelling units comprised of single family, duplex, and multi-family buildings with less than seven dwelling units. Residential dwelling units shall include an enclosed garage space for each dwelling unit. 
ii.  Professional offices. 
2.  Accessory uses. 
i.  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
ii.  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
3.  Conditional uses. 
i.  Buildings used exclusively for residential purposes that contain seven or more dwelling units. 
ii.  Those uses listed in section 122-367(b). 
c.  Neighborhood edge area uses. 
1.  Permitted uses. 
i.  Single-family homes. 
ii.  Duplexes. 
2.  Accessory uses. 
i.  Home occupations that do not involve the coming and going of customers, clients, vendors, etc. 
ii.  Professional home offices where a portion of a residence of a professional is used to assist in conducting their profession and is not the principal office of the professional's business. 
d.  Workshop area uses. 
1.  Permitted uses. 
i.  Corporate and divisional headquarters. 
ii.  Administrative, business and professional offices. 
iii.  Banks and finance companies. 
iv.  Public buildings intended for general public utilization including meeting rooms, community centers and libraries. 
v.  Data processing centers. 
vi.  Laboratories and facilities for research, testing or consulting. 
vii.  Production or assembly of prototype products, or assembly of high technology products. 
viii.  Manufacturing, processing, fabrication, packing, packaging and assembly of products with machinery or equipment wholly enclosed within a building, which building shall be compatible with and shall have an exterior appearance, including rooftop areas and rooflines compatible with first class corporate and professional offices. 
ix.  The production or assembly of computer, photographic, medical and optical products and equipment. 
x.  Indoor storage for wholesale transshipment, future use or safekeeping of materials. 
xi.  Class "A" restaurants. 
2.  Accessory uses. The following shall be permitted in the C-3 district, but only where the applicable use is located within a building specifically permitted in the workshop area. 
i.  Medical or dental clinic. 
ii.  Private noncommercial club or lodge. 
iii.  Barber and beauty shops. 
iv.  Medical or dental laboratory. 
v.  Travel agencies. 
vi.  Telephone answering service, delivery service, and copying service. 
vii.  Class "A" restaurants. 
viii.  Day care facilities. 
3.  Conditional uses. The following uses and structures require a conditional use permit. Requests for conditional use permits are considered by the village board of trustees after receiving a recommendation from the plan commission. The issuance of a conditional use permit is entirely at the village board of trustee's discretion and is, therefore, subject to denial. 
i.  The uses permitted in sections 122-561(2) and (3), 122-563(3), 122-566(2), 122-567 and 122-367(b). 
ii.  Class "B" restaurants. 
iii.  Commercial hotels or motels. 
iv.  Day care facilities. 
v.  Outside storage of any kind. All outdoor material permitted under a conditional use must be completely screened from the street and all abutting properties. The vision screen shall be a minimum of six feet high and approved by the architectural control board. 
(c)  Approval procedure. The approvals of a planned development district shall be as follows: 
Step One: Pre-application conference. 
Step Two: Conceptual development plan review. 
Step Three: Preliminary development plan review. 
Step Four: Master development plan review. 
Step Five: Precise implementation plan review. 
(1)  Pre-application conference. 
a.  The applicant shall contact the planning department to schedule a meeting with representatives of the engineering, public works, planning and zoning departments to discuss the concepts of the proposal. Appropriate topics for discussion may include the location of the project, general project themes and images, the general mix of dwelling unit types and/or business, institutional, and/or workshop uses being considered, approximate residential densities and non-residential intensities, the general treatment of natural features, the general approach to stormwater management, landscaping and trees, amenities such as pocket parks or public plazas or greenbelts, street and alley patterns, and the general relationship to nearby properties and relationship to the adopted comprehensive master plan. Points of discussion and conclusions reached in this stage of the process shall be in no way be binding upon the applicant or the village, but should be considered as the informal, non-binding basis for proceeding to the next step. 
(2)  Conceptual development plan review. 
a.  Purpose and intent: The purpose of a conceptual development plan review is: 
1.  To provide direction to the developer. 
2.  To provide an opportunity to discuss, and options for, the proposed development. 
3.  To provide the plan commission with information necessary to determine the relative merits of the project in regard to private benefits versus public benefit, and in regard to the mitigation of potential adverse impacts created by the design. 
b.  Developments requiring review. All developments require a conceptual review. 
c.  Basic requirements. The developer shall submit all of the following items. 
1.  A location map of the subject property and its vicinity 
2.  Six copies of the concept plan, at a 1? = 20' scale, consisting of the general land use layout and general location of major public streets and or private drives. 
3.  One copy of a reduced concept plan submitted on 11-inch by 17-inch paper. 
4.  The general location and mix of neighborhood centers, mixed residential areas, neighborhood edge areas, and workshop areas. 
5.  Approximate residential densities, and non-residential intensities as described by dwelling units per net developable acre, maximum store unit sizes, floor area ratio, and impervious surface area ratio. 
6.  The general treatment of existing and proposed features including the location of wetlands, stormwater management features, landscaped areas, floodplains, parks, plazas, and greenbelts. An open space diagram or similar drawing is appropriate. 
7.  The general location and width of streets, pedestrian amenities and the location of vehicular parking areas. 
8.  The general location of bikeways and pedestrian circulation systems; 
9.  The general relationship to nearby properties and public streets; 
10.  The general relationship of the project to all adopted plans; 
11.  An initial draft list of the major concepts to be considered in the development code as required in subsection (e). 
12.  A receipt showing the preliminary development review fee, contained in Chapter 42 of the Municipal Code, has been paid. 
13.  Other information when required by village departments.
