The plan commission shall conduct any such public hearing in the same manner as would be conducted under section 122-539 of this chapter. 
(4)  Village board. Upon receipt of the recommendation of the village plan commission, the petition, and all information received, including the minutes of the public hearing if one was held, the village board shall in its sole discretion either grant the petition as requested, or grant the petition as modified, or deny the petition. The village board may impose conditions upon any grant of a petition for adjustment, such as additional landscaping, architectural design, type of construction, fencing, planting screen, and such other requirements as may be necessary to fulfill the purpose of this chapter. 
(5)  Acceptance. Any conditions that may be imposed upon the grant of an adjustment to the yard requirements shall be accepted by the petitioner and the property owner in writing. 
(6)  Recording. The grant of the adjustment and any conditions imposed shall be recorded against the affected property in the office of the Waukesha County Register of Deeds prior to the adjustment being effective, and upon recording shall run with the land. 
(Ord. No. 173-O-02, § 3, 2-18-02) 
Sec. 122-625. - Adjustments to height requirements in C and I districts. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to allow adjustments of up to twice the otherwise applicable height limitations in business (C) and industrial (I) districts where appropriate on a case-by-case basis as determined by the plan commission, after considering a recommendation from the architectural control board. 
(b)  Adjustments. In all business (C) and industrial (I) districts, the maximum height requirements may be increased on a case-by-case basis by the plan commission to not more than two times the otherwise applicable requirement, as follows: 
(1)  Petition. Any business (C) or industrial (I) property owner in the village may request an adjustment to the height requirement of their lot by filing for an adjustment with the department of community development. The application shall include the name and address of the applicant; the address of the property; the legal description of the property; the extent of the requested exception; and payment of the required fee set out in Chapter 42 of this Code. Additional information may also be required by the village plan commission, village architectural control board, or village staff. 
(2)  Architectural control board. Upon receipt of such application, the department of community development shall refer the matter to the architectural control board. The architectural control board shall consider among other things, the character of the neighborhood where the exception would be made, the peculiar suitability of the location for particular uses, the impact if any that the adjustment would have upon adjoining properties, and with a view to conserving the value of buildings and encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the village. The architectural control board shall consider the petition and all related information and make a written recommendation to the village plan commission that the petition be granted as requested, or as modified, or that the petition be denied. The architectural control board may recommend such conditions as additional landscaping, architectural design, type of construction, fencing, planting screen, and such other requirements as may be necessary to fulfill the purpose of this chapter. 
(3)  Public hearing. Upon receipt of the recommendation of the village architecture control board, the village plan commission shall consider if a public hearing should be held. Unless the plan commission votes unanimously to waive the requirement of a public hearing, a public hearing shall be scheduled. Upon such request, the matter shall be set for public hearing and such persons shall be notified of any public hearing as the plan commission may direct. The plan commission shall conduct any such public hearing in the same manner as would be conducted under section 122-539 of this chapter. 
(4)  Action. The plan commission in its sole discretion shall either grant the petition as requested, or grant the petition as modified, or deny the petition. The plan commission may impose conditions upon any grant of a petition for adjustment, such as additional landscaping, architectural design, type of construction, fencing, planting screen, and such other requirements as may be necessary to fulfill the purpose of this chapter. 
(5)  Acceptance. Any conditions that may be imposed upon the grant of an adjustment to the height requirements shall be accepted by the petitioner and the property owner in writing. 
(6)  Recording. The grant of the adjustment and any conditions imposed shall be recorded against the affected property in the office of the Waukesha County Register of Deeds prior to the adjustment being effective, and upon recording, shall run with the land. 
(Ord. No. 173-O-02, § 4, 2-18-02) 
Secs. 122-626-122-640. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - GENERAL USE RESTRICTIONS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 122-641. - Principal uses. 
    Only the principal uses specified, their essential services, and the uses specified in this division shall be permitted in any district. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(1)) 
Sec. 122-642. - Conditional uses. 
    Conditional uses and their accessory uses are considered as special uses requiring review, public hearing if the plan commission so determines, and approval by the village plan commission in accordance with article VI of this chapter. Public hearings and notice shall be in accordance with regulations set forth in division 2, article II of this chapter, except that publication of the notice need be only two times prior to the hearing and within only ten days prior to the hearing, and property owners within 300 feet of the proposed conditional use shall also be notified by mail within ten days prior to such hearing. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(3)) 
Sec. 122-643. - Unclassified or unspecified uses. 
    Any use not specifically listed as a permitted use shall be considered to be prohibited except as may be otherwise specifically provided in this division. In case of a question as to the classification of a use, the question shall be submitted to the plan commission for determination. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(4)) 
Sec. 122-644. - Additional requirements. 
    Any use, in any district which becomes hazardous, harmful, noxious, offensive or a nuisance to the surrounding neighborhood, may be required to be corrected or improved by such measures as are directed by the village board consistent with reasonable technological and economic practicality. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(5)) 
Sec. 122-645. - Temporary uses. 
    Temporary uses, such as real estate sales field offices or shelters for materials and equipment being used in the construction of a permanent structure, shall be permitted upon a finding that such use is not contrary to the intent of the chapter. Such permit shall be valid for a period of six months and may be renewable for six-month periods. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(6)) 
Sec. 122-646. - Unenclosed storage of recreation vehicles. 
(a)  One recreational vehicle, without habitation, may be stored unenclosed in a single family district or planned residential development district. 
(b)  In addition to a recreational vehicle permitted under subsection (a) above, parcels located within the R-1 Single Family Residential District, R-2 Single Family Residential District, or PRD Planned Residential Development District - and classified for a density of two dwelling units per acre or less in the village comprehensive plan - may store one additional unenclosed recreational vehicle without habitation. 
(c)  In addition to the applicable requirements of this section, all unenclosed recreational vehicles shall be: 
(1)  Well maintained, licensed and operable. 
(2)  Owned by a person residing on the parcel. 
(3)  Located in an area free of litter as defined in section 18-371. 
(4)  Located in an area free of tall grass, weeds, or other factors creating a public nuisance as described in section 38-24. 
(5)  Stored without tarps or covers other than those tarps or covers specifically designed for the recreational vehicle. 
(6)  Less than 35 feet in length. 
(7)  Meet the following setbacks. 
a.  Street. The recreational vehicle shall be stored in a location meeting the minimum street yard setback for principal uses in the zoning district the recreational vehicle is stored in. 
1.  Exception for corner lots. For corner lots, the recreational vehicle is set back a minimum of five feet from the street yard that does not have driveway access. If the recreational vehicle exceeds five feet in height, the minimum setback from the street yard that does not have driveway access shall be increased to the height of the recreational vehicle plus five feet. 
b.  Rear. Minimum five feet. 
c.  Side. Minimum of five feet, however if the recreational vehicle exceeds five feet in height, and abuts another residential use, the minimum setback from the side lot line shall be increased to the height of the recreational vehicle plus five feet. 
(d)  No recreational vehicle may be stored unenclosed in any multi-family residential, business, or public and semi-public zoning districts. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(7); Ord. No. 677-O-16, § 2, 9-19-16; Ord. No. 716-O-18, § 3, 4-16-18) 
Sec. 122-647. - Standard garage space. 
    No single-family dwelling shall be hereafter erected, structurally altered or relocated unless: 
(1)  The building plans for such dwelling include private garage space to accommodate two motor vehicles as an integral part thereof or by a contemporaneously erected permanent accessory structure; or 
(2)  It is shown that the size and shape of the lot, and the size, shape and placement of structures built thereon are in such a relation as to permit later erection of an attached or detached private garage (accommodating two motor vehicles) without violation of any law or chapter. 
(3)  If the alternative plan as outlined in subsection (2) of this section is followed, an affidavit bearing the signature of the homeowner must be filed with the occupancy permit application indicating the owner's understanding of the requirements of subsection (2) and indicating that his eventual garage construction will be in conformance with all zoning requirements. 
(4)  Any future garage construction shall be of such architectural style as to be in general conformity with the architectural style of the existing or proposed building. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(8); Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 1, 4-18-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 1, adopted April 18, 2005, amended the title of section 122-647 to read as herein set out. Formerly, said title pertained to dwellings on lots without standard garage space. 
Sec. 122-648. - Utility lines, poles and towers. 
    Except as provided in chapter 94 of this Code, overhead and underground electric and/or telephone or communication lines are permitted uses in any district; provided, however, that when a utility proposes a main intermunicipal transmission facility, such utility shall give notice to the plan commission of such intention and of the date of hearing before the public service commission if such hearing is required. Before beginning construction of a specific route, the utility shall file with the plan commission a mapped description of the route of such transmission line for approval. Poles, towers, including wires, manholes and/or underground conduit and cable, and/or their appurtenances installed by a utility, shall not be deemed to be principal uses or structures as defined by this chapter; however, all pad-mounted transformers and pedestals shall be located as provided in section 95-155 of the Municipal Code. No zoning permit shall be required for facilities covered by this provision as recited under sections 122-36, 122-38 and division 1, article VII of this chapter. No occupancy permit shall be required for facilities covered by this section as recited under section 122-39. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(9); Ord. No. 661-O-16, § 1, 4-4-16) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 110. 
Sec. 122-649. - Adult-oriented establishments. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult bookstore means an establishment having as a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, for sale, rent, lease, inspection or viewing, books, films, video cassettes, magazines or other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matters depicting, describing or related to "specific anatomical areas" as defined in this section, or an establishment with a segment or section devoted to the sale and display of such material. 
    Adult cabaret means a cabaret which features topless dancers, strippers, male or female impersonators, or similar entertainers. 
    Adult entertainment means any exhibition of any motion pictures, live performance, display or dance of any type, which has as its dominant theme, or is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on, any actual or simulated "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas." 
    Adult-oriented establishment means, but is not limited to, "adult bookstores," "adult motion picture theaters," "adult minimotion picture establishments," or "adult cabarets." It further means any premises to which public patrons or members are invited or admitted and which are so physically arranged so as to provide booths, cubicles, rooms, compartments or stalls separate from the common areas of the premises for the purposes of viewing adult-oriented motion pictures, or wherein an entertainer provides adult entertainment to a member of the public, a patron or a member, whether or not such adult entertainment is held, conducted, operated or maintained for a profit, direct or indirect. 
    Adult minimotion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of less than 50 persons used for presenting material having as its dominant theme, or distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on, matters depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons used for presenting materials distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on, matters depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," for observation by patrons therein. 
    Specified anatomical areas means less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region, buttocks and female breasts below the point immediately above the top of the areola. 
(b)  Location of adult-oriented establishments. 
(1)  Adult-oriented establishments are prohibited in all districts except C-1 and C-2 districts. 
(2)  In C-1 and C-2 districts, adult-oriented establishments shall not locate within 1,000 feet of any residential zone, any public or private school, church, religious institution, or any public park, and shall not locate within 500 feet of any other adult-oriented establishment. 
(c)  Standards of measurement. The distance provided in this section shall be measured in a straight line without regard to intervening structures or objects from the closest point of the structure or portion of the structure occupied or proposed for occupancy by the adult-oriented establishment to the nearest point of the parcel of property or land use district boundary relined from which the proposed land use is to be separated. 
(d)  Conformance with this chapter. In all zones where adult-oriented establishments are permitted, all regulations and requirements of this chapter must be met. Additionally, all provisions of the zoning district in which the establishment is located must also be met. 
    Specified sexual activities means simulated or actual: 
(1)  Showing of human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
(2)  Acts of masturbation, sexual intercourse, sodomy, bestiality, necrophilia, sadomasochistic abuse, fellatio or cunnilingus; 
(3)  Fondling or erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breasts. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(10)) 
Cross reference- Adult oriented establishments, § 22-21 et seq. 
Sec. 122-650. - Community living arrangements. 
(a)  Community living arrangements, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 46.03(22), are principal uses and conditional uses in the zoning districts specified in this division, and shall be subject to all procedures, requirements and conditions of this chapter which are applicable to the principal uses and conditional uses in the zoning districts specified in this division, and shall be subject to all requirements of Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7)(i). 
(b)  Community living arrangements for one to eight persons are principal uses in all residential districts in the village and in the institutional district P-2. 
(c)  Community living arrangements for nine to 15 persons are principal uses in the residential districts RM-1, RM-2, the planned residential district (PRD), and in the institutional district P-2; and are conditional uses in the residential districts R-1, R-2, R-3.5, R-4, R-5, and R-6. 
(d)  Community living arrangements for 16 or more persons are conditional uses in all residential districts in the village and in the institutional district P-2. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(11)) 
State Law reference- Community living arrangements, foster homes, treatment foster homes and adult family homes as allowable uses, Wis. Stats. §§ 61.35, 62.23(7)(i). 
Sec. 122-651. - Outdoor lighting. 
    All public and private outdoor lighting installed in the Village of Menomonee Falls shall be in conformance with the requirements established by this section. 
(1)  Control of glare; luminaire design factors. 
(a)  Any luminaire rated greater than or equal to 1,800 lumens and all flood or spot luminaires shall not emit any direct light above a horizontal plane through the lowest direct light-emitting part of the luminaire. 
(b)  Any luminaire rated greater than or equal to 1,800 lumens shall be mounted at a height equal to or less than the value 3 + (D/3), where D is the distance in feet to the nearest property boundary. The maximum height of the luminaire may not exceed 25 feet. 
(2)  Exceptions. 
(a)  Any luminaire with a lamp or lamps rated less than 1,800 lumens may be used without restriction to light distribution or mounting height, except that if any spot or flood luminaire rated 900 lumens or less is aimed, directed or focused so as to cause direct light from the luminaire to be directed toward residential buildings on adjacent or nearby land or to create glare perceptible to persons operating motor vehicles on public ways, the luminaire shall be redirected or its light output controlled as necessary to eliminate such conditions. 
(b)  All luminaires for public street lighting required by federal, state, county or village authorities. 
(c)  All luminaires intended for lighting of athletic fields owned by the village, county, and non profit organization. 
(d)  All temporary emergency lighting needed by the police department, the fire department or other emergency services, as well as all vehicular luminaires, shall be exempt from the requirements of this article. 
(e)  All hazard warning luminaires required by federal regulatory agencies are exempt from the requirements of this article, except that all luminaires used must be red and must be shown to be as close as possible to the federally required minimum lumen output requirement for the specific task. 
(f)  Luminaires used primarily for sign illumination may be mounted at any height to maximum of 15 feet regardless of lumen rating. 
(g)  Temporary outdoor lighting may be allowed if it can be found that the intent of this chapter is in conformance with, and after considering the following: 
1.  The public and/or private benefits that will result from the temporary lighting; 
2.  Any annoyance or safety problems that may result from the use of the temporary lighting; 
3.  The duration of the temporary lighting. 
(h)  As to luminaries for parking facilities, an applicant may petition to the department of community development to allow higher mounting height than otherwise allowed herein. The application shall include two photometric plans, one showing the lighting that would exist if the literal requirements of this chapter were followed, and the second showing the lighting that would exist if the requested exception were granted. Upon considering such application, the village plan commission, in its sole discretion, may grant the petition if it is found to be in conformance with the intent of this chapter, and upon consideration of the following: 
(1)  The public and/or private benefits that will result from such higher mounting height. 
(2)  Any annoyance or safety problems that may result with or without such higher mounting height. 
(3)  The intended uses of the parking facility, and times of day that the parking facility would be used. 
(4)  The security of persons and property in the parking facility. 
(5)  The impact that the higher mounting height would have upon the architectural design and aesthetic appearance of the building to which it is associated. 
If the plan commission grants the request, the applicant shall present written proof of the same with the application required by subsection (3), below. 
(i)  Specialty lighting. 
1.  All luminaries and lighting standards within the Village Centre Overlay District shall comply with subsection 122-447(m) of the Municipal Code. 
2.  All luminaries and lighting standards within the Planned Development District No. 2 shall comply with section 122-0026 of the Municipal Code. 
(3)  Application requirements. 
(a)  Temporary lighting. The applicant shall submit a detailed description of the proposed temporary lighting to the department of community development. 
1.  Survey. Current survey by a licensed land surveyor showing lot lines, existing buildings, existing site features, and the proposed location of the temporary lighting. 
2.  Specifications. A set of lighting specifications including information pertaining to the lighting fixture, luminaires, lamp, and any other specifications that the department of community development may determine is necessary for review. 
(b)  Permanent lighting. The applicant shall submit a detailed description of the proposed lighting to the department of community development. 
1.  Survey. Current survey by a licensed land surveyor showing lot lines, existing buildings, existing site features, and the proposed location of the lighting. 
2.  Reserved. 
3.  Specifications. A set of lighting specifications including information pertaining to the lighting fixture, luminaires, lamp, and any other specifications that the department of community development may determine is necessary for review. 
(4)  Nonconforming luminaires. All luminaires in place prior to the date of this section shall be considered an existing nonconforming luminaire. However, any luminaire that replaces an existing nonconforming luminaire, or any existing nonconforming luminaire that is moved, must meet the standards of this section. 
(Ord. No. 67-O-00, § 1(17.050), 1-17-00; Ord. No. 173-O-02, §§ 5, 6, 2-18-02; Ord. No. 353-O-06, § 21, 11-20-06) 
Secs. 122-652-122-665. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Accessory Uses 

Sec. 122-666. - Permitted in all districts; conditions. 
    Accessory uses and structures are permitted in any district but not until the principal structure is present or under construction. Residential accessory uses shall not involve the conduct of any business, trade or industry, except as provided for under the district regulations where household occupations or professional home offices are allowed. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(2)) 
Sec. 122-667. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 173-O-02, § 7, adopted Feb. 18, 2002, repealed § 122-667 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to outdoor lighting installations as adopted by the 1963 Code. 
Sec. 122-668. - Game courts. 
    Game courts shall not be permitted closer than five feet to an abutting property line and shall be screened from view of adjoining property by adequate landscaping or architectural screen or combination thereof. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(2)(b)) 
Sec. 122-669. - Fences, walls and screening devices. 
    Fences, walls and other architectural screening devices, when anchored to supports imbedded in the ground, shall be considered permanent structures and shall be subjected to the following: 
(1)  Any such structure, not in excess of 41/2 feet in height, may be permitted anywhere on the lot consistent with other standards set out in section 122-670. 
(2)  Any such structure in excess of 41/2 feet in height may be placed anywhere on the lot except that in residential districts such structure shall be constructed no closer to the base setback line than a distance equal to 11/2 times the minimum street yard setback required in the district in which the structure is located. In commercial or industrial districts such structures shall be no closer to the base setback line than the minimum street yard setback required in the district in which the structure is located. 
(3)  No such structure (excepting open fences) shall be permitted in the vision setback area if it exceeds a height of three feet above the elevation of the center of the intersection referred to in section 122-604. 
(4)  Except as set forth in subsection (3) of this section, the height of such structure shall be the vertical distance measured from the top of the structure to the approved grade level, at the point of measurement, of the lot in which it is located. If the fence is to be constructed on a berm, the allowable vertical height of the fence shall include the height of the berm plus the height of the fence. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(2)(c); Ord. No. 197-O-02, § 2, 4-16-02) 
Sec. 122-670. - Nuisances. 
    No accessory use or structure shall be permitted which by reason of noise, dust, odor, appearance, or other objectionable factor creates a nuisance or a substantial adverse effect upon the property value or reasonable enjoyment of the surrounding property. 
(Code 1963, § 17.025(2)(d)) 
Sec. 122-671. - Polystructures. 
    A polystructure, subject to the dimensional regulations of the Zoning Code, shall only be allowed as part of a conditional use under section 122-568. 
(Ord. No. 78-O-00, § 2(17.025(2)(e)), 4-17-00; Ord. No. 341-O-06, § 1, 6-19-06) 
Sec. 122-672. - Clock/temperature devices. 
(a)  Clock/temperature devices that use LED technology for display shall be permitted subject to the following: 
(1)  Time displays shall be limited to the nearest whole minute. 
(2)  Temperature displays shall be limited to the nearest whole degrees with a minus (-) symbol provided when needed. Temperature displays may be displayed in either Celsius or Fahrenheit or a combination of both and may use appropriate symbols. 
(3)  Area. Devices shall be limited to 15 square feet. In the case of a non-rectangular device the square footage shall be calculated using appropriate geometric arithmetic (such as the area of a circle (r 2 ). 
(4)  Text and screens. Devices shall not have text that revolves, scrolls, flashes, blinks, travels, moves or is animated in any manner, but may have sequential screens that indicate time change, temperature change, time and temperature change, or alternates between time and temperature. 
(5)  Height. The maximum height of the structure shall be 15 feet. 
(6)  Setback. The structure shall be located five feet from all property lines. 
(7)  Clock/temperature devices when combined with signage shall comply with all signage regulations in addition to the requirements of this section. 
(8)  Approval. The device shall receive approval from the architectural control board. 
(b)  Mechanical arm style. Clock/temperature devices that use mechanical arms or similar technology for display shall be permitted subject to the following: 
(1)  Time displays shall be limited to the nearest whole minute or second. 
(2)  Temperature displays shall be limited to the nearest whole degrees. Temperature displays may be displayed in either Celsius or Fahrenheit or a combination of both and may use appropriate symbols. 
(3)  Area. Devices shall be limited to 15 square feet. In the case of a non-rectangular device the square footage shall be calculated using appropriate geometric arithmetic (such as the area of a circle (r 2 ). 
(4)  Faces. May be illuminated or non-illuminated. 
(5)  Height. The maximum height of the structure shall be 15 feet. 
(6)  Setback. The structure shall be located a minimum of five feet from all property lines. Except for clock/temperature devices in pedestrian oriented areas such as the Village Centre, which according to the director of public works, do not interfere with traffic or pedestrians. 
(7)  Clock/temperature devices when combined with signage shall comply with all signage regulations in addition to the requirements of this section. 
(8)  Approval. The device shall receive approval from the architectural control board. 
(9)  Location within right-of-way. Devices mounted within right of way shall receive approval from the director of public works and shall only be permitted in pedestrian oriented areas such as the OVC. Devices shall not interfere with traffic or pedestrians. Devices that project above the right of way shall be located a minimum of ten feet from grade. 
(Ord. No. 303-O-05, § 5, 4-4-05) 
Secs. 122-673-122-685. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TRAFFIC, PARKING, AND ACCESS[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, adopted April 18, 2005, repealed and recreated division 4 to read as herein set out. Formerly, said division pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Code 1963; as subsequently amended. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 106. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 122-686. - Loading requirements. 
    For all non-residential uses, adequate loading area shall be provided so that all vehicles loading, maneuvering, or unloading are completely off the public ways and not back onto, or off of, the public way. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-687. - Parking of trucks, trailers and equipment. 
(a)  No truck, commercial trailer, house or camp trailer, or other vehicular equipment of a commercial or industrial nature shall be parked regularly on a lot in any district except industrial and commercial districts, except as hereinafter specifically provided or as follows: 
(1)  Agricultural equipment shall be permitted without limitation where accessory to a permitted agricultural use. 
(2)  Vehicles approved by the village board of trustees as part of a permitted home occupation. 
(3)  No more than two pick-up trucks, exceeding one ton each shall be permitted. 
(4)  Without habitation, unenclosed parking of a recreational vehicle as defined in section 122-2 shall be considered an accessory use, subject to the provisions of sections 122-646. 
(b)  Outside parking of personal vehicles, including pick-up trucks and passenger vans, shall only be allowed on a driveway or turnaround meeting the provisions of section 122-711. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05; Ord. No. 716-O-18, § 4, 4-16-18) 
Sec. 122-688. - Driveways. 
    All driveways installed, altered, changed, replaced, or extended after February 5, 1973, shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Residential districts. In residential districts, openings for vehicular ingress and egress shall be a minimum of ten-feet wide, but shall not exceed 24 feet at the street line. No driveway may be closer than three feet to an abutting property line other than a street line, with the exception that on a lot where the side yard distance to the principal structure is less than 15 feet or where two adjacent lots have a common driveway serving both which was established by recorded mutual easement, then the three feet minimum distance shall not apply. 
(2)  Nonresidential districts. In all nonresidential zoning districts, openings for vehicular ingress and egress shall be a minimum of 24 feet wide, but shall not exceed 30 feet at the street line, except that additional width shall be permitted upon demonstration of necessity due to special circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-689. - Highway access. 
    No direct private access shall be permitted to the existing or proposed rights-of-way of expressways or to any controlled access arterial street without permission of the highway agency that has access control jurisdiction. Access barriers, such as curbing, fencing, ditching, landscaping, or other topographic barriers, shall be erected to prevent unauthorized vehicular ingress or egress to the below specified streets or highways. No direct public or private access shall be permitted to the existing or proposed rights-of-way of the following: 
(1)  Freeways, expressways, interstate highways, and their interchanges or turning lane nor to intersecting or interchanging street within 500 feet of the centerline of the turning lane. 
(2)  Arterial streets, intersecting another arterial street within 50 feet of the intersection of the right-of-way lines on the lesser street and 100 feet on the arterial. 
(3)  Nonarterial streets intersecting an arterial street within 50 feet of the intersection of the right-of-way lines on the lesser street, and 100 feet on the arterial. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Secs. 122-690-122-705. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Off-Street Parking 

Sec. 122-706. - Provided in all districts; exception. 
    In all districts, in connection with every use, except where parking space is provided by a parking utility, adequate off-street parking facilities shall be provided at the time any use or building is erected, enlarged, extended, or increased for all vehicles in accordance with this subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-707. - Plan requirements for all uses except one- and two-family structures. 
(a)  A site plan shall be furnished for all proposed, enlarged/reduced, redesigned, or resurfaced parking lots within the village. 
(b)  The site plan shall contain: 
(1)  North arrow 
(2)  Scale 
(3)  Dimensions of parking requirements detailed similar to 122-709(b)(2) of this ordinance. 
(4)  Chart indicating: 
a.  Gross square feet of structure (s). When multiple uses are proposed for one structure the gross square feet of each use shall be provided. 
b.  Maximum capacity. 
c.  Number of employees for largest work shift. 
d.  Other information or measurements that may be needed to determine calculations such as floor area, service bay, tenant area, etc. 
(c)  Related landscaping plan as required. (Refer to section Article VII Division 5). 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-708. - Adequate access. 
    Adequate access to a public street shall be provided for each parking space. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-709. - Parking space size. 
(a)  The size of each parking space shall be determined in subsection (b) of this section, except for spaces provided by use by physically disabled persons, and parallel parking stalls. 
(1)  Parking spaces for use by physically disabled persons shall be regulated by Wis. Stats. §§ 346.50 through 346.505. 
(2)  Parallel parking stalls shall have a stall length of 21 feet. 
(b)  Parking lot dimensions. The design of parking lots shall use the following dimensions and configurations. 
    (1)

Parking Lot Dimensions 
(3)  Parking structures. Parking structures shall conform to section (a) and (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
_____
Sec. 122-710. - Location. 
    Location shall be on the same lot as the principal use, or less than 400 feet from the parcel the principal use is located on. When the required parking use is provided on a lot or parcel separated from the principal use, the parcel designated for parking must be restricted by means of a recorded easement, enforceable by the village and the owners of all lands adjacent to either parcel. The easement shall state the parcel is to be used solely for parking and shall be in such form as the plan commission may prescribe or approve. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-711. - Surfacing. 
(a)  All driveways, except in residential or agricultural districts, shall be surfaced with an asphalt pavement, cement pavement, permeable surfacing or pavers to provide a durable and dust free surface. Surfacing of driveways shall be completed at the time the occupancy is issued. The plan commission may waive this requirement in the I-2 heavy industrial district if the applicant shows just cause, while providing a dust free surface. 
(b)  New driveways in all residential districts shall be surfaced with an asphalt pavement, cement pavement, permeable surfacing or pavers to provide a durable and dust free surface. Surfacing of residential driveways shall be completed within two years of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05; Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 38, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 122-712. - Screening. 
(a)  Any off-street parking area, other than that provided for a single-family residence, which abuts or faces a residential district shall provide and maintain an efficient planting screen, landscaped fence, or wall, at least four feet in height along the side abutting or fronting the residential district. Plans for such screen shall be submitted to the department of community development for approval as to sufficiency before installation, and shall comply to division 5 of article VII of the zoning chapter of the Municipal Code dealing with landscape standards or section 122-447(l) (2) if applicable. 
(b)  Parking lots adjacent to public rights of way within commercial, industrial, PRD and multi-family districts shall be screened from public rights of way with landscaping, and shall comply to division 5 of article VII of the zoning chapter of the Municipal Code dealing with landscape standards, or section 122-447(l) (2) if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-713. - Setback. 
    Parking lots shall not be located closer than ten feet from the existing street line in all non-residential zoning districts, except as regulated in Section 122-447(l)(2). Parking lots shall not be located closer than five feet from the existing street line in all residential zoning districts. Parking lots shall not be located closer than three feet from any side or rear lot line in any district, except as regulated in Section 122-447(l)(2). 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-714. - Curbs and barriers. 
    Curbs, wheel stops or other barriers shall be installed to prevent the wheels of the parked cars from extending over the setback lines. The parcel of land between the street line and the parked vehicles shall be maintained as greenspace, and may include vegetated stormwater control measures. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05; Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 39, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 122-715. - Lighting. 
    Lights provided in any parking area shall be hooded or beamed so as not to create undesirable glare or illumination of adjacent residential property and shall meet the provisions of section 122-651. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
_____
Sec. 122-716. - Number of parking stalls required. 
    In the case of structures or uses not specified herein, the number of spaces specified for similar structure or use shall apply. In developments involving the establishment or addition of two or more uses on one lot or parcel, the cumulative number of spaces required for each use shall determine the total number of spaces required.

Queue: 12 stacking spaces per drive up window, with a minimum of 5 spaces at ordering station. Retail specialty a store < or = to 2,500 square feet of gross floor area 1 space per 200 square feet of gross floor area Retail general a store with > 2,500 square feet of gross floor area. 1 space per 250 square feet of gross floor area Shopping center regional (1,000,000 square feet) 1 space per 300 square feet of gross floor area Shopping center (w/o supermarket) 1 space per 200 square feet of gross floor area Shopping center (w/supermarket) 1 space per 181 square feet of gross floor area Shopping center (specialty average tenant space < 2,500 square feet) 1 space per 250 square feet of gross floor area Supermarket (not associated with a shopping center) 1 space per 181 square feet of gross floor area Vehicle sales Merchandise/inventory: 1 space per each vehicle displayed outside of structure. 
1 space for each sales persons of the largest work shift.

Industrial Uses Minimum Number of Spaces Required Industrial general (except as herein noted) Customer area: 1 space per 500 square feet of gross area.

Institutional and Related Uses Minimum Number of Spaces Required Children's nursery schools and commercial care centers 1 space per each employee of the work shift with the largest number of employees, plus 1 space per every 6 children at highest attendance period Churches, synagogue, mosques, other places of worship, community centers, and other places of public assembly 1 space per each 3 seats based upon maximum capacity Dormitories, monasteries, and convents To be determined by plan commission based upon report prepared by applicant detailing a program for allocation of spaces or 1 space per bed. Funeral homes 1 space for every 4 seats based on maximum capacity Hospitals and dormitories 1 space per each 2 beds plus one space for each employee of the work shift with the largest number of employees Medical, dental, and similar professional health services. 1 space for each employee of the work shift with the largest number of employees plus 1.5 spaces for each examination and treatment room/dental chair. Schools-Elementary and middle 1 space per employee plus 1 space per 225 square feet of gross office area Schools-High school 1 space per employee plus 1 space per 225 square feet of gross office area and

A maximum of 20% of gross square feet may be considered unleaseable space under a net square foot analysis. Research center 1 space per 300 square feet of the net area-based upon floor plan utilization report 
A maximum of 20% of gross square feet may be considered unleaseable space under a net square foot analysis.  
Residential Uses Minimum Number of Spaces Required Continuing care communities 1 space per each 4 beds plus 1 space per each employee of the largest work shift. Duplexes Two spaces per dwelling unit with a minimum of 1 being fully enclosed. Multi-family (3 units and more) 1 space per bedroom with a minimum of 1 space fully enclosed, and a maximum total of 2 spaces per unit with 1 additional space provided for each 2 units for visitors. Mobile homes 2 spaces per unit and 1 space for each two units for visitor parking. Nursing homes, institutions and sanatoriums 1 stall for every eight patient beds plus 1 space for each employee of the work shift with the largest number of employees Retirement communities < 3 dwellings per building-Two spaces per each unit with a minimum of one enclosed.

Determination shall be by the village manager or designee.  
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05; Ord. No. 375-O-07, § 1, 5-21-07) 
Sec. 122-717. - Seating and occupancy defined. 
    The seating or occupancy capacity of a building shall be as determined by the Wisconsin Administrative Code "Rules of the Industrial Commission". 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 122-718. - Adjustments to required parking. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to allow adjustments to the minimum number of parking spaces required to avoid constructing unneeded and excessive off-street parking facilities. Reducing the amount of excess off-street parking facilities is intended to provide for more cost-efficient site development, to eliminate constructing more impervious surface than necessary, to minimize stormwater runoff, to avoid construction of unnecessarily large stormwater management facilities, and to provide more landscape areas and open space on commercial and industrial sites. To achieve these purposes, the plan commission may reduce the minimum number of required off-street parking spaces in specific cases as described in this section. 
(b)  Adjustments. In all commercial, institutional, residential, and industrial districts, the minimum number of required parking spaces may be adjusted by the plan commission on a case-by-case basis. The petitioner for such an adjustment shall show to the satisfaction of the plan commission that adequate parking will be provided for customers, clients, visitors, and employees. The following provisions and factors shall be used as a basis to adjust parking requirements: 
(1)  Evidence that actual parking demands will be less than article requirements. The petitioner shall submit written documentation to the satisfaction of the plan commission that the operation will require less parking than the article requires. 
(2)  Availability of shared or off-site parking. The petitioner shall submit written documentation to the satisfaction of the plan commission that shared or off-site shared parking spaces are available to satisfy the parking demand. 
a.  Shared parking agreements shall provide evidence that either parking lots are large enough to accommodate multiple users or that parking spaces will be shared at certain times of the day (i.e.-A church uses parking on Sundays, when other businesses are closed). 
b.  Off-site parking lots shall not be located more than 400 feet from the principal use that it is intended to serve. 
(3)  Parking management plans. Parking management plans/operations may be used as a basis to reduce required parking. 
a.  Parking management plans may include but are not limited to: 
1.  Flexible working hours. 
2.  Bus transit. 
3.  Van/car pool. 
4.  Bicycle use. 
b.  Proposals for adjustments of parking requirements under this section shall show how the alternative transportation modes will be implemented, the permanency of such modes, extent of the program, the number of vehicles the mode will replace, and other pertinent information the may be requested by the department of community development. 
(4)  Space set aside for reduced parking. The site plan for proposed use shall be designed to provide sufficient open space on the subject site to accommodate the additional parking spaces otherwise required by this article. The open space shall be provided which, if converted to parking spaces, would provide off-street parking to meet the full requirements of this article along with all related open space requirements, stormwater management standards, and any other code regulation or adopted standards. 
(5)  Changes in occupancy or use. When the use of a building, structure, or land is changed to another use or occupant that requires more parking spaces than required for the use existing immediately prior to such change, additional parking spaces shall be constructed for the new use or occupant in the amount necessary to conform to this article. 
(6)  Changes in intensity of use. When the intensity of use of a building, structure or land is increased by an addition of employees, gross floor area, seating capacity, or other unit of measurement, additional parking spaces shall be constructed for such additions in the amount necessary to conform to this article. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-719. - Bicycle racks in off-street parking areas. 
(a)  Bicycle racks shall be provided in all developments located in commercial and industrial zoning districts when the property is located along an existing or proposed bike route, multi use trail, bike lane, or sidewalk. 
(1)  When required, bicycle parking shall be provided at a rate of one bicycle space for every twenty parking spaces provided in the development. 
(2)  Bicycle areas and bicycle racks shall be approved by the department of community development. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-720. - Pedestrian amenities. 
(a)  A pedestrian connection from the right-of-way to the establishment shall be provided when a development is located in a commercial, or industrial zoning district and when the property is located along a right-of-way with existing, planned, proposed sidewalk, multi-use trail, or bike path. 
(b)  Parking lot with 20 or more parking spaces shall provide an internal pedestrian circulation system. 
(c)  Pedestrian walkways shall be a minimum of four-feet wide, and comply to division 5 of article VII of the zoning chapter of the Municipal Code dealing with landscape standards. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Sec. 122-721. - Interconnecting parking lots. 
    Interconnecting parking lots may be permitted, subject to all required setbacks. The connecting aisles shall have a maximum width of 24 feet. 
(Ord. No. 304-O-05, § 2, 4-18-05) 
Secs. 122-722-122-730. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - LANDSCAPE STANDARDS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 114. 

Sec. 122-731. - Application of division provisions; necessity of standards. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this division, this division applies to commercial and industrial districts. Landscape standards are necessary to ensure that landscaping becomes an integral part of development. Landscaping also is encouraged to be used as a means of reducing stormwater runoff, both by retaining or planting vegetation and trees, and by integrating vegetated stormwater control measures into landscaped areas. 
(Code 1963, § 17.058; Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 40, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 122-732. - Site restrictions. 
(a)  For purposes of determining the number of plants necessary to meet this section of the Code, a standard greenspace calculation must be made based on this table: 
Zoning District To obtain the standard greenspace needed, multiply the gross lot area by: C-1 30% C-2 20% C-3 40% C-4 30% OC-5 30% C-6 40% I-1 15% I-2 10% I-3 20%  
(1)  At least one shade or ornamental deciduous tree, no less than 2.5? caliper for deciduous shade trees, and 2.0? caliper for deciduous ornamental trees, shall be incorporated into the design for every 1,500 square feet of standard greenspace. To assure a diversity of deciduous trees, no more than 25 percent of the required trees may be of any one deciduous tree classification. 
(b)  At least 25 percent of the standard greenspace shall be landscaped utilizing plant materials, other than maintained turf, that contribute to at-grade coverage. 
    For purposes of determining the number of plants necessary to meet the minimum 25 percent "at-grade" coverage requirement, plant types are categorized by their general size and potential mature at-grade coverage area. 
Plant Type Area of Coverage 
Provided Evergreen Tree (>8? Dia.) 75 sq. ft. Large Shrub (6-8? Dia.) 38 sq. ft. Medium Shrub (4-6? Dia.) 20 sq. ft. Small Shrub (2-4? Dia.) 12 sq. ft. Perennial (4.5? Pot) 6 sq. ft.  
*;hg;Note: Shade and ornamental trees are not considered a plant type contributing to "at-grade" coverage. 
(c)  To ensure a diversity of color, texture and year-round interest, the total number of shrub type plant materials must be comprised of a minimum 25 percent evergreens, but no more than 70 percent. 
(d)  Plants and shrubs within the landscaped vision triangle (section 122-604) shall not exceed 30 inches in height at maturity, or obstruct the view between the street and the access drives near the street yard entries and exits. 
(e)  Paved parking areas larger than 5,000 square feet shall have landscaped areas equaling not less than 15 percent of the parking area intermittently placed throughout the parking area. Landscaped areas shall consist of parking islands and perimeter screening, which can be used as stormwater management areas. Parking islands shall be placed at the end of parking rows, unless required to be sited at other locations as part of the stormwater management plan for the site. Planting strips may also be utilized to fulfill the requirements for large parking lots. 
(1)  Planting islands. Planting islands shall be a minimum of one parking stall, 180 feet in area, underlain by soil (not base course material) and other media as appropriate for stormwater management, and shall be protected by curbing, wheel stops, bollards, or other protective treatment with breaks to allow stormwater flow as appropriate. Each planting island shall contain one shade tree plus shrubs, and/or groundcover, and/or perennials to cover the entire area, or a planting plan appropriate for stormwater management functions. 
(2)  Parking lot screening. All parking lots or vehicular area shall be screened when they abut a public right-of-way. An eight-foot-wide landscape screen consisting of a mix of evergreen and deciduous shrubs, or a combination of fencing and plantings with an equivalent degree of opacity, shall be provided. The planting screen shall be located within 15 feet of the edge of pavement and may be designed to accommodate vegetated stormwater control measures. Areas that provide parking lot screening may be counted towards the required 15 percent of landscaped areas within a parking lot, when sufficient internal islands have been provided. 
(3)  Planting strips. Planting strips, which may include vegetated stormwater control measures, may be provided within parking lots. The planting strip area may contribute to the required 15 percent internal landscaping requirements. Planting strips shall be of sufficient width to sustain the vegetation placed within them or to function as stormwater control measures. Strips shall run the length of the parking row, underlain by soil and other media as appropriate for stormwater management, and shall be protected by curbs, wheel stops, or bollards with breaks to allow stormwater flow as appropriate. Planting strips shall have a planting plan appropriate for stormwater management functions, and may contain canopy trees plus shrubs, and/or groundcover, and/or perennials to cover the entire area. When determined during plan review, a walking path/sidewalk shall be designed into the planting strip, which will provide for pedestrian access to the entrance of a building. 
(f)  Landscaping shall be installed within nine months of occupancy or substantial completion of the building, whichever comes first, weather and appropriate planting seasons permitting. A planting schedule for any plantings requiring seasonal phasing shall be submitted with any request for extension under this subsection. 
(g)  For purposes of this section, environmental areas, such as wetlands and natural wooded areas, may be excluded from the lot area determination in (a) and (b), above. If the net area, after removal of the environmental area(s), is less than the minimum lot size for the respective zoning district, minimum requirements shall apply. 
Zoning 
District Minimum Requirement Number of Trees At-Grade 
Coverage 
(Square Feet) C-1 4 1,500 C-2 1 320 C-3 93 34,848 C-4 16 6,000 OC-5 6 2,250 C-6 5 1,800 I-1 5 1,634 I-2 3 1,089 I-3 12 4,356  
(h)  Landscape credit. Existing, healthy trees and shrubs when not located in woodlands or wetlands shall be credited towards the required trees or plant materials. Existing plant material must be indicated on the plan. Shrubs and evergreen trees shall be counted on a one for one basis. Existing deciduous trees shall be calculated as follows: 
Existing Tree 
(dbh) Number of Trees 
Credited 
(21/2? caliper) 36? or greater 8 trees 18-35? 6 trees 12-17? 4 trees 8-11? 2 trees 21/2?-8? 1 tree Less than 21/2? No credit  
(i)  In a common development, which includes more than one lot, each lot shall meet the requirements of this section. Each phase of a phased project shall meet the requirements of this section. 
(j)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  If a building is damaged by fire, explosion, flood, tornado, riot, or accident of any kind, the landscaping shall be replaced according to a previously approved landscape plan. If there is no previously approved landscape plan, current landscape standards shall apply. 
(2)  Restoration of buildings or landscapes with a historic designation. 
(3)  Interior remodeling as long as the front, rear, and side exterior walls of the building remain in the same location and so long as no greater intensity of use is proposed. 
(4)  Expansion of a parking lot or circulation area without any other modifications to any structures on the site shall not require the entire site to be brought up to full compliance with landscape standards, but the requirements of this ordinance pertaining to parking lots shall be applied. 
(5)  Expansion or remodeling of a building which is less than 10 percent of the existing floor area, and no parking lot modifications are being made, then the provisions of this section shall not apply. 
(Code 1963, § 17.058(1); Ord. No. 97-O-00, §§ 2-7, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 41, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 122-733. - Maintenance requirements. 
    The owner of the site shall have the duty of, and the responsibility for: 
(1)  Keeping all grass, trees, shrubbery and other greenspace areas in a well-maintained, safe, clean and attractive condition comparable with the surrounding area at all times. This maintenance shall include practices that promote healthy plant growth, free from diseases, pests, weeds and litter. Vegetated stormwater control measures shall be maintained in accordance with the maintenance plan and requirements for their design and function as stormwater controls. 
(2)  The repair or replacement of landscape structures. 
(3)  The regular maintenance, repair and/or replacement where necessary of any screening or buffering required by the plan commission or architectural control board. 
(4)  Required plant materials, if dead, diseased or severely damaged, shall be removed by the owner as soon as possible, but no later than 30 days after notification. These plants shall be replaced within three months of removal or by the next planting season, whichever comes first. 
(5)  Replacement plants must be of the same or greater size and species as shown on the approved landscape plan approved by the architectural control board. 
(Code 1963, § 17.058(2); Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 42, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 122-734. - Landscape plan; contents. 
    A landscape plan must be submitted which includes details of all proposed landscaping, buffering, and screening. These plans shall be prepared by a state-licensed landscape professional, and shall include the stamp of that professional. Plans including vegetated stormwater control measures shall require certification by a professional engineer, where these measures are part of a required stormwater management plan. The requirement that such plans and specifications be prepared by a registered landscape architect may be waived for minor alternations and improvements which, in the sole discretion of the department of community development, does not require the services of such a professional. The plans shall show the location and dimensions of all existing and proposed structures, parking, drives, rights-of-way, and any other permanent features, and all other information required by the plan commission and/or the architectural control board, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  A plant list and coverage chart showing the location, quantity, size (at time of planting and at maturity), spacing, and the scientific and common names of all landscape materials used. 
(2)  The dbh of existing trees shall be provided. 
(3)  The location and percent of slope of all proposed berms using one-foot contours. 
(4)  Detailed sections showing elevations of all proposed architectural features, such as walls, lighting or water features. 
(5)  Methods used in staking, mulching, wrapping or any other early tree care used. 
(6)  Existing plant materials proposed to remain. A separate plant list and coverage chart showing the location, quantity, size (at time of planting and at maturity), spacing, and the scientific and common names of all landscape materials used. 
(7)  Existing plant materials proposed to be removed. A separate plant list and coverage chart showing the location, quantity, size (at time of planting and at maturity), spacing, and the scientific and common names of all landscape materials used. 
(8)  The design, location, proposed grading and planting, and sections of all vegetated stormwater control measures. 
(Code 1963, § 17.058(4); Ord. No. 97-O-00, §§ 8-10, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 596-O-14, § 43, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 122-735. - Preservation of topography. 
    In order to preserve the natural topography as much as possible and in order to protect against danger and damage caused by manmade changes in existing topography, no lots nor portions of lots nor any parcels of land shall be excavated or filled unless the following conditions are met in all zoning districts: 
(1)  In all development where grading and changes to the natural topography must occur to accommodate the development, all grading shall conform to a site grading and stormwater drainage plan approved by the village manager or designee. Stormwater drainage plans shall conform to the village stormwater management guidelines. Individual lot landscape grading, in residential developments, shall conform, as near as practicable, to the approved subdivision grading plan. 
(2)  If a difference in grade between two adjacent lots along a lot line, or wholly within a single lot, is to be no greater at any point than three feet, this difference in levels may be sloped toward or away from the lot line at a gradient of no more than one foot vertical to three feet horizontal or a retaining wall shall be constructed to retain the higher ground. An area along or near the lot line shall graded to allow stormwater drainage to flow, where practicable, unobstructed to the front and/or rear of the lot. 
(3)  If a difference in grade between two adjacent lots along a lot line, or wholly within a single lot, is to be greater than three feet at any point, the following procedure shall govern: 
a.  An area along or near the lot line shall be graded to allow stormwater drainage to flow, where practicable, unobstructed to the front and/or rear of the lot. 
b.  Sodded slopes shall not exceed a gradient of one foot vertical to three feet horizontal. 
c.  A slope protected by riprap construction may not exceed a gradient of one foot vertical to one foot horizontal. 
d.  No retaining wall shall exceed four feet in height unless it has been designed and its construction supervised by a professional engineer. A retaining wall may be stepped to achieve greater height. Each step of the wall shall be no more than four feet in height and shall be set back a minimum of three feet from the previous step. 
e.  In single-family residential developments adjustments to the yard grade around the house to accommodate grade differences within the lot can be achieved using architectural features, such as: exposed and/or larger basement windows; partial or total exposure of the basement wall with the appropriate siding treatment; lowering the garage floor. 
(4)  Berms greater than 30 inches in height, in all zoning districts, require architectural review board approval. Side slopes of berms shall not exceed a gradient of one foot vertical to three feet horizontal unless approved by the architectural review board. See section 122-669(4) fences, walls and screening devices. 
(Code 1963, § 17.058(4); Ord. No. 197-O-02, § 3, 4-16-02) 
Secs. 122-736-122-750. - Reserved.
